Point 11 of the joint communique of this summit states that �The Regional Summit urged all the parties to the Burundi conflict including the Government of Burundi to genuinely extend maximum co-operation to the new Facilitator so as to enable him accomplish his mission.�

The Arusha multiparty talks continued during 2000, with Nelson Mandela as a new mediator. He mediated a first round of negotiations on 21 February. Key issues, such as the leadership of the transition, the future electoral system, and the equal ethnic representation of the armed forces were discussed but not agreed on. Mandela had strong support from the UN Security Council, the European Union and the Regional Peace Initiative in his efforts to bring the 19 parties together.
third_party: Nelson Mandela, South Africa, UN, OAU, Regional peace initiative (members: Burundi, DR Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia)

description: From early 2000 onwards, simultaneously to the Arusha talks, South African Deputy President Jacob Zuma engaged in shuttle diplomacy with the objective to secure a ceasefire, but without success.
The eighth round of Arusha negotiations started on 27 March. The talks focused on the issue of army integration, despite the continued absence of the CNDD-FDD and the Palipehutu-FNL.
third_party: Nelson Mandela, South Africa, UN, OAU, Regional peace initiative (members: Burundi, DR Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia)

description: During talks in July 2000, the parties mainly discussed who should lead the transition, the nature of the electoral system and how to achieve a ceasefire. However, no agreements could be made by the parties on the main issues.
third_party: Nelson Mandela, South Africa, UN, OAU, Regional peace initiative (members: Burundi, DR Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia)

description: A further round of negotiations was planned for August, prior to which Mandela conducted a series of bilateral discussions with the heads of party delegations at Arusha, to persuade them to commit themselves to signing an accord. To increase the pressure, Mandela invited a number of Heads of State, including the US President Bill Clinton, and other senior international political figures to the August discussions. On the 28 August 2000, a peace agreement was signed: the Arusha Peace and Reconciliation Agreement for Burundi. The agreement outlined several key provisions. Firstly, it established a ceasefire and required all troops to either remain in their current positions or be stationed in designated sites, where they would await demobilization or integration into the new armed forces. To monitor and supervise the ceasefire, a joint ceasefire commission was established, consisting of government delegates, representatives from the warring parties, as well as members from the UN, the OAU, and the Regional Peace Initiative for Burundi. The parties also agreed on the reform of the armed forces, with a 50-50 ethnic quota, ensuring equal representation of Hutus and Tutsis. The agreement included provisions for a pre-transition and transition period, followed by democratic elections. It was determined that a Senate would be elected based on ethnic representation to maintain balance in higher levels of government. Procedures for the assembly and the senate were agreed upon to prevent any single political or ethnic group from dominating the political system. Additionally, an Implementation Verification Commission was established to oversee and supervise the implementation of the agreement's provisions. The transitional period would conclude with elections for the National Assembly, Presidency, and Senate. The agreement also included a general amnesty for individuals who did not commit crimes against humanity or crimes related to the genocide. Furthermore, provisions were made for the repatriation of refugees and displaced persons, along with extensive reconstruction programs aimed at economic and social development.
third_party: Nelson Mandela, South Africa, UN, OAU, Regional peace initiative (members: Burundi, DR Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia)
agreement_name: Arusha Peace and Reconciliation Agreement for Burundi

description: On 23 July, Mandela convened a regional summit meeting in Arusha. On 25 July, agreement was reached on the transitional leadership.
third_party: Nelson Mandela, South Africa, UN, OAU, Regional peace initiative (members: Burundi, DR Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia)

In September, Nyerere�s health worsened and the Arusha process was suspended. However, the main negotiating parties met in the Tanzanian capital the same month, and good progress was reported. Nyerere died in October, after which the regional heads of state unanimously endorsed Nelson Mandela as the new mediator at the Eight Arusha regional summit on Burundi on 1 December 1999. Point 11 of the joint communique of this summit states that �The Regional Summit urged all the parties to the Burundi conflict including the Government of Burundi to genuinely extend maximum co-operation to the new Facilitator so as to enable him accomplish his mission.� Furthermore, the Regional Summit underscored the importance of urgently concluding the negotiations and called upon all the parties to �accelerate the momentum of the Burundi Peace Negotiations until the conclusion of a final peace agreement that will ensure lasting peace, genuine democracy and security for all.� Mandela adopted a more urgent and outspoken approach from the outset. The Arusha multiparty talks continued during 2000, with Nelson Mandela as a new mediator. He mediated a first round of negotiations in February 2000. Key issues, such as the leadership of the transition, the future electoral system and the equal ethnic representation of the armed forces were discussed but not agreed on. Mandela had strong support from the UN Security Council, the European Union and the Regional Peace Initiative in his efforts to bring the 19 parties together.

description: In 2004, negotiations between the government and Palipehutu-FNL-Rwasa faction were held in the Netherlands between 8 and 21 January. The talks ended with a joint declaration calling for an end to violence in Burundi, but this ceasefire was soon broken. No new negotiations were held between the Government and Palipehutu-FNL in 2004. Palipehutu-FNL refused to negotiate with the Government if they did not stop their military action against them, while the government refused to cease military action until the Palipehutu-FNL agreed to negotiate. Although a unilateral ceasefire was declared by Palipehutu-FNL in April 2004, it was broken within 24 hours. In August 2004, Palipehutu-FNL offered a ceasefire on the condition that refugees in Bujumbura Rural were allowed to return home and the agreement was implemented, but the Government of Burundi did not accept this offer.

A round of negotiations between the Palipehutu-FNL and the Government of Burundi, mediated by South Africa, led to the signing of a ceasefire with the Government on 15 May 2005, but this ceasefire was broken by both the Government and the rebels. After an electoral victory of the former Hutu rebel group CNDD-FDD, prospects for successful negotiations seemed to have improved, yet repeated promises by Palipehutu-FNL to negotiate with the Government came to nothing.

Another round of negotiations between Palipehutu-FNL and the newly installed Burundian Government started on 29 May 2006. These talks were mediated by South Africa and took place in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. Charles Nqakula, the Minister of Safety and Security of South Africa, acted as the chief mediator. Nqakula was mandated by South African President Thabo Mbeki, following a request from the leadership of the East African region of the African Union for South Africa to continue with mediation efforts in Burundi. On 18 June 2006, the parties signed the Dar-Es- Salaam Agreement of Principles Towards Lasting Peace, Security and Stability in Burundi, in which the parties agreed on a two-week ceasefire to negotiate a permanent ceasefire. More specifically, the agreement included provisions to address various aspects of the conflict and promote reconciliation. Firstly, it granted provisional immunity to members of Palipehutu-FNL, ensuring their protection from prosecution. Additionally, the agreement called for the release of political prisoners and prisoners of war. Palipehutu-FNL was permitted to transition into a political party, but only after separating its political and military branches. This separation aimed to establish a clear distinction between the movement�s political activities and armed operations. To facilitate healing and societal reconciliation, a Truth, Forgiveness, and Reconciliation Commission was to be established. This commission would involve all segments of Burundian society and have the mandate to rewrite the nation's history and foster a renewed social contract. The agreement also addressed the repatriation of refugees and the return of displaced and regrouped individuals, aiming to restore their rights and facilitate their reintegration into society. Furthermore, the agreement designated the members of the Regional Peace Initiative as guarantors of the peace process, entrusting them with ensuring the fulfilment of the agreed-upon terms and maintaining the stability and progress achieved.
agreement_name: Dar-Es- Salaam Agreement of Principles Towards Lasting Peace, Security and Stability in Burundi

description: After the signing of the Dar-Es- Salaam Agreement of Principles Towards Lasting Peace, Security and Stability in Burundi, talks held in June 2006 primarily focused on Palipehutu-FNL�s wish to disband the Burundian armed forces and police and reconstruct them from scratch. The government instead wanted the integration of the Palipehutu-FNL into the existing structures, in line with earlier peace agreements in Burundi. As a result, talks broke down in mid-July.

Although Palipehutu-FNL subsequently walked out of negotiations in mid-July, the government and the Palipehutu-FNL resumed peace talks in early September 2006 and signed the Comprehensive Ceasefire Agreement between the Government of Burundi and the Palipehutu-FNL on 7 September 2006, which established a ceasefire, mandating an immediate halt to hostilities. To ensure compliance, the Joint Verification and Monitoring Mechanism (JVMM) was established. This mechanism consisted of the African Union (AU), the United Nations (UN), and the warring parties themselves. Its primary responsibility was to monitor and verify the implementation of the ceasefire. In addition, the mechanism was tasked with overseeing the assembly of Palipehutu-FNL combatants and facilitating their demobilization. It played a crucial role in developing criteria for the integration of these combatants into the national army or supporting their reintegration into society as ex-combatants. The objective was to promote peace and stability by providing viable options for former fighters to transition to civilian life successfully. Political power sharing and the transformation of Palipehutu-FNL into a political party were, however, not addressed. The JVMM, in which the AU and ONUB participated, was launched in October 2006, after which some cantonment began. Temporary immunity was granted to ex-combatants in November 2006. However, disputes over details of a final agreement continued. The AU was also involved in mediation through its establishment and participation in the monitoring and verification mechanism.
agreement_name: Comprehensive Ceasefire Agreement between the Government of Burundi and the Palipehutu-FNL

description: A new round of negotiations between the government and Palipehutu-FNL led to a ceasefire agreement on 9 July 2007, but this agreement was breached by both conflict parties.

After an unsuccessful offensive in April 2008 � and under strong international pressure � the Palipehutu-FNL returned to the negotiating table. A ceasefire was signed on 25 May, reaffirming the parties� commitment to the 2006 agreement.

In October 2008, to mediate the final issues, South African Defence Minister Charles Nqakula, who had mediated between the parties, on behalf of the South African Facilitation, requested the help of the Regional Peace Initiative headed by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni. The latter presided over a one-day summit in December 2008 in Bujumbura, Burundi. The stated goal of this summit was to break the stalemate which has struck the Peace Process in Burundi with the objective of finding a lasting solution. When the final issues were resolved and a peace agreement signed, removing the final obstacles for the transformation of Palipehutu-FNL into a political party. The Government agreed to integrate Palipehutu-FNL into the political process and to grant government positions to 33 of its senior members. President Nkurunziza and Palipehutu-FNL leader Agathon Rwasa subsequently met in Bujumbura on 8 December 2008 to sign the Declaration of the Summit of the Heads of State and Government of the Great Lakes region on the Burundi Peace Process. The agreement presented a resolution to the remaining unresolved issues in the peace process. It addressed concerns such as the removal of ethnic references from the name of Palipehutu-FNL and the integration of its members into the government. Palipehutu-FNL recognized that its name violated the Burundian Constitution and agreed to change it in order to register as a political party. In response, the government committed to integrating Palipehutu-FNL into the political process and allocating government positions to 33 senior members of the organization. This step aimed to foster inclusivity and ensure the participation of Palipehutu-FNL in the governance of Burundi. Furthermore, both parties reaffirmed their dedication to the demobilization process, which would be monitored by the JVMM. This mechanism played a crucial role in overseeing the implementation of the agreement and ensuring compliance with the demobilization efforts. The agreement also reiterated the commitment to the release of political prisoners, as outlined in the 2006 agreement. This provision aimed to promote reconciliation and address issues related to political imprisonment. Overall, the agreement provided a comprehensive solution to the outstanding issues, promoting political integration, demobilization, and the release of political prisoners.
agreement_name: Declaration of the Summit of the Heads of State and Government of the Great Lakes region on the Burundi Peace Process

description: On 30 August 2002, following another round of peace talks, the two sides signed memorandums of understanding regarding the peace efforts.

Mediation conducted by Zuma subsequently led to the conclusion of three new peace agreements. The Pretoria Protocol on Political, Defence and Security Power Sharing in Burundi was concluded on 8 October 2003. The agreement outlined specific provisions regarding the distribution of roles within the military and the political sectors. Firstly, it established a 60/40 quota for the General Staff and Officer Corps, with the Government and the CNDD-FF dividing the positions accordingly. The exact allocation of positions for the rank and file was to be determined through discussions among the integrated General Staff. Regarding the disarmament of militias, the agreement referred to the provisions outlined in the December 2002 Ceasefire Agreement. It mandated the disarming of militias under the supervision of the African Mission. In the political realm, the agreement established extensive power-sharing arrangements. The CNDD-FDD was granted participation at various levels of the government. They secured four ministerial positions, one of which being the Minister of State. Additionally, the agreement stipulated that the CNDD-FDD would hold the positions of Second Vice President and Deputy Secretary General. Moreover, the CNDD-FDD was allocated representation in the National Assembly, with 15 of its members holding seats in the assembly.
agreement_name: Pretoria Protocol on Political, Defence and Security Power Sharing in Burundi

description: The Pretoria Protocol on Outstanding Political, Defence and Security Power Sharing Issues in Burundi was concluded on 2 November 2003. The agreement upheld the previously signed ceasefire agreement on 2 December 2002, while emphasizing the need to continue the process of military cantonment. It reiterated the specific guidelines for integrating CNDD-FDD forces into the Burundian armed forces, granting the CNDD-FDD power-sharing arrangements within the military domain. Furthermore, the agreement mandated the reconstitution of the transitional government of Burundi within three weeks after the agreement's endorsement, with the inclusion of the CNDD-FDD. As part of this transformation, the CNDD-FDD would transition into a political party, and its members would be granted temporary immunity. Lastly, the agreement established both an International Criminal Tribunal and a National Truth and Reconciliation Commission. These institutions were tasked with addressing war criminals and facilitating the process of national reconciliation.
agreement_name: Pretoria Protocol on Outstanding Political, Defence and Security Power Sharing Issues in Burundi

description: The Global Ceasefire agreement between CNDD-FDD of Mr. Nk�runziza was concluded on 16 November 2003. The agreement, concluded on November 16, 2003, marked the culmination of the Burundian peace process and ensured the commitment of all parties to the previous agreements signed since the ceasefire agreement on 2 December 2002, up to the Pretoria protocols addressing unresolved matters. By signing this agreement, the CNDD-FDD became an integral part of the Arusha process, leaving only Palipehutu-FNL as the remaining party outside the peace agreements. The Global Ceasefire agreement not only reaffirmed the earlier agreements but also introduced comprehensive power-sharing arrangements in both the military and political spheres. These power-sharing provisions aimed to distribute authority and responsibilities among the involved parties, promoting inclusivity and cooperation within the armed forces and the broader political framework. On 8 August, CNDD-FDD became a political party.
agreement_name: Global Ceasefire agreement between CNDD-FDD of Mr. Nk�runziza

description: In late June 1992, the Government of Chad and MDD representatives met in Libreville, Gabon, for talks mediated by President Omar Bongo, which led to the conclusion of the Libreville Agreement on 24 June 1992. The agreement was signed by Health Minister of the Chadian Government, Ali Mahamat Zene Ali Fadel, and the vice-president of MDD, Brahim Malla Mahamat. The agreement stipulated an end to all armed activity between the parties and the integration of the MDD forces into the national army and the release of all prisoners of war. It was further stipulated that some of the MDD leaders would take part in the government administration and participate in the process of installing multi-party democracy in Chad. The agreement failed to be implemented, as government forces attacked the MDD fighters at Lagasula in the Lake Chad region on 18 October 1992.

In 1995, negotiations, without the involvement of any third party, led to signing of an agreement in Dougia, Chad, on 22 November. The 16-point peace agreement put forth several provisions to establish peace and stability. Firstly, an immediate ceasefire was called for and the MDD fighters were to be encamped. Subsequently, they would have the opportunity to integrate into the armed forces of Chad. A technical committee was designated to make decisions regarding which rebels would be integrated into the armed forces and which ones would reintegrate into civilian life. The agreement also granted the MDD the right to participate in the management of public affairs, allowing them a role in shaping the country�s governance. Former MDD members who had previously served in the civil service were reinstated in their positions before the conflict. Additionally, the agreement ensured the release of MDD prisoners, guaranteed freedom of movement for all parties involved, and mandated the return of confiscated property to its rightful owners, aiming to restore justice and normalcy.

In January 1996, the MDD took part in the inter-Chadian table talks between the Government and various opposition groups. The talks, which were hosted by Gabon, concerned the legalisation of rebel groups as political parties, and the reorganisation of the defence and security forces. The talks were mediated by the presidents of the Central African Republic, Gabon, and Niger. The involvement of the Central African Republic and Gabon was based on a mandate stipulated in the Bangui-2 Agreement, signed on 11 August 1994, which set up committee � consisting of the Central African Republic, France, Gabon and the UNHCR � to oversee the implementation of the agreement.

Niger helped to mediate a peace accord in Zinder on 30 September 1996. Little information is available on the content of this peace agreement, but it at least included provisions concerning a ceasefire, the recognition of the MDD, and a general amnesty.

On 20 May 1998, the Chadian Government held talks with the MDD. President Ibrahim Bare Mainassara of Niger mediated these talks. The negotiations focused on the right of return for MDD fighters based in Niger, after which the MDD fighters in Niger agreed to lay down their weapons and return to Chad.

Sudanese mediation between the Chadian government and the MDD led to the signing of the Reconciliation Agreement in Khartoum on 3 July 1999. In addition to a ceasefire, the agreement stipulated that the rebels would be integrated into the national army and into the civil administration of Chad. This was to pave way for a unified army in Chad. A general amnesty was also extended to former MDD combatants.

In August 1993, Libya and Sudan mediated peace talks between the Government of Chad and the CNR. As far as known, the talks at least concerned the right of return for the CNR�s leader, Colonel Abbas Koty. The negotiations led to the signing of an initial peace accord on 15 August 1993.

A second round of negotiations led to another accord on 16 October 1993: the Tripoli-1 Agreement. Not many details are known about this agreement, but the agreement stipulated a regrouping of rebel forces at Adre, a town near the Sudanese border. It was further agreed that these rebels would be integrated into the national army within two months. It was also agreed that the CNR would become involved in the government administration and that it would be allowed to transform into a legal political party.
Nevertheless, the conflict parties agreed in a round of bilateral negotiations on a ceasefire in June 1993.

In October 1993, CSNPD leader Kette declared that the CSNPD was willing to initiate new negotiations with the Government. Negotiations subsequently started in Bangui on 22 February 1994. The conflict parties concluded a ceasefire on 26 February 1994.

Another round of negotiations led to the signing of the Bangui-2 Agreement on 11 August 1994. The agreement established an immediate ceasefire between the government and the CSNPD. As part of the agreement, the government agreed to withdraw its Republican Guard from the territory of Southern Chad, while the CSNPD committed to ending its armed struggle against the government. One important provision of the agreement was the integration of CSNPD fighters into the national army. The process was to be carried out promptly, ensuring the incorporation of CSNPD members into the existing armed forces. Additionally, the agreement aimed to bring the CSNPD into the democratic process by facilitating its transformation into a political party. This step would allow the CSNPD to participate in the political landscape as a recognized entity. To foster reconciliation, a general amnesty was proclaimed by the government, offering forgiveness and immunity for past actions committed during the conflict. Lastly, a committee consisting of representatives from the Central African Republic, France, Gabon, and UNHCR was established to oversee the implementation of the agreement. This committee had the responsibility of ensuring that the terms of the agreement were upheld and facilitating the reconciliation process between the parties involved.

In 1992, several rounds of negotiations between the Chad National Front (FNT) and Chadian Government representatives, mediated by Sudan, took place in El Geneina in Sudan. A first round of negotiations resulted in the conclusion of a ceasefire on 5 September 1992. The conflict parties further agreed that the FNT fighters would disarm within two months. In return, the government provided an amnesty to all imprisoned FNT members.

Another round of talks led to the signing of the El Geneina Agreement on 31 October 1992. The agreement was signed in Judnaynah, Sudan, as well as in El Geneina, which is located on the border of Chad and Sudan. The agreement charged the FNT to regroup its forces within 45 days. It further specified that all FNT personnel would be integrated based on their qualifications, either into the army or government administration. The objective was to restore security in the central, eastern, and south-eastern provinces of Chad. Politically, the agreement recognized the FNT as a political party and established a joint commission to study the FNT charter and its relevance to Chad�s political structure and policies. To foster reconciliation, a general amnesty was declared, and provisions were made for the repatriation of refugees and internally displaced persons. The agreement aimed to address the humanitarian consequences of the conflict and pave the way for stability and peace in Chad.

On 13 and 14 May 1993, talks took place concerning the terms for a truce, the legalisation of the FNT as a political party, and for the return of the FNT leader, Harris Bachar, from exile. No third parties were involved in these talks.

On 12 October 1994, an eight-point peace agreement was signed in Abeche between the FNT rebels and the government of Chad. The encamped forces were to be integrated into the national army, while civilian members were to be integrated into the Chadian civil service. Additionally, the agreement mandated the release of all FNT prisoners detained before 20 May 1994, with a potential consideration for the release of those arrested after that date. The provisions aimed to facilitate the reconciliation process and contribute to a peaceful transition in Chad. No third party was involved in the negotiations leading up to this peace agreement.

In 1997, Sudan conducted mediation between the Chadian government and the FNT, which led to the signing of the National Reconciliation Agreement in N�Djamena on 3 October 1997. The agreement lacks specific measures addressing the conflict behaviour of the parties, such as a ceasefire or rebel integration into the armed forces. Instead, the focus is on legalizing rebel movements and their transition into political parties. The government committed to reinstating all civil servants and granting a general amnesty to former combatants. Additionally, the government pledged to collaborate with the UNHCR and host countries to facilitate the return of refugees. The provisions aim to formalize rebel movements, promote reconciliation, and facilitate the return of displaced populations in cooperation with international organizations and host nations.
A round of negotiations without the involvement of a third party led to the signing of a ceasefire on 27 August 1996. The ceasefire did not hold.

On 7 May 1998, the Chadian Government and the FARF signed the Donya agreement in Donya, Chad. No third party was involved in the negotiations leading up to the conclusion of this peace agreement. The agreement established an immediate ceasefire, putting an end to all military activities. A key aspect was the withdrawal of the Chadian army from southern Chad, specifically the Nomadic Guard and the Republican Guard�s elite units. In terms of reconciliation and integration, the agreement mandated the integration of FARF fighters into the national army and civil service. FARF was also to undergo a transformation into a political party, and its members were granted a general amnesty. To address past human rights abuses, a Truth and Justice Commission was established. Its purpose was to investigate alleged violations committed by both sides during the conflict, aiming to promote accountability and justice.

Although Togoimi had spoken out against any negotiations with the Government of Chad, Libya mediated a series of talks between the Chadian government and the Mouvement pour la d�mocratie et la justice au Tchad (MDJT) (Movement for Democracy and Justice) in Sirte in September 2000. Both MDJT leader Youssouf Togoimi and Chadian president Idriss Deby participated in the negotiations. Muammar al-Gaddafi, the ruler of Libya, acted as the chief mediator during this peace initiative. As observed in a report by the International Crisis Group, the �Libyan leader has always considered the country as being in his backyard, his exclusive domain. President Gaddafi has therefore gradually imposed himself as someone who cannot be ignored in relation to resolving the conflicts in which Chad is involved, whether they are internal or international conflicts.� Issues addressed during the talks concerned an amnesty for the rebels, the integration of MDJT fighters into the Chadian forces, and transparency in the election process. The talks, however, did not yield concrete results and the government forces launched a major offensive on rebel positions only a few months later.

Another round of negotiations mediated by Libya started on 5 January 2002. These negotiations were mediated by Libya�s African unity minister Ali Abdel Salam Triki. The negotiations led to the signing of the Tripoli agreement on 7 January 2002. In addition to stipulating an immediate ceasefire, the agreement called for an end to hostile propaganda. MDJT fighters were to be integrated into the national army in accordance with modalities agreed upon by a military and security subcommittee. Participation in the government and other state institutions by the MDJT was also agreed upon and the modalities were to be drawn up by a political and legal subcommittee. A general amnesty was proclaimed, and there was to be a release of all prisoners and detainees by both sides. A tripartite military commission comprised of the government, Libya, and the MDJT was created to oversee and verify the provisions of the agreement.

Burkina Faso mediated a round of negotiations between the Chadian government and the MDJT in December 2003. This led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 14 December 2003. The ceasefire document � titled the Peace Agreement between the Government of Chad and the Movement pour la d�mocratie et la justice au Tchad (MDJT) � also provided for an amnesty for MDJT fighters and supporters and the appointment of an undisclosed number of MDJT ministers in the government. A number of hard-liner MDJT fighters rejected the ceasefire signed by MDJT leader Adoum Togoi.

On 18 August 2005, another peace agreement was signed: the Yebibou agreement 2005. No third party was involved in the negotiations leading up to the conclusion of this peace agreement. The agreement established an immediate ceasefire and mandated the suspension of all military actions. As part of the agreement, 600 MDJT combatants were to undergo retraining and, if they desired, integrate into the national army of Chad within three months. Other MDJT members were to be reintegrated into the civil service. The agreement included the release of all prisoners held by both sides involved in the conflict. Additionally, it stipulated that the MDJT, which was founded by the late former interior minister Youssouf Togo�mi in 1997, would transform itself into a recognized political party. The MDJT would then have the opportunity to participate in all levels of civilian politics, contributing to the country's political landscape.

No direct negotiations took place between the Government of Chad and the FUCD until late 2006, but some negotiations took place between Chad and Sudan. These talks between Chad and Sudan were aimed at ending the military support Chad was providing to the SLM/A and JEM and ending the military support Sudan was providing to the FUCD, the RAFD, and the UFDD. The Organization of the Islamic Conference (OIC) mediate a round of indirect negotiations between Chad and Sudan in late January 2006. This round of negotiations, which involved an OIC envoy shuttling between the parties, was aimed at ending the military support both countries were simultaneously providing to each other�s rebel groups.

On 8 February 2006, the African Union hosted a mini-summit in Tripoli, which was aimed at improving relations between Chad and Sudan and ending military support both countries were providing to each other�s rebel groups. At this summit, Chad and Sudan signed an agreement which stipulated that each country would refrain from using each other�s territory for hostile activity directed against the other and prohibited each country from accepting rebels from the other. However, the agreement between Chad and Sudan concluded in February 2006 did not hold. A Sudan-supported attack by the FUCD on Chad�s capital took place on 13 April 2006.

On 16 April 2006, Libyan foreign minister made a brief visit to Chad and a Libyan envoy met with the Sudanese President on 17 April. These shuttle talks were aimed at ending the military support Sudan and Chad were providing to each other�s rebel groups.
During the seventh AU Summit in Gambia, Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi arranged a tripartite meeting with Sudan and Chad on 2 and 3 July 2006.

As a follow up to the meeting at the AU summit, Chadian foreign minister went to Khartoum for several days in mid-July 2006 and met with the Sudanese government to discuss political and security matters as well as the possibility of resuming diplomatic relations. After the Chadian foreign minister's visit to Sudan in mid-July, which was an outcome of the Libyan initiative during the AU Summit, the two countries continued their negotiations that led to a peace deal. On 26 July 2006, Chad and Sudan signed a peace deal agreeing to take steps to normalize their relations and end military support to each other�s rebel groups. The agreement called for a joint military commission to monitor the border and forbade the presence of rebel elements in both countries.

On 8 August 2006, many African leaders, including the President of Sudan, were present in Ndjamena to attend President Deby's inauguration ceremony after his re-election as president. Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi persuaded Sudanese and Chadian Presidents to hold an impromptu mini-summit after the inauguration ceremony. The mini-summit was also attended by the head of the AU, and the leaders of the Republic of Congo and Gabon. At the end of this impromptu mini-summit, Chad and Sudan agreed to end military support to each other�s rebel groups, as well as immediately restore diplomatic ties by reopening their common border and respective embassies.
third_party: Libya, AU, Republic of Congo, Gabon

description: In late 2006, the FUCD began negotiations with the government. These peace talks were mediated by Libyan President Muammar al-Gaddafi. This resulted in the signing of the Tripoli Accord by the leader of FUCD Mahamat Nour Abdulkerim and the Chadian president Idriss D�by in Tripoli on 24 December 2006. The agreement provided for a ceasefire, an amnesty for the rebels, and for the release of prisoners by both sides. The FUCD was also assigned a place in the government. The FUCD was part of the Union des Forces pour la D�mocratie et le D�veloppement (UFDD) (English: Union for Democracy and Development) alliance, of which other groups besides the UFDD criticised these negotiations and the subsequent peace agreement. As a result, the FUCD broke away from UFDD alliance.

However, the agreement between Chad and Sudan concluded in February 2006 did not hold. A Sudan-supported attack by the FUCD on Chad�s capital took place on 13 April 2006.

During the seventh AU Summit in Gambia, Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi arranged a tripartite meeting with Sudan and Chad on 2 and 3 July 2006.

As a follow up to the meeting at the AU summit, Chadian foreign minister went to Khartoum for several days in mid-July 2006 and met with the Sudanese government to discuss political and security matters as well as the possibility of resuming diplomatic relations. After the Chadian foreign minister's visit to Sudan in mid-July, which was an outcome of the Libyan initiative during the AU Summit, the two countries continued their negotiations that led to a peace deal. The agreement called for a joint military commission to monitor the border and forbade the presence of rebel elements in both countries.

Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi persuaded Sudanese and Chadian Presidents to hold an impromptu mini-summit after the inauguration ceremony. The mini-summit was also attended by the head of the AU, and the leaders of the Republic of Congo and Gabon. At the end of this impromptu mini-summit, Chad and Sudan agreed to end military support to each other�s rebel groups, as well as immediately restore diplomatic ties by reopening their common border and respective embassies.
third_party: Libya, AU, Republic of Congo, Gabon

description: On 10 April 2007, Libyan leader President Muammar al-Gaddafi dispatched Abdel Salem Triki, his personal envoy, as part of a mediation effort between Chad and Sudan aimed at ending the military support both countries were providing to each other�s rebel groups. Eritrea joined the effort as well, and the two sides met with both mediators that same day. On 12 April 2007, Libyan mediators reached an agreement with Chad and Sudan to allow Eritrean and Libyan military observers to monitor the border region. On 17 April 2007, the mediation effort by Libya and Eritrea led to the creation of a joint military and high security committee.

On 3 May 2007, Saudi Arabia hosted another meeting between President al-Bashir and Chadian President Deby in which the leaders of state agreed on ending military support to each other�s rebel groups, as well as on measures to prevent cross-border attacks by these rebel groups.

Negotiations between the Government of Chad and the RAFD started in Sirte, Libya, in July 2007. The Union des Forces pour la D�mocratie et le D�veloppement (UFDD) (English: Union for Democracy and Development) rebel alliance was also involved in these negotiations. Sudanese diplomats supported the Libyan-led mediation effort. The negotiations led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 4 October 2007. This ceasefire also a stipulated an amnesty for civil and military personnel and the release of all detainees from both sides

Continued negotiations led to the signing of a peace agreement in Sirte 25 October 2007. Libyan President Muammar al-Gaddafi acted as the chief mediator. Libya mediated another round of negotiations in July 2009. This led to the signing of peace agreement on 26 July 2009.

No direct negotiations have taken place between the Government of Chad and AN, but some negotiations took place between Chad and Sudan in 2008, aimed at ending the military support Sudan was providing to AN and ending the military support Chad was providing to the SLM/A and JEM. On 27 January 2008, Sudan and Chad participated in a summit of African countries that was convened to try and defuse tensions between Chad and Sudan and resolve the crisis in Darfur through persuading Chad to stop supporting Darfurian rebel groups. In addition to Gabon in the role of chief mediator, Libya, Egypt, Eritrea, Senegal, and Mauritania also attended this summit.
third_party: Gabon, Libya, Egypt, Eritrea, Senegal, Mauritania

description: On 6 March 2008, Senegal announced that it had been conducting shuttle diplomacy between Chad and Sudan. Senegal also announced that the two sides had consented in principle to sign an agreement at an upcoming meeting of the Organization of the Islamic Conference (OIC) to be held in Dakar. Despite Chad's and Sudan's pledge to sign the agreement, both sides continued to accuse each other of supporting the other's rebel groups and questioning each other's prospective commitment to the agreement, blaming each other for breaking all previous agreements. Nevertheless, Chad and Sudan signed the Dakar Agreement on 13 March 2008 at the OIC summit. Both sides agreed to stop supporting each other's armed opposition movements and to stop allowing their respective territories to be used as bases from which rebels could launch border incursions. The agreement failed to end the crisis however, as Chad accused Sudan of sending Chadian rebels to attack only hours before the agreement was signed. This confirmed the fears expressed by many analysts, as well as Chadian and Sudanese opposition movements, that the agreement would not be signed in good faith and would have little effect on the overall conflict. What is more, the JEM was able to attack Khartoum on 10 May 2008. In response, Sudan immediately cut diplomatic ties with Chad. Chadian rebels started an offensive in early June 2008. Chadian government troops had repelled this offensive by 18 June 2008.

Libya met with Chad and Sudan in late July 2008 and made proposals that were accepted by both sides, including ending military support to rebel groups, the restoration and normalization of diplomatic relations, and resumption of cooperation between the two countries.

No direct negotiations took place between the Government of Chad and the UFR until August 2010, but some negotiations took place between Chad and Sudan. These talks between Chad and Sudan were aimed at ending the military support Chad was providing to the SLM/A and JEM and ending the military support Sudan was providing to the UFR. On 2 May 2009, Chad and Sudan signed a new reconciliation agreement in Doha in Qatar. This agreement stipulated an end to the military support Sudan was providing to the UFR and Chad was providing to the SLM/A and JEM. However, the next day, on 3 May 2009, the UFR launched a new major raid on Chadian territory.

In August 2009, Sudanese and Chadian government representatives held exploratory talks in Tripoli under Libyan auspices. These talks were aimed at ending the military support Chad was providing to the SLM/A and JEM and ending the military support Sudan was providing to the UFR.

Chadian President D�by sent his foreign minister to Khartoum in December 2009 in order to start a process of rapprochement between the two countries. Sudanese President Al-Bashir responded by sending his adviser, Ghazi Salah al-Din al-Atabani, to N�Djamena to discuss the details of a security pact and in order to start a process of rapprochement between the two countries. The efforts of the Chadian foreign minister and the Sudanese presidential adviser paved the way for the conclusion of an agreement on 25 December 2009. The agreement committed Sudan and Chad to previous protocols that addressed controlling the border between the two countries and end military support to each other�s rebel groups.
On 15 January 2010, another agreement was signed by Chad and Sudan, this time mediated by Libyan President Muammar Gaddafi.

Qatar began another mediation effort in early 2010, meeting with Sudan in late February and then Chad in early March. This mediation effort was led by Qatarese Emir Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani. The agreement between Chad and Sudan concluded on 25 December 2009 was confirmed on 9 February 2010, when Chadian President Idriss Deby visited Sudan and met with Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir. During the visit, Chad and Sudan signed a formal agreement in which they agreed that neither would support rebel organizations targeting the other. The agreement held: Chad expelled the JEM in February 2010, while Sudan expelled all Chadian rebels in July 2010.
Negotiations between UFR and the Chadian government took place in August 2010, resulting in the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement.

In June 2011, the Central African Republic mediated between the Front Populaire pour le Redressement (FPR), which was part of the UFR alliance, and the Chadian government. Paulin Pomodimo acted as the chief mediator. This mediation effort led to the Communiqu� Final sanctionnant la rencontre entre la d�l�gation officielle tchadienne et le Front Populaire pour le Redressement (FPR) signed on 13 June 2011.
agreement_name: Communiqu� Final sanctionnant la rencontre entre la d�l�gation officielle tchadienne et le Front Populaire pour le Redressement (FPR)

description: Qatar initiated a mediation effort between the Chadian government and numerous Chadian armed opposition groups in March 2022. Negotiations in Doha, mediated by Qatar, culminated into the signing of a peace agreement on 8 August 2022. Over 30 rebel groups signed this peace pact with Chad�s transitional authorities. The agreement committed the signatories to a ceasefire and active participation in a national dialogue. The goal of this dialogue was to pave the way for elections in the country. The signatories of the agreement concluded in Doha were representatives from the following groups: UFR, CMSR, MLT, CNR, MNR, MCDT, UFDD, ADR, RFUTD, CNLT, MMT, FSR, FPLT, PA-X, ALC, MJST, NARR, RAFAD, UNC, UFCJ, MNDRD, MDJT, ANR, MRT, MSNT, MAR, APLT, ACTUS PRPE, ANUC, UFDD-F, RNDP, CPM/CDR. FACT participated but did not sign the agreement.
agreement_name: Doha Agreement for Peace and Involvement of Political-Military Movements in the Sovereign and Inclusive National Dialogue in Chad

description: The peace agreement concluded in Doha paved the way for the National Inclusive and Sovereign Dialogue (DNIS) held in N�Djamena from 20 August to 8 October 2022. Numerous governments, political, civil society, and opposition actors participated in the National Dialogue. CCMSR representatives also participated in this national dialogue, but did not sign the peace agreement concluded towards the end of the dialogue.

FACT participated but did not sign the agreement.
agreement_name: Doha Agreement for Peace and Involvement of Political-Military Movements in the Sovereign and Inclusive National Dialogue in Chad

description: The peace agreement concluded in Doha paved the way for the National Inclusive and Sovereign Dialogue (DNIS) held in N�Djamena from 20 August to 8 October 2022. Numerous governments, political, civil society, and opposition actors participated in the National Dialogue. FACT representatives also participated in this national dialogue, but did not sign the peace agreement concluded towards the end of the dialogue.

In July 2011, the Government of Nigeria announced that it planned to enter into negotiations with Boko Haram. On 2 August 2011, the government set up an eight-member committee led by Usman Galtimari, its former envoy to Chad, to advice on how to end the Boko Haram insurgency. Galtimari submitted a report on 26 September 2011 that recommended talks and amnesty for Boko Haram members who renounce violence. A preliminary round of negotiations between the conflict parties took place in Maiduguri on 16 September 2011. Former President Olusegun Obasanjo led the government delegation. Boko Haram laid out conditions for a temporary ceasefire during these negotiations, which were an end to arrests and killings of Boko Haram members and compensation for families of members killed by security personnel. In spite of these peace talks, the conflict continued to escalate in 2012, both in terms of the number of people killed and in its geographical scope.
Government and Boko Haram representatives engaged in negotiations in January 2013. This led to the signing of a ceasefire on 28 January 2013.

In May 2013, President Goodluck Jonathan established a committee to negotiate a settlement with the Boko Haram leadership. A round of negotiations between this committee and Boko Haram led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 8 July 2013.
A new round of talks on the release of the school girls and a ceasefire in November 2015 also broke down.

Nigeria�s information minister Lai Mohammed announced in March 2018 that government representatives were negotiating with Boko Haram. The talks were aimed at securing a permanent cessation of hostilities.

In 1989, in response to the tumultuous events immediately following the start of the implementation process of Namibia�s independence as outlined in UN Security Council Resolution 435, UN Secretary-General Javier P�rez de Cu�llar mediated between SWAPO and South Africa and put forward new ceasefire proposals. By mid-May 1989, the South African and SWAPO forces were again confined to their bases and the implementation process could begin. Elections between 7 and 11 November 1989 were directed by the South African administration, but under supervision of Martti Ahtisaari, the Special Representative of the UN Secretary General, and a UN Transition Assistance Group (UNTAG). Implementation went relatively smoothly and according to schedule. SWAPO won the elections with 57.3 percent of the vote, with the Democratic Turnhalle Alliance coming in second with 28.6 percent. On 21 November 1989, the elected Constituent Assembly convened to begin drawing up a Constitution. South African troops, which had already been reduced to 1,500 by June 1989, were completely withdrawn one week after the election was certified.

On 19-21 February 1989, a round of negotiations took place between the Government of Cambodia, the KPNLF, FUNCINPEC, and KR in Jakarta in Indonesia. The negotiations � referred to as the Second Jakarta Informal Meeting � were initiated by Indonesia, which led the mediation effort, but other ASEAN countries, as well as Vietnam and Laos, were involved too. The negotiations were aimed at finding a way to address the conflict and consisted of a largely Asian-based initiative. The result was a �consensus statement� regarding the broad agreements on the international aspects of the conflict, namely the withdrawal of Vietnamese forces from Cambodia and the cessation of foreign military support to the warring factions. Many issues, mainly regarding the internal aspects of the conflict, remained unsolved.
agreement_name: consensus statement on international aspects of conflict

description: On 11 September 1989, Thai Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan mediated between the Government of Cambodia, the KPNLF, FUNCINPEC, and the KR via shuttle diplomacy. He hoped to break the impasse blocking a settlement, but failed in doing so. This was partly due to the other ASEAN states criticizing his efforts because they regarded the Cambodian Government under Hun Sen as illegitimate.

On 27 February 1990, a round of negotiations took place between the Government of Cambodia, the KPNLF, FUNCINPEC, and the KR in Jakarta in Indonesia. The negotiations were mediated by France and Indonesia and lasted until 1 March 1990. The peace talks resulted in a communique stipulating a ceasefire and establishing a Supreme National Council (SNC), but no agreement on addressing the conflict issues was reached. The meeting collapsed when the issue of genocide committed by KR in the 1970s was raised. This had already been a deal-breaker in the 1989 negotiations in Paris.

On 28 August 1990, the Framework for a comprehensive Political Settlement of the Cambodia Conflict was adopted by the five permanent members of the UN Security council and was accepted by the Cambodian parties as a base for settling the Cambodian conflict.

On 10 September 1990, a round of negotiations took place between the Government of Cambodia, the KPNLF, FUNCINPEC, and the KR in Jakarta. The negotiations were mediated by the UN, France, and Indonesia. The peace talks resulted in the formation of the National Supreme Council (SNC).

On 26 April 1991, a round of negotiations took place between the Government of Cambodia, the KPNLF, FUNCINPEC, and the KR. The negotiations were mediated by the UN, France, and Indonesia and resulted in the conflict parties agreeing on a ceasefire set to start on 1 May 1991.

On 24-26 June 1991, a round of negotiations took place between the Government of Cambodia, the KPNLF, FUNCINPEC, and the KR in Pattaya in Thailand. The negotiations were mediated by the UN, France, Indonesia, and Thailand. The mediators achieved some success, but important issues, such as the demobilization and disarming of the factions, had yet to be resolved.

On 26-28 August 1991, a round of negotiations took place between the Government of Cambodia, the KPNLF, FUNCINPEC, and the KR in Pattaya. The negotiations were mediated by the UN, France, Indonesia, and Thailand. In this round of negotiations, the conflict parties agreed on demobilizing major parts of their military forces and on certain rules for the planned democratic elections, which were set to take place after the peace agreement was put into effect.

On 19 September 1991, a round of negotiations took place between the Government of Cambodia, the KPNLF, FUNCINPEC, and the KR in New York. The negotiations were mediated by the UN and the conflict parties agreed on their intention to sign a full peace agreement at an upcoming peace conference in Paris. The parties also agreed on more rules for the planned elections, for example on the electoral system.

On 23 October 1991, the Government of Cambodia, the KPNLF, FUNCINPEC, and the KR met in Paris for a Peace conference under the co-chairmanship of France and Indonesia. The conference led to the signing of a peace agreement by all of the four conflict parties. The agreement specified the terms for the demobilization and disarmament of the military forces, the modalities for the elections and the role of the UN Transitional Authority in Cambodia (UNTAC) during the transitional period. The main tasks of UNTAC were the supervision of the ceasefire, disarmament and demobilization of the armed forces of the different factions, promotion of human rights, the resettlement of refugees, and the preparation and organization of free and fair elections. By early 1993, UNTAC had completed some, but not all its objectives. While it managed to resettle over 350,000 refugees and prepare elections by registering over 4.7 million voters, the whole process took place in an atmosphere of confrontation and violence. The biggest obstacle was the KR, which was not adhering to the Paris Peace Agreement. The KR did not properly respect the ceasefire, disarm their troops, or demobilize. By 1993, it became clear, that they would not support the peace progress or the elections, as they also attacked civilians and UNTAC personnel.
agreement_name: Framework for a Comprehensive Political Settlement of the Cambodia Conflict

description: On 28 May 1994, a round of negotiations took place between the Government of Cambodia and the KR in Pyongyang in North Korea. However, the KR refused to conclude a ceasefire.

The result was a �consensus statement� regarding the broad agreements on the international aspects of the conflict, namely the withdrawal of Vietnamese forces from Cambodia and the cessation of foreign military support to the warring factions. Many issues, mainly regarding the internal aspects of the conflict, remained unsolved.
agreement_name: consensus statement on international aspects of conflict

The main tasks of UNTAC were the supervision of the ceasefire, disarmament and demobilization of the armed forces of the different factions, promotion of human rights, the resettlement of refugees, and the preparation and organization of free and fair elections. After the conference, the KPNLF transformed itself into a political party, called the Buddhist Liberal Democratic Party (BLDP), and participated in the 1993 elections. It subsequently entered the government collation with the more powerful CPP and FUNCINPEC.
