On 20 November 1991, the Government of Cambodia, under its new name as Cambodian People�s Party (CPP), met with FUNCINPEC in Phnom Penh for a round of negotiations. These negotiations resulted in the signing of an accord in which both parties agreed to cooperate in creating a more peaceful situation and ensuring that the monarchy could be restored.

On 7 February 1998, a round of negotiations took place between the Government of Cambodia and the Forces of Norodom Ranariddh in Phnom Penh. The negotiations were mediated by Japan and resulted in a ceasefire. Hun Sen also agreed to let Prince Ranariddh, who was in exile, return to Cambodia and take part in the 1998 elections.
On the basis of the peace plan brokered by Japan, Ranariddh and Hun Sen expressed their commitment to concluding a permanent ceasefire during a round of talks on 27 February 1998.

On 26 July 1998, national elections were held the forming of a new coalition among political parties proved to be difficult. On 5 September 1998, a round of negotiations took place between the Government of Cambodia, FUNCINPEC (as the political group representing the Forces of Norodom Ranariddh), and the Sam Rainsy Party (SRP) in Siem Reap in northwestern Cambodia. The talks were initiated and mediated by Cambodian King Norodom Sihanouk. The talks ended without success.

On 22 September 1998, a round of negotiations took place between the Government of Cambodia, FUNCINPEC, and the SRP in Siem Reap in northwestern Cambodia. The talks were mediated by Cambodian King Norodom Sihanouk. The talks were a positive step in defusing the increasingly violent situation, but still failed to address proposals for a coalition.

On 29 September 1998, a round of negotiations took place between the Government of Cambodia, FUNCINPEC, and the Sam Rainsy Party in Phnomh Penh. Unlike in the previous two meetings, only subordinates were delegated for this �working group meeting� and they achieved very little in terms of forging a new coalition. There were two more rounds of negotiations with the same format, but it is unclear when and where these were held.

On 13 November 1998, a round of negotiations took place between the Government of Cambodia and FUNCINPEC in Phnom Penh. The parties declared adherence to the Paris Peace Accords and the talks resulted in a new coalition government being formed. Hun Sen was to become the sole prime minister, while Prince Ranariddh would assume the position of chairman of the National Assembly. This strengthened Hun Sen�s position.

In February 2002, a summit between the presidents of Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia was held in Rabat under the auspices of Morocco�s King Mohammed VI. The meeting led to the Rabat Accord, which confirms the signatories� commitment to �total security along their common borders.� The RFDG did not participate in the regional summits

In March 1989, a new Sudanese government assumed power, which proposed a peace plan that was based on the peace deal that was reached between SPLM/A and DUP in November 1988, calling for a freeze on Islamic laws. The UN became involved in April 1989, trying to make both parties accept a ceasefire. At a meeting on 1 May 1989, the UN managed to convince the conflict parties observe a �month of tranquillity� to allow aid to reach the area where people are threatened with famine. This ceasefire was later extended for another two weeks. The Government of Sudan subsequently accepted the DUP-SPLM/A Sudan Peace Agreement, after which it was also ratified by the parliament.

Following the collapse of the Carter initiative, Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi invited Bashir and Garang to his Presidential retreat in Nakuru for peace talks. Both Bashir and Garang accepted the invitation and the meeting was set for 27 February 1990. However, at the last minute, Garang decided not to go, so only Bashir showed up. Similarly, Zaire and Egypt mediated in 1990, but could not bring the conflict parties to the negotiation table. The Government of Sudan took the initiative in March 1990 to request the US to mediate. The US subsequently initiated a mediation effort. In order to move the conflict parties towards a peace settlement, US Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs Herman Cohen began to shuttle between the conflict parties in March 1990. Cohen formulated a proposal that stipulated the conclusion of a ceasefire, withdrawal of troops, followed by a constitutional conference that would decide on a federal system. With regard to the withdrawal of troops, Cohen proposed the complete evacuation of the national army to positions north of the 11th parallel, while the SPLM/A had to guarantee that it would not take control of southern Sudan militarily if the government forces would withdraw. With neither conflict party agreeing to this proposal, Cohen subsequently formulated a new proposal, which stipulated that half of the government forces would be pulled out from southern Sudan, while the SPLM/A would in exchange withdraw all its troops 15 kilometres from the besieged towns. Moreover, the withdrawal of troops would be internationally monitored. Cohen also proposed to hold a constitutional conference. Cohen personally presented the adapted proposal to President al-Bashir in Khartoum on 9 March 1990. While al-Bashir promised Cohen to study the proposal carefully, he soon conveyed that he rejected the possibility of a constitutional conference, preferring bilateral talks with John Garrang. The Government of Sudan also refused to withdraw from some garrison towns in areas controlled by the rebels including some oil fields. This terminated his round of shuttle talks in March 1990.

The first phase of what came to be known as the Abuja peace talks started on 26 May 1992 and ended on 4 June 1992 without any progress made. The talks were hosted by the Nigerian president Ibrahim Babangida in his capacity as chair of the OAU. Talks focused particularly on issues related to national identity, religion and state, self-determination, and interim security arrangements. The Nigerian mediators suggested to the conflict parties that an effective ceasefire would require a neutral observer team that would ensure all the parties complied with the peace agreement. Although the SPLM/A agreed, the Government of Sudan insisted that such a team would constitute �foreign intervention in the affairs of Sudan.� The first phase of the Abuja negotiations ended with the adoption of the Communique of the Abuja Sudanese Peace Conference. The adversaries further committed themselves to continued negotiations mediated by Nigeria in the future, in order to build upon the gains achieved in Abuja.
agreement_name: Communique of the Abuja Sudanese Peace Conference

description: In spite of its promise to continue negotiations, involvement of the wider region was necessary to bring the Sudanese government back to the negotiation table. In order to revive the peace process, Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni invited a government delegation led by Ali al-Hag and a SPLM/A delegation led by John Garang to Uganda to discuss the modalities of future negotiations. After two days of discussions taking place in Entebbe on 22 and 23 February 1993, the parties issued a communique in which they committed themselves to a second round of peace talks in Abuja mediated by Nigeria.

Another round of negotiations was subsequently held in Nairobi between 18 and 28 July 1994. While the SPLM/A accepted the DoP, the government side rejected the document. Nevertheless, on 23 July 1994, the Government of Sudan declared a unilateral ceasefire. This ceasefire was initially rejected by SPLM/A, but was eventually accepted. The ceasefire was later broken by both sides.

In 1995, former US president Jimmy Carter managed to conduct shuttle mediation between the conflict parties, which led to a two-month ceasefire that was unilaterally announced by the Government of Sudan on 28 March 1995. The two-month ceasefire would help a health campaign organized by the Carter Center against Guinea worm infestation and river blindness in the south. In addition to the ceasefire, the rebels were offered amnesty if they laid down their weapons. The SPLM/A accepted the ceasefire on 1 June 1995, although some elements within the organisation rejected the ceasefire. The SPLM/A also called for international monitoring of the ceasefire. According to Carter, the ceasefire was holding with a few minor exceptions. Yet, the conflict parties accused each other of violating the ceasefire. In August 1995, the conflict parties agreed to resume peace talks, but not to extend the ceasefire. Yet, the talks never took place.

Libya mediated a round of negotiations between Sudanese and Ugandan representatives in Tripoli in early April 1995. The LRA and the SPLM/A were excluded from the talks. The negotiations focused on Uganda ending military support to the SPLM/A and Sudan ending military support to the LRA. The Sudanese and Ugandan representatives signed an agreement in Tripoli in Libya on 5 April 1995, which called for the end of military assistance to rebel groups in both countries. The agreement stipulated, among others, a �commitment to noninterference in either side's internal affairs, pledging to refrain from providing aid to any opposing gang in either country and barring the use of either side�s territory for attacks against the other side.� However, the agreement failed. Uganda severed diplomatic relations with Sudan on 23 April 1995, and expelled eleven Sudanese diplomats from the country on 24 April 1995. Sudanese troops and Ugandan troops clashed near the border on 29 October 1995.

Iran mediated negotiations between the countries between September and November 1996. The LRA and the SPLM/A were excluded from the talks. The negotiations focused on Uganda ending military support to the SPLM/A and Sudan ending military support to the LRA. Sudanese and Ugandan representatives signed a draft peace agreement in Tehran in November 1996.

The conflict parties resumed peace talks in Nairobi on 4 May 1998, under the auspices of IGAD. Not wanting to appear as an obstructionist, the Sudanese government accepted self-determination for the South on the basis of a referendum during this round of talks.

On 15 July, the SPLM/A declared a 3-month ceasefire in Bahr el-Ghazal in order to facilitate humanitarian aid. The Government of Sudan accepted the ceasefire. In August 1998, the Government of Sudan extended the ceasefire throughout southern Sudan, but this was rejected by the SPLM/A.

Another round of IGAD-sponsored peace talks was held in Addis Ababa between 6 and 8 August 1998. This round of talks was also attended by Secretary-General of the OAU Salim Ahmed Salim. In October, the humanitarian ceasefire was extended by both parties for another 3 months.

In addition to negotiations between the Sudanese government and the SPLM/A, some negotiations took place between Sudan and its neighbours that were aimed at ending military support provided to the SPLM/A and the military support Sudan was providing to rebel groups in neighbouring countries. The border dispute between Ethiopia and Eritrea that escalated into an armed conflict in May 1998 motivated the Ethiopian leadership to improve relations with Sudan. In late September and early November 1998, a high-level Ethiopian delegation was in Khartoum for discrete talks with a Sudanese delegation on reconciliation between the two countries. The talks concerned the ending of Ethiopian military support to the SPLM/A and Sudanese military support to the OLF. The negotiations were successful and the Ethiopian government shut down offices of the SPLM/A in Gambela in western Ethiopia near the Ethiopia-Sudan border, though the SPLM/A maintained a presence in the frontier zone. The Sudanese authorities, in turn, closed the OLF offices in Khartoum and suburbs.

When the border dispute between Ethiopia and Eritrea escalated into an armed conflict in May 1998, the leadership of Eritrea wanted to improve relations with Sudan. Consequently, Eritrean Foreign Minister Haile Woldensae and Sudanese Foreign Minister Mustafa Osman Ismail of Sudan engaged in negotiations mediated by Qatari Foreign Minister Sheikh Hamad bin Jassim bin Jabr al-Thani in Doha. These negotiations began on 9 November 1998 and ended on 2 February 1999 with the signing of a peace agreement. This peace agreement stipulates that both Eritrea and Sudan should abstain from supporting groups that undermine the security and stability of neighboring countries.

In a round of negotiations on 31 March 1999, the leaders of Sudan and Ethiopia restored diplomatic relations and concluded an agreement in which they committed to abstain from activities that undermine peace and security in each other�s countries. Specifically, the Government of Ethiopia committed to end support to the SPLM/A, while the Government of Sudan committed to end support to the OLF and the AIAI.

President Muammar Qaddafi of Libya mediated negotiations between the presidents of Eritrea and Sudan in Tripoli on 16 and 17 April 1999. These negotiations were aimed at ending the military support Eritrea and Sudan were providing to each other�s rebel groups.

The presidents of Eritrea and Sudan held another round of negotiations mediated by Qatar in Doha in Qatar on 2 and 3 May 1999. The Sudanese and Eritrean delegations agreed to abstain from supporting groups that undermine the security and stability of neighboring countries, as well as agreed to restore diplomatic ties. Eritrean authorities subsequently forced Sudanese opposition figures to leave Eritrea by the end of May 1999. Eritrea and Sudan resumed diplomatic relations on 4 January 2000.

The humanitarian ceasefire was continuously extended by both parties for 3-month periods throughout 1999. Former vice-president of Sudan Abel Alier separately consulted Garang and Bashir, after which he proposed a confederal solution to the conflict. This was rejected by the Government of Sudan.

Up until 1999, the Kenyan minister of Foreign Affairs had acted as the chief mediator of the peace talks, but it was decided in mid-1999 that a mediator needed to be appointed that could lead sustained negotiations. To this end, Daniel Mboya, the former Kenyan Ambassador to Sudan, was appointed. IGAD-sponsored peace talks were resumed in Nairobi on 20 July 1999. The parties agreed on procedural issues for further talks, but they failed to make any progress on substantial issues pertaining to a comprehensive ceasefire, self-determination for the south, defining a border, and the relation between religion and state.

In August 1999, the Carter Center mediated a round of negotiations between Sudan and Uganda. The LRA and the SPLM/A were excluded from the talks. The negotiations focused on Uganda ending military support to the SPLM/A and Sudan ending military support to the LRA.

Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir and Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi engaged in negotiations in Addis Ababa on 18 and 19 November 1999, confirming the March 1999 agreement that committed both states to abstain from activities that undermine peace and security in each other�s countries.

In early December 1999, Jimmy Carter, representing the Carter Center, mediated negotiations between Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir and Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni in Nairobi in Kenya. The leaders of Sudan and Uganda signed an eleven-point agreement in Nairobi on 8 December 1999, which provided, among others, for the resumption of diplomatic relations and the end to military assistance to rebel groups. The Nairobi Agreement stipulated an end to the support of Uganda to the SPLM/A and the support of Sudan to the LRA. More specifically, in the agreement the conflict parties pledged that �1. Each of us will respect the sovereignty and territorial integrity of each other, in accordance with the charters of the United Nations and the Organization for African Unity. 2. We renounce the use of force to resolve differences, and will take steps to prevent any hostile acts against each other. 3. We will make every effort to disband and disarm terrorist groups and to prevent any acts of terrorism or hostile actions that might originate in our territory that might endanger the security of the other nation. 4. We agree not to harbor, sponsor, or give military or logistical support to any rebel groups, opposition groups, or hostile elements from each other�s territories.�

A round of negotiations mediated by IGAD took place in January 2000. After this round of negotiations, the parties issued a joint communiqu� in which they reiterated their commitment to a peaceful solution and said they agreed on self-determination for the people of southern Sudan.

Additionally, the UN was also involved in mediation between the conflict parties in a round of shuttle negotiations in February 2000. The goal of this UN mediation effort was to conclude a humanitarian ceasefire to allow for the vaccination of 54,000 children in the Nuba mountains. This mediation effort was successful. The conflict parties agreed on a three-day ceasefire in February 2000 and another three-day ceasefire in March 2000.

In May 2001, the Government of Sudan called for a comprehensive ceasefire, but the SPLM/A rejected the call and instead proposed a conditional ceasefire, stating that the SPLM/A would only lay down their weapons if the Government of Sudan would stop producing oil. The Government of Sudan rejected this condition.
In November 2001, the conflict parties agreed on a four-week long ceasefire in order to allow food deliveries.

Representatives of the conflict parties met with diplomats from the US and Switzerland in Buergenstock in December 2001 to discuss the possibility of negotiations concerning a ceasefire in the Nuba Mountains. US Special Envoy John Danforth acted as the US mediator during these talks and Ambassador Josef Bucher as the Swiss mediator.

After pre-negotiations in Buergenstock in December 2001, the Government of Sudan and the SPLM/A met for a week of talks in Buergenstock in January 2002. The mediation team included both American and Swiss diplomats and the Swiss Ambassador Josef Bucher acted as the chief mediator. After six days of negotiations, the conflict parties concluded a ceasefire pertaining to the Nuba Mountains on 19 January 2002. It was agreed that the ceasefire in Nuba Mountains would be monitored by Britain, France, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, Switzerland and the US. The peace talks in Switzerland were coordinated with IGAD and thus complementary to the IGAD-led peace process.

Negotiations mediated by IGAD were resumed in Machakos in June 2002. The mediation team at Machakos was led by Kenyan General Lazaro Sumbeiywo. Although Kenya chaired the peace talks, diplomats from Eritrea, Ethiopia and Uganda were also heavily involved. Moreover, there was active engagement from the four official observer countries in the peace process: the UK, the US, Norway and Italy. As soon as the talks at Machakos started, the conflict parties agreed to extend the ceasefire in the Nuba Mountains for another six-month period. On 20 July 2002, the SPLM/A and the Government of Sudan signed the Machakos Protocol. The peace agreement stipulated the general procedures for a transitional process, but also committed the conflict parties to engage in further negotiations to specify the terms of the framework. The agreement outlined a transitional process, starting with a six-month pre-transition period, followed by a six-year transition period. Afterward, a supervised referendum would decide whether southern Sudan would secede. During the transition, a broad-based government would govern in Khartoum. The southern states would also receive a measure of autonomy during this period. Additionally, the agreement specified that Sharia law would only apply in the northern region.
third_party: IGAD, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya, UK, US, Norway, Italy

description: Nevertheless, the adversaries engaged in another round of IGAD-mediated negotiations between October and November 2002. At the start of this round, the conflict parties signed an initial ceasefire on 15 October 2002, referred to as the Memorandum of Understanding on Cessation of Hostilities. On 18 November 2002, when negotiations closed for the year, a Memorandum of Understanding was signed, but no comprehensive agreement had been reached. The talks were adjourned until 6 January 2003, due to Ramadan, Christmas, and the Kenyan elections.
third_party: IGAD, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya, UK, US, Norway, Italy

description: IGAD-negotiations, led by the chief mediator Lazaro Sumbeiywo, continued in 2003 throughout the entire year. The US, the UK, Norway and Italy all had observer status during the talks and took part in the mediation. Norway also funded the peace talks. The Arab League announced in May 2003 that it would also begin attending the peace talks as an observer. Ambassador Samir Hosni, Director of the Arab-African cooperation at the Arab League subsequently attended the meetings. In spite of some clashes in early 2003, negotiations started on 23 January 2003. The talks focused on power and wealth sharing.
third_party: IGAD, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya, UK, US, Norway, Italy

description: The implementation of the Memorandum of Understanding on Cessation of Hostilities signed on 15 October 2002 was further improved during a round of negotiations in February 2003, with the signing an addendum to the MOU on 4 February 2003, which created a Verification and Monitoring Team (VMT). The VMT consisted of international observers to verify accusations of ceasefire violations. The conflict parties also agreed to cede control of areas captured since the signing of the ceasefire agreement in October 2002. With regard to the issue of power sharing, the conflict parties agreed on a framework of a government of national unity in which the SPLM/A would be a major partner.
third_party: IGAD, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya, UK, US, Norway, Italy

description: A new round of talks, addressing security issues, started on 7 April 2003, but was stalemated on how to unify the national army.
third_party: IGAD, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya, UK, US, Norway, Italy

description: Yet another round of negotiations on security issues was held in August 2003. None of these rounds of talks resulted in much progress. Nevertheless, the ceasefire, which was due to expire on 30 June 2003, was extended by both parties.
third_party: IGAD, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya, UK, US, Norway, Italy

description: The peace process took a positive turn when Vice President Ali Osman Mohamed Taha and John Garang entered into negotiations on 4 September 2003. Subsequent discussions on power sharing and security issues resulted in the signing of the Agreement on Security Arrangements During the Interim Period on 25 September 2003. The parties agreed that an internationally monitored ceasefire would come into place once the Comprehensive Peace Agreement was signed. Subsequently, both parties� forces would be appropriately downsized. Throughout the interim period, the majority of their forces would remain separate entities. However, if the final referendum on Southern Sudan�s territorial status resulted in unity rather than secession, the armies would be unified and integrated. The ceasefire was also extended by two months.
third_party: IGAD, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya, UK, US, Norway, Italy
agreement_name: Agreement on Security Arrangements During the Interim Period

description: Throughout 2004, the SPLM/A and the Government of Sudan held negotiations in Kenya based on the process agreed on in the Machakos Protocol singed in 2002. The continuous negotiations resulted in the signing of several protocols and agreements that were to make up the foundation of the final Comprehensive Peace Agreement. During a round of negotiations in Naivasha in January 2004, the Framework on Wealth Sharing During the Pre-Interim and Interim Period was signed on 7 January 2004. The agreement stipulated a 50-50 split of oil revenues from southern Sudan between the two parties. Moreover, it was agreed that separate banking systems would be applied in the north and the south.
third_party: IGAD, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya, UK, US, Norway, Italy
agreement_name: Framework on Wealth Sharing During the Pre-Interim and Interim Period

description: The next round of talks in May 2004 resulted in the signing of three agreements in Naivasha on 26 May. The first agreement was the Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on the Resolution of Conflict in Southern Kordofan/Nuba Mountains and Blue Nile States on 26 May 2004. This agreement covered the administration of contested border areas between the north and south. It confirmed Southern Kordofan and the Blue Nile States as federal states of Sudan. The agreement established a power-sharing arrangement in their state legislatures, with 55% of seats controlled by the governing party of Sudan (NPC) and 45% of seats by the SPLM/A. However, this arrangement would only be in effect during the interim period. Afterward, elections would be held to establish a democratically elected government and assembly in these regions. Furthermore, the agreement did not grant any special standing to these states, unlike the Abyei area settlement. It also emphasized the need for joint agreement between conflict parties on a program for the resettlement of refugees and internally displaced persons. The second agreement concluded in Naivasha on 26 May 2004 was the Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on the Resolution of Conflict in Abyei Area on 26 May 2004. The agreement established a temporary administrative arrangement for Abyei and emphasized that its final status should not be predetermined by this agreement. It required the redeployment of military forces from both the government of Sudan and the Republic of South Sudan from the Abyei region. Instead, an Interim Security Force for Abyei (ISFA) composed of Ethiopian troops would be deployed in the area. The third agreement concluded in Naivasha on 26 May 2004 was the Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on Power Sharing on 26 May 2004. This peace agreement established an interim constitution and set up a Government of Southern Sudan for the interim period. During this period, the government would have a legislative assembly and executive powers. In the legislature, the SPLM/A would hold 70% of the seats, while the ruling Khartoum party (NCP) would have 15%, and other Southern Sudanese political forces would receive 15% of the seats. The same formula applied to the executive authority of Southern Sudan. At the national level, a power-sharing arrangement was agreed upon. John Garang, the leader of SPLM/A, was appointed as the first Vice-President. The National Assembly was formed with a formula of 52% of seats for the NCP and 28% of seats for the SPLM/A. Both the Southern Sudanese Government and the Sudanese Government were given the right to control their own police and security forces. They also agreed to work together in addressing the issue of resettlement of refugees and internally displaced persons. The conclusion of the three agreements concluded in Naivasha on 26 May 2004 finalised the political negotiations. The only issues that still needed to be addressed were the more technical issues of a comprehensive ceasefire, security arrangements, and the implementation of the peace agreement. However, during the two months after signing of the three peace agreements, the Government of Sudan claimed to be too busy with the situation in Darfur.
third_party: IGAD, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya, UK, US, Norway, Italy
agreement_name: Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on the Resolution of Conflict in Southern Kordofan/Nuba Mountains and Blue Nile States, the Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on the Resolution of Conflict in Abyei Area, and the Protocol Between the SUDANESE GOVERNMENT and SPLM on Power Sharing

description: On 7 October 2004, Garang and Taha started another round of negotiations. On 19 November, the government and SPLM/A signed a Memorandum of Understanding, committing the conflict parties to sign a comprehensive peace agreement no later than 31 December 2004.
third_party: IGAD, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya, UK, US, Norway, Italy

description: Consequently, talks between Garang and Taha resumed again on 7 December 2004 and continued until Christmas Eve. The parties marked the end of the conflict on 31 December 2004 by the signing of a permanent ceasefire.
third_party: IGAD, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya, UK, US, Norway, Italy

description: The Comprehensive Peace Agreement was signed in Naivasha on 9 January 2005. The agreement stipulated that the south would have autonomy for an interim period of 6 years, followed by a referendum in 2011 offering the option of independence from Sudan. John Garang, the leader of SPLM/A, would become the First Vice President, and SPLM/A would hold 28 percent of the seats in the National Government. The application of Sharia law was limited to the north and only to Muslims. Oil revenues in the south were specified to be shared equally (50-50) between the north and the south. The forces of the National Government and SPLM/A were to remain separate, but integrated units of 21,000 troops were to be formed. The government was required to withdraw 91,000 troops from the south within two and a half years, while the SPLM/A would have eight months to withdraw its troops from the north. Finally, the north and the south would have separate banking systems and currencies. The Government of National Unity � consisting of members of the National Congress Party (NCP), the SPLM/A, and the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) � was formed on 22 September 2005. One of the most contentious issues that remained following the signing of the CPA was the status of Abyei. The protocol on Abeyi included in the CPA stipulated the formation of the Abyei Borders Commission (ABC), which was tasked to demarcate the borders of Abyei. It had been agreed that if the five representatives of the Sudanese government and the five representatives of the SPLM/A seated in the ABC could not agree on the location of the borders, five international experts would map the borders. These experts issued a decision on the borders of Abyei on 14 July 2005, but the Sudanese government immediately rejected this decision. In addition, as soon as the international experts of the ABC had issued their report, several minor violent clashes took place in Abyei between different tribal militias supported by each side. Later that month, on 30 July 2005, SPLM/A leader John Garang died in a helicopter crash. Salva Kiir subsequently assumed the leadership of the SPLM/A.
third_party: IGAD, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya, UK, US, Norway, Italy

description: In August 2006, the SPLM/A and Sudanese government forces clashed in the Rubkona area of Unity State, resulting in the death of eight civilians and three soldiers. Heavy fighting between the SPLM/A and government forces in Malakal from 27 to 30 November 2006 resulted in at least 150 people dead. The conflict parties subsequently engaged in a round of negotiations and concluded a new ceasefire in December 2006, which also stipulated joint investigation.

Fighting escalated in Abyei in May 2008. Between 13 and 21 May 2008, at least 90 people were killed in Abyei during violence between government forces and the SPLM/A. Negotiations mediated by the UN led to the signing of an agreement on 8 June 2008. This agreement stipulated a new ceasefire and referred the boundary demarcation to the Permanent Court of Arbitration (PCA) in The Hague. In 2009, the PCA issued its ruling, which considerably decreased the size of Abyei and moved the Heglig and Kharsana oil fields to Sudan. In spite of this ruling, the NCP still rejected the ruling and even occupied Abyei with armed forces.

With tensions increasing and the referendum on self-determination for Southern Sudan approaching, the AU started to take the lead in mediating the successful implementation of the CPA. To this purpose, the AU High-Level Implementation Panel for Sudan (AUHIP) was established during a meeting of the AU Peace and Security Council on 29 October 2009. Led by former South African President Thabo Mbeki, the panel was mandated to assist the Sudanese parties in the implementation of the CPA. A round of negotiations in June 2010, without the involvement a third party, led to the signing of the Mekelle Memorandum of Understanding between the NCP and the SPLM on Post-referendum Issues and Arrangements on 21 June 2010. This agreement outlined arrangements for negotiations after the 2011 referendum on self-determination. The agreement also listed all issues that need to be negotiated, including citizenship, security, financial, economic, and natural resources, and international treaties and legal issues. The parties also agreed that these negotiations would be mediated by the AUHIP, with support from IGAD, IGAD partner�s forum, and the UN.
agreement_name: Mekelle Memorandum of Understanding between the NCP and the SPLM on Post-referendum Issues and Arrangements

description: Next, between 7 and 13 November 2010, the Sudanese government and Sudanese government representatives discussed post-referendum issues, agreeing that the overriding principle of post-secession relations between Sudan and Southern Sudan should be the concept of two viable states. However, the negotiation partners could not agree on the status of Abyei, inhibiting them from signing a Framework Agreement.

No direct negotiations between the NDA and the Government of Sudan took place until July 1999, but some negotiations took place between Sudan and Eritrea that were aimed at ending the military support Eritrea was providing to the NDA and the SPLM/A and Sudan was providing to the EIJM - AS. When the border dispute between Ethiopia and Eritrea escalated into an armed conflict in May 1998, the leadership of Eritrea wanted to improve relations with Sudan. Consequently, Eritrean Foreign Minister Haile Woldensae and Sudanese Foreign Minister Mustafa Osman Ismail of Sudan engaged in negotiations mediated by Qatari Foreign Minister Sheikh Hamad bin Jassim bin Jabr al-Thani in Doha. These negotiations began on 9 November 1998 and ended on 2 February 1999 with the signing of a peace agreement. This peace agreement stipulates that both Eritrea and Sudan should abstain from supporting groups that undermine the security and stability of neighboring countries.

President Muammar Qaddafi of Libya mediated negotiations between the presidents of Eritrea and Sudan in Tripoli on 16 and 17 April 1999. These negotiations were aimed at ending the military support Eritrea and Sudan were providing to each other�s rebel groups.

The presidents of Eritrea and Sudan held another round of negotiations mediated by Qatar in Doha in Qatar on 2 and 3 May 1999. The Sudanese and Eritrean delegations agreed to abstain from supporting groups that undermine the security and stability of neighboring countries, as well as agreed to restore diplomatic ties. Eritrean authorities subsequently forced Sudanese opposition figures to leave Eritrea by the end of May 1999. Eritrea and Sudan resumed diplomatic relations on 4 January 2000.

Following a round of negotiations from 14 to 16 June 2005, under the auspices of the Government of Egypt, the conflict parties signed a peace process agreement in Cairo on 16 January 2005. This framework agreement outlines the issues involved in reaching a comprehensive peace and complements the SPLM/A peace agreement of the same month and year. It calls for abolishing emergency laws and statutes restricting freedoms, establishing new laws for Sudanese political parties, methods of allowing for power sharing, and the dissolution of NDA forces. The agreement set up a number of commissions to discuss these issues in order to reach a comprehensive peace agreement.
A round of negotiations in June 2005 subsequently led to the signing of a full peace agreement on 18 June 2005, referred to as the Cairo Agreement.

In late March 2004, peace talks between the Government of Sudan and the two rebel groups SLM/A and JEM began in N�djamena in Chad. Chad mediated these negotiations. However, both the SLM/A and JEM were dissatisfied with the mediation by Chad, whom they considered too biased towards the Government of Sudan. The Government of Sudan initially refused to hold face-to-face talks. Yet, when the SLM/A threatened to walk out of the negotiations, the Government of Sudan gave in and sat down with the rebels. The negotiations that started in late March 2004 led to the signing of the N�djamena Humanitarian Ceasefire Agreement on 8 April 2004, stipulating among others a 45-day cessation of hostilities, the release of prisoners of war, and the facilitation of humanitarian access to Darfur. The ceasefire agreement also called for the deployment of a monitoring team to observe compliance with the ceasefire. The Government of Sudan also committed to neutralizing the armed militias during the negotiations.

In early March 2004, senior AU officials held consultations with Sudanese government officials in Khartoum to discuss mediation by the AU. On the basis of these consultations, the AU initiated pre-negotiations between the Government of Sudan on the one side and the SLM/A and JEM on the other side in May 2004. The director of the AU Department of Peace and Security, Ambassador Sam Ibok, had been mandated by the AU Chairperson and President of Mali, Alpha Konar�, to act as the AU chief mediator at these talks. The talks in May 2004 resulted in an agreement on the establishment of a Ceasefire Commission and the deployment of 130 observers in Darfur that were stationed at five locations in Darfur and one location in Chad. The observers came from AU countries, but also from the US, the EU, and the warring parties themselves. The documents were signed at Abuja on 28 May 2004.

The parties met between 11 and 21 December for the fourth round of the Abuja talks, which ended with a promise of the conflict parties to commit to the ceasefire agreement signed on 8 April and the Humanitarian and Security Protocols from November, as well as a promise to seek a peaceful solution to the conflict.

Libya brokered a meeting between President Aferworki and President al-Bashir on the margins of the Tripoli summit on Darfur in May 2005. This meeting was aimed at ending Eritrea�s military support to Darfurian rebel groups.

In May 2005, Salim Ahmed Salim, the former Secretary-General of the OAU, was appointed as the AU Special Envoy for the Darfur Talks and chief mediator. Salim Ahmed Salim mediated a round of negotiations in Abuja between 10 June and 5 July 2005. This round of negotiations led to the signing of the �Declaration of Principles� on 5 July 2005, after more than three weeks of negotiating. The declaration included provisions for refugees to return home and new security arrangements. It also committed the signatories to respect the different ethnic and religious groups in Sudan and work towards an equitable distribution of national wealth.

The seventh and final round of talks mediated by the AU started in Abuja on 29 November 2005. From the start of the seventh round of talks, the pressure on the conflict parties to sign a peace agreement steadily increased. The Western governments funding the peace process warned the parties that funding for the peace process could dry up in the absence of progress during the talks. The meetings of the seventh round of negotiations were held at different locations, but finished again in Abuja. The negotiations took place within three categories: power sharing, wealth sharing, and security arrangements. On the basis of the bilateral consultations and plenary sessions on these three categories which had been ongoing for more than five months, the AU mediation team submitted to the parties a draft peace agreement for the parties to sign in late April 2006. The rebel parties requested three more weeks to review the draft peace agreement, but this request was rejected. Instead, a number of high-profile diplomats arrived on 2 May 2006 in order to force a breakthrough in the negotiations. US Deputy Secretary of State Robert Zoellick and British Secretary of State for International Development Hilary Benn took over the mediation process in this final stage of the seventh round of the Abuja peace talks. Only two 48-hour extensions to the talks� deadline were subsequently allowed. The US mediation team promised the rebel leaders that if they signed the Darfur Peace Agreement (DPA), the US would guarantee its implementation. To back-up this promise, Zoellick carried personal letters with him from President George W. Bush assuring the rebel leaders of the US�s commitment to the DPA. In addition, the UN Security Council had imposed an arms embargo on all non-governmental entities operating in Darfur in July 2004. This sanctions regime was strengthened with the adoption of resolution 1591 in March 2005, which expanded the scope of arms embargo to also include all the parties to the N�djamena Ceasefire Agreement and any other belligerents, as well as imposed a travel ban and assets freeze on individuals designated by the UN Sanctions Committee. In spite of the pressure put on the conflict parties to sign the peace agreement, the JEM and the SLM/A refused to sign the agreement, leaving the SLM/A faction led by Minni Minnawi as the only rebel party that signed the DPA on 5 May 2006.

The Organization of the Islamic Conference (OIC) mediate a round of indirect negotiations between Chad and Sudan in late January 2006. This round of negotiations, which involved an OIC envoy shuttling between the parties, was aimed at ending the military support both countries were simultaneously providing to each other�s rebel groups. This round of negotiations aimed at ending military support was held in parallel to the seventh and final round of talks of the Abuja peace processes, which was held between 29 November 2005 and 5 May 2006.

On 8 February 2006, the African Union hosted a mini-summit in Tripoli, which was aimed at improving relations between Chad and Sudan and ending military support both countries were providing to each other�s rebel groups. At this summit, Chad and Sudan signed an agreement which stipulated that each country would refrain from using each other�s territory for hostile activity directed against the other and prohibited each country from accepting rebels from the other. However, the agreement between Chad and Sudan concluded in February 2006 did not hold. A Sudan-supported attack by the FUCD on Chad�s capital took place on 13 April 2006. This round of negotiations aimed at ending military support was held in parallel to the seventh and final round of talks of the Abuja peace processes, which was held between 29 November 2005 and 5 May 2006.

On 16 April 2006, Libyan foreign minister made a brief visit to Chad and a Libyan envoy met with the Sudanese President on 17 April. These shuttle talks were aimed at ending the military support Sudan and Chad were providing to each other�s rebel groups. This round of negotiations aimed at ending military support was held in parallel to the seventh and final round of talks of the Abuja peace processes, which was held between 29 November 2005 and 5 May 2006.

The leaders of Sudan and Eritrea met in Khartoum on 12 June 2006. This was the first meeting between the two leaders in more than five years. The leaders discussed the prospects for peace in Sudan, but also agreed to end support for the armed opposition in each other's countries.
During the seventh AU Summit in Gambia, Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi arranged a tripartite meeting with Sudan and Chad on 2 and 3 July 2006.

As a follow up to the meeting at the AU summit, Chadian foreign minister went to Khartoum for several days in mid-July 2006 and met with the Sudanese government to discuss political and security matters as well as the possibility of resuming diplomatic relations. After the Chadian foreign minister's visit to Sudan in mid-July, which was an outcome of the Libyan initiative during the AU Summit, the two countries continued their negotiations that led to a peace deal. On 26 July 2006, Chad and Sudan signed a peace deal agreeing to take steps to normalize their relations and end military support to each other�s rebel groups. The agreement called for a joint military commission to monitor the border and forbade the presence of rebel elements in both countries.

On 8 August 2006, many African leaders, including the President of Sudan, were present in Ndjamena to attend President Deby's inauguration ceremony after his re-election as president. Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi persuaded Sudanese and Chadian Presidents to hold an impromptu mini-summit after the inauguration ceremony. The mini-summit was also attended by the head of the AU, and the leaders of the Republic of Congo and Gabon. At the end of this impromptu mini-summit, Chad and Sudan agreed to end military support to each other�s rebel groups, as well as immediately restore diplomatic ties by reopening their common border and respective embassies.
third_party: Libya, AU, Republic of Congo, Gabon

description: Khartoum's new national unity government, particularly Foreign Minister Lam Akol, attempted to normalize relations with Eritrea to end Eritrea�s military support to Darfurian rebel groups. In October 2006, an Eritrean delegation visited Khartoum for talks with a Sudanese government delegation led by Akol.
In December 2006, a Sudanese delegation led by Vice-President Salva Kiir visited Asmara for talks on normalizing relations and ending Eritrea�s military support to Darfurian rebel groups.

On 10 April 2007, Libyan leader President Muammar al-Gaddafi dispatched Abdel Salem Triki, his personal envoy, as part of a mediation effort between Chad and Sudan aimed at ending the military support both countries were providing to each other�s rebel groups. Eritrea joined the effort as well, and the two sides met with both mediators that same day. On 12 April 2007, Libyan mediators reached an agreement with Chad and Sudan to allow Eritrean and Libyan military observers to monitor the border region. On 17 April 2007, the mediation effort by Libya and Eritrea led to the creation of a joint military and high security committee.

On 3 May 2007, Saudi Arabia hosted another meeting between President al-Bashir and Chadian President Deby in which the leaders of state agreed on ending military support to each other�s rebel groups, as well as on measures to prevent cross-border attacks by these rebel groups.

On 27 January 2008, Sudan and Chad participated in a summit of African countries that was convened to try and defuse tensions between Chad and Sudan and resolve the crisis in Darfur through persuading Chad to stop supporting Darfurian rebel groups. In addition to Gabon in the role of chief mediator, Libya, Egypt, Eritrea, Senegal, and Mauritania also attended this summit.
third_party: Gabon, Libya, Egypt, Eritrea, Senegal, Mauritania

description: On 6 March 2008, Senegal announced that it had been conducting shuttle diplomacy between Chad and Sudan. Senegal also announced that the two sides had consented in principle to sign an agreement at an upcoming meeting of the Organization of the Islamic Conference (OIC) to be held in Dakar. Despite Chad's and Sudan's pledge to sign the agreement, both sides continued to accuse each other of supporting the other's rebel groups and questioning each other's prospective commitment to the agreement, blaming each other for breaking all previous agreements. Nevertheless, Chad and Sudan signed the Dakar Agreement on 13 March 2008 at the OIC summit. Both sides agreed to stop supporting each other's armed opposition movements and to stop allowing their respective territories to be used as bases from which rebels could launch border incursions. The agreement failed to end the crisis however, as Chad accused Sudan of sending Chadian rebels to attack only hours before the agreement was signed. This confirmed the fears expressed by many analysts, as well as Chadian and Sudanese opposition movements, that the agreement would not be signed in good faith and would have little effect on the overall conflict. What is more, the JEM was able to attack Khartoum on 10 May 2008. In response, Sudan immediately cut diplomatic ties with Chad. Chadian rebels started an offensive in early June 2008. Chadian government troops had repelled this offensive by 18 June 2008.

Libya met with Chad and Sudan in late July 2008 and made proposals that were accepted by both sides, including ending military support to rebel groups, the restoration and normalization of diplomatic relations, and resumption of cooperation between the two countries.

On 2 May 2009, Chad and Sudan signed a new reconciliation agreement in Doha in Qatar. This agreement stipulated an end to the military support Sudan was providing to the UFR and Chad was providing to the SLM/A and JEM. However, the next day, on 3 May 2009, the UFR launched a new major raid on Chadian territory.

In August 2009, Sudanese and Chadian government representatives held exploratory talks in Tripoli under Libyan auspices. These talks were aimed at ending the military support Chad was providing to the SLM/A and JEM and ending the military support Sudan was providing to the UFR.

Chadian President D�by sent his foreign minister to Khartoum in December 2009 in order to start a process of rapprochement between the two countries. Sudanese President Al-Bashir responded by sending his adviser, Ghazi Salah al-Din al-Atabani, to N�Djamena to discuss the details of a security pact and in order to start a process of rapprochement between the two countries. The efforts of the Chadian foreign minister and the Sudanese presidential adviser paved the way for the conclusion of an agreement on 25 December 2009. The agreement committed Sudan and Chad to previous protocols that addressed controlling the border between the two countries and end military support to each other�s rebel groups.

In February 2007, a joint UN/AU mediation effort was initiated, headed by Jan Eliasson and Salim Ahmed Salim, who respectively represented the UN and the AU. However, the JEM refused to attend any negotiations. In the beginning of 2008, the joint UN/AU mediation effort continued. Yet, no substantial progress was made. As a result, Jan Eliasson and Salim Ahmed Salim resigned in July 2008, after which Djibril Bassol�, the former foreign minister of Burkina Faso, assumed the role of chief mediator. In addition to the joint UN/AU initiative, Qatar conducted some effort to initiate negotiations. However, no negotiations took place in 2008. JEM resisted negotiations with other rebel groups present and said that they should be the only one representing the Darfur side in the negotiations. The reason they stated for this was that the government could play the rebels against each other if they were represented by several groups. Bassol� went along with this demand by JEM, because he also believed that if the JEM would sign a deal, then the other rebel parties would follow. In January 2009, after it had been agreed that JEM would be the sole representative of the Darfurian rebels, Djibril Bassol� succeeded in initiating negotiations between the Government of Sudan and the JEM. The negotiations took place from January to February in Doha, the capital of Qatar. The negotiations led to the signing of the declaration of good will and confidence-building agreement (CBA) on 17 February 2009. This agreement was supposed to pave the way for more comprehensive negotiations. However, one day after the agreement was signed, JEM positions were bombed by government forces.
agreement_name: Declaration of good will and confidence-building agreement

description: A round of negotiations between the Sudanese government and JEM took place in November 2009. These talks took place in Chad and were mediated by Chadian President Idriss D�by, without the involvement of UN/AU mediator Djibril Bassol�. President D�by initiated these peace negotiations between the JEM and the government of Sudan as part of a rapprochement between Sudan and Chad. Accordingly, D�by presented Sudanese government negotiators with the draft of framework agreement that stipulated that in a final peace agreement the JEM should have representation at all governmental levels.
On 15 January 2010, another agreement was signed by Chad and Sudan, this time mediated by Libyan President Muammar Gaddafi.

Qatar began another mediation effort in early 2010, meeting with Sudan in late February and then Chad in early March. This mediation effort was led by Qatarese Emir Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani. The agreement between Chad and Sudan concluded on 25 December 2009 was confirmed on 9 February 2010, when Chadian President Idriss Deby visited Sudan and met with Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir. During the visit, Chad and Sudan signed a formal agreement in which they agreed that neither would support rebel organizations targeting the other. The agreement held: Chad expelled the JEM in February 2010, while Sudan expelled all Chadian rebels in July 2010.

Another round of negotiations between the Sudanese government and the JEM mediated by Chad led to the conclusion of a framework agreement between the Sudanese government and the JEM on 20 February 2010. D�by had invited Bassol� to N�Djamena to witness the signing of the framework agreement between the Sudanese government and the JEM on 20 February 2010. The agreement called for a ceasefire, release of hundreds of JEM-fighters that were imprisoned, and set out terms for future negotiations. The agreement also stipulates that JEM will become a political party after the signing of a final agreement. Moreover, it is stipulated that JEM and the Government of Sudan shall share power at all levels and that the administration of Darfur will be part of a final agreement.

Three days later, the Sudanese government and the JEM signed an almost identical agreement in Doha, allowing �the Qataris to claim the glory for the deal hatched entirely in N�Djamena� as Alex de Waal puts it. As the host country, Qatar provided material incentives for the conflict parties to make peace through promising to allocate substantial funds for future development projects in Darfur. During the negotiations leading up to the Doha Agreement, Qatar had promised an amount of two billion US Dollars for rebuilding Darfur if the Government of Sudan and the various rebel movements participating in the Doha negotiations were to sign a peace agreement. The agreement did not hold. JEM left the ongoing negotiations on 3 May 2010, making it clear that it suspended its participation in the Doha process because of the Sudanese army of breaching the cessation of hostilities agreement. Bassol� resigned in April 2011, after which he was succeeded by the former Nigerian Minister for External Affairs Ibrahim Gambari. Since JEM had suspended its participation in the Doha process, Gambari�s mediation effort shifted to talks between the Sudanese government and the newly formed rebel coalition known as the Liberation and Justice Movement (LJM).
agreement_name: Doha Document for Peace in Darfur

description: In November 2011, the JEM � together with the Sudan People�s Liberation Movement-North (SPLM/A-North), the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A), and the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army led by Minni Minnawi (SLM/A-MM) � formed a new rebel coalition: the Sudanese Revolutionary Army (SRF). The rebel groups declared to collectively fight to topple the Sudanese Government. Accordingly, any peace efforts only involving the JEM from this point onwards are listed here, while peace efforts involving the SRF are listed under that dyad. In 2012, the African Union (AU) Peace and Security Council mandated the African Union�s High Level Implementation Panel (AUHIP) led by former South African President Thabo Mbeki to mediate between the Sudanese government and the Sudanese armed opposition. In 2012, the AUHIP mainly mediated peace talks between the Sudanese government and the SRF, but the AUHIP�s mediation efforts in 2013 mainly focused on negotiations between the Government of Sudan and JEM. A round of negotiations mediated by the AUHIP led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 10 February 2013.
Another round of AU-mediated negotiations in March 2013 led to Protocol on the Participation of JEM-Sudan at the different levels of Government and on the Integration of its Forces on 29 March 2013.
agreement_name: Protocol on the Participation of JEM-Sudan at the different levels of Government and on the Integration of its Forces

description: Another round of AU-mediated negotiations in April 2013 led to the Agreement between the Government of Sudan and the Justice and Equality Movement-Sudan on the Basis of the Doha Document for Peace in Darfur (DDPD) on 6 April 2013. This last agreement was based on the DDPD and all its annexes, as well as stipulated additional power-sharing and wealth-sharing provisions. The agreement also stipulated compensation and return of IDPs and refugees and included a permanent ceasefire
agreement_name: Agreement between the Government of Sudan and the Justice and Equality Movement-Sudan on the Basis of the Doha Document for Peace in Darfur (DDPD)

description: A round of negotiations between the Sudanese government and JEM in February 2018, mediated by Qatar, led to the signing of a ceasefire on 11 February 2018. The ceasefire was signed by Mohamed Bashir Ahmed of the JEM-Military Command in Qatar.

From March 2003 onwards, when attacks on government targets became more frequent, the Governor of North Darfur, Ibrahim Suleiman, formed and ad hoc Darfur Security Committee to negotiate an end to the violence in Darfur. However, this peace effort was terminated as soon as government officials had successfully negotiated the return of commander of the Sudanese air force Ibrahim Bushra, who had been captured during the attack on El Fasher airbase.

In late August 2003, Chad acted as mediator during talks between the Sudanese Government and the SLM/A in Ab�ch�, under the auspices of President Idriss Deby. After five days of negotiations, the conflict parties signed a ceasefire agreement on 3 September. Directly after the talks, Sudan released 54 rebel prisoners as part of the deal. However, only a few days later, the SLM/A accused the Government of Sudan of breaking the ceasefire, which the latter denied. A month later, the SLM/A released 42 prisoners.

The Ab�ch� Ceasefire Agreement also called for comprehensive peace talks. Consequently, official negotiations � which came to be known as the Ab�ch� Ceasefire renewal talks � started on 29 October 2003, one day prior to the ceasefire which had been negotiated on 15 September would end. During these talks, the Chadian Government proposed a draft peace agreement. The talks ended without any results, mainly because the SLM/A demanded the presence of international monitors in Darfur, while the Government of Sudan rejected this.

In late March 2004, peace talks between the Government of Sudan and the two rebel groups SLM/A and JEM began in N�djamena in Chad. Chad mediated these negotiations. However, both the SLM/A and JEM were dissatisfied with the mediation by Chad, whom they considered too biased towards the Government of Sudan. The Government of Sudan initially refused to hold face-to-face talks. Yet, when the SLM/A threatened to walk out of the negotiations, the Government of Sudan gave in and sat down with the rebels. The negotiations that started in late March 2004 led to the signing of the N�djamena Humanitarian Ceasefire Agreement on 8 April 2004, stipulating among others a 45-day cessation of hostilities, the release of prisoners of war, and the facilitation of humanitarian access to Darfur. The ceasefire agreement also called for the deployment of a monitoring team to observe compliance with the ceasefire. The Government of Sudan also committed to neutralizing the armed militias during the negotiations.

In early March 2004, senior AU officials held consultations with Sudanese government officials in Khartoum to discuss mediation by the AU. On the basis of these consultations, the AU initiated pre-negotiations between the Government of Sudan on the one side and the SLM/A and JEM on the other side in May 2004. The director of the AU Department of Peace and Security, Ambassador Sam Ibok, had been mandated by the AU Chairperson and President of Mali, Alpha Konar�, to act as the AU chief mediator at these talks. The talks in May 2004 resulted in an agreement on the establishment of a Ceasefire Commission and the deployment of 130 observers in Darfur that were stationed at five locations in Darfur and one location in Chad. The observers came from AU countries, but also from the US, the EU, and the warring parties themselves. The documents were signed at Abuja on 28 May 2004.

The parties met between 11 and 21 December for the fourth round of the Abuja talks, which ended with a promise of the conflict parties to commit to the ceasefire agreement signed on 8 April and the Humanitarian and Security Protocols from November, as well as a promise to seek a peaceful solution to the conflict.

Libya brokered a meeting between President Aferworki and President al-Bashir on the margins of the Tripoli summit on Darfur in May 2005. This meeting was aimed at ending Eritrea�s military support to Darfurian rebel groups.

In May 2005, Salim Ahmed Salim, the former Secretary-General of the OAU, was appointed as the AU Special Envoy for the Darfur Talks and chief mediator. Salim Ahmed Salim mediated a round of negotiations in Abuja between 10 June and 5 July 2005. This round of negotiations led to the signing of the �Declaration of Principles� on 5 July 2005, after more than three weeks of negotiating. The declaration included provisions for refugees to return home and new security arrangements. It also committed the signatories to respect the different ethnic and religious groups in Sudan and work towards an equitable distribution of national wealth.

The seventh and final round of talks mediated by the AU started in Abuja on 29 November 2005. From the start of the seventh round of talks, the pressure on the conflict parties to sign a peace agreement steadily increased. The Western governments funding the peace process warned the parties that funding for the peace process could dry up in the absence of progress during the talks. The meetings of the seventh round of negotiations were held at different locations, but finished again in Abuja. The negotiations took place within three categories: power sharing, wealth sharing, and security arrangements. On the basis of the bilateral consultations and plenary sessions on these three categories which had been ongoing for more than five months, the AU mediation team submitted to the parties a draft peace agreement for the parties to sign in late April 2006. The rebel parties requested three more weeks to review the draft peace agreement, but this request was rejected. Instead, a number of high-profile diplomats arrived on 2 May 2006 in order to force a breakthrough in the negotiations. US Deputy Secretary of State Robert Zoellick and British Secretary of State for International Development Hilary Benn took over the mediation process in this final stage of the seventh round of the Abuja peace talks. Only two 48-hour extensions to the talks� deadline were subsequently allowed. The US mediation team promised the rebel leaders that if they signed the Darfur Peace Agreement (DPA), the US would guarantee its implementation. To back-up this promise, Zoellick carried personal letters with him from President George W. Bush assuring the rebel leaders of the US�s commitment to the DPA. In addition, the UN Security Council had imposed an arms embargo on all non-governmental entities operating in Darfur in July 2004. This sanctions regime was strengthened with the adoption of resolution 1591 in March 2005, which expanded the scope of arms embargo to also include all the parties to the N�djamena Ceasefire Agreement and any other belligerents, as well as imposed a travel ban and assets freeze on individuals designated by the UN Sanctions Committee. In spite of the pressure put on the conflict parties to sign the peace agreement, the JEM and the SLM/A refused to sign the agreement, leaving the SLM/A faction led by Minni Minnawi as the only rebel party that signed the DPA on 5 May 2006.

The Organization of the Islamic Conference (OIC) mediate a round of indirect negotiations between Chad and Sudan in late January 2006. This round of negotiations, which involved an OIC envoy shuttling between the parties, was aimed at ending the military support both countries were simultaneously providing to each other�s rebel groups. This round of negotiations aimed at ending military support was held in parallel to the seventh and final round of talks of the Abuja peace processes, which was held between 29 November 2005 and 5 May 2006.

On 8 February 2006, the African Union hosted a mini-summit in Tripoli, which was aimed at improving relations between Chad and Sudan and ending military support both countries were providing to each other�s rebel groups. At this summit, Chad and Sudan signed an agreement which stipulated that each country would refrain from using each other�s territory for hostile activity directed against the other and prohibited each country from accepting rebels from the other. However, the agreement between Chad and Sudan concluded in February 2006 did not hold. A Sudan-supported attack by the FUCD on Chad�s capital took place on 13 April 2006. This round of negotiations aimed at ending military support was held in parallel to the seventh and final round of talks of the Abuja peace processes, which was held between 29 November 2005 and 5 May 2006.

On 16 April 2006, Libyan foreign minister made a brief visit to Chad and a Libyan envoy met with the Sudanese President on 17 April. These shuttle talks were aimed at ending the military support Sudan and Chad were providing to each other�s rebel groups. This round of negotiations aimed at ending military support was held in parallel to the seventh and final round of talks of the Abuja peace processes, which was held between 29 November 2005 and 5 May 2006.

From the signing of the DPA on 5 May 2006 onwards, AU mediators Alex de Waal and Sam Ibok met with SLM/A leader Abdul Wahid several times a day to get clarity on his objections to the DPA. They encouraged him to write to Salim Ahmed Salim a letter in which he could specify on what was needed in order for him to sign the DPA. In his letter send to Salim on 10 May, Abdul Wahid proposed to conclude a �supplementary agreement� to the DPA, demanding greater representation at the legislature and executive bodies of Darfur, as well as a larger compensation fund for Darfur. However, Salim knew that the chief government negotiator, Majzoub El Khalifa, would reject this option, instead insisting that Abdul Wahid had to sign the DPA first, after which some of the remaining issues could be negotiated. Consequently, on 13 May 2006, Salim replied to Wahid that the AU could not re-open negotiations on the DPA, but was willing to support the conflict parties in implementing the agreement. Sam Ibok subsequently tried to persuade Wahid that the AU�s insistence on implementation rather than concluding a supplementary agreement would still allow Wahid to get what he wanted. Ibok�s effort to persuade Wahid did not work. Wahid kept insisting on a supplementary agreement. The AU Peace and Security Council decided on 16 May 2006 that the non-signatory groups would have another two weeks to sign the DPA. A final mediation attempt was launched by the EU during the last week of May 2006, but Abdul Wahid in the end did not show up for negotiations. Instead, he flew to Asmara, Eritrea, at the invitation of JEM leader Khalil Ibrahim to discuss the founding of a rebel alliance.

The leaders of Sudan and Eritrea met in Khartoum on 12 June 2006. This was the first meeting between the two leaders in more than five years. The leaders discussed the prospects for peace in Sudan, but also agreed to end support for the armed opposition in each other's countries. While there were some talks on ending military support to the armed opposition groups in Darfur, the SLM/A did not engage in peace talks with the government between 2007 and 2011 in spite of some joint UN/AU mediation effort. In February 2007, a joint UN/AU mediation effort was initiated, headed by Jan Eliasson and Salim Ahmed Salim, who respectively represented the UN and the AU. The SLM/A faction led by Minni Minnawi lost power and the movement was now led by Abdul Wahid. The SLM/A refused to attend the UN/AU organised negotiations in Sirtre, Libya. Hence, they were not involved in any negotiations with the Government of Sudan in 2007, although the SLM/A leadership did consult with the UN/AU negotiation team. In the beginning of 2008, the joint UN/AU mediation effort continued. Yet, no substantial progress was made. As a result, Jan Eliasson and Salim Ahmed Salim resigned in July 2008, after which Djibril Bassol� assumed the role of chief mediator, the former foreign minister of Burkina Faso. In addition to the joint UN/AU initiative, Qatar conducted some effort to initiate negotiations. However, no real negotiations took place. Abdul Wahid, the leader of SLM/A, demanded that security had to be provided for the civilians in Darfur before he would enter negotiations. Djibril Bassol� continued his efforts as the chief mediator of the joint UN/AU mediation effort in 2009. SLM/A leader Abdul Wahid refused to leave his exile in Paris. Consequently, no negotiations were held between the SPLM/A and the Government of Sudan in 2009. In 2010, Djibril Bassol� continued his efforts as the chief mediator of the joint UN/AU mediation effort. In contrast to several of the other rebel groups based in Darfur, the SLM/A and its leader Abdul Wahid refused to negotiate with the Government of Sudan until the security situation in Darfur would improve. In November 2011, the SLM/A � together with the Sudan People�s Liberation Movement-North (SPLM/A-North), the Justice and Equality Movement (JEM), and the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army led by Minni Minnawi (SLM/A-MM) � formed a new rebel coalition: the Sudanese Revolutionary Army (SRF). The rebel groups declared to collectively fight to topple the Sudanese Government. All peace efforts involving the SLM/A from this point onwards took place under the banner of the SRF and are therefore listed under that dyad.
During the seventh AU Summit in Gambia, Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi arranged a tripartite meeting with Sudan and Chad on 2 and 3 July 2006.

As a follow up to the meeting at the AU summit, Chadian foreign minister went to Khartoum for several days in mid-July 2006 and met with the Sudanese government to discuss political and security matters as well as the possibility of resuming diplomatic relations. After the Chadian foreign minister's visit to Sudan in mid-July, which was an outcome of the Libyan initiative during the AU Summit, the two countries continued their negotiations that led to a peace deal. On 26 July 2006, Chad and Sudan signed a peace deal agreeing to take steps to normalize their relations and end military support to each other�s rebel groups. The agreement called for a joint military commission to monitor the border and forbade the presence of rebel elements in both countries.

On 8 August 2006, many African leaders, including the President of Sudan, were present in Ndjamena to attend President Deby's inauguration ceremony after his re-election as president. Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi persuaded Sudanese and Chadian Presidents to hold an impromptu mini-summit after the inauguration ceremony. The mini-summit was also attended by the head of the AU, and the leaders of the Republic of Congo and Gabon. At the end of this impromptu mini-summit, Chad and Sudan agreed to end military support to each other�s rebel groups, as well as immediately restore diplomatic ties by reopening their common border and respective embassies.
third_party: Libya, AU, Republic of Congo, Gabon

description: Khartoum's new national unity government, particularly Foreign Minister Lam Akol, attempted to normalize relations with Eritrea to end Eritrea�s military support to Darfurian rebel groups. In October 2006, an Eritrean delegation visited Khartoum for talks with a Sudanese government delegation led by Akol.
In December 2006, a Sudanese delegation led by Vice-President Salva Kiir visited Asmara for talks on normalizing relations and ending Eritrea�s military support to Darfurian rebel groups.

On 10 April 2007, Libyan leader President Muammar al-Gaddafi dispatched Abdel Salem Triki, his personal envoy, as part of a mediation effort between Chad and Sudan aimed at ending the military support both countries were providing to each other�s rebel groups. Eritrea joined the effort as well, and the two sides met with both mediators that same day. On 12 April 2007, Libyan mediators reached an agreement with Chad and Sudan to allow Eritrean and Libyan military observers to monitor the border region. On 17 April 2007, the mediation effort by Libya and Eritrea led to the creation of a joint military and high security committee.

On 3 May 2007, Saudi Arabia hosted another meeting between President al-Bashir and Chadian President Deby in which the leaders of state agreed on ending military support to each other�s rebel groups, as well as on measures to prevent cross-border attacks by these rebel groups.

On 27 January 2008, Sudan and Chad participated in a summit of African countries that was convened to try and defuse tensions between Chad and Sudan and resolve the crisis in Darfur through persuading Chad to stop supporting Darfurian rebel groups. In addition to Gabon in the role of chief mediator, Libya, Egypt, Eritrea, Senegal, and Mauritania also attended this summit.
third_party: Gabon, Libya, Egypt, Eritrea, Senegal, Mauritania

description: On 6 March 2008, Senegal announced that it had been conducting shuttle diplomacy between Chad and Sudan. Senegal also announced that the two sides had consented in principle to sign an agreement at an upcoming meeting of the Organization of the Islamic Conference (OIC) to be held in Dakar. Despite Chad's and Sudan's pledge to sign the agreement, both sides continued to accuse each other of supporting the other's rebel groups and questioning each other's prospective commitment to the agreement, blaming each other for breaking all previous agreements. Nevertheless, Chad and Sudan signed the Dakar Agreement on 13 March 2008 at the OIC summit. Both sides agreed to stop supporting each other's armed opposition movements and to stop allowing their respective territories to be used as bases from which rebels could launch border incursions. The agreement failed to end the crisis however, as Chad accused Sudan of sending Chadian rebels to attack only hours before the agreement was signed. This confirmed the fears expressed by many analysts, as well as Chadian and Sudanese opposition movements, that the agreement would not be signed in good faith and would have little effect on the overall conflict. What is more, the JEM was able to attack Khartoum on 10 May 2008. In response, Sudan immediately cut diplomatic ties with Chad. Chadian rebels started an offensive in early June 2008. Chadian government troops had repelled this offensive by 18 June 2008.

Libya met with Chad and Sudan in late July 2008 and made proposals that were accepted by both sides, including ending military support to rebel groups, the restoration and normalization of diplomatic relations, and resumption of cooperation between the two countries.

On 2 May 2009, Chad and Sudan signed a new reconciliation agreement in Doha in Qatar. This agreement stipulated an end to the military support Sudan was providing to the UFR and Chad was providing to the SLM/A and JEM. However, the next day, on 3 May 2009, the UFR launched a new major raid on Chadian territory.

In August 2009, Sudanese and Chadian government representatives held exploratory talks in Tripoli under Libyan auspices. These talks were aimed at ending the military support Chad was providing to the SLM/A and JEM and ending the military support Sudan was providing to the UFR.

Chadian President D�by sent his foreign minister to Khartoum in December 2009 in order to start a process of rapprochement between the two countries. Sudanese President Al-Bashir responded by sending his adviser, Ghazi Salah al-Din al-Atabani, to N�Djamena to discuss the details of a security pact and in order to start a process of rapprochement between the two countries. The efforts of the Chadian foreign minister and the Sudanese presidential adviser paved the way for the conclusion of an agreement on 25 December 2009. The agreement committed Sudan and Chad to previous protocols that addressed controlling the border between the two countries and end military support to each other�s rebel groups.
On 15 January 2010, another agreement was signed by Chad and Sudan, this time mediated by Libyan President Muammar Gaddafi.

Qatar began another mediation effort in early 2010, meeting with Sudan in late February and then Chad in early March. This mediation effort was led by Qatarese Emir Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani. The agreement between Chad and Sudan concluded on 25 December 2009 was confirmed on 9 February 2010, when Chadian President Idriss Deby visited Sudan and met with Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir. During the visit, Chad and Sudan signed a formal agreement in which they agreed that neither would support rebel organizations targeting the other. In February 2007, a joint UN/AU mediation effort was initiated, headed by Jan Eliasson and Salim Ahmed Salim, who respectively represented the UN and the AU. The SLM/A faction led by Minni Minnawi lost power and the movement was now led by Abdul Wahid. The SLM/A refused to attend the UN/AU organised negotiations in Sirtre, Libya. Hence, they were not involved in any negotiations with the Government of Sudan in 2007, although the SLM/A leadership did consult with the UN/AU negotiation team. In the beginning of 2008, the joint UN/AU mediation effort continued. Yet, no substantial progress was made. As a result, Jan Eliasson and Salim Ahmed Salim resigned in July 2008, after which Djibril Bassol� assumed the role of chief mediator, the former foreign minister of Burkina Faso. In addition to the joint UN/AU initiative, Qatar conducted some effort to initiate negotiations. However, no real negotiations took place. Abdul Wahid, the leader of SLM/A, demanded that security had to be provided for the civilians in Darfur before he would enter negotiations. Djibril Bassol� continued his efforts as the chief mediator of the joint UN/AU mediation effort in 2009. SLM/A leader Abdul Wahid refused to leave his exile in Paris. Consequently, no negotiations were held between the SPLM/A and the Government of Sudan in 2009. In 2010, Djibril Bassol� continued his efforts as the chief mediator of the joint UN/AU mediation effort.
