In contrast to several of the other rebel groups based in Darfur, the SLM/A and its leader Abdul Wahid refused to negotiate with the Government of Sudan until the security situation in Darfur would improve. In November 2011, the SLM/A � together with the Sudan People�s Liberation Movement-North (SPLM/A-North), the Justice and Equality Movement (JEM), and the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army led by Minni Minnawi (SLM/A-MM) � formed a new rebel coalition: the Sudanese Revolutionary Army (SRF). The rebel groups declared to collectively fight to topple the Sudanese Government. All peace efforts involving the SLM/A from this point onwards took place under the banner of the SRF and are therefore listed under that dyad.

The SLM/A-MM was part of the seventh and final round of the Darfur peace talks mediated by the AU. This round started in Abuja on 29 November 2005. The negotiations took place within three categories: power sharing, wealth sharing, and security arrangements. On the basis of the bilateral consultations and plenary sessions on these three categories, which had been ongoing for more than five months, the AU mediation team submitted to the parties a draft peace agreement for the parties to sign in late April 2006. The rebel parties requested three more weeks to review the draft peace agreement, but this request was rejected. Instead, a number of high-profile diplomats arrived on 2 May 2006 in order to force a breakthrough in the negotiations. US Deputy Secretary of State Robert Zoellick and British Secretary of State for International Development Hilary Benn took over the mediation process in this final stage of the seventh round of the Abuja peace talks. Only two 48-hour extensions to the talks� deadline were subsequently allowed. The US mediation team promised the rebel leaders that if they signed the Darfur Peace Agreement (DPA), the US would guarantee its implementation. To back-up this promise, Zoellick carried personal letters with him from President George W. Bush assuring the rebel leaders of the US�s commitment to the DPA. In addition, the UN Security Council had imposed an arms embargo on all non-governmental entities operating in Darfur in July 2004. This sanctions regime was strengthened with the adoption of resolution 1591 in March 2005, which expanded the scope of arms embargo to also include all the parties to the N�djamena Ceasefire Agreement and any other belligerents, as well as imposed a travel ban and assets freeze on individuals designated by the UN Sanctions Committee. Zoellick also threatened Minni Minawi with possible UN sanctions or an International Criminal Court indictment if he did not sign the agreement. In addition, Zoellick threatened that an attack on Minawi�s forces in South Darfur by Sudanese troops would be executed if he failed to sign the DPA. Despite these threats, Minawi still had reservations when the final stretch of the Abuja talks started on 4 May, which were hosted by Nigerian President Olusegun Obasanjo at his state house in Abuja. During a break of the plenary peace talks on 4 May, Zoellick allegedly told Minawi privately, �Have no doubt where I stand. I am a good friend and I am a fearsome enemy.� Minawi signed the DPA the next day, on 5 May 2006. However, the JEM and the SLM/A led by Abdul Wahid refused to sign the agreement, leaving the SLM/A led by Minni Minnawi as the only rebel party that signed the peace agreement. The agreement included a comprehensive ceasefire agreement, reaffirming the N�Dajema Agreement of April 2004. It aimed to integrate the forces of SLM/A and JEM into Sudan's security institutions, with 4000 soldiers joining the armed forces, 1000 joining the police, and 3000 receiving professional and educational training for civilian reintegration. The agreement covered both political representation and the future status of Darfur. In the political aspect, it focused on power-sharing at the national and state levels, establishing the Transitional Darfur Regional Authority (TDRA), and ensuring fair representation of Darfurians in Sudanese affairs. During the interim period until elections, SLM/A and JEM would be represented at the national level by a Senior Assistant to the President, chosen from a list of nominees provided by these two movements.

In November 2011, the SLM/A-MM � together with the Sudan People�s Liberation Movement-North (SPLM/A-North), the Justice and Equality Movement (JEM), and the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A) � formed a new rebel coalition: the Sudanese Revolutionary Army (SRF). The rebel groups declared to collectively fight to topple the Sudanese Government. Accordingly, any peace efforts only involving the SLM/A-MM from this point onwards are listed here, while peace efforts involving the SRF are listed under that dyad. The JEM and the SLM/A-MM on the one side and the government on the other side held informal discussions, mediated by the AU, in the Ethiopian town of Debre Zeit on 23 January 2016. These talks did not take place under the SRF banner.
Another round of negotiations starting in early January 2011 led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 5 January 2011. The Episcopal Church of Sudan moderated these talks.

In early June 2011, the AU High-Level Implementation Panel on Sudan (AUHIP) led by former South African president Thabo Mbeki initiated mediated negotiations to end the fighting. SPLM/A-North chairman Malik Agar negotiated for the SPLM/A-North and Ali Nafi for the Sudanese government. This mediation effort led to the signing of a ceasefire on 16 June 2011.

Although the conflict parties had signed the ceasefire agreement and were engaged in negotiations, fighting continued throughout June 2011. Negotiations in Addis Ababa, mediated by Mbeki, led to the conclusion of an agreement for comprehensive political and security arrangements in the border states of Blue Nile and South Kordofan on 28 June 2011, referred to as the Addis Ababa Agreement. This agreement was signed by Presidential Bashir�s aide Nafie Ali Nafie and SPLM/A-North leader Malik Agar. The peace agreement stipulated that a joint political committee would be formed, tasked to resolve the issue of governance in the contested states. The agreement also includes a ceasefire and provisions with regard to disarmament. In spite of the conclusion of this agreement, fighting continued. On 7 July 2011, the government backed out of the agreement with SPLM/A-North.

By the end of August 2011, Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi mediated talks between President Bashir and Agar. However, the talks did not produce any tangible results. The government announced a unilateral ceasefire for South Kordofan on 23 August 2011, but fighting continued. In November 2011, the SPLM/A-North � together with the Justice and Equality Movement (JEM), the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A), and the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army led by Minni Minnawi (SLM/A-MM) � formed a new rebel coalition: the Sudanese Revolutionary Army (SRF). The rebel groups declared to collectively fight to topple the Sudanese Government. Accordingly, any peace efforts only involving the SPLM/A-North from this point onwards are listed here, while peace efforts involving the SRF are listed under that dyad.

In 2012, the African Union (AU) Peace and Security Council mandated the African Union�s High Level Implementation Panel (AUHIP) led by former South African President Thabo Mbeki to mediate between the Sudanese government and the Sudanese armed opposition. A first round of negotiations mediated by the AUHIP took solely place between the SPLM/A-North and the Government of the Sudan in Addis Ababa on 26 July 2012. These negotiations focused on political and security issues underlying the continuing conflict in Blue Nile and Southern Kordofan States. The talks were conducted indirectly via the AUHIP, with both sides setting preconditions for engaging in direct talks. The Government of the Sudan insisted that the SPLM/A-North would disengage from South Sudan, as well made it clear that it opposed the return to the Agreement of 28 June 2011. On 16 September 2012, the AUHIP submitted a draft proposal for a political solution based on the Agreement of 28 June 2011, reflecting views of the conflict parties and the �changed circumstances and current realities on the ground.� Neither party accepted this agreement.

At the start of a round of negotiations on 25 February 2014, the Sudanese government accepted the draft framework agreement put forward by AUHIP to cease hostilities and deliver humanitarian aid to civilians in Sudan�s �Two Areas� of Blue Nile and South Kordofan, but negotiations between the SPLM/A-N and the government were suspended on 2 March 2014 because the conflict parties disagreed on how the resolve the conflict.

In December 2015, the Sudanese government and SPLM/A-North expressed to the AUHIP their willingness to sign a comprehensive agreement. An informal round of peace talks was subsequently held in Addis Ababa from 16 to 18 December 2015. However, this round of talks did not lead to an agreement, as the parties disagreed about whether the SPLM/A-North should be allowed to keep its troops. The conflict parties and the mediation team agreed to resume discussions in January 2016. A government attack on the SPLM/A-North in Aroum on 23 January 2016 led SPLM/A-North officials to publicly question the government�s commitment to establishing peace. In late 2016, the AUHIP called upon the SPLM/A-North to review their positions on the talks on the Two Areas. The SPLM/A-N insisted on a provision allowing humanitarian access through Asosa in Ethiopia, but the Sudanese government rejected such a provision. In March 2017, the SPLM/A-North split into two factions, resulting in several clashes. While there were many calls to engage in negotiations throughout 2017 and 2018, the conflict parties did not engage in peace talks. The split was a result of long-simmering ethnic and political�military tensions within the SPLM/A-North in Blue Nile. While the Uduk, Berta, and Burun had made up the majority of the SPLM/A�s 10th Division during war between the SPLM/A and the Sudanese government between 1983 and 2005, members of the Ingessana tribe assumed increasingly more power within the rebel group from 2012 onwards. This led to widespread dissatisfaction among the non-Ingessana tribes. Tensions were temporarily put on hold due to intense fighting between the SPLM/A-North and government forces throughout 2015-2016, but following a unilateral ceasefire issued by the Sudanese government on 18 June 2016 tensions escalated. In March 2017, SPLM/A-North deputy chairman Abdelaziz al-Hilu publicly released a resignation letter. Abdelaziz al-Hilu accused Agar of not fully representing the entire SPLM/A-North movement in the peace process led by the AU, particularly with regard to the issue of self-determination of the Nuba Mountains. Al-Hilu�s letter essentially forced the members of the SPLM/A-North to choose between himself and chairman Malik Agar of the Ingessana tribe. The Nuba Mountains Liberation Council (NMLC) subsequently passed resolutions that removed Arman as the SPLM/A-North�s lead negotiator with the AUHIP, as well as put the NMLC in power of both South Kordofan and Blue Nile. Moreover, many senior non-Ingessana leaders began to publicly voice support for al-Hilu and the NMLC. In April 2017, almost all of the non-Ingessana Blue Nile Liberation Council (BNLC) members declared their support for the NMLC decision to dismiss Arman as the SPLM/A-North AUHIP lead negotiator. Accordingly, although the deputy chairman Abdelaziz al-Hilu broke away from the rebel group led by chairman Malik Agar, the UCDP codes the SPLM/A-North led by Malik Agar (SPLM/A-N-MA) as the splinter faction because the dismissal of Agar was endorsed by the NMLC and most of the BNLC.

Following a massive popular uprising, President Omar al-Bashir was ousted from power in April 2019. The transitional government that was put in place continued to negotiate with the SPLM/A-North. Both the SRF and the SPLM/A-North participated in negotiations in Juba in September 2019, which led to the signing of the Juba Declaration for Confidence Building Procedures and the Preparation for Negotiation on 11 September 2019.
agreement_name: Juba Declaration for Confidence Building Procedures and the Preparation for Negotiation

description: A third round of negotiations in Juba took place between 10 December and early January 2020. This round of negotiations consisted of five separate tracks covering Darfur, the Two Areas of Blue Nile and Southern Kordofan, and central, east and north Sudan. While the SPLM/A-North led by Malik Agar signed a ceasefire with the Sudanese government during these peace talks, the SPLM/A-North refused to sign an agreement.

Negotiations between the Sudanese government and the SPLM/A-N led by al-Hilu on the Two Areas resumed on 21 January 2020 after a two week suspension. The talks would last until 14 February 2020. The talks saw advancement on six key points of a framework agreement However, there was still contention over al-Hilu's demands for establishing a secular state in South Kordofan and Nuba Mountains, as well as for self-determination in the Blue Nile region.

From 2 to 5 September 2020, Abdallah Hamok and Abdel Aziz of the SPLM/A-N held a meeting in Addis Ababa to discuss how they can include the separation between religion and politics in the peace process, in a way to satisfy the positions of the two sides. The negotiations led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 3 September 2020. The agreement stated that �Sudan is a multi-racial, multi-ethnic, multi-religious and multi-cultural society. Full recognition and accommodation of these diversities must be affirmed. [...] The state shall not establish an official religion. No citizen shall be discriminated against based on their religion.�

On 28 March 2021, Sudan�s government and SPLM-N concluded an agreement in Juba. The �declaration of principles� outlines priorities including the unification of armed forces and the establishment of a democratic, secular state with freedom of religion.

The declaration of principles signed between Sudan and the SPLM-North in March paved the way for peace talks in Juba on 15 June 2021. The talks focused on reaching a framework peace deal to address Sudan's internal conflicts. Unlike the SPLM/A-North-MA that was part of the SRF, the SPLM/A-North did not sign an agreement.

In 2012, the African Union (AU) Peace and Security Council mandated the African Union�s High Level Implementation Panel (AUHIP) led by former South African President Thabo Mbeki to mediate between the Government of Sudan and the SRF. Indirect negotiations between the SRF and the Government of Sudan were mediated by the AUHIP. These negotiations led to the signing of an agreement to allow humanitarian assistance in rebel-controlled areas of South Kordofan and Blue Nile on 4 August 2012. Yet, the agreement did not address the conflict issues.

On 1 September 2014, leaders of the SRF met with the chairman of the AU High Level Implementation Panel (AUHIP), Thabo Mbeki, in Addis Ababa to discuss the format of future negotiations. On the basis of this discussion, the African Union�s Peace and Security Council issued Communique 456 on 15 September 2014, which stipulated that government�s talks with the Darfuris and SPLM-North should be conducted in a synchronized manner, referred to as the �one process, two tracks� approach. This effectively focused the negotiations on reaching a ceasefire in Darfur and South Kordofan and Blue Nile, while simultaneously implementing the national dialogue that al-Bashir had announced in January 2014. The alliance between the SRF and the Umma Party forged in Paris in August was reiterated and extended to include other traditional political party leaders and civil society representatives on 3 December 2014, with the signing of the Sudan Call.

A round of AUHIP-mediated negotiations between the SRF and the Sudanese government started in Addis Abba on 12 November 2014. This round of negotiations consisted of two track. The SLM/A-MM and the JEM negotiated with the government on a ceasefire in Darfur (the SLM/A boycotted this round of talks with the government), while the SPLM/A-North negotiated on a ceasefire in the two areas. This round of negotiations ended with the AU mediation team announcing on 9 December 2014 that the government delegation and the SPLM-North failed to agree on a ceasefire. The reason for this deadlock was that the SPLM/A-North had insisted on a comprehensive solution for Sudan entirely, while Khartoum insisted on a cessation of hostilities for the Blue Nile and South Kordofan only. What is more, the Sudanese government had already initiated what it referred to as a deceive summer campaign in South Kordofan on 1 December 2014. The government�s military summer campaign in South Kordofan continued until mid-January 2015 and was extended to Blue Nile in February 2015. In addition, the Sudanese government refused to attend a preparatory meeting for the national dialogue that the AUHIP had wanted to facilitate in Addis Ababa on 29 and 30 March 2015. This effectively ended the SRF�s participation in the national dialogue.

On 24 August 2015, the Sudanese government announced a two-month ceasefire with the SRF, which could be extended if progress is made in negotiations. The ceasefire applied to both Darfur and the Blue Nile and South Kordofan. The SRF agreed to the ceasefire and also indicated it was ready resume negotiations with the government without further delay. On 14 September 2015, the SRF leadership announced that it was ready to sign a six-month cessation of hostilities agreement with the Sudanese government. The SRF further called on the government to �engage in a comprehensive dialogue.� However, no direct negotiations between the Sudanese government and the SRF were held in 2015.

Another round of negotiations between the Sudanese government and the SRF took place in Addis Ababa between 19 and 21 March 2016. Based on this round of talks, the AU mediators drew up a roadmap agreement for the conflict parties� consideration. The Sudanese government signed the roadmap agreement on 21 March 2016, but the SRF refused to sign the roadmap. Subsequent third party efforts were aimed at making the SRF accept the roadmap.

On 17 June 2016, Donald Booth, the US special envoy to Sudan and South Sudan, met with representatives of the JEM and the SLM/A-MM, as well as representatives from the National Umma Party, in Addis Ababa. Booth tried to persuade the JEM and the SLM/A-MM representatives to sign the roadmap agreement.

Another round of negotiations between the Government of Sudan and the SRF in Addis Abba in early August 2016 made some progress. On 8 August 2016, the SRF accepted and signed the roadmap agreement put forward by the AU on 21 March 2016. The roadmap stipulates a ceasefire, as well as outlined a framework for negotiations on the conflicts in Darfur and the two areas of Southern Kordofan and Blue Nile.

The conflict parties started another round of AU-mediated negotiations in mid-August 2016. These negotiations were supposed to focus on implementing the roadmap agreement, but the AUHIP declared the collapse of Darfur and Two Areas Ceasefire talks on 15 August 2016, blaming the JEM and the SLM/A-MM for introducing new demands on issues that had previously been agreed and which contradicted the roadmap agreement.

A third round of negotiations in Juba took place between 10 December 2019 and 14 February 2020. This round of negotiations consisted of five separate tracks covering Darfur, the Two Areas of Blue Nile and Southern Kordofan, and central, east and north Sudan. The talks between the Sudanese government and the SRF in the Darfur track led to the signing of a framework agreement on 28 December 2019.

Following a massive popular uprising, President Omar al-Bashir was ousted from power in April 2019. The transitional government that was put in place continued to negotiate with the SRF. Negotiations in Juba in September 2019 led to the signing of the Juba Declaration for Confidence Building Procedures and the Preparation for Negotiation on 11 September 2019.
agreement_name: Juba Declaration for Confidence Building Procedures and the Preparation for Negotiation

description: A second round of negotiations in Juba between 14 and 21 October 2019 led to the signing of a political declaration between the transitional Government and SRF.

On 21 February 2020, the transitional government and eastern Sudan groups signed an agreement to address the development issues in the region and ensure their political participation in the federal government. The deal was reached within the framework of the Juba hosted negotiations between the government and the armed and political groups members of the SRF.

On 10 June 2020, the head of the Sudanese government negotiating team Mohamed Haman Daglo �Hemetti� and the Sudanese rebel negotiators took part in a teleconference session of talks on national issues. The parties all committed to sign a peace agreement on 20 June. The parties agreed on the entire document except for the question of power-sharing, which they agreed would be tackled later. However, no peace agreement was concluded on 20 June 2020.

The Sudanese government and the SRF started another round of negotiations in Juba in August 2020. The negotiated were mediated by South Sudan. A critical issue during the negotiations was that of demobilization and reintegration. On 15 August 2020, the Sudanese government delegation discussed the DDR process with the SPLM-N led by Malik Agar, who was part of the SRF alliance. The conflict parties reached two agreements during the negotiations. The first agreement was a security agreement to integrate the SRF into the Sudanese Armed Forces and was reached on 17 August 2020. Ahmed El Omda, a member of the SPLM/A-N initialed the peace document on behalf of the entire SRF. Talks on political issues subsequently continued. Another agreement was reached on 31 August 2020. This agreement addressed critical topics such as security, land rights, transitional justice, the distribution of power, and the resettlement of individuals displaced by conflict. It also outlined plans for disbanding rebel groups and assimilating their members into the national military. The negotiations involved the leaders of both Sudan and South Sudan. One day before the second agreement was reached, Sudanese Prime Minister Abdalla Hamdok and several ministers flew to Juba to have a private meeting with South Sudan President Salva Kiir. The signing ceremony of the Juba Peace Agreement (JPA) took place on 3 October 2020. The transitional Government of Sudan, the SRF, the SLM/MM and the SPLM-North-MA signed the peace agreement in Juba. The Juba Peace Agreement stipulated the integration of the rebels into the security forces, as well as well as grant the rebel groups political representation and economic and land rights. In addition, the agreement committed the Sudanese government to a 10-year plan to invest $750 million to develop southern and western regions and to guarantee the return for displaced people.

From 5 to 6 September 2021, UNITAMS convened a technical consultative meeting of the Permanent Ceasefire Committee of the Darfur Permanent Ceasefire and Final Security Arrangement of the Juba Agreement for Peace in Sudan. The meeting discussed the implementation modalities of the Permanent Ceasefire Committee and its subsidiary mechanisms. It included participants who were members of these entities and stakeholders.

In response to armed clashes between the government forces and the SARC, President Omar al-Bashir sent a delegation to Darfur to negotiate with Musa Hilal on 12 January 2015, which led to the conclusion of an agreement and the reintegration of SARC fighters into the Border Guard. SARC even supported the Sudanese government during the elections that were held in this year. However, the Sudanese government had strong financial incentives to take back control of the area controlled by SARC. A UN Panel of Experts estimated that the SARC earned around $54 million a year from taxing and gold mining. Clashes resumed again in 2016 following efforts by the government forces to disarm SARC fighters. Following a clash between the SARC and government forces, Hilal was arrested in November 2017.

Between 6 and 12 May 2023, delegates from the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the RSF met directly for the first time in Jeddah in Saudi Arabia. Saudi Arabia and the US acted as mediators. The talks were described as pre-negotiation talks.

During negotiations in May 2023, the conflict parties signed the Treaty of Jeddah on 20 May 2023, committing to a short-term ceasefire, as well as vowing to ensure the safe passage of civilians, protect relief workers, and prohibit the use of civilians as human shield. The agreement included a remote monitoring mechanism executed by the US. US secretary of state Antony Blinken stated in this regard: �If the ceasefire is violated, we'll know, and we will hold violators accountable through our sanctions and other tools at our disposal.�

Between 26 October and 3 December 2023, the SAF and RSF engaged in another round of negotiations in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia. Saudi Arabia and the US acted as mediators. The talks ended without any of the side wanting to commit to a ceasefire.

A ceasefire agreement was concluded at a peace meeting at Tegot-Atto on 2 February 1994. Yet, soon after this meeting, the national Ugandan army claimed that LRA fighters had made contact with the Government of Sudan. This was unacceptable to the government delegation and on 6 February 1994, President Museveni announced that the LRA had a week to surrender, otherwise the government would defeat them. The LRA did not take up this ultimatum, after which most of its troops crossed the border into Sudan, only to return in a few months conducting attacks with more sophisticated weapons and landmines. Fighting continued during the rest of 1994.

Libya mediated a round of negotiations between Sudanese and Ugandan representatives in Tripoli in early April 1995. The LRA and the SPLM/A were excluded from the talks. The negotiations focused on Uganda ending military support to the SPLM/A and Sudan ending military support to the LRA. The Sudanese and Ugandan representatives signed an agreement in Tripoli in Libya on 5 April 1995, which called for the end of military assistance to rebel groups in both countries. The agreement stipulated, among others, a �commitment to noninterference in either side's internal affairs, pledging to refrain from providing aid to any opposing gang in either country and barring the use of either side�s territory for attacks against the other side.� However, the agreement failed. Uganda severed diplomatic relations with Sudan on 23 April 1995, and expelled eleven Sudanese diplomats from the country on 24 April 1995. Sudanese troops and Ugandan troops clashed near the border on 29 October 1995.

President Museveni stated in a speech on 3 June 1996 amnesty would be given to ordinary fighters of the LRA, but not to the LRA leaders. In September 1996, several members of the LRA called for peace talks. A �Kacoke Madit� � which is a big meeting of the Acholi � was subsequently convened in London during October and November 1996. This meeting brought together Acholi communities from Uganda, the diaspora, the Government of Uganda, and the LRA. The Ugandan Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Martin Aliker, stated that he had been mandated by the government to talk to the LRA on its behalf. The LRA was represented by James Alfred Obita, the Secretary for External Affairs and Mobilisation. Both parties expressed their desire to initiate peace negotiations.

Iran mediated negotiations between the countries between September and November 1996. The LRA and the SPLM/A were excluded from the talks. The negotiations focused on Uganda ending military support to the SPLM/A and Sudan ending military support to the LRA. Sudanese and Ugandan representatives signed a draft peace agreement in Tehran in November 1996.

On 12 December 1997, the Community of Sant�Egidio mediated negotiations between the conflict parties in Rome. Andrea Riccardi and Matteo Zuppi acted as the chief mediators. The Government of Uganda was represented by Amama Mbabazi, the State Minister of Foreign Affairs, and David Pulkol, Director of the External Security Organisation. Charles Laroker and James Alfred Obita negotiated on behalf of the LRA. No agreement was reached, but the conflict parties agreed to meet again in January 1998.

The Community of Sant�Egidio succeeded in initiating talks between the conflict parties on 13 May 1999. This led to a promise by President Museveni that an amnesty to all LRA rebels would be granted and that Joseph Kony would get a cabinet post should he be democratically elected.

In August 1999, the Carter Center mediated a round of negotiations between Sudan and Uganda. The LRA and the SPLM/A were excluded from the talks. The negotiations focused on Uganda ending military support to the SPLM/A and Sudan ending military support to the LRA.

In early December 1999, Jimmy Carter, representing the Carter Center, mediated negotiations between Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir and Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni in Nairobi in Kenya. The leaders of Sudan and Uganda signed an eleven-point agreement in Nairobi on 8 December 1999, which provided, among others, for the resumption of diplomatic relations and the end to military assistance to rebel groups. The Nairobi Agreement stipulated an end to the support of Uganda to the SPLM/A and the support of Sudan to the LRA. More specifically, in the agreement the conflict parties pledged that �1. Each of us will respect the sovereignty and territorial integrity of each other, in accordance with the charters of the United Nations and the Organization for African Unity. 2. We renounce the use of force to resolve differences, and will take steps to prevent any hostile acts against each other. 3. We will make every effort to disband and disarm terrorist groups and to prevent any acts of terrorism or hostile actions that might originate in our territory that might endanger the security of the other nation. 4. We agree not to harbor, sponsor, or give military or logistical support to any rebel groups, opposition groups, or hostile elements from each other�s territories.�

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. Negotiations aimed at implementing the Nairobi Agreement therefore continued. The first Nairobi Agreement implementation meeting between Uganda and Sudan was held in Nairobi in January 2000.

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. Negotiations aimed at implementing the Nairobi Agreement therefore continued. A second Nairobi Agreement implementation meeting was held in Nairobi in March 2000. Following a bilateral meeting on 20 March 2000, Uganda and Sudan issued a joint statement to the United Nations Security Council, emphasizing their commitment to �further foster and maintain security across their common border.�

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. Negotiations aimed at implementing the Nairobi Agreement therefore continued. The Carter Center hosted a joint ministerial meeting in Atlanta on 18 and 19 July 2000 where the Atlanta Joint Action Plan for the Nairobi Agreement was drawn up.

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. The foreign ministers of Sudan and Uganda attended a round of talks mediated by Egypt and Libya in Kampala on 26 and 27 September 2000. It was announced following this round of negotiations that Sudan had agreed to move the LRA 1,000 miles north of the Ugandan border. Both sides also agreed to a partial restoration of relations.

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. The Carter Center mediated a Nairobi Agreement implementation meeting at the ministerial level of the governments of Uganda and Sudan in Khartoum on 6-7 October.

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. A Nairobi Agreement implementation meeting was held in Nairobi in November 2000.

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. Representatives of Sudan and Uganda engaged in negotiations mediated by the Carter Center in Nairobi on 19 and 21 January 2001.

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. A Nairobi Agreement implementation meeting was held in Nairobi on 3 June 2001.

With the signing of the Nairobi Agreement on 8 December 1999, Sudan and Uganda had agreed to end the military support they provided to the LRA and the SPLM/A respectively. However, rogue elements within the Sudan army continued to support the LRA. A Nairobi Agreement implementation meeting was held in Nairobi in November 2001. This meeting was successful. Sudan committed to fully ending its support for the LRA and it allowed Uganda to enter its territory to pursue the LRA in Operation Iron Fist in February 2002.

Following a meeting in Kampala on 13 March 2002, Ugandan and Sudanese government officials issued a statement on the improvement of relations between the two countries. The statement reconfirmed the commitments and obligations of both Governments under the Nairobi Agreement of December 1999.

On 23 February 2003, the LRA declared an immediate ceasefire to pave the way for peace talks. The Government of Uganda accepted this ceasefire in early March 2003. Yet, the Government of Uganda reneged on the ceasefire in late April.

Prior to the start of negotiations in Juba in July 2006, President Museveni announced that he guaranteed Joseph Kony�s safety if an agreement was signed. This announcement received widespread attention, since Kony and four of his deputies had been indicted by the International Criminal Court for crimes against humanity. At Juba, Machar was supported both by a mediation team within his vice-Presidential office and by a mediation group that included delegates of Pax Christi, the Netherlands, and Switzerland. Switzerland provided a professional negotiator that assisted Machar during the talks, while Pax Christi provided the LRA delegates with training in negotiating. The Community of Sant�Egidio, who had been invited by the LRA, also attended the negotiations. UN representatives from the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs and the Department of Political Affairs were also involved in the process to advice on issues related to the protection of internally displaced persons political aspects of the process respectively. The UN had initially been ambivalent regarding the Juba process being more supportive of the ICC position. Jan Egeland, the UN Emergency Relief Coordinator, faulted the Sudanese and Ugandan government for agreeing to talks to those indicted, stating that �Those who are indicted have been indicted because they are responsible for mass murder of the worst possible kind, and so those who are indicted should go and face justice in The Hague.� However, the UN became increasingly involved in the process over time and in October statements were made saying that the world body was firmly behind the process. The UN subsequently contributed 4.8 million US Dollars to sponsor the peace talks. In addition, in early December UN Secretary-general Kofi Annan named former Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano his special envoy for LRA-affected areas. Chissano was mandated to develop a cohesive policy approach among all external actors in the peace process and to liaise with the ICC on questions regarding the indicted leadership of LRA. Neither Kony nor his top commanders attended the talks at Juba. Instead, the LRA delegation consisted of 14 negotiators, who had been appointed by Kony. Almost all of these 14 negotiators were Acholis from the Diaspora. The negotiation teams at Juba soon managed to agree on the issues that needed to be addressed in order to resolve the armed conflict: the cessation of hostilities, comprehensive solutions addressing the underlying issues of the conflict, reconciliation and accountability, the conclusion of a formal ceasefire, and disarmament, demobilization and reintegration of the fighters. Yet, the parties were unable to agree in which order these issues needed to be addressed and talks were adjourned on 24 July. In the meantime, the two negotiation teams consulted with their seniors.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, Netherlands, Switzerland, UN

description: On 18 August, negotiations resumed. The focus in this round of talks was particularly on the cessation of hostilities and demobilisation. After eight days, on 26 August 2006, the parties signed a cessation of hostilities agreement. The Cessation of Hostilities Agreement, among others, called upon all rebels to assemble at two designation points in Southern Sudan within three weeks. These assembly points were to be supervised and protected by SPLM forces.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, Netherlands, Switzerland, UN

description: In late September 2006, the Juba process resumed for a third round of talks, but this time the talks focused on finding a comprehensive solution to the conflict. As the progress made during these talks stalled, Ugandan president Museveni flew in to meet the LRA negotiation team in October 2006. This did not produce any results. In addition, while many rebels had assembled in the two camps by the deadline, the LRA leadership did not turn up and rebels started to move away from the camps again. The two sides continued to accuse each other of violations of the truce during the rest of the year. On 1 November 2006 and later again on 16 December 2006, the two sides recommitted to their ceasefire.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, Netherlands, Switzerland, UN

description: In November 2006, Jan Egeland met LRA leader Joseph Kony in a mediation effort to support the Juba peace talks.

In preparation of another round of peace talks between the LRA and Ugandan government, UN Special Envoy Joaquim Chissano mediated negotiations between the conflict parties between 14 and 16 April 2007. These negotiations led to a ceasefire agreement 16 April 2007. This agreement was based on a previous ceasefire from August 2006 and was set to last two months.

On 26 April, the Juba process resumed, leading to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 2 May 2007: the Agreement on Comprehensive Solutions. The agreement outlines comprehensive principles to tackle the persistent economic, political, and social challenges affecting the region of northern Uganda. It emphasizes the importance of promoting equal opportunities, fostering diversity within government institutions, revitalizing the North�s economic and educational infrastructure, and facilitating the resettlement of internally displaced persons. These crucial measures are identified as indispensable prerequisites to establish a lasting and sustainable peace in the region. Regional observers from Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo and South Africa were also present at the Juba talks in 2007, serving as informal mediators by promoting communication, confidence, and compromise.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa

description: After the conclusion of the Agreement on Comprehensive Solutions, talks focused on issues related to reconciliation and accountability. A round of negotiations in June 2007 led to the signing of the Agreement on Accountability and Reconciliation on 29 June 2007. This agreement addresses how the conflict parties aim to establish a viable national alternative to ICC indictments against five top-LRA leaders, including Kony. The agreement provided for the establishment of a domestic legal framework that would function as a substitute for the ICC prosecutions. This was complemented by alternative processes like traditional justice. Under the accord, rebel commanders accused of serious crimes were to face formal criminal and civil justice proceedings in courts, which could impose �alternative penalties and sanctions� to replace existing punitive measures. However, the specifics of these alternative penalties and sanctions were not specified. Additionally, the agreement stipulated that abuses by the national army were to be pursued in the criminal justice system. Although another round of negotiations was scheduled in August 2007, no other peace talks were held during the rest of 2007. However, on 1 November, a LRA delegation went on a historic first trip to Kampala, where it released a white dove as a symbolic gesture of peace. They then visited President Museveni and signed an addendum to the cessation of hostilities agreement that extended the pact for another three months. Martin Ojul, the LRA delegation leader, then led the group up to Gulu and appeared on a local radio station asking for forgiveness from the local population.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa

description: Two events resulted in uncertainty with regard to whether the Juba talks would continue in 2008. First, the LRA�s second in command, Vincent Otti had died in October 2007. Second, on 22 January 2008, LRA leader Joseph Kony sacked the head of LRA�s negotiating delegation, Martin Ojul, together with three others, accusing them of making money from the peace talks. Nevertheless, the Juba talks resumed on 30 January 2008 with the two sides extending the ceasefire the day before. The LRA team was now led by David Matsanga. Riek Machar continued to act as the chief mediator. In addition to the third parties already present in 2007, the US, the EU, Canada and Norway joined the talks. The conflict parties reached agreement on a number of issues. On 22 February 2008, the Implementation protocol to the Agreement on Comprehensive Solutions was signed. The protocol laid out the framework for the implementation of the Agreement on Comprehensive Solutions signed on 2 May 2007. According to the accord, the armed forces and security agencies were required to ensure that their recruitment and composition reflected the ethnic diversity of Uganda. Additionally, the agreement mandated the creation of an �Equal Opportunities Commission� shortly after the Final Peace Agreement�s signing. The primary responsibility of this commission was to investigate any regional or ethnic disparities and imbalances in government departments and institutions� participation. Furthermore, the agreement made provisions for the establishment of a �diaspora desk� within the Foreign Ministry. The purpose of this desk was to facilitate the repatriation and return of Ugandans residing abroad to their home country. On 23 February 2008, the Agreement on a Permanent ceasefire was signed. This agreement provided for an immediate truce, which was set to take effect 24 hours after the Final Peace Agreement's signing. As per the terms of the accord, all forces belonging to the LRA were required to be stationed within the Ri-Kwang-Ba assembly area, and a buffer zone surrounding it was to be respected. To monitor the cessation of hostilities, the existing Cessation of Hostilities Monitoring Team underwent transformation into a Ceasefire Monitoring Team. This new team consisted of five representatives from each of the parties involved in the agreement, five members from each of the AU observer countries participating in the peace talks, and a five-person liaison team from the UN. Additionally, it was specified that the Ceasefire Monitoring Team would be led by two senior officers from the SPLA. This arrangement aimed to ensure effective oversight and implementation of the ceasefire provisions outlined in the agreement. On 28 February 2008, the Agreement on Disarmament, Demobilisation and Reintegration was signed. This agreement established the Ceasefire Monitoring Team, which was created under the Agreement on a Permanent Ceasefire, with the primary responsibility of overseeing the disarmament and demobilization process. The accord specified that the Ceasefire Monitoring Team would develop a Disarmament Operations Plan, outlining the establishment of disarmament sites, among other details. Moreover, the Ceasefire Monitoring Team took on the task of facilitating the repatriation of ex-fighters from Ri-Kwan-Ba back to Uganda. The Government of Uganda was entrusted with the duty of identifying and preparing reception points for these returning individuals. Furthermore, the agreement granted former fighters the right to make a choice between joining the army or receiving reintegration support aimed at assisting them in their transition to civilian life. This provision aimed to offer these individuals the opportunity to pursue a path that best suited their aspirations and reintegration needs after leaving the armed forces. On 29 February 2008, the conflict parties signed the Agreement on Implementation and Monitoring Mechanisms. This agreement confirmed all the previous accords signed in the Juba process. It called for a transitional period of one month, commencing immediately after the Final Peace Agreement's signing, during which the Government of Uganda and the LRA were to prepare for the implementation of the Final Peace Agreement. As part of the accord, the parties agreed to develop an Implementation Schedule, which would be appended to the Final Peace Agreement, outlining all pertinent dates and timeframes for various actions and measures. Additionally, the Agreement on Implementation and Monitoring Mechanisms established an �Oversight Forum� responsible for overseeing and monitoring the implementation of the Final Peace Agreement. The forum would also offer advice and support to the parties and any relevant institutions created under the Final Peace Agreement. The Chief Mediator of the Juba process, Riek Machar, was designated as the chair of this forum, while the UN Secretary-General�s Special Envoy for LRA-affected areas, Joaquim Chissano, assumed the role of its spokesperson. Moreover, the agreement outlined the creation of a Joint Liaison Group, tasked with on-the-ground monitoring of the Final Peace Agreement's implementation in accordance with the Implementation Schedule. The Joint Liaison Group was further responsible for providing the Oversight Forum with progress reports on the implementation process.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa
agreement_name: Implementation protocol to the Agreement on Comprehensive Solutions, Agreement on a Permanent Ceasefire, Agreement on Disarmament, Demobilisation and Reintegration, Agreement on Implementation and Monitoring Mechanisms

description: After an agreement had been reached on these issues, the LRA team travelled to Joseph Kony�s base in Garamba National Park in early March for a new round of negotiations on the text of a proposed Final Peace Agreement before signing. The focus in the negotiations subsequently shifted to the provisions for a final ceasefire, followed by talks on disarmament, demobilization and reintegration. It is unclear whether Kony was briefed, but plans for the signing ceremony continued. On 3 March 2008, the LRA and Government of Uganda signed an agreement that included provisions for not only a ceasefire, but also disarmament and demobilization. On 10 April, all actors that had been involved in the Juba talks assembled at Ri-Kwangba to witness the signing of the final agreement. However, Kony did not show up, stating he wanted clarification on the issues of the Mato Oput (traditional judicial system) and the Special Division of the High Court. Kony stated he no longer trusted the mediators, claiming that they were in favour of the Government of Uganda. Kony also fired Matsanga, replacing him with James Obita. The legitimacy of LRA�s negotiation team was thus seriously hampered. This problem became even become worse when Matsanga reappeared in June 2008 and claimed to have been reinstated by Kony as the chief negotiator, which has remained unclear whether this was the case.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa

description: UN Secretary-General�s special envoy Joaquim Chissano worked to get the negotiations process back on track after Kony had failed to turn up for the signing ceremony on 10 April 2008. To this purpose, Chissano held a series of separate meetings with President Museveni and Kony between April and July 2008. While the LRA continued to request further mediated negotiations, Uganda�s president Museveni stated in July 2008 that his government would not hold further negotiations with Kony. Instead, the Government of Uganda would wait for Kony to sign the Final Peace Agreement. On 11 September 2008, Machar declared the peace process over. Another signing ceremony was prepared in November 2008, but Kony again failed to show up. The LRA called for a ceasefire in January, March, and June 2009. However, the LRA was only willing to resume peace talks provided that another mediator would lead the process and that talks would be held at another venue. In October 2009, Matsanga stated that talks should be held on �neutral ground� such as in Kenya or Tanzania. Matsanga also claimed that Kony would prefer Nigerian ex-president Olusegun Obasanjo to act as the chief mediator. Machar conducted yet a final attempt at restarting negotiations at Juba by the end of September 2009. Prior to Machar�s attempt, Chissano had made several attempts to find a credible negotiator of the LRA, but concluded that this was impossible and ended his role as Special Envoy to the Secretary-General on 29 May 2009. The Government of Uganda rejected calls for peace talks, regardless of the venue and chief mediator, stating that an agreement had already been reached and that the only thing missing was Kony�s signature on the final accord.
third_party: Sudan, Pax Christi, The Netherlands, Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, US, Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique, Congo, South Africa

description: It was not until 1999 that negotiations between the conflict parties took place for the first time, though some one-sided peace initiatives took place before. In August 1997, President Museveni publicly stated that he was willing to pardon fighters from the ADF who turned themselves in. In October 1997, the ADF sent a list of preconditions for peace talks to President Museveni. These included power-sharing with the rebel groups, suspension of the country�s 1995 constitution that bans all political parties, and the release of all captured rebels. The Ugandan government did not respond to these demands. In May 1999, Roman Catholic leaders of the Ruwenzori region offered to mediate between the Ugandan Government and the ADF, but this offer was not accepted. In November 1999, the Chairman of the Ugandan district of Kasese, Yokas Mikande, and the Busongora South Minister of Parliament, Christopher Kibanzanga, held seven peace meetings with the commanders of the ADF in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. The talks concerned the possibility of peace in the Ruwenzovi region in western Uganda. The peace talks were the result of a letter sent by the ADF leadership to the Ugandan army saying that they were ready to stop fighting. Commenting on the letter, a senior army commander stated that the Government of Uganda was willing to negotiate with the ADF.

Throughout 2005, Ugandan government representatives attempted to convince the ADF rebels to embrace the amnesty law and return from their camps in the Democratic Republic of Congo. This was done via radio messages and the distribution of leaflets. In September 2005, plans were revealed for a meeting to be held between the government and the ADF in the near future. However, the meeting never took place. In early December 2005, Adams Lwanga, in charge of the ADF negotiations desk, stated that negotiations would only be considered after the release of some ADF members. In December 2007, it was the ADF leadership that tried to initiate negotiations. The head of MONUC, the UN peacekeeping force in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Olamide Adedeji, stated that MONUC�s political section had been in contact with the ADF leadership, who reportedly wanted to negotiate peace and go home. Confidential negotiations between the government of Uganda and the ADF, without the involvement of a third party, were held in Nairobi starting in May 2008. The negotiations were aimed at reaching a ceasefire and amnesty, but the talks failed because the negotiations were complicated as a result of the fragmentation of the ADF�s leadership. In mid-December 2008, it was reported that both sides expected that formal peace talks would be initiated in early 2009, but these talks never materialised.
Several days of negotiations in Arua State Lodge in June 2002 led to the signing of a formal ceasefire agreement on 15 June 2002.

Negotiations in December 2002 led to signing of the Yumbe Peace Agreement on 24 December 2002. The Chairman for the Uganda Amnesty Commission, Justice Onega, mediated the negotiations, but no international third parties were involved. The accord stipulated a ceasefire. It also provided for the integration of around 700 rebels into the national army, while the remainder would be given resettlement packages. All UNRF II commanders would retain their ranks. Furthermore, it was agreed that the movement would receive ten government posts.

No negotiations have taken place between Eritrea and the EIJM - AS, but Eritrea has engaged in negotiations with Sudan about the latter ending military support to the EIJM - AS. When the border dispute between Ethiopia and Eritrea escalated into an armed conflict in May 1998, the leadership of Eritrea wanted to improve relations with Sudan. Consequently, Eritrean Foreign Minister Haile Woldensae and Sudanese Foreign Minister Mustafa Osman Ismail of Sudan engaged in negotiations mediated by Qatari Foreign Minister Sheikh Hamad bin Jassim bin Jabr al-Thani in Doha. These negotiations began on 9 November 1998 and ended on 2 February 1999 with the signing of a peace agreement. This peace agreement stipulates that both Eritrea and Sudan should abstain from supporting groups that undermine the security and stability of neighboring countries.

President Muammar Qaddafi of Libya mediated negotiations between the presidents of Eritrea and Sudan in Tripoli on 16 and 17 April 1999. These negotiations were aimed at ending the military support Eritrea and Sudan were providing to each other�s rebel groups.

The presidents of Eritrea and Sudan held another round of negotiations mediated by Qatar in Doha in Qatar on 2 and 3 May 1999. The Sudanese and Eritrean delegations agreed to abstain from supporting groups that undermine the security and stability of neighboring countries, as well as agreed to restore diplomatic ties. Eritrean authorities subsequently forced Sudanese opposition figures to leave Eritrea by the end of May 1999. Eritrea and Sudan resumed diplomatic relations on 4 January 2000.

A unilateral victory by either side was increasingly perceived as unlikely in the civil war in Angola by the end of the 1980s. This explains why both President dos Santos and Savimbi, attended a conference organised by Zairian President Mobutu Sese Seko in Gbadolite, Zaire, in June 1989, that involved 20 African countries. Prior to this meeting, Mobutu had obtained a mandate to mediate from the conflict parties through separate meetings on two occasions with Savimbi and Angolan President Eduardo dos Santos to �restore peace and National Reconciliation in Angola.� He had also consulted the regional heads of state at a summit in Tokyo on 22 February 1989 and a conference of regional leaders in Luanda on 16 May 1989. According to some observers, Mobuto wanted to portray himself as a regional peacemaker, since he lost some influence due to the end of the Cold War. The Gbadolite Peace Agreement was signed on 22 June 1989. The heads of states of the following countries attended the conference in Gbadolite: Zambia, Botswana, Burundi, Cameroon, Cape Verde, Chad, Congo, Gabon, Guinea-Bissau, Mozambique, Niger, Rwanda, Sao Tome and Principe, Tanzania, Zanzibar, Zimbabwe and the king of Morocco. Only a few days after President dos Santos and UNITA leader Savimbi signed the agreement, fighting erupted again with both parties disagreeing about the content of the agreement.

A breakthrough occurred in the summer of 1990 when the MPLA government abandoned its Marxist inspired ideology and compromised to the principle of �evolution to a multi-party state�, two points which the US had repeatedly emphasized as essential for their support to the peace process. These concessions allowed the US and the Soviet Union to become directly involved in the negotiations for the first time in the fourth round of talks in September 1990. The conflict parties agreed at this fourth round of negotiations that once a schedule for a ceasefire and elections had been negotiated, military support from the US and the Soviet Union to the conflict parties would end.

The negotiations gained further momentum during the fifth round of negotiations in December 1990, when United States Secretary of State James Baker held several meetings with Angolan Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi in Washington, which led to what became known as the Washington Concepts Paper. The meeting in Washington was also attended by the Portuguese intermediaries and Soviet diplomats. The Washington Concepts Paper stipulated that once a ceasefire would be concluded the conflict parties would organize free and fair elections, and that the parties would create a national army between the time of the conclusion of the ceasefire and the elections. The Washington Concept Paper further specified that the restructuring of the army and holding of elections were to be overseen by a UN monitoring force.

As a result of the Washington Concepts Paper, most of the underlying issues had been resolved by the time the sixth round of negotiations that started on 4 April 1991. This allowed the conflict parties to focus on the remaining key issues, which were the formulation of a unified national army, the setting of dates for a ceasefire and multiparty elections, and the international monitoring of implementation of an agreement. Of these remaining issues, the election date proved to be the most contentious point. While the MPLA government demanded the election to be held three years after the ceasefire date, UNITA proposed the elections to be held as early as nine months after the ceasefire. It was only after the US and the Soviet Union agreed to take part in the implementation process of the agreement that the conflict parties agreed to the elections taking place 18 months after the ceasefire would take effect, which was set for 15 May 1991. On 31 May 1991, the Bicesse Agreement was signed. The agreement established a ceasefire to be monitored by a joint commission, comprised of the two warring parties and a number of third parties. Furthermore, the agreement stipulated reforms of the military and security sector, creating an integrated army and a new police force. The agreement stipulated that both parties would contribute 20000 troops each to the new armed forces. The forces that were not integrated into the new army were to be demobilized and reintegrated into civilian life. The agreement allowed UNITA to become a legal political party. The agreement committed the parties to a multi-party democracy. An elections process was to be held in which the people would vote for a new President and a National Assembly. Political rights were extended, such as the freedom of expression and freedom of association. The authority of the central administration was extended to include the entire Angolan territory. The implementation of the peace agreement became the responsibility of the joint political-military commission. All civilian and military prisoners were to be released as a consequence of the agreement. The question of the return of exiles was to be discussed in the joint political-military commission. A variety of different mediation methods were used by the third parties to move the conflict parties towards the Bicesse Accords. First, the Bush administration made negotiations more attractive to the MPLA Government by promising that if the conflict parties would reach a negotiated settlement, then Washington would normalise relations with the MPLA Government and recognise it. Second, the third parties used military inducements, both through extending and refusing to extend military assistance. Seeking to maintain their position in Southern Africa, the US had been supporting UNITA, while the Soviet Union had been supporting the MPLA government. However, as the Cold War waned by the end of the 1980s, the conflict parties could no longer depend on unqualified support from their clients. Besides scaling back their support, both Washington and Moscow became increasingly willing to apply pressure to the conflict parties in favour of a peaceful solution to the conflict. The US drew on its patron client relationship with UNITA by urging the latter to make public statements calling for national reconciliation, making it easier for the MPLA government to reach out. The US had also tacitly assured dos Santos that with national reconciliation, the military aid to UNITA would be ended. In addition, the third parties guaranteed the implementation of the Bicesse Accords. The agreement stipulated that representatives of Portugal, the USA and the USSR, together with sub-groups and members of the government and UNITA, were to take part in the joint Politico-Military Commission (CCPM), with the task of overseeing the political and ceasefire process. It was also agreed that around 30 observer states would be involved in the implementation process, as well as a UN force of 800 people financed by a US grant of 40 million US Dollars. Moreover, President dos Santos was promised by US Secretary of State James Baker that �the USA had all the means to guarantee the implementation of the accords and also to prevent the accords being violated.�

As a result, in December 1993, a new round of peace talks was launched in Lusaka, Zambia, by the new UN�s special envoy to Angola, Alione Blondin Beye, who was mandated to implement the Bicesse Accords. On 24 March 1992, this mandate had been confirmed by the UN Security Council, which stated in Resolution 747 that it welcomed Beye�s appointment and that he would be �in charge of all current and projected activities of the United Nations in connection with the [Bicesse] Accords.� UN SC Resolution 747. On 15 December 1993, the UN Security Council issued Resolution 890, in which it stated mandated Bye to conduct mediation �with the goal of restoring a cease-fire and reinstating the peace process for the full implementation of the Acordos de Paz [Bicesse Accords] and relevant Security Council resolutions.�

The negotiations launched in Lusaka in November 1993, at which Beye acted as the chief mediator, continued throughout 1994. American, Russian and Portuguese diplomats also took part, including US President Bill Clinton�s special envoy, Paul Hare. On 16 November 1994, the two sides signed a truce in order to support the ongoing peace talks. The Lusaka Accord was signed on 20 November 1994. The agreement reinstated the ceasefire from 1991, but contained some important amendments. Among other things this ceasefire agreement included the withdrawal of UNITA forces from specific locations to allow for a UN monitoring and verification presence in these areas. UNITA forces would withdraw to encampment areas, while government forces, in turn, would remain �in situ�. The agreement stipulated a proportionate integration of UNITA forces into the new national army. The agreement amended the earlier deal on the police forces, stipulating a specific number of UNITA troops that would become police officers in the new police force. A demobilization program was created under which military forces were to be demobilized and integrated into civilian society. The implementation of the agreement would be monitored and verified by a joint commission and the UN. The agreement stipulated that UNITA was to participate in all levels of Government, and that the movement was given certain ministerial portfolios, diplomatic missions, governorships and assured participation in the National Assembly. The agreement also provided UNITA with a formal amnesty for crimes committed during the conflict, and supplied the UNITA party and political leaders with �appropriate� housing. The agreement also stipulated that a Joint Commission would oversee the peace agreement. This was to be composed of government and UNITA representatives and chaired by the Alioune Blondin Beye, while representatives of Portugal, Russia and the USA were to be observers. On 8 December 1994, the UN Security Council mandated Beye and the Joint Commission to �continue their efforts aimed at the full implementation of the �Acordos de Paz� [Bicesse Accords], the Lusaka Protocol and relevant Security Council resolutions.�

In August 1995, dos Santos and Savimbi met at the Franceville summit in Gabon. Negotiations did not reach any concrete results. The key stumbling block was the disarmament of UNITA, the confinement to barracks of government security forces and the formation of a single national army.

Another meeting was held in Libreville, Gabon, on 1 March 1996, where dos Santos and Savimbi managed to reach an agreement on the formation of a government of national unity within the following four months. Savimbi also committed himself to complete the quartering of UNITA forces by June 1996 and both leaders agreed that the formation of the unified armed forces should be concluded by the same date. President dos Santos repeated his invitation for Savimbi to become a vice-president, but the latter failed to respond. The creation of a government of national unity was never realised.

In mid-March 1997, the Joint Commission finally managed to meet after five successive postponements. Agreement was reached on some, including the granting of �special status� to Savimbi, following his rejection of the title of vice-president in late 1996. It was agreed at the same meeting that several UNITA leaders would become members of Parliament, providing the first parliamentary opposition to the MPLA since Angola gained independence in 1975. Dos Santos dissolved his government and subsequently formed a government of national unity in April 1997, with four UNITA cabinet ministers and seven deputy ministers.

Negotiations aimed at implementing the Lusaka Declaration continued following the establishment of a government of national unity. On 9 January 1998, negotiations took place in Luanda, attended by dos Santos together with a delegation from the government and UNITA. A new schedule was agreed for the implementation of the accord, stipulating that the terms of the protocol was to be fulfilled by 28 February. However, this failed to materialise. Since this deadline was yet again not met, the UN Security Council imposed new sanctions on UNITA on 25 June 1998, which stipulated the freezing of UNITA�s foreign bank accounts and a ban on the purchase of Angolan diamonds without a certificate of origin, as well as prohibited all air and water transport in and out of the territories controlled by UNITA. Savimbi had indicated on 6 June 1998 that if the UN would impose new sanctions, UNITA would regard this as an attack on UNITA to which it was ready to respond. Indeed, following the imposition of new UN sanctions, UNITA immediately seized control in some of the localities in which it had transferred power to the central government. By the end of 1998, the Government of Angola had lost patience with the lack of implementation of the Lusaka Protocol and resumed the civil war. At an MPLA congress held in early December 1998, President dos Santos stated that �the only path to lasting peace is the total isolation of Jonas Savimbi and his movement.� Large-scale armed fighting subsequently resumed. Following the resumption of war in late 1998, the UN Security Council terminated MONUA in February 1999 and replaced it with a small political mission in Luanda � the United Nations Office in Angola (UNOA) � which was mandated to watch political developments and promote human rights. However, the new set of UN sanctions, imposed against UNITA in June 1998, made a third party peacemaking role for the UN problematic. Unable to initiate new peace talks, the UN officially terminated its mediation effort in March 1999. The secretary-General�s special envoy to Angola, Issa Diallo, who had replaced Beye after Beye had died in a plane crash in June 1998, left the country in March 1999, stating that �the UN did what it could.� President Dos Santos stated that the Government of Angola would never negotiate with Savimbi again.

It was not until 2002 that the conflict parties engaged in negotiations again. These talks followed the death of UNITA leader Savimbi, who was killed by government forces on 22 February 2002, after which plans were immediately made to initiate peace talks. The Government of Angola initially indicated that its counter-insurgency campaign against UNITA would continue in spite of Savimbi�s death, but following a series of meetings President dos Santos held with the Portuguese Government in Lisbon, President George W. Bush in Washington, and UN Under Secretary for African Affairs Ibrahim Gambari in New York, the Government of Angola announced on 2 March that it would contact UNITA to prepare the ground for a ceasefire. The Secretary-General of UNITA, Paulo Lukamba, subsequently formed the so-called Management Committee which was to negotiate with the Government of Angola. The conflict parties engaged in informal discussions, which led the Government of Angola to declare a unilateral ceasefire on 13 March.

The Government of Angola also presented a peace plan, which called for negotiations on the outstanding military and political issues in accordance with the Bicesse Accords and Lusaka Protocol. No third parties were involved in the peace process, but the UN endorsed the peace plan. The UN Special Representative in Angola, Mussagy Jeichande, expressed satisfaction with the peace plan, describing it as �conciliatory.� Crucially, UNITA�s breakaway factions, which had challenged Savimbi�s leadership in 1998, also supported the peace talks. UNITA-Renavado leader Eugenio Manuvakola publicly declared not to interfere with the peace negotiations, reportedly allowing �UNITA to represent UNITA.� Preliminary talks between the conflict parties subsequently started on 15 March in the town of Cassamba in Moxico province. It was agreed at these talks that official negotiations would mainly focus technical military matters. The conflict parties also decided that the provincial capital Luena would be the venue of the peace talks, because the Government of Angola had the necessary facilities in this town to host talks, but the town was also close to the battlefield. The conflict parties signed a ceasefire at Cassamba on 18 March. In spite of the ceasefire, some low-level fighting continued throughout Angola. Yet, the negotiators kept the positive momentum, insisting that this fighting was only the result of a lack of information getting to the fighting elements.

Official peace talks started on 20 March in Luena. The UNITA delegation was headed by UNITA�s Information Secretary Marcial Dachala and by UNITA�s Secretary for Foreign Affairs Alcides Sakala. The negotiations focused mainly on the technicalities of a ceasefire and the DDR process. The negotiators agreed that the Lusaka Protocol would be taken as the basis for the political resolution of the conflict. On 30 March 2002, the parties agreed on a ceasefire agreement, referred to as the Luena Memorandum. The Luena Memorandum was formally signed in Luanda on 4 April 2002. The agreement essentially provides for the implementation of a ceasefire and the signatories� compliance with the outstanding clauses of the Lusaka peace agreement from 1994. In contrast to the peace agreements previously concluded to end Angola�s civil war, the security provisions in the Luena Memorandum were quickly implemented. No armed fighting took place following the signing of the agreement and UNITA troops began to move towards the assembly points designated by the Luena Agreement on the same day the agreement was signed. UNITA officially gave up its armed wing on 2 August 2002, declaring it would from this moment onwards solely be a political party.

No negotiations have taken place between the Ethiopian government and AIAI, but the Ethiopian government has engaged in negotiations with Sudan about the latter ending military support to the AIAI. When the border dispute between Ethiopia and Eritrea escalated into an armed conflict in May 1998, the leadership of Eritrea wanted to improve relations with Sudan. In a round of negotiations on 31 March 1999, the leaders of Sudan and Ethiopia restored diplomatic relations and concluded an agreement in which they committed to abstain from activities that undermine peace and security in each other�s countries. Specifically, the Government of Ethiopia committed to end support to the SPLM/A, while the Government of Sudan committed to end support to the OLF and the AIAI.

Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir and Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi engaged in negotiations in Addis Ababa on 18 and 19 November 1999, confirming the March 1999 agreement that committed both states to abstain from activities that undermine peace and security in each other�s countries.

By the end of 2011, President Meles Zenawi confidentially encouraged the resumption of ONLF-government talks. In order to bring about talks, Meles also requested Kenya to mediate. The presence of a third party was tantamount to the ONLF, after the killing of its negotiator in 1998. Talks mediated by Kenya were scheduled to take place in August 2012, but were postponed due to the death of President Meles. A first meeting was subsequently held between 6 and 7 September 2012, when a delegation from the Ethiopian government, led by Defence Minister Siraj Fegisa, met an ONLF delegation under the leadership of the group�s foreign secretary Abd-al-Rahman Mahdi. A Kenyan team under the leadership of Yusuf Haji, the Defence and a Kenyan Ogaadeni, functioned as the mediators during the process that aimed to start up official negotiations between the Ethiopian government and ONLF. At this initial meeting, the parties focused mainly on the modalities for future talks and at the end of it, they had agreed on principles to end the conflict. It was announced by the ONLF that the two sides were committed to holding formal negotiations to solve the conflict, that the goal of the process was to attain just and lasting peace, that the negotiations were to be comprehensive, addressing the root causes of the conflict, that no preconditions were to be made of either party, that the substantive agenda was to include issues that would facilitate the implementation of a future agreement, and, finally, that both parties were to agree to specific measure of good-will and confidence-building in order to create a favourable climate for the negotiations.

On 12 August 2018, the Ogaden National Liberation Front (ONLF) declared a unilateral ceasefire. The leadership of the group publicly stated that it declared the ceasefire in response to call for peace by the Ethiopian government led by Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed. The improvement in relations between Ethiopia and Eritrea in July 2018 gave further impetus to the peace process between the Government of Ethiopia on the one hand and the OLF and the ONLF on the other hand. In spite of Eritrea hosting both groups on its territory, it initiated a mediation effort between the Ethiopian government and these two rebel groups. A round of negotiations in Asmara mediated by Eritrea led to the signing of a peace agreement between the government and the ONLF on 21 October 2018. Many ONLF leaders subsequently returned to Ogaden to transform the group into a political party ahead of 2020 elections.
agreement_name: Joint Declaration Between the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia And The Ogaden National Liberation Front

description: A POLISARIO delegation, led by Mahfoud Ali Beiba, held negotiations with King Hassan II in Marrakesh on 4 and 5 January 1989, although the King described the meeting as �discussions� rather than �negotiations�. The talks took place without the involvement of any third party and was instead chaired by King Hassan II himself. However, the UN Secretary-General remained involved in the conflict throughout the year, particularly with regard to the implementation of the in 1988 presented peace plan, which aimed to end the war by holding a referendum to decide on the future status of the disputed territory.

In 1991, P�rez de Cuellar mediated between the conflict parties throughout the entire year regarding updating the administrative aspects of his peace plan. On 28 June 1991, during a round of peace talks mediated by the UN, the government of Morocco and POLISARIO agreed to a ceasefire starting on 6 September. On 19 December 1991, less than two weeks before he would leave office, the UN Secretary-General submitted a final report to the UN Security Council, recommending extending the eligibility of potential voters in the referendum. However, the proposal was only �welcomed� by the UN Security Council.
