Nevertheless, Morocco began moving around 170,000 individuals to the Western Sahara who were supposedly allowed to vote on the basis of P�rez de Cuellar�s proposed criteria.

In 2001, Baker formulated a blueprint to resolve the conflict titled the Personal Envoy�s Draft Framework Agreement, also known as Baker Plan I. The document was immediately rejected by representatives of POLISARIO, who stated that it aimed at �the precipitous integration of the Saharan Territory into Morocco.� POLISARIO continued to oppose the Baker plan between 2001 and 2002. Consequently, in January 2003, Baker presented a new peace plan to the parties, named the �Peace plan for self-determination of the people of Western Sahara�, also known as the Baker Plan II. This plan provided for a referendum to take place within four to five years. The final vote would offer the inhabitants of the territory a choice between independence, autonomy within Morocco or complete integration with Morocco. The plan also proposed that, in the run-up to the referendum, an autonomous Western Sahara Authority would be made responsible for running key parts of the administration, taking control of local government, taxation, economic development, internal security and other dossiers. Yet, Morocco would retain control over foreign relations, national security, external defence and all matters relating to the production, sale, ownership and use of weapons during the interim period.

Ross mediated direct talks between the parties in Duernstein, Austria, on 10 and 11 August 2009. Although the parties appeared satisfied with the talks and promised continued negotiations in the near future, no progress towards an agreement appeared to have been made, as Morocco continued to propose autonomy while POLISARIO demanded a referendum and possible independence.

The parties came together for a third round of talks from 8 November to 1 December 1990, which led to a partial ceasefire. The conflict parties agreed to stop fighting in the Beira and Maputu corridors, which link Zimbabwe and other landlocked countries with the ocean. It was also decided that the number of Zimbabwean troops would be reduced by half and confined to the corridors.

In late December 1990, during the fourth round of negotiations, a Joint Verification Committee � consisting of members of the government, Renamo, and eight countries � was set up to monitor the ceasefire, ensuring non-defection. Of the eight countries serving on the committee, Renamo chose Kenya, Portugal, the US, and Zambia, while the Government of Mozambique selected Congo, France, the UK, and the Soviet Union.

However, during the eighth round of talks, held in October 1991, substantial progress was made. On 18 October, a protocol on Fundamental Principles was signed, where Renamo recognised the legitimacy of the Government during a transitional period between a formal ceasefire and elections. The protocol confirmed the May agenda and cleared the ground for a general peace agreement once a protocol for each agenda item had been negotiated.

On 13 November, a partial peace agreement, dealing with criteria for political parties was signed: the Agreement on Establishment and Recognition of Political Parties. In this partial peace agreement, the parties reached consensus on certain aspects of the future multi-party democracy by defining the general principles, rights, and responsibilities of political parties. Additionally, it was agreed that RENAMO would undergo a transformation into a political party once a final peace agreement was signed.
agreement_name: Agreement on Establishment and Recognition of Political Parties

description: On the ninth round of negotiations in December 1991, a joint communiqu� confirming consensus on simultaneous presidential and parliamentary elections supervised by the UN and the OAU and held within a year of the signing of a general peace agreement, was issued. Throughout the Rome talks, the Government of Italy constantly provided extensive financial incentives to Renamo in particular in order to keep it engaged in the peace processes.

Round ten of the Rome negotiations � which were mediated by the Roman Catholic Community of Sant�Egidio, the Archbishop of Beira, and the Italian government � took place between 21 January and 12 March 1992. The tenth round resulted in the signing of a protocol, which supplemented the earlier agreements on electoral issues. The agreement ensured several fundamental rights, including freedom of the press, access to the media, freedom of association, expression, and political engagement, freedom of movement and residence, the right of refugees to return, and the right to vote. It also specified that national elections would be conducted within one year of the final peace agreement's signing, with a detailed process outlined for the elections. The elections would include direct voting for a national assembly based on proportional representation and a president overseen by a National Elections Commission. The agreement established that a political party would need a minimum of 5% and a maximum of 20% of votes to obtain seats, while a presidential candidate would require 10,000 signatures. Furthermore, the agreement encouraged the return of refugees and internally displaced persons to participate in the forthcoming elections in Mozambique.

In mid-June 1992, round eleven of the negotiations started. They were supposed to focus on military issues, but instead revolved around famine relief due to the worst drought in 30 years. British businessman Tiny Rowland together with Zimbabwean president Robert Mugabe managed to convince Renamo leader Dhlakama and President Chissano to meet face to face for negotiations in Dhlakama, Botswana, on 5 July 1992. As a result of this meeting, the parties signed, on 7 August 1992, a declaration of intent to sign a ceasefire in early October 1992. Tiny Rowland had already become involved in the peace process in 1990, when he and President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia launched a separate initiative in parallel to the Rome process. Rowland was the chairman of Lonroho, a company based in the United Kingdom which was the first major transnational corporation to make major investments in Mozambique. Rowland regarded the civil war as a serous hindrance to expansion of his business interests, which is why he worked to initiate a face-to-face meeting between President Chissano and Renamo leader Dhlakama.
On 16 July 1992, representatives from the government of Mozambique and Renamo reached a ceasefire agreement in Rome to allow for humanitarian aid to reach rebel areas.

The 7 August declaration of intent was signed at the twelfth and final round of the Rome process, which was initiated on 5 August 1992. Finally, the Acordo General de Paz (English: General Peace Agreement), also known as the Rome Accord, was signed on 4 October 1992. The Acordo Geral de Paz consolidated various previous protocols signed by the government and RENAMO. Upon assembly ratification, a ceasefire would be implemented. Both forces would then withdraw from their current positions and relocate to designated sites for integration into a new armed unit or demobilization. The agreement outlined the establishment of a new army comprising 30,000 men, with each party contributing 15,000. Remaining forces would be disarmed and demobilized under UN supervision within six months. RENAMO would transform into a political party, and free multi-party elections would be held. Under UN supervision, presidential and legislative elections were scheduled one year after the signing of the General Peace Agreement, contingent upon full implementation and completion of the demobilization process. Additionally, all prisoners were to be released, and refugees and internally displaced persons were granted the right to return freely and voluntarily to the country. Lastly, UN peacekeepers would monitor the ceasefire and oversee the elections. The Government of Italy constantly provided extensive financial incentives to Renamo in particular to keep it engaged in the peace processes, in fact, by the time of the signing of the Rome Accord, the Government of Italy had spent around 20 million US Dollars on purchases to promote cooperation in the peace process.

The Community of Sant�Egidio, which had also been heavily involved in mediation during the first civil war, subsequently started to play a leading role in mediation. Community of Sant�Egidio mediator Matteo Zuppi mediated a round of negotiations in late September 2013. The negotiations did not lead to any tangible results. While the government side demanded that all Renamo troops would lay down their weapons, Renamo demanded the withdrawal of government troops from the main Renamo stronghold, the Gorongosa area. Renamo also demanded a better representation within the armed forces, a share of the mineral revenues, and a new electoral law.
A round of negotiations on 10 February 2014 led to an agreement that called for the restructuring of the National Electoral Commission.
Following another round of negotiations on 14 April 2014, Renamo agreed to disarm and reintegrate its members into the national army.

A round of negotiations that started on 21 July 2014 led to a full draft of a peace agreement on 28 July 2014. This draft agreement included provisions for a ceasefire and the reintegration of rebel members. However, the agreement was neither formally signed nor implemented.

The conflict parties continued to negotiate in 2014, but without the involvement of a third party. Ahead of elections on 15 October 2014, the conflict parties agreed to a ceasefire in Maputo on 24 August 2014. As part of the negotiations, the government began to release Renamo prisoners a week prior to the conclusion of the ceasefire. The ceasefire was signed by Renamo�s chief negotiator Saimon Macuiane and government representatives. The ceasefire was seen as part of a wider attempt to bring peace to the country ahead of elections scheduled for October 2014. Saimon Macuiane, the Renamo� chief negotiator, called the ceasefire an �important step towards national reconciliation... and a durable peace.�

A round of negotiations in September led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 5 September 2014. The agreement was signed by Mozambican President Arnando Guebuza Renamo leader Afonso Dhlakama. The latter emerged from two years in hiding to sign the deal in the capital, Maputo. Foreign military observers under the Military Group for the Observation of the Military Hostilities (EMOCHM) would later arrive to oversee the implementation of this agreement. It was intended to last 135 days, but would be extended.
On 26 December, the parties reached a 7-day ceasefire agreement through bilateral negotiations over the phone.

The previously agreed upon ceasefire was extended for two months during a round of negotiations on 3 January 2017. In February 2017, Switzerland was announced as a lead mediator in an international team intended to mediate between the rebels and government. However, in early March 2017, the Government of Mozambique announced that a further round of negotiations would be held, but without the involvement of international mediators.
The ceasefire was extended once again in early May and the parties met 11 May 2017 for a round of negotiations.
On 11 July 2018, leadership from both sides met for a peace talk in which progress was made regarding integration of former rebels.

A round of negotiations in August 2018 led to the signing of a memorandum of understanding on 6 August 2018 that outlined terms for disarmament. Later that year, in December 2018, several of Renamo officials were announced as new members of the Mozambican government.

The Ambassador of Switzerland and Chairman of Contact Group, Mirko Manzoni, mediated another meeting between President Filipe Nyusi and the Renamo leader President Ossufo Momade on 2 June 2019. The meeting focused on disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration (DDR) provisions.
third_party: UN, Contact Group (Switzerland, Botswana, China, EU, Great Britain, Norway, US)

description: Swiss diplomats led the international mediation team that was involved in the peace efforts during 2019. On 1 August 2019, on Swiss National Day, the conflict parties signed the final cessation of hostilities agreement in the rebel stronghold of Gorongosa Park. This date was chosen on purpose in honour of Switzerland. The ceasefire agreement was signed by President Filipe Nyusi and Renamo leader Ossufo Momade at Renamo�s remote military base in the Gorongosa mountains.
third_party: UN, Contact Group (Switzerland, Botswana, China, EU, Great Britain, Norway, US)

description: This ceasefire paved the way for the signing of the Maputo Accord for Peace and National Reconciliation on 6 August 2019. The new RENAMO leader Ossufo Momade signed the peace accord with President Nyusi.
third_party: UN, Contact Group (Switzerland, Botswana, China, EU, Great Britain, Norway, US)
agreement_name: Maputo Accord for Peace and National Reconciliation

description: On 11 October 2019, Mozambican President Filipe Nyusi had a phone call with the Renamo leadership about the implementation of the peace agreement.

On 5 September 2020, Mirko Manzoni, the personal envoy of the UN Secretary-General for Mozambique and President of the Contact Group, met with President Filipe Nyusi and Renamo leader Ossufo Momade to discuss progress made with regard to DDR. The meeting took place in the context of a meeting at a Renamo base located in Gorongosa where a DDR process took place.
third_party: UN, Contact Group (Switzerland, Botswana, China, EU, Great Britain, Norway, US)

description: Another meeting between President Filipe Nyusi and Renamo Leader Ossufo Momade, mediated by the personal envoy of the UN Secretary-General for Mozambique, took place on 5 April 2022. A range of topics were discussed including the ongoing DDR process, pensions for DDR beneficiaries, and the evolving COVID-19 situation in the country. Tensions remained surrounding the issue of demobilisation and the pensions of the demobilized Renamo fighters. It was only in March 2023 that the pensions were approved by the Council of Ministers through decree no. 12/2023. Two months later, in June 2023, the demobilisation process was completed with the demobilisation of the final group of former Renamo combatants and the closure of the last remaining military base in Vunduzi, Sofala province.

Through much of late 1992, Mohamed Sahnoun, the Special Representative on Somalia for the UN Secretary-General, tried to mediate a ceasefire between the conflict parties. Sahoun had been appointed in March 1992 and was mandated to work out a �plan whereby the United Nations could facilitate the cessation of hostilities between the Somali factions, promote reconciliation, and provide urgently needed humanitarian assistance.� Earlier in 1992, the UN Security Council had imposed an arms embargo on Somalia. By mid-October 1992, all major conflict parties agreed to a reconciliation conference. The Ethiopian President Meles Zinawi would act as the chief mediator of this conference, which was scheduled to take place in Addis Ababa in January 1993. The UN Secretary-General would attend the conference as well. It was further agreed that direct, bilateral discussions between the leaders of the different conflict parties would be held in November and December 1992, prior to the conference. On 5 December 1992, the American-led Unified Task Force (UNITAF) was deployed in Mogadishu to create a secure environment for conducting humanitarian operations. However, the force was also used to move the conflict parties to the negotiation table. For instance, as soon as USC-Faction leader General Mohammed Farah Aideed made it clear that he would not participate in the Addis Ababa conference, the US attacked one of his camps in Mogadishu with 400 marines. Aideed subsequently agreed to come to Addis Ababa.

The SNM participated in the Addis Ababa conference in 1993. From 4 to 15 January 1993, the UN � in collaboration with Ethiopia, the OAU, the Arab League, the OIC, and the US � convened a preparatory meeting for a conference of national reconciliation and unity in Addis Ababa between several Somali political movements. In addition to hosting the talks, Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi mediated the negotiations. In his opening speech, Boutros-Ghali emphasised that the UN peace enforcement mission deployed in December 1992 created a window of opportunity that would not remain open for long, stating that �The world could forget about Somalia in a few minutes.� On 8 January 1993, the conflict parties declared an immediate ceasefire and a cessation of all hostile propaganda against each other. In the following days, the adversaries reached consensus on issues regarding the disarmament and monitoring of the ceasefire. Moreover, an ad hoc committee was created. It was agreed at the first meeting of this committee on 22 January that another reconciliation conference would be held in Addis Ababa in March 1993. A donor conference organised by the UN was held prior to the second conference in Addis Ababa, with the goal to collect funds for humanitarian assistance. In addition, the American-led UNITAF was conducting attacks on some of the conflict parties to enforce the ceasefire agreement.
third_party: Ethiopia, OAU, Arab League, OIC, US

description: The second Addis Ababa conference led to the conclusion of the Addis Ababa Agreement on 27 March 1993. The agreement established a ceasefire, and it included a provision requiring Somalia insurgent groups to disarm by surrendering their weapons to UNITAF/UNOSOM. As part of the accord, the parties agreed to create a Transitional National Council (TNC) to govern for a two-year period, followed by the emergence of a political system based on democratic principles, the rule of law, decentralization of power, and the protection of human rights and individual liberties. During the transitional period, the TNC would have legislative functions and would also be responsible for establishing an independent judiciary. The TNC's composition would include representatives from all regions in Somalia, as well as political factions that participated in the peace conference in Addis Ababa. Additionally, the agreement called for the establishment of Central Administrative Departments, Regional Councils, and District Councils to support the governance and administrative structures during the transitional phase. These provisions aimed to pave the way for a more stable and democratic political system in Somalia. However, fighting between the conflict parties continued. In a mission to capture two of Mohammed Farah Aideed�s high-echelon lieutenants on 3 October 1993, a battle ensued between forces of the United States and Somali militia fighters. This resulted in the death of 19 US soldiers and around 100 militia fighters. The US subsequently decided to withdraw its forces. In order to create sufficient order for the US to withdraw and limit political damage, US President Bill Clinton sent Ambassador Oakley back to Somalia.
third_party: Ethiopia, OAU, Arab League, OIC, US

description: A final mediation attempt was conducted by Italy in early January 1991. Italy shuttled between the conflict parties, proposing a peace plan on 9 January 1991, which recognised Siad Barre as the head of state. Yet, this plan was immediately rejected by the USC. Subsequent mediation efforts by Mario Raffaelli, the Italian Special Envoy for Somalia, also failed. Fighting continued until the main Somalia rebel groups, including USC, managed to overthrow the Barre regime on 26 January 1991.

Between 3 and 5 January 1992, the UN assistant Secretary-General, James O. C. Jonah, visited Mogadishu. He shuttled between the conflict parties in an attempt to end the fighting between Mahdi�s forces and the USC/SNA, but he failed in his mission.
On 14 February 1992, the parties met again for talks mediated by Boutros-Ghali in which solely the UN was involved. This resulted in the signing of a ceasefire agreement, but fighting continued.

By mid-October 1992, all major conflict parties agreed to a reconciliation conference. The Ethiopian President Meles Zinawi acted as the chief mediator of this conference, which was scheduled to take place in Addis Ababa in January 1993. The UN Secretary-General would attend the conference as well. It was further agreed that direct, bilateral discussions between the leaders of the different conflict parties would be held in November and December 1992, prior to the conference. On 5 December 1992, the American-led Unified Task Force (UNITAF) was deployed in Mogadishu to create a secure environment for conducting humanitarian operations. However, the force was also used to move the conflict parties to the negotiation table. For instance, as soon as USC/SNA leader General Mohammed Farah Aideed made it clear that he would not participate in the Addis Ababa conference, the US attacked one of his camps in Mogadishu with 400 marines. Aideed subsequently agreed to come to Addis Ababa.

Through much of late 1992, Mohamed Sahnoun, the Special Representative on Somalia for the UN Secretary-General, tried to mediate a ceasefire between the conflict parties. Sahoun had been appointed in March 1992 and was mandated to work out a �plan whereby the United Nations could facilitate the cessation of hostilities between the Somali factions, promote reconciliation, and provide urgently needed humanitarian assistance.�

From 4 to 15 January 1993, the UN � in collaboration with Ethiopia, the OAU, the Arab League, the OIC, and the US � convened a preparatory meeting for a conference of national reconciliation and unity in Addis Ababa between several Somali political movements. In addition to hosting the talks, Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi mediated the negotiations. In his opening speech, Boutros-Ghali emphasised that the UN peace enforcement mission deployed in December 1992 created a window of opportunity that would not remain open for long, stating that, �The world could forget about Somalia in a few minutes.� On 8 January 1993, the conflict parties declared an immediate ceasefire and a cessation of all hostile propaganda against each other. In addition, the American-led UNITAF was conducting attacks on some of the conflict parties to enforce the ceasefire agreement.

description: On 24 March 1994, Aideed and Mahdi signed a peace agreement in Nairobi, following negotiations brokered by Ambassador Lansana Kouyate of Guinea, who had been appointed the Acting Representative of the UN Secretary-General for the UNOSOM II mission in February 1994. The Nairobi Agreement committed the conflict parties to implement a ceasefire and disarm their militias. It further stipulated the formation of a government of national reconciliation thorough a conference to be held on 15 May 1994, at which a President, Vice-Presidents and a Prime Minister would be appointed.

A ceasefire was declared by both conflict parties on 1 August 1996, following the death of USC/SNA leader Mohammed Farah. However, heavy fighting erupted again in mid-August, after Aideed�s son, Hussein Aideed, had taken over the leadership of USC/SNA.

Although the USC/SSA led by Mahdi, which is considered the Government of Somalia by the UCDP, called for mediation by the UN, the USC/SNA rejected this proposal, stating it objected to outside interference. Nevertheless, between 9 and 15 October 1996, peace talks took place in Nairobi, under the aegis of Kenyan President Daniel Arap Moi. Moi�s mediation effort did not lead to the conclusion of a peace agreement, but the adversaries did commit to an immediate cessation of hostilities. The ceasefire lasted until December when renewed fighting broke out in Mogadishu.

However, in January 1997, a meeting did take place between Mahdi and Aideed, which was mediated by Italian Special Envoy Giuseppe Casini. The negotiations resulted in the conclusion of a ceasefire. Casini was now mandated by the EU, which closely coordinated its peacemaking efforts with Kenya.
Building on the momentum of the ceasefire, Kenya subsequently mediated negotiations in Nairobi in February 1997.
Between 4 and 12 May 1997, another round of talks was held in Yemen, which resulted in the conclusion of a ceasefire.
This ceasefire was confirmed at a round of negotiations between Aideed and Mahdi in Cairo on 29 May 1997.

Peace talks were resumed in Cairo on 12 November 1997, which resulted in the signing of the Cairo Declaration on Somalia on 22 December 1997. The parties reached a unanimous decision to establish a ceasefire and a cessation of hostilities. As part of the agreement, all armed forces were to be relocated to prearranged encampment sites. Subsequently, a joint security force for the National Reconciliation Conference would be established, although the agreement did not specify the exact composition of this force. The National Reconciliation Conference was scheduled to take place in Baidoa on 15 February 1998, and the agreement outlined the composition of delegates for this conference. The primary objective of the conference was to elect a Presidential Council, a Prime Minister, and to adopt a Transitional Charter. As part of the transitional process, the agreement also mandated the establishment of a Constituent Assembly and an independent judiciary. Crucially, the agreement emphasized that the Presidential Council and the Constituent Assembly were to be representative of the different Somali social groups. During the transitional period, a new constitution would be drafted and approved through a referendum. Finally, the agreement committed the parties to hold elections as soon as possible, completing the process of reconciliation and establishing a more stable and democratic political system in Somalia.

Peace talks, mediated by Kenyan President Moi�s Special Envoy for Somalia Elijah Wasike Mwangale, between the TNG and SRRC were held on 23 and 24 December 2001 in Nakuru, Kenya. These talks led to a ceasefire, but not any substantial outcome on political issues.

A Reconciliation Conference in Eldoret, Kenya, started in October 2002. Numerous third parties were involved, but IGAD called for the conference on 15 October 2002 and subsequently organised the conference. Mwangale acted as the chief mediator at Eldoret. The first round of negotiations mediated by IGAD ended with the signing of a ceasefire between the TNG and the opposing groups on 27 October 2002.
third_party: IGAD, US, UN, EU, Arab League, Egypt, Kenya, Ethiopia, Djibouti, Eritrea, Sudan, Uganda

description: Another round of negotiations mediated by IGAD took place in mid-December 2002. More than 300 participants were divided in six committees with 23 delegates and each were formed to deal with different aspects of the conflict. The committees included Federalism and Provisional Constitution, Demobilisation Disarmament and Reintegration, Land and Property Issues, Economic Recovery, Institution Building and Resource Mobilisation, and Regional and International Relations.
third_party: IGAD, US, UN, EU, Arab League, Egypt, Kenya, Ethiopia, Djibouti, Eritrea, Sudan, Uganda

description: Following a round of negotiations in July 2003, representatives from both sides signed the Somali Interim Charter. However, President Abduqassim Salad Hassan rejected the accord and sacked the TNG representatives that had signed the Interim Charter in August 2003.
third_party: IGAD, US, UN, EU, Arab League, Egypt, Kenya, Ethiopia, Djibouti, Eritrea, Sudan, Uganda

description: In November 2003, the UN Security Council urged all Somali leaders to reach an agreement on a viable government through a �Leaders meeting� that was being planned by IGAD in Kenya. The dates for the 10-day meeting were being pushed forward throughout December. At the end of the year, it was announced that the Conference would begin on 9 January 2004. Not much progress was made at the Somali peace conference in Kenya that started on 9 January 2004, when Ugandan and Kenyan mediators brought 38 Somali leaders into the Safari Park Hotel in Nairobi. The transitional charter agreed on in September 2003 was criticized during these negotiations. Three weeks later, on 29 January 2004, the Transitional Federal Charter for the Somali Republic, also referred to as the Safari Park Declaration, was signed by eight representatives. The agreement establishes the Transitional Federal Government (TFG) as the sovereign government of Somalia, as well as defines the TFG as a federation with State Governments, Regional Administrations, and District Administrations. The revised transitional charter immediately became contested and, after a month, only three of the signatories still supported the Declaration. Negotiations continued until October 2004. In early May, it seemed like the entire peace process would collapse. However, at the Sixth IGAD Ministerial Meeting on Somalia on 21 and 22 May 2004, the member states reaffirmed their unity of purpose and agreed to jointly push the process forward. The IGAD mediation team warned the Somali leaders that �spoilers and those who obstruct the process from within and outside SNRP [Somali National Reconciliation Process] will be named publicly and subject to targeted international sanctions.� A few days later, the AU also declared that targeted sanctions would be imposed against the Somali leaders who did not participate in the process. On 22 August 2004, the first 194 members of the Transitional Parliament were sworn in at the UN complex in Nairobi. During the nomination period, the breakaway leaders had returned to participate in the negotiations, as preparations were made for the election of a president. On 14 October 2004, the Transitional Parliament elected Abdullahi Yusuf as interim president. The TNG thus transformed into Transitional Federal Government (TFG) in 2004.
third_party: IGAD, Kenya, Uganda, AU, UN, US
agreement_name: Transitional Federal Charter for the Somali Republic

description: The AU and the UN were active as third parties in Somalia in 2008. Negotiations, mediated by the Special Representative for the UN Secretary-General for Somalia, Ahmedou Ould Abdalla, started in Djibouti on 31 May and lasted until 9 June 2008. The mediation team focused predominantly on securing a commitment to formal peace talks during the first half of 2008. The peace process gained momentum when the conflict parties agreed on the basic principles of the peace process on 9 June 2008. It was agreed that the Ethiopian forces, which had intervened in Somalia in July 2006, would withdraw. This last issue led the UIC to split in July.
The basic principles were subsequently laid down during a round of negotiations in August 2008. The principles were laid down in the Djibouti Agreement signed on 19 August 2008.

During another round of negotiations in November 2008, the Djibouti agreement was complemented on 26 November 2008. The Djibouti Agreement stipulated the immediate cessation of hostilities within a timeframe of 30 days and the withdrawal of Ethiopian troops from the region. Furthermore, the parties agreed to jointly request the United Nations to deploy an international stabilisation force within 120 days to ensure peace and stability in the area. As part of the agreement, a High-Level Committee was established to address issues of political cooperation between the parties involved. This committee would focus on fostering collaboration and understanding among the different groups. Additionally, the agreement provided for the formation of a Joint Security Committee, which was assigned the responsibility of devising and overseeing the implementation of security arrangements. The primary objective of this committee was to establish measures that would maintain security and prevent any potential resurgence of hostilities in the region. On 26 November, the two sides also came to an agreement on collaborating on Somalia Emergency Drought Relief (SEDR). Supplementing the UN Security Council arms embargo that had been in place since 1992, the UN, IGAD, and the AU repeatedly threatened to impose targeted sanctions throughout the mediation process in 2008. These sanctions would be aimed at individuals and entities obstructing the peace process.

An episode of armed fighting in north Mogadishu between different clans triggered peace talks in May 2009. The UIC and the Somali government were also involved in these negotiations. On 12 May 2009, UIC and the Somali government along with other actors signed a ceasefire.

An episode of armed fighting in north Mogadishu between different clans triggered peace talks in May 2009. The Al-Shabaab and the Somali government were also involved in these negotiations. On 12 May, Al-Shabaab and the Somali government along with other actors signed a ceasefire.

Somali state actors and international organizations have refrained from directly dealing with Al-Shabaab. Instead, they have occasionally employed clan elders to mediate negotiations with factions or induvial members of Al-Shabaab. One notable example is the defection of Hassan Dahir Aweys, who was Al-Shabaab�s former spiritual leader. Aweys initially resisted defection and refused to engage with the government. However, following pre-negotiation talks held in early 2013 and led by the highest-ranking elder of the Ayr/Habar Gidir clan, Ugas Hasan, Aweys eventually agreed to enter into direct negotiations with the Somali government.

The rebels advanced quickly during the first half of 1990. In an attempt to halt the chaos, ECOWAS launched a regional peacekeeping mission in August 1990, named the Economic Community of West African States Monitoring Group (ECOMOG). In addition to the deployment of ECOMOG, ECOWAS established a five-member Standing Mediation Committee with the task of achieving a peace settlement to the Liberian civil war. This committee had been set up at the 13th summit of the Heads of States of ECOWAS countries in Banjul, on 30 May 1990. This committee was chaired by Gambian President Dawda Jawara. On 7 August 1990, ECOWAS held the first mediation session at Banjul. At this meeting, ECOWAS presented a peace plan which called for a ceasefire, the establishment of ECOMOG, a national conference to establish a broad based interim government in Liberia, and elections within 12 months. The peace plan was rejected by the NPFL, as it objected an ECOWAS-sponsored interim government and an ECOWAS peacekeeping force.

Peace talks on 28 November 1990 led to the signing of the Bamako Ceasefire Agreement between the Government of Liberia, NPFL and INPFL. The agreement included a ceasefire provision, but the specific details and procedures for implementing it were left to be determined at a later time. ECOMOG was designated to monitor and oversee the ceasefire to ensure compliance by the parties involved. Additionally, the agreement addressed the resolution of disagreements regarding the establishment of an Interim Government for Liberia, which was part of the ECOWAS Peace Plan. This indicated that the NPFL and the INPFL accepted the ECOWAS Peace Plan as a framework for resolving the conflict. However, NPFL leader Charles Taylor did not see the endorsement of the Bamako agreement as an acceptance of President Sawyer, who had been sworn in as President of the Interim Government on 22 November 1990.

Talks continued. On 21 December 1990, the parties signed the Banjul IV agreement. The agreement built upon the ceasefire established in the Bamako agreement and added provisions for the formation of an Interim government. One significant aspect of the agreement was the designation of all seaports and airports as military-free zones, implying that military activities would be prohibited in those areas. Furthermore, it was agreed that an All-Liberian National Conference would take place within 60 days. The purpose of this conference was to facilitate discussions among various stakeholders on the practical details and procedures for establishing an interim regime. Once the Interim government was formed, one of its primary responsibilities would be to initiate the process of disarmament among the warring factions. This meant that the government would oversee the collection and surrender of weapons by the parties involved in the conflict.

The interim government sent out proposals to the warring parties on how to end the conflict in early February 1991, after which the ECOWAS Standing Mediating Committee continued negotiations in Togo on 12 and 13 February 1991. At these negotiations Gnassingbe Eyadem, the President of Togo, acted as the chief mediator. The negotiations led to the signing of the Lom� Ceasefire Agreement. This agreement provided detailed guidelines and procedures for the involvement of ECOMOG. However, the matter of disarmament for the fighters involved in the conflict was postponed. It was agreed that the process of disarmament would take place after the interim Government was reconstituted. According to the agreement, the installation of a new interim government was a crucial requirement. Additionally, it mandated that presidential and legislative elections must be held in October 1991. However, the peace process subsequently stalled, since the Government of Liberia insisted on disarmament prior to the installation of another interim government, whereas the NPFL insisted on the formation of a new interim government before disarmament.
On 1 March 1991, leaders from both sides met to affirm their intentions to work with ECOWAS to bring the conflict to a peaceful end.

Between 15 March and 18 April 1991, the All-Liberia National Conference was held, with the goal to discuss the distribution of political power in Liberia until the upcoming elections. Taylor sent an NPFL delegation, but refused to attend the talks himself. The conference formed an Interim government of National Unity to be led by Amos Sawyer. Elections were stipulated to be held in October 1991.

Four rounds of direct negotiations between Sawyer and Taylor were held in Yamossoukro between June and October 1991, under the auspices of ECOWAS and the International Negotiations Network (INN) of former US President Jimmy Carter. The first round of negotiations held in June led to the Yamossoukro I Peace Agreement on 30 June 1991.
The second round of negotiations held in July led to the Yamosoukro Peace Agreement II on 29 July 1991.
The third round of negotiations held in September led to the Yamosoukro III Peace Agreement on 17 September 1991.

The fourth round of negotiations held in October led to the Yamosoukro IV Peace Agreement on 30 October 1991. The Yamoussoukro IV agreement reinforced the provisions outlined in the previous agreements reached in Yamoussoukro. It restated the commitment to a ceasefire, the establishment of a buffer zone along the border between Liberia and Sierra Leone, and the responsibility of ECOMOG for disarmament activities. Furthermore, the agreement set a timeline for the holding of national elections within a period of six months. This emphasized the importance of conducting democratic elections to establish a legitimate government in Liberia. The UN Security Council passed Resolution 788 in November 1992, which reaffirmed the Yamoussoukro IV Accord as the best possible framework for a peaceful resolution of the Liberian conflict. Resolution 788 also imposed an arms embargo on Liberia, which continued to be in place in various forms until 2003.

The OAU appointed Reverend Canaan Banana, the former President of Zimbabwe, as its eminent person to Liberia in January 1993. Together with Gordon-Sommers, Banana was actively involved in peacemaking activities and discussed the establishment of a ceasefire with Charles Taylor in April 1993.

A UN-sponsored peace conference was held in the UN Palais des Nations in Geneva from 10 to 17 July 1993, under the joint chairmanship of the UN, ECOWAS, and the OAU. At this peace conference, Somers acted as the UN�s chief mediator, while the OAU�s eminent for Liberia person Canaan Banana acted as the OAU�s chief mediator. In addition, Nic�phore Soglo, President of Benin and chairman of ECOWAS, acted as the chief mediator of ECOWAS. Although the UN, ECOWAS, and the OAU cooperated in the Liberian peace process, there was some rivalry between the different third parties. The peace conference led to the signing of a peace agreement in Cotonou on 25 July 1993. In addition to the government and the NPLF, the United Liberation Movement of Liberia for Democracy (ULIMO) was also a signatory to this agreement. ULIMO had emerged in May 1991 as an anti-rebel party predominantly fighting the NPLF. The Cotonou Agreement established a ceasefire to be monitored by ECOMOG. As part of the agreement, the troops engaged in the conflict were required to remain in their respective locations until the process of encampment and subsequent demobilization could begin. The parties involved in the agreement also reached a consensus on the composition and scope of a transitional government. This transitional regime was granted full authority over the Liberian territory and incorporated several power-sharing arrangements across the executive, legislative, and judicial branches of government. The executive branch of the transitional government would consist of a five-member Council of State, with delegates selected by �prominent Liberians.� The transitional Assembly would comprise representatives from the government (13 members), the NPFL (13 members), and another armed group called the ULIMO (9 members). ULIMO was also given the right to nominate one delegate to the Supreme Court. Power-sharing principles were further applied in the formation of an elections commission, tasked with facilitating the preparations for general elections. Additionally, a general amnesty was declared, and a program was initiated to repatriate refugees and displaced persons. The agreement also included provisions for the release of all prisoners of war, aiming to foster reconciliation and stability in Liberia.

On 9 September 1994, NPFL announced a unilateral ceasefire. A round of negotiations mediated by Rawling led to the conclusion of the Akosombo Peace Agreement in Ghana on 12 September 1994. The Akosombo Peace Agreement served as a supplement to and amendment of the Cotonou agreement. In addition to reaffirming the ceasefire, the agreement introduced certain modifications to the provisions concerning the armed forces of Liberia. The agreement included specific details for the establishment of a new military force. It outlined that the demobilization of existing troops and the subsequent formation of a new national army would be the responsibility of the Transitional Government. Furthermore, the agreement specified that the Transitional Government would have a lifespan of approximately 16 months. It also mandated that elections were to be held on 10 October 1995.

At the time of the signing of the Akosombo Peace Agreement, the fighting was still raging throughout Liberia. In fact, Charles Taylor and his forces were being expelled from their headquarters in Gbarnga simultaneously to the peace process in Akosombo. Hence, the peace process continued and another conference started in Accra in November 1994 that led to a ceasefire agreement and a reaffirmation of the Akosombo agreement on 22 December 1994. The Accra Agreements � also known as the Akosombo clarification agreements � confirmed and further specified the Akosombo Agreement, as well as commits several non-signatories to the Akosombo Agreement.

In early 1995, a new round of negotiations between all the factions was mediated by Nigeria�s General Sani Abacha in Abuja. Prior to these talks, Abacha had held private consultations with NPFL leader Taylor for four days, which had led to a rapprochement between Nigeria and the NPFL. With Nigeria no long opposing his ambitions, Taylor became more amenable to a political solution to the conflict. A peace agreement was concluded in Abuja on 19 August 1995. The Abuja Accord managed to bring the leaders of all warring factions into the transitional government, which was installed on September 1995. The agreement amends and supplements the Cotonou Accord, the Akosombo Agreement, and the Accra Agreements. A new ceasefire was declared to take effect on 26 August 1995. The most important amendments to previously concluded agreements were minor shifts in the power-sharing arrangements between the parties.

In April 1996, heavy fighting broke out in Monrovia between the NPFL and fighters loyal to Roosevelt Johnson. Liberia�s Government forces were not involved in this fighting, but government representatives were involved in subsequent peace talks. At the behest of representatives from Nigeria and Ghana, the NPFL announced a unilateral ceasefire on 6 May. A new peace agreement, which was signed by both the NPFL and the Government of Liberia, was mediated by Abacha in Abuja on 17 August 1996, known as the Abuja II Agreement. The Abuja II peace agreement is an amended version of the former Abuja accord with minor amendments to the Transitional Government and an extension of its life-span. It confirmed the ceasefire and stipulated elections to be held in May 1997. At an OAU meeting in Yaound� earlier in July 1996, the OAU leaders had made it clear that if the ECOWAS assessment of the Liberian peace process would be negative, then the OAU would help sponsor a draft Resolution in the UN Security Council for the imposition of severe sanctions.

At the 13th summit of the Heads of States of ECOWAS countries, held in Banjul on 30 May 1990 under the chairmanship of Sir Dawda Jawara of Gambia, the member states decided to set up the five-member Standing Mediation Committee with the task of achieving a peace settlement to the Liberian civil war. Subsequent negotiations between the Government of Liberia and the INPFL in Gambia led to the signing of the Banjul III agreement on 24 October 1990. The Banjul III agreement had three main components. Firstly, it established a ceasefire arrangement. Secondly, it included a provision that required the troops to be confined to specific locations, which would be determined in consultation with ECOMOG. Once the troops were confined to these agreed-upon locations, the process of disarmament would begin. This meant that all combatants would be required to hand over their weapons. Thirdly, the agreement outlined some initial guidelines for establishing an interim government. To ensure that the agreement was properly carried out, the ECOWAS Standing Mediation Committee and ECOMOG were given the responsibility of supervising its implementation.

Another round of peace talks on 28 November 1990 led to the signing of the Bamako Ceasefire Agreement between the Government of Liberia, NPFL, and INPFL. The agreement included a ceasefire provision, but the specific details and procedures for implementing it were left to be determined at a later time. ECOMOG was designated to monitor and oversee the ceasefire to ensure compliance by the parties involved. Additionally, the agreement addressed the resolution of disagreements regarding the establishment of an Interim Government for Liberia, which was part of the ECOWAS Peace Plan. This indicated that the NPFL and the INPFL accepted the ECOWAS Peace Plan as a framework for resolving the conflict. However, NPFL leader Charles Taylor did not see the endorsement of the Bamako agreement as an acceptance of President Sawyer, who had been sworn in as President of the Interim Government on 22 November 1990.

Talks continued and the parties signed the Banjul IV agreement on 21 December. The agreement built upon the ceasefire established in the Bamako agreement and added provisions for the formation of an Interim government. One significant aspect of the agreement was the designation of all seaports and airports as military-free zones, implying that military activities would be prohibited in those areas. Furthermore, it was agreed that an All-Liberian National Conference would take place within 60 days. The purpose of this conference was to facilitate discussions among various stakeholders on the practical details and procedures for establishing an interim regime. Once the Interim government was formed, one of its primary responsibilities would be to initiate the process of disarmament among the warring factions. This meant that the government would oversee the collection and surrender of weapons by the parties involved in the conflict.

The interim Government of Liberia sent out proposals to the warring parties on how to end the conflict in early February 1991, after which the ECOWAS Standing Mediating Committee continued negotiations in Togo on 12 and 13 February 1991. At these negotiations Gnassingbe Eyadem, the President of Togo, acted as the chief mediator of the Standing Mediating Committee. The negotiations led to the signing of the Lom� Ceasefire Agreement. This agreement provided detailed guidelines and procedures for the involvement of ECOMOG. However, the matter of disarmament for the fighters involved in the conflict was postponed. It was agreed that the process of disarmament would take place after the interim Government was reconstituted. According to the agreement, the installation of a new interim government was a crucial requirement. Additionally, it mandated that presidential and legislative elections must be held in October 1991.

On 15 March 1991, the All-Liberia National Conference was held to discuss the distribution of political power in Liberia until the upcoming elections. Taylor sent an NPFL delegation, but refused to attend the talks himself. The conference formed an Interim government of National Unity to be led by Amos Sawyer. Elections were stipulated to be held in October 1991. The INPFL was subsequently excluded from the Yamossoukro peace talks held between the government and the NPFL between June and October 1991.

The conflict parties started another round of negotiations on 12 June 2003 in order to conclude a ceasefire agreement in preparation for negotiations on a political solution to the conflict. This round of negotiations resulted in the conflict parties agreeing on a ceasefire on 17 June 2003, in which a clause was included that Charles Taylor would not be included in the transitional government.

As another round of negotiations unfolded in Accra between July and August 2003, the participants focused on the details of an interim government. The President of Ghana, John Agyekum Kufuor, who had assumed the role of Chairman of ECOWAS on 31 January 2003, also acted as a mediator at these talks, but Abubakar continued to act as the chief mediator. On 5 August 2003, the conflict parties declared a ceasefire. Finally, on 18 August 2003, the Accra Agreement was signed. The Accra Agreement outlined the establishment of a transitional power-sharing government known as the National Transitional Government of Liberia (NTGL), which was scheduled to be installed on 14 October 2003 and mandated to govern until January 2006. The NTGL was granted full authority over the unified country. The NTGL comprised a total of 76 members, with representation from various parties: 12 members from the three warring factions, 18 members from political parties, seven members from civil society and special interest groups, and one member from each of Liberia�s 15 counties. The agreement also set a deadline for holding elections, which had to take place no later than 2005. In addition to reaffirming the earlier ceasefire, the parties agreed to a comprehensive national process that encompassed cantonment, disarmament, demobilization, rehabilitation, and reintegration of the armed forces. The agreement stipulated the creation of a new national army that would include combatants from all parties involved in the conflict, as well as civilians with relevant qualifications and experience. ECOMOG, the regional peacekeeping force, was entrusted with the responsibility of establishing a multinational peacekeeping force to maintain peace and stability during the transitional period. The agreement also addressed important humanitarian aspects. It emphasized the repatriation of refugees and internally displaced persons, recommended the implementation of a general amnesty, and proposed the establishment of a truth and reconciliation commission to address past grievances and promote national healing.
In follow-up negotiations mediated by ECOWAS in November 2003, the Government of Liberia, MODEL, and LURD signed a disarmament agreement on 3 November 2003.

MODEL had not participated in the peace talks in Sierra Leone in early 2003, but did participate in negotiations starting in Akosombo in early June 2003. These negotiations took place within the framework of the ECOWAS Peace Process for Liberia and were mediated by General Abdulsalami Abubakar, the former Head of State of Nigeria. Throughout the negotiations, chief mediator Abubakar employed a mediation strategy aimed at facilitating consensus among the conflict parties. However, the negotiations were simultaneously influenced by pressure from external actors. Arguably the most external influence came from an indictment against Charles Taylor. Just as the negotiations were to begin, on 4 June 2003, the Special Court for Sierra Leone, which was established by the UN Security Council, issued an indictment against Charles Taylor for complicity in crimes against humanity in Sierra Leone. Consequently, Ghana had to decide whether to hand over Taylor or not. Many of the participants commented on the possible removal of Taylor as being in violation with African hospitality. Indeed, in line with earlier statements on the absolute safety of all participants in the negotiations, the Government of Ghana refused to turn over Taylor. Nonetheless, later that same day, Charles Taylor left Accra and went back to Monrovia, while negotiations would continue according to schedule. Although Charles Taylor stayed in close contact with the representatives of the Government of Liberia present in Accra, his departure had a profound effect on the dynamics of the negotiations. Before the indictment of Taylor, the prospect for the conclusion of a peace agreement seemed bleak. Most participants of the negotiations believed President Taylor would never give up his presidency, while the rebel parties would never compromise on their main demand of Taylor�s immediate removal. These insurmountable positions remained relevant when Taylor left Accra, as he still had no intention of giving up the presidency. However, the indictment resulted in Taylor losing any last support from international partners and de-legitimatized him. It also affected the morale of his troops, who had not been paid in months at that time. These developments negatively affected Taylor�s bargaining position in the negotiations.

The conflict parties started another round of negotiations on 12 June 2003 in order to conclude a ceasefire agreement in preparation for negotiations on a political solution to the conflict. This round of negotiations resulted in the conflict parties agreeing on a ceasefire on 17 June 2003, in which a clause was included that Charles Taylor would not be included in the transitional government.

As another round of negotiations unfolded in Accra between July and August 2003, the participants focused on the details of an interim government. The President of Ghana, John Agyekum Kufuor, who had assumed the role of Chairman of ECOWAS on 31 January 2003, also acted as a mediator at these talks, but Abubakar continued to act as the chief mediator. On 5 August 2003, the conflict parties declared a ceasefire. Finally, on 18 August 2003, the Accra Agreement was signed. The Accra Agreement outlined the establishment of a transitional power-sharing government known as the National Transitional Government of Liberia (NTGL), which was scheduled to be installed on 14 October 2003 and mandated to govern until January 2006. The NTGL was granted full authority over the unified country. The NTGL comprised a total of 76 members, with representation from various parties: 12 members from the three warring factions, 18 members from political parties, seven members from civil society and special interest groups, and one member from each of Liberia�s 15 counties. The agreement also set a deadline for holding elections, which had to take place no later than 2005. In addition to reaffirming the earlier ceasefire, the parties agreed to a comprehensive national process that encompassed cantonment, disarmament, demobilization, rehabilitation, and reintegration of the armed forces. The agreement stipulated the creation of a new national army that would include combatants from all parties involved in the conflict, as well as civilians with relevant qualifications and experience. ECOMOG, the regional peacekeeping force, was entrusted with the responsibility of establishing a multinational peacekeeping force to maintain peace and stability during the transitional period. The agreement also addressed important humanitarian aspects. It emphasized the repatriation of refugees and internally displaced persons, recommended the implementation of a general amnesty, and proposed the establishment of a truth and reconciliation commission to address past grievances and promote national healing.
In follow-up negotiations mediated by ECOWAS in November 2003, the Government of Liberia, MODEL, and LURD signed a disarmament agreement on 3 November 2003.

The first substantive negotiations between the ANC and the government took place in Cape Town between 2 and 4 May 1990. At the end of the meeting, the parties signed a joint declaration of intent to end violence and begin negotiations. This declaration was referred to as the Groote Schuur Minute.

Another round of negotiations in August 1990 led to the signing of the Pretoria Minute on 6 August 1990. The Pretoria Minute stipulated an end to the use of violence by the ANC its military wing Umkhonto we Sizwe and also stipulated an end to the state of emergency.

During negotiations in January 1991, the ANC leadership presented a proposal for an all-party congress which would be tasked with negotiating and drafting a new constitution. This was a major concession, as the ANC had up to this point maintained that the constitution should be drafted by an assembly appointed through democratic elections.

This concession paved the way for a round of negotiations in September 1991 that led to the signing of the National Peace Accord on 14 September 1991. This agreement was signed by representatives of twenty-seven political organisations and the government and prepared the way for the all-party congress, named the Convention for a Democratic South Africa (CODESA).

The CODESA began on 20 December 1991. Delegates of nineteen political groups engaged in negotiations and aimed to draft an interim constitution at this conference, which resulted in the signing of a declaration of intent that outlined the basic principles of the future constitution.

Attempts to resume negotiations were initially rejected by the ANC, but Cyril Ramaphosa and Roelf Meyer, the chief negotiators for the ANC and the Government of South Africa respectively, conducted negotiations in September 1992. No international third party was involved in these negotiations. These talks culminated in the Record of Understanding signed by Nelson Mandela and de Klerk on 26 September 1992. The Record of Understanding commits the conflict parties to curbing factional violence. It also established a ban on the public display and carrying of weapons. The parties further reaffirm the need for a democratically elected constitution-making body and that this parliament could have one or two chambers. It also stipulated the need for a transitional government of national unity. The Interim Constitution was adopted as the Constitution of the Republic of South Africa Act 200 of 1993. The Interim Constitution was replaced by the final constitution, adopted by the democratically elected national assembly, on 18 December 1996.

The Algerian government called for a ceasefire and invited the Government of Mali, the MPA and another rebel group, the Tuareg group Front islamique arabe de l�Azaouad (FIAA) (English: Islamic Arab Front of Azawad), to negotiate to find a peaceful solution to the crisis. Negotiations, mediated by Algeria, on 5 and 6 January 1991 led to the conclusion of the Tamanrasset Agreement. The Minister of Interior Department of Algeria acted as the chief mediator at these negotiations. The first point of the agreement called for a ceasefire and an end to hostilities. The ceasefire did not involve giving up any territory, instead, the opposing forces would remain in their current locations. This meant that the rebels would continue occupying northern Mali for the time being. Later on, a phased withdrawal would demilitarize the North. The agreement also included the demobilization of rebel forces, with the option of integrating them into the armed forces. It was agreed that Mali�s armed forces would not interfere in internal political activities. A joint commission, including Algeria as the mediator, would monitor the ceasefire. The agreement granted internal autonomy to the Adrar region (Gao and Timbuktu), and additional state funds were allocated for its development. Finally, the agreement stipulated the release of all prisoners.

Another round of negotiations in April 1992 led to the signing of the National Pact on 11 April 1992. Ahmed Baba Miske, a representative from Mauritania, and Edgar Pisani, a representative from France, also played a role in the mediation leading up to the National Pact. The National Pact was signed in Bamako, Mali, as a finalization of the Mopti Accord in 1991. The agreement established a new ceasefire, preventing any further troop movements and freezing the armed forces in their current locations. A military pact was formed, allowing voluntary integration of the Tuareg rebels into various branches of the armed forces, such as the military, police, or gendarmerie. Complete demilitarization of the North was planned. The agreement also modified Mali�s political structure by decentralizing authority to regional and sub-regional assemblies with executive powers. These assemblies had control over socio-economic, cultural, and budgetary aspects of governance. Special administrative structures were established for the Adrar region. To enhance representation, four seats in the assembly were designated for delegates from the Northern peoples of Mali. Efforts were made to integrate ex-rebels into different levels of government institutions, aiming for fuller inclusion of the Tuareg in the country�s political and economic spheres.

The Algerian government called for a ceasefire and invited the Government of Mali, the FIAA and another rebel group, the Mouvement populaire de l�Azaouad (MPA) (English: Azawad People�s Movement), to negotiate to find a peaceful solution to the crisis. Negotiations, mediated by Algeria, on 5 and 6 January 1991 led to the conclusion of the Tamanrasset Agreement. The Minister of Interior Department of Algeria acted as the chief mediator at these negotiations. The first point of the agreement called for a ceasefire and an end to hostilities. The ceasefire did not involve giving up any territory, instead, the opposing forces would remain in their current locations. This meant that the rebels would continue occupying northern Mali for the time being. Later on, a phased withdrawal would demilitarize the North. The agreement also included the demobilization of rebel forces, with the option of integrating them into the armed forces. It was agreed that Mali�s armed forces would not interfere in internal political activities. A joint commission, including Algeria as the mediator, would monitor the ceasefire. The agreement granted internal autonomy to the Adrar region (Gao and Timbuktu), and additional state funds were allocated for its development. Finally, the agreement stipulated the release of all prisoners.

Another round of negotiations in April 1992 led to the signing of the National Pact on 11 April 1992. Ahmed Baba Miske, a representative from Mauritania, and Edgar Pisani, a representative from France, also played a role in the mediation leading up to the National Pact. The National Pact was signed in Bamako, Mali, as a finalization of the Mopti Accord in 1991. The agreement established a new ceasefire, preventing any further troop movements and freezing the armed forces in their current locations. A military pact was formed, allowing voluntary integration of the Tuareg rebels into various branches of the armed forces, such as the military, police, or gendarmerie. Complete demilitarization of the North was planned. The agreement also modified Mali�s political structure by decentralizing authority to regional and sub-regional assemblies with executive powers. These assemblies had control over socio-economic, cultural, and budgetary aspects of governance. Special administrative structures were established for the Adrar region. To enhance representation, four seats in the assembly were designated for delegates from the Northern peoples of Mali. Efforts were made to integrate ex-rebels into different levels of government institutions, aiming for fuller inclusion of the Tuareg in the country�s political and economic spheres.

The first negotiations between the conflict parties took place in Tripoli in April 2007 and were mediated by the Gaddafi Foundation, which was a charitable organization chaired by Libyan leader Muammar al-Gaddafi�s son Saif al Islam. These talks led to a ceasefire, which also stipulated that the rebels were to release any soldiers being held hostage, while the Malian army was to partly withdraw from the Kidal area. The parties expressed in a joint statement that the ceasefire would create a climate of appeasement which would open the way for a dialogue to forge a final settlement. However, the ceasefire soon broke down with both parties accusing each other of not implementing it.

In June 2007, the Malian Foreign Minister Moctar Ouane went to Algeria to meet with President Abdelaziz Bouteflika to request mediation by Algeria. Bouteflika agreed, after which Abdelkrim Ghrieb, the Algerian Ambassador to Mali, acted as the main mediator in peace talks in July 2007, which led to a new ceasefire on 21 July 2007.
On 31 August 2007, the conflict parties engaged in negotiations without the involvement of a third party. This led to a ceasefire, but this ceasefire did not appear to last.
On 19 September 2007, a temporary ceasefire was concluded in negotiations in which elected Tuareg officials served as mediators.
During a round of negotiations in the first week of April, the conflict parties agreed to a ceasefire agreement in Tripoli on 3 April 2008.
Another ceasefire agreement was negotiated in Algiers on 21 July 2008, but this ceasefire failed to bring peace.

Another round of negotiations mediated by Algeria in April 1992 led to the signing of the National Pact on 11 April 1992. Ahmed Baba Miske, a representative from Mauritania, and Edgar Pisani, a representative from France, also played a role in the mediation leading up to the National Pact. The National Pact was signed in Bamako, Mali, as a finalization of the Mopti Accord in 1991. The agreement established a new ceasefire, preventing any further troop movements and freezing the armed forces in their current locations. A military pact was formed, allowing voluntary integration of the Tuareg rebels into various branches of the armed forces, such as the military, police, or gendarmerie. Complete demilitarization of the North was planned. The agreement also modified Mali�s political structure by decentralizing authority to regional and sub-regional assemblies with executive powers. These assemblies had control over socio-economic, cultural, and budgetary aspects of governance. Special administrative structures were established for the Adrar region. To enhance representation, four seats in the assembly were designated for delegates from the Northern peoples of Mali. Efforts were made to integrate ex-rebels into different levels of government institutions, aiming for fuller inclusion of the Tuareg in the country�s political and economic spheres. FPLA�s representative in MFUA was Zeidane ag Sidi Alamine, who was a relative of FPLA leader Rhissa ag Sidi Mohamed. Rhissa and Zeidane disagreed about whether or not to sign the National Pact when it was on the table. Rhissa continued to refuse to sign, but Zeidane travelled to Bamako to sign it on behalf of the FPLA. However, with Zeidane unable to exert influence over the fighters on the ground at this point in time, attacks on government targets continued. On 27 March 1996, the so-called Flame of Peace ceremony was held in Timbuktu to symbolically mark the end of the armed conflict. Around 3,000 decommissioned weapons were destroyed in a giant fire. Furthermore, Zeidane ag Sidalamine, representing not only FPLA, but the entire rebel movement in northeren Mali, announced the formal dissolution of all major rebel groups.

The MNLA had concluded an alliance with the Islamist insurgent group, Ansar Dine, which resulted in military successes and the MNLA had announced the creation of the independent state of Azawad on 6 April 2012. However, soon thereafter the tactical alliance broke down and Ansar Dine evicted MNLA from the towns in the region. By late 2012, most MNLA fighters were based in the countryside, attempting to regroup. On 4 December 2012, MNLA and Ansar Dine again met for a round of talks with Compaor� in Ouagadougou. The conflict parties agreed during this round of negotiations to end hostilities with the government.

Another round of mediated talks mediated by Blaise Compaor� was held in Ouagadougou between 8 and 10 June 2013 and brought together MNLA and Ansar Dine representatives. This round of negotiations focused on establishing an agenda for peace talks and led to the Ouagadougou Accord on 18 June 2013, which was a preliminary agreement that stipulated an immediate ceasefire, as well as commits the conflict parties to create the conditions for holding presidential elections and outlined the principles for future inclusive peace talks. The full name of this agreement is the Accord pr�liminaire � l��lection pr�sidentielle et aux pourparlers inclusifs de paix au Mali (English: Preliminary agreement for the presidential election and inclusive peace talks in Mali).

Between February and June 2014, consultations were held in Algeria, intended to bring together the many disparate groupings of the North under one unified front. MINUSMA facilitated three short workshops with representatives of the Government of Mali, local authorities, armed groups, and civil society in Algiers between 3 February and early March 2014. The conflict parties reaffirmed their willingness during these workshops to take part in an inclusive dialogue to reach a comprehensive settlement of the armed conflict. These workshops also resulted in the signing of a technical document on 18 February by all present. This document outlined the steps that needed to be taken to further the cantonment process. UN Security Council Resolution 2100 (2013), a February visit by its members, as well as the Ouagadougou Agreement informed the agreement�s timeframe for the cantonment process.
On 18 May 2014, a MINUSMA delegation led by mediator Major General Jean Bosco Kazura attempted to mediate a ceasefire between MNLA and the government in response to a recent episode of fighting.

Between 14 and 19 April 2015, the CMA delegation in Algiers maintained that it would sign the draft peace agreement if the mediator could guarantee that some outstanding issues would be addressed during the implementation process.

The Government of Mali and the CMA subsequently met in Algiers on 30 May 2015 for a new round of negotiations, while fighting continued in the north despite the previously concluded ceasefire. This round ended with the conflict parties signing the Relev� de Conclusions des Consultations Pr�paratoires � la mise en �uvre de l�Accord pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali Issu du Procesus d�Alger (English: Statement of Conclusions of the Preparatory Consultations for the Implementation of the Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation in Mali Arising from the Algiers Process) on 5 June, which addressed stipulated the creation of two regions in Mali, the integration of rebel fighters into the national army, and several arrangements to promote regional economic development. On the same day, the conflict parties also signed another ceasefire, the Arrangement s�curitaire pour une cessation des hostilit�s (English: Security Arrangements for a Cessation of Hostilities).
agreement_name: Relev� de Conclusions des Consultations Pr�paratoires a la mise en �uvre de l�Accord pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali Issu du Procesus d�Alger, Ceasefire (Arrangement s�curitaire pour une cessation des hostilit�s)

description: This paved the way for the CMA finally signing a comprehensive peace agreement in Bamako on 20 June 2015: the Accord Pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali - Issu du Processus d�Alger (English: Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation in Mali - Resulting from the Algiers Process), also referred to as the Bamako Agreement.
agreement_name: Accord Pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali - Issu du Processus d�Alger (Bamako Agreement)

description: The CSA�s efforts to implement the Bamako Peace Agreement continued in 2016. The CMA and the other non-state signatory to the agreement, Platform, were both unhappy with the slow pace of the implementation of the agreement. Hence, the signatories met in Bamako on 19-26 February 2016, but no progress was made. While the Government of Mali presented the measures that it had taken, including the creation of the M�naka and Taoudenni regions and the review of the Code des collectivit�s territoriales, the signatory armed groups, in a joint letter, deplored the lack of progress on the establishment of the interim administrations, reiterating the need for further efforts on institutional issues before moving forward on security and defense aspects.
third_party: Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU

description: In June 2018, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 2423, calling for the signing of a �Pact for Peace� by the Malian parties. At a meeting in October 2018, the Malians parties signed this Pact for Peace, emphasizing the urgency of taking steps to �accelerate the full and inclusive implementation� of the agreement.

On 16 January 2018, a CSA meeting also attended by the CMA led to the endorsement of a timeline to accelerate the implementation of key provisions of the Bamako Agreement. By September 2018, signatory parties made some progress in the implementation of the Agreement, including the nomination of interim authorities at the district level, the creation of municipalities for the M�naka and Taoudenni regions, and the adoption of the national security sector reform strategy.
third_party: Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU

description: On 22 August 2019, the signatories to the 2015 peace agreement held a working session in Bamako. This meeting was chaired by the Minister of Social Cohesion, with support from the Carter Center, to examine in detail the progress made with regard to implementing the peace agreement.

A political crisis and the COVID-19 pandemic brought the implementation of the 2015 peace agreement to a standstill. The CSA held its first-ever meetings outside of Bamako, namely in Kidal, in February 2021. The CSA comprises the Government of Mali, the CMA, Platform, as well as the mediation team chaired by Algeria and further including Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the United Nations, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, the African Union, and the European Union.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Another CSA meeting was held in Kayes in March 2021. However, shortly after this meeting, two specific events further stymied the implementation process during the first half of 2021. First, on 13 April 2021, CMA leader Sidi Brahim Ould Sidat was assassinated. Second, a second coup d��tat took place on 24 May 2021.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: According to the Carter Center, which acted as the official observer of the implementation process of the Agreement on Peace and Reconciliation in Mali concluded in 2015, the implementation had reached a state of unprecedented impasse in its seventh year. The CSA met in October 2021, but this meeting ended when intense disagreements broke out among the signatories. After this meeting, the work of the CSA and its various subgroups was suspended.

The signatories to the 2015 peace agreement held a working session in Bamako on 16-17 February 2022. The working session was chaired by the Minister of Social Cohesion, with support from the Carter Center, to examine in detail the progress made with regard to implementing the peace agreement.

On 16 March 2022, the signatories to the Algiers Accord met in Gao to address their ongoing disagreements, particularly regarding the creation and mission of the Cadre strat�gique permanent (CSP) (English: Permanent strategic coalition), which was formed by the CMA and Platform to strengthen the relations between them, but was also envisioned as a key security provider in the northern regions. The Government of Mali insisted that security matters should remain under the state�s authority and that any concerns raised by the movements should be resolved within the framework of the peace agreement. However, there was no concrete resolution reached.

Although the CSA did no longer meet, the Technical Security Commission (CTS) � tasked with monitoring the ceasefire, investigating potential violations, and monitoring security arrangements � met on 31 March 2022.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Although the CSA did no longer meet, the Technical Security Commission (CTS) � tasked with monitoring the ceasefire, investigating potential violations, and monitoring security arrangements � met on 16 June 2022.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: A high-level decision-making meeting was held in Bamako from 1 to 5 August 2022, attended by the Prime Minister, ministers, the High Representative of the transitional President for the implementation of the Agreement, and leaders of the signatory movements. The members of the international mediation team and the Carter Center, acting as the Independent Observer, were also present at this meeting. During this meeting, the Malian parties reached an agreement on the integration of ex-combatants into the national defense and security forces and the public administration in two phases.
The CSA, having been inactive since October 2021, restarted by initiating a ministerial meeting on 2 September 2022.
