third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Consultations were held among the signatories of the Algiers Accord in Bamako on 9 and 10 January 2023 to discuss the way forward regarding the peace agreement. The former Minister for Foreign Affairs of Algeria, Ramtane Lamamra acted as the mediator.

The international mediation team � including Algeria, the UN, ECOWAS, the AU, the EU, France, and the US � shuttled between the conflict parties in February 2023. On 1 February 2023, the international mediation team met with the CMA leadership in Kidal to discuss the viability of the Algiers Accord concluded in 2015. On 13 February 2023, the international mediation team held discussions with the Platform and the Mouvements de l�inclusivit� in Bamako. The international mediation team conducted a meeting with government officials on 14 February 2023. Following these meetings, the international mediation team called on the parties on 20 February 2023, to demonstrate renewed commitment and to refrain from any statements or actions that could further complicate the situation and efforts for the early holding of a high-level session of the CSA.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: The Minister for Reconciliation, Peace, and National Cohesion, Colonel-Major Isma�l Wagu�, met with representatives of the CMA and Platform in Kidal on 12 May 2023 to rebuild confidence and facilitate the resumption of the work of the monitoring mechanisms. However, tensions increased and the Platform movements left the CSP in September 2023.

In June 1994, negotiations between the CRA and the Government of Niger began in Paris. France served as mediator, together with Algeria and Burkina Faso. After the talks, the government agreed to meet the CRA demands for autonomy for Tuareg regions, which would be governed by elected assemblies and governors. The government agreed, in principle, to the carving out of a new administrative map, taking account of �cultural and social homogeneity.� The agreement also included a quota system which would guarantee Tuaregs a fair share of government jobs and military positions.

In October 1994, the negotiations resumed in Ouagadougou, where Burkina Faso initially solely hosted the meetings with no external mediators involved in the talks, but later mediators from France and Algeria joined and participated in the talks. The talks led to the signing of the Ouagadougou Accord on 9 October 1994. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire, but also stated that the issues of defence and internal security would be dealt with at a later stage of the negotiations. The agreement emphasized that Niger was unitary and indivisible, but also contained amendments to the political-territorial structure of Niger, rearranging the country into smaller entities of political control. Finally, the accord included provisions with regard the facilitation of the return and resettlement of refugees.

Another round of negotiations mediated by these third parties took place in April 1995. This led to the signing of a comprehensive peace agreement in Niamey on 24 April 1995. The agreement had several key points. First, it declared a ceasefire and confirmed the previous ceasefire established in 1994. Second, it required the restructuring of Niger�s armed forces by integrating rebel fighters into the government army. Third, it included measures for decentralizing Niger�s political system. The agreement specifically focused on promoting the economic, social, and cultural development of the Tuareg areas. To oversee the agreement�s implementation, a peace committee was established. Additionally, the government announced a general amnesty and initiated a resettlement program to assist those who were displaced, both within the country and externally.

At another meeting in November 1995, following a clash in which one Tuareg was killed, both the government and the CRA reaffirmed their commitment to peace agreement. This meeting came after the most serious clash since the April Peace Accord was signed.

On 18 March 1996, the transitional government recognized the CRA as a political party. On 17 December 1996, the government held some peace talks with the CRA and other Tuareg groups. This led to the signing of an agreement providing for the return to barracks of former Tuareg fighters, which was agreed to precede the integration of the former Tuareg rebels back into the regular army.
To signal their respect of the ongoing peace efforts, Rwanda and FPR concluded a ceasefire agreement, without any direct negotiations between them, on 24 October 1990.

The third ad-hoc summit was the Goma summit on 20 November attended by the Presidents of Zaire, Rwanda, and Burundi, as well as the third deputy Prime Minister of Uganda. The Zairian President Mobutu Sese Seko acted as the chief mediator of the countries in the region during these three summits. Mobutu�s appointment was in large part based on the idea that he could prevail over Habyarimana, thus delivering the agreement of the conflict party that the mediator favoured. Although no real attempts to bring the FPR in seemed to be made, talks were held between Ugandan President Museveni and Habyarimana, where the former promised to put pressure on the FPR to commit to a ceasefire. In addition, most of the regional conferences focused on the refugee problem, which was at least in part due to the perception that the refugee problem forced the FPR into Rwanda.

Meetings between countries in the region continued to be held in early 1991 through the efforts of both the CEPGL and the OAU, in which the participants discussed the refugee situation, as well as the possibility of the deployment of a neutral peacekeeping force in Rwanda. A summit was held in Zanzibar on 17 February 1991.

While little effort was made to include the FPR in negotiations during the summits in 1990, the regional leaders persuaded President Habyarimana to engage in peace talks with the FPR leadership during the summits in early 1991. At the Dar-es-Salaam summit on 19 February, a declaration was drafted in which President Mobutu was thanked �for his efforts in instituting a dialogue between the Rwandan government and the armed opposition� and urged him to �maintain the momentum of the dialogue.� The Declaration further committed the conflict parties to �find a definitive and durable solution to the problem.� Accordingly, the Government of Rwanda and the FPR met for the first time in March 1991. Under Mobutu�s mediation, the conflict parties agreed to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 17 March 1991, which was signed by Rwandan Foreign Minister Casimir Bizimugu and FPR vice-Chairman Paul Kagame in N�Sele on 29 March 1991. This agreement stipulated a ceasefire and the deployment of a Neutral Military Observer Group, comprised of personnel from Nigeria, Senegal, Zimbabwe, the OAU, and representatives of the warring parties. The agreement � referred to as the N�Sele Ceasefire Agreement � did not include provisions on how to resolve the conflict issues. Instead, the document included a short agenda for future talks, specifying that rule of law and democracy should be created, that the formation of a new national army should commence, and that power-sharing arrangements need to be established. The ceasefire did not hold, with government forces attacking FPR forces almost immediately after the Neutral Military Observer Group was deployed on 7 May 1991.

Direct talks between the Rwandan Government and the FPR continued in Gbadolite between 15 and 17 September 1991. Zairian President Mobutu acted as mediator at these talks, which ended with the parties expressing their commitment to the N�Sele Ceasefire Agreement. The Gbadolite Ceasefire did not hold.

The first round of negotiations in Arusha started on 10 July 1992. This led to the signing of a temporary ceasefire agreement. This followed three more days of peace talks. Although Zairian President Mobutu was present at the first round of the negotiations in Arusha, the Tanzanian mediation team was most actively involved in the negotiations. In fact, at the meeting in Gbadolite in September 1991, the Tanzanian President Ali Hassan Mwinyi had been mandated by the regional countries to mediate. While Mobuto officially continued to be the mediator, Mwinyi officially was appointed the chief facilitator. Hence, although Mobutu continued to be the chief mediator on paper, Miwinyi in reality assumed the role of chief mediator. Mobutu became increasingly less active from the second round of the Arusha talks onwards and the first three rounds of negotiations in June, July, and August were primarily led by the Tanzanian Minister of Foreign Affairs Hassan Ahmed, aided by Ami Mpungwe, who worked for the Tanzanian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The first three rounds focused on the implementation of the new ceasefire, as well as the integration of the FPR in the army and the issues of democracy and national unity.
The second round of negotiations in late July led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 31 July 1992.
In October 1992, during a fourth round of negotiations, a partial accord on power sharing was signed in Arusha.

However, during peace talks in November 1992, the parties failed to agree on the creation of a neutral zone for the OAU observers, as well as on the issue of repatriation of refugees, the participation of the FPR in the transitional government, and the final incorporation of the FPR in the Rwandan army.

Another round of negotiations started in January 1993. This led to the signing of a protocol on power sharing in Arusha. However, President Habyarimana�s political party the Mouvement r�publicain national pour la d�mocratie et le d�velopement (MRND) (English: National Republican Movement for Democracy and Development) immediately rejected the agreement. This round of negotiations subsequently broke down in early February 1993.

A month later, in March 1993, new peace talks were convened in Arusha, in which the Tanzanian President Ali Hassan Mwinyi acted as the chief mediator. The talks focused on the structure of the Rwandan armed forces, but the parties could not reach an agreement on this issue. Nevertheless, the conflict parties signed a ceasefire on 7 March 1993.

A new round of negotiations started in Kinihira in May 1993. During this round of peace talks, progress was made. A timetable for the demobilisation of the 19,000 troops of security forces was agreed upon. Consensus was also reached on the creation of a neutral zone to be observed by the OAU observer group. Moreover, an agreement was signed for the establishment of transitional structures and the demilitarisation of Kigali.

The final round of negotiations in Arusha took place in August 1993 and led to the signing of the Arusha Accord on 4 August 1993. This agreement included all the provisions agreed upon during the Arusha talks from July 1992 onwards.

In 1994, the UN and the OAU initiated several attempts to negotiate ceasefires during the ongoing genocide. On 8 April 1994, the two sides reached a 48-hour ceasefire agreement during negotiations in Kigali.
Two other ceasefire agreements were reached during negotiations between 12 and 13 April 1994.
On 5 May 1994, General Rom�o Dallaire, the Force Commander of the UN peacekeeping mission in Rwanda, brokered a ceasefire between the FPR and Rwandan government.
On 6 May 1994, the two sides reached a ceasefire in Gbadolite, as well as agreed on another round of peace talks two days later.
Ahead of the arrival of the UN special envoy, a temporary truce was brokered between the conflict parties on 22 May.
On 13 June 1994, the Government of Rwanda and the FPR attended a round of ceasefire talks mediated by the UN in Kigali.
A day later, on 14 June 1994, a round of negotiations mediated by Zaire led to the signing of another ceasefire agreement.

No negotiations have taken place between the Government of Rwanda and ALiR. However, on 3 June 2000, negotiations took place between DRC President Kabila and Rwandan President Kagame in Eldoret in Kenya. The talks were mediated by Kenyan President arap Moi, with support from diplomats from the UN and the OAU. The talks were aimed at ending the Congolese support to ALiR and ending the Rwandan support to the RCD.

The FDLR repeatedly called for an inter-Rwandan dialogue, but the Government of Rwanda continued to refuse to talk to any group connected to the genocide. However, talks occasionally did take place between Rwanda and Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). On 30 July 2002, Rwandan and Congolese presidents, Kagame and Kabila signed an accord in Pretoria under Mbeki�s watch. Kabila pledged to disarm and arrest Rwandan Hutu militias in return for Rwandan troops withdrawing.

On 12 September 2002, Presidents Kabila and Kagame met with US President Bush on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly meeting in New York. They were joined by chief mediator South African President Mbeki. The talks focused on the status of Rwandan troop withdrawal from the DRC and the disarmament and repatriation of armed Rwandan groups based in the DRC, most notably the FDLR.

On 18 September 2002, officials of the governments of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and Rwanda, and representatives of the third parties � South Africa and the UN � met in the Rwandan capital, Kigali, to discuss the status of Rwandan troop withdrawal from the DRC and the disarmament and repatriation of armed Rwandan groups based in the DRC, most notably the FDLR.

On 1 November 2002, Presidents Kabila and Kagame met in Pretoria for talks mediated by President Mbeki of South Africa. The talks focused on the implementation of the Pretoria Accord signed on 30 July 2002, which stipulated that the DRC would disarm and arrest Rwandan Hutu militias in return for Rwandan troops withdrawing from the DRC. Kabila and Kagame agreed to give each other another 90 days to implement the peace deal.

On 20 October 2003, Rwandan Foreign Minister Charles Murigande arrived in Kinshasa for talks with the Congolese government. The talks were aimed at restoring normal ties and ending Congolese support to the FDLR.

On 27 November 2003, Presidents Kabila and Kagame met in Pretoria for a round of talks mediated by President Mbeki. The talks focused on the implementation of the Pretoria Accord signed on 30 July 2002, which stipulated that the DRC would disarm and arrest Rwandan Hutu militias in return for Rwandan troops withdrawing from the DRC. The meeting was also attended by UN and AU representatives. Kabila and Kagame agreed to finish implementing the Pretoria Accord within 12 months.

On 6 July 2004, on the sidelines of an AU summit, a mini-summit was held in Addis Ababa to ease tensions between the DRC and Rwanda. It was attended by President Kagame and the DRC Foreign Minister representing President Kabila, who did not attend after the AU published a report critical of him. Presidents Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, Domitien Ndayizeye of Burundi and Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique, who was also the outgoing chairman of the AU, acted as mediators. The talks focused, among others, on the DRC ending its support to the FDLR.

On 25 August 2004, the foreign ministers of the DRC and Rwanda met in Munyonyo in Uganda. The negotiations were mediated by Uganda�s defense minister, with support from US diplomats. The DRC delegation agreed to end support to the FDLR rebels and disarm them. The talks were sponsored by the US.

On 22 and 23 September 2004, meetings involving senior DRC and Rwandan officials, including President Kabila, were held at the UN Headquarters in New York. UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan was involved as a mediator in these talks, alongside US diplomats. The talks resulted in the signing of the Joint Verification Mechanism (JVM) on 22 September 2004 and the Memorandum of Intent (MOI) on Regional Security in the Great Lakes of Africa on 23 September 2004 by the Foreign Ministers of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and Rwanda, and the Defense Minister of Uganda. The Joint Verification Mechanism (JVM) was established to create a cooperative framework for monitoring and verifying allegations of cross-border incursions and the presence of hostile forces in the eastern DRC and along the borders with Rwanda and Uganda. The primary objective of the JVM was to build trust between the DRC, Rwanda, and Uganda by providing a transparent mechanism to investigate claims of military activity or support for rebel groups across their borders. The JVM was composed of representatives from the DRC, Rwanda, and Uganda, as well as observers from the international community, including the UN, the AU, and other regional organizations. The mechanism allowed for joint inspections and verification missions to investigate reported incidents or movements of armed groups in the border areas. The parties agreed to share information and cooperate in addressing any violations or security threats identified through the JVM. The Memorandum of Intent (MOI) on Regional Security in the Great Lakes of Africa was a broader agreement aimed at enhancing regional cooperation on security matters. The MOI aimed to foster collaboration among the DRC, Rwanda, and Uganda to combat armed groups, including foreign and domestic militias operating in the eastern DRC, such as the FDLR and the LRA.
agreement_name: Joint Verification Mechanism (JVM), Memorandum of Intent (MOI) on Regional Security in the Great Lakes of Africa

description: On 5 October 2004, DRC and Rwandan delegations led by senior government officials met in Kigali to set up the Joint Verification Mechanism (JVM) that had been agreed upon the previous month in New York. Ambassador William Swing, head of the UN peacekeeping mission in the DRC, attended the meeting.

At a meeting in Kigali on 26 October 2004, the DRC, Rwanda, and Uganda signed the Tripartite Commission Agreement. This agreement deals with security issues and calls for cooperation in neutralizing armed groups, including the FDLR.  The US and the UN were involved as mediators in this initiative.

On 19 and 20 November 2004, Presidents Kabila and Kagame attended the Conference on the Great Lakes Region in Dar es Salaam, hosted by the Tanzanian President, with support from the UN and the AU. The final document signed at the conference � the Dar-es-Salaam Declaration on Peace, Security, Democracy and Development in the Great Lakes Region � obliged its signatories to �halt all direct and indirect� support to armed groups in the region. The document thus stipulated an end to the Congolese support to the FDLR.
agreement_name: Dar-es-Salaam Declaration on Peace, Security, Democracy and Development in the Great Lakes Region

description: Tensions between Rwanda and the DRC increased after Rwanda claimed that the FDLR had launched a rocket attacks from the DRC into Rwanda on 15 November 2004. In mid-December 2004, EU cooperation and development commissioner Louis Michael mediated a round of shuttle talks between the DRC and Rwanda, visiting the DRC on 18 December 2004 and Rwanda on 19 December 2004. Michael focused on ending Congolese support to the FDLR during his talks with Congolese government representatives. Michael managed to convince Rwanda to withdraw its threat to invade the DRC.

At a two-day AU summit in January 2005, the AU Peace and Security Council discussed the conflict between Rwanda and the DRC and urged the DRC to end their support to the FDLR and disarm FDLR forces. The AU also decided to send troops to the region in order to help the DRC disarm the FDLR.

The US mediated between the foreign ministers of Rwanda, Uganda and the DRC in Washington in late January 2005. The negotiations that took place in Washington were aimed at ending Congolese support to the FDLR and promote cooperation and trust between the countries. As a result of these negotiations, the Rwanda-DRC Joint Border Verification Mechanisms was launched on 8 February 2005.

On 2 February 2005, the US hosted a meeting of the Tripartite Joint Commission in Washington, DC. The Tripartite Commission was formed to implement previous agreements on ending support to rebel groups, including Congolese support to the FDLR. Foreign ministers of Rwanda and Uganda, Congo�s minister of regional cooperation, and the defense minister of Uganda participated meeting. The meeting was mediated by Assistant US Secretary of State Constance Newman. Representatives of the EU, the AU, and the UN supported the US mediation effort.

The FDLR repeatedly called for an inter-Rwandan dialogue, but the Government of Rwanda continued to refuse to talk to any group connected to the genocide. Although the Government of Rwanda did not participate in these talks, a FDLR delegation went to Rome in March 2005 to discuss their disarmament with the Community of Sant�Egidio as a mediator. While Rwanda did not participate in these one-sided negotiations, the Democratic Republic of Congo did participate in the meeting. At the end of the meeting, the FDLR leadership issued a declaration that it would disarm and demobilize in May 2005 and transform into a political party. It was further agreed that it would repatriate to Rwanda in June 2005. In August 2005, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Rwanda, and Uganda gave the FDLR until 30 September to disarm or face possible military action. FDLR reaffirmed their commitment to the Rome Declaration in September 2005, but they again pressed the necessity of accompanying measures to be taken by Rwanda. However, the Government of Rwanda rejected any direct negotiations involving the FDLR. From this moment onwards, no more negotiations involving the FDLR have taken place. In fact, Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo began to cooperate militarily from late 2008 onwards to attack the FDLR.

On 21 and 22 April 2005, Congolese, Rwandan, and Ugandan ministers met in Lubumbashi for a US-sponsored Tripartite Commission meeting. The Tripartite Commission was formed to implement previous agreements on ending support to rebel groups, including Congolese support to the FDLR. The Congolese delegation confirmed its commitment to end support to the FDLR and facilitate the repatriation of the FDLR to Rwanda.

On 25 and 26 August 2005, the DRC, Rwanda, and Uganda met in Kigali for a US-facilitated Tripartite Commission meeting. The Tripartite Commission was formed to implement previous agreements on ending support to rebel groups, including Congolese support to the FDLR. The Congolese delegation confirmed its commitment to end support to the FDLR and facilitate the repatriation of the FDLR to Rwanda.

On 16 September 2005, at a meeting held in New York, Burundi was included in the Tripartite Joint Commission, which previously consisted solely of Rwanda, the DRC, and Uganda. The renamed Tripartite Plus Joint Commission continued to serve as a platform for implementing previous agreements on ending support to rebel groups in the region. The commission representatives agreed that military and diplomatic pressure on all militias on the member States� territories would be continued to ensure their disarmament and repatriation or reintegration, and that sanctions would be imposed on such armed groups should they refuse to disarm voluntarily before 30 September 2005.

On 20 and 21 October 2005, the Tripartite Plus Commission met in Kampala. This commission served as a platform for implementing previous agreements on ending support to rebel groups in the region. In the presence of US Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs Donald Yamamoto, ministers and senior officials from Burundi, the DRC, Rwanda, and Uganda agreed to seek from foreign states punitive measures, including financial restrictions and visa bans, against members of nine rebel groups operating in the region.

On 20 and 21 April 2006, the Tripartite Plus Joint Commission met in Bujumbura. This meeting took place in the context of support provide by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. The meeting ended with a call for UN and AU sanctions to be imposed on rebel groups operating in the eastern DRC. The US acted as mediator.

On 26 and 27 May 2006, the Tripartite Plus Commission met in Kigali. This meeting took place in the context of support provide by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. The parties agreed on a provisional list of rebel chiefs on whom they wanted sanctions imposed for destabilizing the region. The meeting in Kigali, the third between the four countries in the space of two months, was facilitated by US Deputy Assistant Secretary for African Affairs Donald Yamamoto.

The DRC and Rwanda were among the signatories of the Pact on Security, Stability and Development in the Great Lakes Region at an international summit in Nairobi on 15 December 2006. This agreement, among others, included provisions on non-aggression and mutual defense. This makes the agreement relevant in relation to the support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda.
agreement_name: Pact on Security, Stability and Development in the Great Lakes Region

description: On 15 and 16 March 2007, the Tripartite Plus Commission met in Kigali. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. Ministers from the four countries reiterated their commitment to end rebel activities in the region.

On 18 April 2007, top military officials from Burundi, the DRC, Rwanda, and Uganda held a Tripartite Plus Commission meeting in Bujumbura. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support.

In early June 2007, the Tripartite Plus Commission met in Lubumbashi. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support.

On 27 and 28 August 2007, top military officials of the Tripartite Plus Commission met in Kigali. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. Opening the talks, Rwandan Foreign Affairs Minister Charles Murigande criticized the DRC for stopping military action against the FDLR.

DRC President Kabila and Rwandan President Kagame met on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly in New York in September 2007 and asked the UN for support in removing foreign rebel groups from the DRC. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending support they respectively provided to the FDLR and the CNDP.

The Tripartite Plus Commission met in Kampala between 15 and 17 September 2007. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support.

The Tripartite Plus Commission met in Kinshasa in late September 2007. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. Rwanda raised concerns about the lack of Congolese action against the FDLR during the meeting.

Following a round of negotiations mediated by the UN, Rwanda and the DRC signed the Nairobi Communiqu� on 9 November 2007. The agreement specified a common approach to deal with the FDLR. The Government of the DRC agreed to end support to the FDLR and design a plan to disarm the FDLR.

President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, President Paul Kagame of Rwanda, President Pierre Nkurunziza of Burundi, and Minister of State for Interior Denis Kalume, representing President Joseph Kabila of the DRC, met in Addis Ababa on 5 December 2007 for a Tripartite Plus Joint Commission meeting. US Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice acted as the mediator during this meeting. This meeting took place in the context of support provided by the DRC to the FDLR and support provided to the CNDP by Rwanda. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending this support. The parties agreed at the end of the meeting that �No member state will harbor any Negative Forces. Participants recommitted to deny safe haven or support to any Negative Forces.�

In late March 2008, the Tripartite Plus Commission met in Bujumbura to discuss efforts against rebel groups in the region. Talks between the DRC and Rwanda were focused on implementing previous agreements aimed ending support to rebel groups.

Chiefs of defence staff of the Tripartite Plus Joint Commission member states approved an operational plan to be used in stopping rebel groups � including the FDLR and the CNDP � operating in the DRC at a meeting in Kigali on 20 June 2008.

On 4 December 2008, government representatives of the DRC and Rwanda signed the so-called �Four on Four Agreement� that specified that the Congolese government forces would end their military support of the FDLR and would, with support from the Rwandan government forces, forcefully disarm the FDLR. In the framework of the so-called �four plus four� mechanism in which four Rwandan officials met several times with their Congolese counterparts, the Rwandan and the DRC governments planned a joint military operation, called �Umoja Wetu� (English: Our Unity) to root out the FDLR. The joint operation lasted for one month in 2009 and ended with Rwanda withdrawing at the end of February 2009. In return for the Congolese support, Rwanda agreed to end its support for the CNDP and even helped the DRC to arrest CNDP leader Nkunda in Rwanda on 22 January 2009.

Negotiations between Rwanda and the DRC at the Ihusi Hotel in Goma in January 2009 led to a formal rapprochement in the form of the signing of the Ihusi Agreement on 16 January 2009. The agreement committed Rwanda to ending its support to the CNDP and arresting CNDP leader Nkunda, while it committed the DRC to end support to the FDLR and help the Rwanda attack the FDLR forces in the DRC.
Negotiations between the Senegalese government and the MFDC led to a ceasefire on 29 March 1991.

In May 1991, negotiations, mediated by Guinea-Bissau, led to the signing of the Bissau Accord. This accord called for a ceasefire, as well as the release of hundreds of Casaman�e detainees, among them the political leaders of MFDC. However, the accord mainly focused on a ceasefire and failed to address any of the conflict issues, including the status of Casamance.

On 8 April 1993, the leader of the MFDC, Diamacounce Senghor, called for a ceasefire between the parties to take effect on 10 April 1993, while calling for negotiations with France as mediator. However, the government responded with heavy clashes on 18 and 19 April 1993, after which it also called for a ceasefire with the rebels on 27 April 1993. Senegal�s Minister of Defence, Madieng Khary Dieng, and the leader of MFDC, Diamacoune Senghor, conducted a round of negotiations in early July 1993 and signed a ceasefire agreement on 8 July 1993. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire, the release of Casaman�e prisoners, the non-reinforcement of government troops in Casaman�e, and the free return of refugees.
President Abdou Diouf held talks with MFDC leader Diamacounce Senghor on 22 January 1999, which led to a call for an end to hostilities and a peaceful settlement.

On 26 December 1999, new negotiations commenced in Banjul, where the conflict parties agreed to an immediate ceasefire in the Casamance. They also agreed to meet face to face at least once a month to negotiate. In addition to representatives of the Gambian government, representatives of Guinea Bissau also mediated in this round of negotiations in December.

After his inauguration in April 2000, Senegalese President Abdoulaye Wade, immediately dismissed all those persons who mediated in the Casamance crisis before his election to the presidency. A round of negotiations between the Senegalese government and the MFDC in November 2000 led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement on 30 November 2000.
With the Bishop of Ziguinchor serving as mediator, a round of negotiations between the conflict parties let to the signing of a truce on 16 March 2001 in Ziguinchor.

In early 2003, there was an upsurge in fighting between the Senegalese army and MFDC forces. The former claimed that the string of operations it conducted were a result of MFDC�s mine laying efforts throughout the region. Nevertheless, negotiations did take place in 2003. On 4 May 2003, President Wade met with MFDC leader Senghor without the involvement of a mediator. These negotiations did not lead to an agreement, but President Wade promised an amnesty for all MFDC fighters, a reintegration program for former combatants, funding for economic recovery of the Casamance region, resettlement of refugees and displaced people.

On 1 February 2005, negotiations on the implementation of the 2004 accord were launched in the central town of Foundiougne. The Government�s delegation was led by Interior Minister Ousmane Ngom, while the rebels were led by MFDC leader Augustin Diamacoune Senghor. After a day of talks, the two sides agreed to set up four 10-member technical committees consisting of five people from each side. The committees were to address political issues, economic and social development, as well as disarmament, demobilisation, and demining. Yet, the talks were suspended two days later. New talks, scheduled to take place in late March 2005, were postponed due to divergences within the MFDC. Groups within the rebel movement opposed the peace deal and the rebel leadership wanted to arrange consultations between the various factions in order to include more factions in the peace process. The peace process was postponed yet again in December 2005.

Both the Community of Sant�Egidio and Humanitarian Dialogue were involved in mediation between 2014 and 2016. There is, however, limited information available about these mediation efforts. On 29 April 2014, the leaders of MFDC, Salif Sadio, declared a unilateral ceasefire. The ceasefire was announced after a government delegation and a MFDC delegation met in Rome in April 2014 under the facilitation of the Community of Sant�Egidio.
third_party: Community of Sant�Egidio, Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue

description: In June 2019, the Ad-Hoc State Negotiating Committee and the Interim Committee of the Unified Political and Combatant Wings of the MFDC held an initial meeting in Banjul aimed at building trust and laying the groundwork for negotiations. The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) acted as the mediator.

On 8 and 9 April 2021, another meeting between the conflict parties took place in Praia, Cabo Verde. The goal of this meeting was to negotiate peace in Casamance. The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) acted as the mediator. The talks concluded with the signing of the Joint declaration of the delegations of the State of Senegal and the Provisional Committee of the MFDC.
agreement_name: Joint declaration of the delegations of the State of Senegal and the Provisional Committee of the MFDC

description: On 14 and 15 July 2021, negotiators convened in the Cape Verdean capital to seek a peaceful solution to the crisis, and discussions on disarmament began. The Senegalese government pledged to take actions to facilitate this process. The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) acted as the mediator.

In February 1992, France, as a former colonial power, mediated a ceasefire between FRUD and the government. Since France provided direct military aid in support of the Government of Djibouti, totaling approximately 5.2 million US Dollars between 1991 and 1994, France had leverage over the government. Nevertheless, when the French Minister-Delegate for Foreign Affairs, Alain Vivien, first met with FRUD on 22 January 1992, the Government of Djibouti accused France for loving the foreign invaders, saying it had never asked France to mediate in the conflict. Foreign Minister Farah stated afterwards that Vivien�s visit had changed nothing.

Yet, the following month, Paul Dijoud, Director of African Affairs at the French Ministry for Foreign Affairs, met with a FRUD delegation on 23 February 1992 and with President Hassan Gouled Aptid on 20 and 24 February 1992. After having mediated between the two parties in these separate talks he announced the deployment of a French peacekeeping force on 25 February.

On 28 February 1992, the rebels declared a unilateral ceasefire, which was followed by the Government releasing the imprisoned FRUD representative Abbate Ebo Adou. However, the ceasefire only lasted for a few months. France subsequently threatened to cut off development aid. Negotiations, in which no international third parties participated, led to the signing of the Agreement for Peace and National Reconciliation in Djibouti on 26 December 1994. This agreement stipulates an immediate ceasefire. According to the agreement, the FRUD rebels would join the military forces of Djibouti, and a comprehensive DDR program was designed to facilitate their integration into the military as well as other sectors of society. The agreement also addressed FRUD�s involvement in the political landscape of Djibouti. In addition to becoming a recognized political party, FRUD officials would take part in the administration of state affairs. The agreement emphasized the need to update the electoral rolls for upcoming general elections., The agreement also called for a nationwide decentralization of authority to improve governance once stability was restored in Djibouti. Extensive reintegration initiatives were established, with the government responsible for finding employment opportunities for FRUD members not incorporated into the military. Those who surrendered their weapons were granted a general amnesty. The government committed to allocate funds for reconstruction projects, including the restoration of damaged infrastructure and assistance for refugees and internally displaced persons. FRUD was also tasked with actively promoting resettlement in war-affected areas of the country.
agreement_name: Agreement for Peace and National Reconciliation

description: Negotiations in 2000 with the FRUD-C resulted in the conclusion of a peace agreement on 7 February 2000. No mediator was involved in the negotiations leading up to this agreement. The agreement called for an end to hostilities and the release of prisoners. Under the agreement, a new ceasefire was established, and it was decided that the FRUD-C rebels would be integrated into the national army. The political aspects of the agreement aimed for a more democratic Djibouti by implementing a significant decentralization of authority. This decentralization reform granted greater autonomy to the provinces, ensuring improved governance of state affairs. The agreement also included reforms to enhance the political system's transparency, accountability, and freedom, particularly concerning public spending. Rebuilding the country and facilitating the return of refugees and internally displaced persons were crucial components of the agreement. Additionally, a general amnesty was granted to FRUD-C members, providing them with immunity for their past actions.

Another peace agreement was concluded between the Djibouti government and the FRUD-C on 12 May 2001. No mediator was involved in the negotiations leading up to this agreement. The agreement established a ceasefire, requiring both the FRUD-C rebels and government forces to withdraw from the territories they occupied. The rebels were directed to specific locations, such as Waddi, where they would await demobilization or integration into the national army. Government troops, on the other hand, were to relocate to their peacetime locations and remain stationed in their barracks. Similar to previous agreements between FRUD and the government, the integration of FRUD-C troops into the national army was a central aspect. In the political realm, the agreement addressed three key issues: reaffirming FRUD's status as a legal political party, providing further details on the decentralization of authority, and the government's commitment to conducting multi-party elections. The agreement also included a program for the repatriation of refugees and the reconstruction of areas affected by the war. This emphasized the importance of assisting displaced individuals in returning to their homes and rebuilding the regions devastated by the conflict. The peace agreement ended hostilities between the conflict parties.

The government issued a unilateral ceasefire in December 1993. The RUF used this unilateral ceasefire declared by the Government of Sierra Leone in December 1993 to regroup, after which they conducted a counterattack in early 1994. In November 1994, the Head of State of Sierra Leone addressed a letter to the UN Secretary-General, formally requesting him to provide his good offices to facilitate negotiations between the government and the RUF. The RUF and the government reached a ceasefire agreement on 4 December in indirect negotiations, paving the way for official negotiations.

Although the AFRC and the RUF were ousted from power in early 1998, the war was not over. The AFRC and RUF remained and put up tough resistance against the government forces and their allies in the eastern parts of Sierra Leone. On 1 January, the government announced it had reached a temporary ceasefire with RUF through indirect negotiations. Even so, the RUF and the AFRC forces invaded Freetown on 6 January 1999, resulting in a battle that lasted for more than six weeks.
Another round of ECOWAS-mediated negotiations took place in Lom� in May 1999. On 18 May 1999, a ceasefire agreement was signed.

A further round of ECOWAS-mediated negotiations in July led to the signing of the Lom� Peace Agreement on 7 July 1999, which was mediated by ECOWAS Chairman, President Gnassingbe Eyadema. The agreement�s key points included a monitored ceasefire chaired by UNOMSIL, the creation of a new national army, and power-sharing arrangements throughout the government. Colonel Foday Sankoh, the RUF leader, gained a Vice-President-equivalent seat and significant cabinet positions. The AFRC was given the opportunity for public office inclusion. Commissions for strategic resource management, national reconstruction, and development were established, all chaired by Sankoh. The RUF was to transition into a political party. Lastly, a general amnesty and a program for the voluntary return of refugees and internally displaced people were instituted, granting pardons to Sankoh and all combatants involved in war crimes.

On 15 May 2000, government forces attacked a traditional stronghold of the RUF, after they had secured key bridges and towns the troops had lost to the rebels the previous week. In response, the UN tried to mediate a ceasefire and reconfirm the conflict parties� commitment to the Lom� Agreement.
A six-member ECOWAS delegation mediated between the conflict parties in June 2000, but was unsuccessful in restoring the ceasefire.

From June 2000 onwards, RUF began attacking UNAMSIL troops. However, Sankoh�s attempt to take control of the country was foiled by the arrival of battle-hardened and well-equipped British forces that aligned themselves with the remnants of the Sierra Leone army. Sankoh was captured once again and after significant losses the rebels began to cooperate with the Lom� peace agreement. In November 2000, negotiations, mediated by ECOWAS, were held in Abuja between representatives of the Sierra Leone government and the RUF. The two sides discussed an agenda that included the restructuring of the Sierra Leone Army, the free movement of all people in Sierra Leone, the return of all weapons seized from UN peacekeepers, the ceasefire, the political agenda of the RUF, and disarmament. The Sierra Leone government delegation was led by Justice Minister and Attorney-General Solomon Berewa and the RUF delegation was led by Colonel Jonathan Kposowa. An agreement confirming the Lom� peace agreement was reached on 10 November and would be referred to as the Abuja Ceasefire Agreement. This agreement reaffirmed parties� commitment to the Lom� Peace Agreement, as well as specified a new ceasefire and committed the parties to recommence the disarmament and demobilisation programme.
The two sides reaffirmed their adherence to the Abuja Ceasefire Agreement on 3 May 2001.

The first round of negotiations took place between AIS leaders, Abassi Madani and Ali Belhadj, and Algerian government officials from December 1993 to March 1994. The talks concerned, among other topics, an amnesty and a three-year transitional period towards a democratic political system.

In October 1997, it was reported that Italy had offered to mediate between the Algerian warring parties, but the government once more refused to enter into mediated negotiations. A round of bilateral peace talks without the involvement of a mediator led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 1 October 1997. In December 1997, Luxemburg�s Foreign Minister Jacques Poos, who was in charge of the European Union�s foreign policy at that time, stated that the European Union was ready to help the Algerian Government overcome the crisis. As a result, the European Union sent a mission in January 1998, headed by Derek Fatchett, Minister of State at the United Kingdom Foreign and Commonwealth Office, to discuss the conflict with the Algerian authorities. During the visit, the Algerian authorities rejected an offer by the EU to mediate in the conflict.

In December 1999, negotiations led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in which, among other things, all AIS fighters received full amnesty. The Amnesty Agreement has never been made public. However, the newspaper Echarq El Awsat published a summary of a five-page document of which it is highly likely that it concerns the peace agreement concluded in December 1999. According to this newspaper article, the agreement contained eleven points: (1) a general amnesty for all groups observing the truce, (2) to regard all those who died during the years of violence as victims of the national tragedy, (3) full assumption of responsibility and compensation by the State of all victims, (4) creation of a mixed committee to monitor contacts between the national army and the AIS, (5) creation of an interministerial committee comprising the Ministries of Justice and the Interior charged with supervising the release of ex-AIS leaders within 18 months, (6) concentration of all AIS factions and other armed groups at precise locations under the control of the government forces, (7) integration of these elements into special combat units against terrorist groups, (8) a list of all weapons and ammunition in the possession of the groups joining the truce, (9) evacuation of the families of the groups joining the truce to safe locations far from the anti-terrorist operation zones, (10) drafting of a law providing a legal framework for the truce, (11) recognition by the AIS of the national forces as the only Army in Algeria, and (12) a decisive halt to all armed actions and an undertaking not to lend any direct or indirect support to any terrorist faction or group across national territory. The agreement also contained a promise that the ex-FIS would be allowed to return to the political arena, although under another name and with a new direction that is unconnected to the past and in accordance with the provisions of the 1996 constitution.

Namibian President Sam Nujoma and Foreign Minister Gurirab served as mediators in indirect talks between the government and FLEC-R that took place in Windhoek, Namibia, in early June 1995. These talks were aimed at reaching a ceasefire agreement, which could then clear the road for substantial negotiations on a long-term peace settlement.

A round of negotiations mediated by Congo-Brazzaville finally led to the signing of a four-months ceasefire agreement between the government and FLEC-R in Pointe Noir on 24 September 1995 that came into effect on the night of 26 to 27 September.

Following the ceasefire agreement between the government and FLEC-R that had been reached in September 1995, more rounds of talks were held aimed at making the truce permanent. On 27 February 1996, negotiations in Windhoek led to the conclusion of a ceasefire to confirm the previous ceasefire.

Negotiations in Brazzaville led to another ceasefire in July 1996. However, FLEC-R was divided over the negotiations, and on 31 August 1996 the organisation suspended direct dialogue with the government. When Tiburcio went to a meeting with dos Santos in Brazzaville in September, openly defying a decision made by the central council of the FLEC-R, he was forced to resign in favour of Antonio Bento Bembe.

After some follow-up meetings, the parties met again in Brazzaville in mid-July. After three days of negotiations, the conflict parties agreed on a final text of the memorandum of understanding and, on 18 July, a ceasefire accord was signed.

Another round of negotiations in the municipality of Namibe led to the conclusion of a peace agreement � called the Memorandum of Understanding for Peace and Reconciliation in Cabinda � on 1 August 2006. This agreement was formally signed by Virgilio de Fontes Pereira, the Angolan minister for Territorial Administration, and Antonio Bento Bembe. The agreement included several provisions to establish peace and stability in Cabinda. These provisions consisted of a ceasefire and a reduction in the number of Angolan armed forces in the region. A local government would be established in Cabinda, but its political powers would be under the control of the central government in Luanda. Cabinda would have a "special status" within Angola, although the specific details of this status were not determined in the agreement. However, it was made clear that the FLEC would be granted certain privileges. FLEC would have the right to appoint a Government minister without portfolio, three deputy Ministers (in charge of petroleum, interior, and forestry), and a deputy Governor. In addition, FLEC would have representation in Angola�s state oil company, Sonangol, with two non-executive directors, a deputy director specifically for Cabinda, and three administrative advisers. The agreement also included a provision for a blanket amnesty for the rebels, ensuring that they would not face prosecution for their past actions. Furthermore, there was a plan for the reintegration of the former rebels into society, helping them to reintegrate into civilian life after the conflict.
agreement_name: Memorandum of Understanding for Peace and Reconciliation in Cabinda

description: In February 1994, President dos Santos and FLEC-FAC leader Henriques Tiago N�Zita met face to face for the first time. They discussed a ceasefire to pave the way for negotiations on the future status of the province. Jean Pierre Salanic, who is a French lawyer, and Brigadier Bernard Leandri served as facilitators at this meeting. The talks ended without progress being made.
A subsequent round of negotiations led to a ceasefire agreement in Libreville on 15 May 1996.

Military delegations of the conflict parties met in Libreville, Gabon, on 22 July 1996. These talks focused on the conclusion of a ceasefire and other issues, but FLEC-FAC refused to discuss the possibility of a ceasefire and instead suggested scaling down the hostilities, after which the government delegation unilaterally suspended the meeting.

Fighting in Cabinda intensified in 2002. As a result of the defeat of UNITA, the Angolan government redirected at least 30,000 troops to Cabinda and started a large-scale offensive in October 2002. The government forces managed to destroy the main bases of both FLEC-FAC and FLEC-R by the end of 2002. The Angolan government simultaneously offered negotiations without accepting the separatist�s demands for a referendum on the legal status of Cabinda in October 2002. Simultaneously to the government offensive, FLEC-FAC and the Government of Angola met in Paris for official negotiations in February 2003. The government delegation proposed that in return for Cabinda remaining an integral part of Angola, it would increase its budget for the enclave and promised to integrate FLEC-FAC fighters into the armed forces. The FLEC-FAC rejected this proposal, allegedly because the government had promised the same to FLEC-R. In 2004, the FLEC-R and the FLEC-FAC announced a unified FLEC, but this unification already broke down in 2005 because of a disagreement on entering into negotiations. While the FLEC-FAC opposed peace talks, the FLEC-R was open to the possibility of entering negotiations. Following the collapse of the united front, former FLEC�R leader Ant�nio Bento Bembe negotiated with the government, and a peace agreement was signed on 1 August 2006, but the FLEC-FAC continued to fight the government. In September 2020, the FLEC-FLAC released a press statement calling to relaunch the peace process in Cabinda and security in the region, but this did not lead to renewed negotiations. Moreover, the next month, in October 2020, the FLEC-FLAC decreed �a ceasefire across the territory� in response to the appeal by the United Nations Secretary-General for a Global Ceasefire related to COVID-19. However, this did not lead to negotiations.

In March 1993, some 20 Islamic scholars and leaders mediated between the government side and the representatives of al-Gama'a al-Islamiyya. The mediators shuttled between both sides and suggested terms for a ceasefire. The interior minister, Mohammed Abdel-Halim Moussa, was sacked after he publicly mentioned the mediation effort and the Government of Egypt denied mediation had taken place. Counter-insurgency operations and heavy-handed tactics against the supporters of Al-Gama�a al-Islamiyya led to its defeat in 1998.

On 7 May 1992, the Government of Tajikistan, led by Nabiyev, and Islamist and democratic opposition groups signed an agreement that foresaw the creation of a coalition government, disarmament, and for the opposition rally in the capital to disperse.

On 27 June 1992, the Government of Tajikistan and the opposition groups, made up of Islamists and democrats, signed a ceasefire agreement during a round of negotiations in the town of Khorog. The agreement delineates conditions for freeing hostages, vacating structures held by combatants, dissolving armed factions within a three-day period, and enhancing border monitoring. The ceasefire was set to enter into force on the 28 June 1992. The involved parties opted to initiate political discussions in an attempt to address and resolve their divergences.

On 26 November 1992, the pro-communist coalition of the Government of Tajikistan and the opposition groups, composed of Islamists and democrats, declared a ceasefire and issued a pardon for ex-Communist rebels and their pro-Islamic rivals.

Between 18 and 28 June 1994, Iran and the UN hosted another round of negotiations between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO in Teheran. They attempted to reach a consensus on a ceasefire, but they were eventually unable to finalize an agreement.

Between 12 and 17 September 1994, Iran and the UN mediated a round of negotiations between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO in Teheran. The parties signed the Agreement on a Temporary Ceasefire and the Cessation of Other Hostile Acts on the Tajik-Afghan Border and within the Country for the Duration of the Talks and reached a consensus that the ceasefire would commence upon the arrival of UN military observers and continue until the day of the referendum, to be held in November, and the next presidential election. An agreement was reached concerning the release of political prisoners and prisoners of war, with the implementation set to occur within one month. The ceasefire eventually came into force on 20 October 1992.
agreement_name: Temporary Ceasefire and the Cessation of Other Hostile Acts on the Tajik-Afghan Border and within the Country for the Duration of the Talks

description: Between 20 October and1 November 1994, a round of negotiations between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO took place in Islamabad. The negotiations were mediated by the UN and Pakistan. The parties signed the Protocol on the Joint Commission for the Implementation of the Agreement on a Provisional Ceasefire and the Cessation of Other Hostilities on the Tajik-Afghan Border and within the Country and successfully prolonged the ceasefire arrangement until February 1995. Talks were prolonged due to disagreements on prisoners� release. Eventually, the two sides agreed to release 27 prisoners each before midnight on 5 November 1994.
agreement_name: Protocol on the Joint Commission for the Implementation of the Agreement on a Provisional Ceasefire and the Cessation of Other Hostilities on the Tajik-Afghan Border and within the Country

description: The UN mediated high-level consultations between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO in Moscow between 19 and 26 April 1995. The seven-day conference yielded limited outcomes, including a one-month extension of the ceasefire, a commitment to conduct the initial meeting between the leader of the parties, Rakhmonov and Nuri, before the next round of negotiations, and an arrangement to commence those talks in late May in Almaty, the capital of Kazakhstan.

Between 22 May and 2 June 1995, the UN and Kazakhstan mediated a round of negotiations between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO in Almaty. The parties agreed to extend the ceasefire and exchange prisoners of war.

On 19 July 1995, the UN and Iran mediated a round of negotiations between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO in Teheran. The negotiations were mediated by the UN. The parties agreed on extending the ceasefire and on holding further talks.

On 17 August 1995, the UN and Afghanistan brokered a ceasefire between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO, in Kabul. President Rakhmonov and UTPO leader Nuri also signed a Protocol on Fundamental Principles for Establishing Peace and National Accord in Tajikistan.
agreement_name: Protocol on Fundamental Principles for Establishing Peace and National Accord in Tajikistan

description: Between 26 January and 18 February 1996, the UN and Turkmenistan mediated a round of negotiations between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO in Ashgabat. The parties failed to reach an agreement for peace and for the extension of ceasefire.

On 11 March 1996, the UN mediated the extension of a ceasefire agreement, which had expired in February 1996, between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO. The UN shuttled between the leader of UTO who was in exile during the negotiations and the government side, presenting its proposal for an extension of the ceasefire in a parliamentary session.
On 20 May 1996, the UN mediated between the Government and Tajikistan and the Islamic opposition also part of UTO. The conflict parties agreed to a three-month extension of a ceasefire.

Between 8 and 21 July 1996, the UN and Turkmenistan mediated a round of negotiations between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO in Ashgabat. The talks led to the signing of an agreement, which stipulated the commitment of further peace talks, the release of prisoners, and a ceasefire. The ceasefire entered into force on 20 July 1996.

On 16 September 1996, the UN mediated a ceasefire between the Government of Tajikistan and the Islamic opposition that was part of UTO. The meeting led to the signing of the protocol on the meeting of the delegation of the state commission of the republic of Tajikistan and field commanders of Karategin administration. The ceasefire entered into force on 17 September 1996. The agreement called for the cessation of all military operations in the area, the elimination of checkpoints along the route to the Karategin valley from the capital Dushanbe, and the reinstatement of local authorities in the two towns that were captured. It also enables the resumption of passenger traffic and the transportation of humanitarian aid to the region.
agreement_name: protocol on the meeting of the delegation of the state commission of the republic of Tajikistan and field commanders of Karategin administration

description: On 17 October 1996, the UN and Iran mediated peace talks between the Government of Tajikistan and the Islamic opposition in Teheran. The talks were meant to advance the peace process and prepare the parties for the following Moscow summit.

Between 10 and 11 December 1996, the UN mediated negotiations between the Government of Tajikistan and the Islamic opposition part of UTO in Khos Deh. The negotiations led to the signing of the Joint Statement of the President of the Republic of Tajikistan, E. S. Rakhmonov, and the leader of the UTO, S. A. Nuri. The parties reached a ceasefire agreement to take effect on 11 December 1996.
agreement_name: joint statement of the president of the republic of Takjikistan and the leader of the UTO

description: On 23 December 1996, the UN, Russia, and Iran mediated negotiations between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO in Moscow. The negotiations led to the signing of the Agreement between the President of the Republic of Tajikistan, E. S. Rakhmonov, and the leader of the UTO, S. A. Huri, on the Results of the Meeting held in Moscow on 23 December 1996. In addition to agreeing on a ceasefire, the leaders committed to finalizing all talks and reinstating peace in Tajikistan before 1 July 1997. They vowed to create a reconciliation commission, to announce a comprehensive amnesty, facilitate the exchange of prisoners of war and captives, and establish suitable circumstances for the repatriation of refugees.
agreement_name: Agreement between the President of the Republic of Tajikistan, E. S. Rakhmonov, and the leader of the UTO, S. A. Huri, on the Results of the Meeting held in Moscow on 23 December 1996

description: Between 5 and 19 January 1997, the UN and Iran mediated peace negotiations between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO in Teheran. The parties signed the Joint Statement by the Delegation of the Government of Tajikistan and the Delegation of the United Tajik Opposition. The talks laid the groundwork for the eventual signing of the final document on national reconciliation in the upcoming round of talks. On 13 January 1997, the parties signed the Protocol on Refugee Issues and agreed to facilitate the return of Tajik refugees who were displaced during the four-year civil conflict in the former Soviet republic.
agreement_name: Joint Statement by the Delegation of the Government of Tajikistan and the Delegation of the United Tajik Opposition, Protocol on Refugee Issues

description: Between 20 and 21 February 1997, the UN and Iran mediated peace negotiations between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO in Meshed. The negotiations led to the signing of the Statute of the Commission on National Reconciliation, the Additional Protocol to the Protocol on the main functions and powers of the Commission on National Reconciliation, as well as a Joint Statement. This agreement established that the government and opposition would both have 50% representation in a national reconciliation commission, as well as a included a statement condemning terrorist attacks in Tajikistan. General amnesty, rebel disarmament, security assurances for dissidents, and the mandate of a national reconciliation commission were not yet decided upon. Additionally, the conflict parties agreed that the opposition would occupy up to 30% of all government positions.
agreement_name: Statute of the Commission on National Reconciliation, the Additional Protocol to the Protocol on the main functions and powers of the Commission on National Reconciliation, as well as a Joint Statement

description: Between 26 February and 8 March 1997, the UN and Russia mediated a round of negotiations between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO in Moscow. This led to the signing of the Protocol on Military Issues. The agreement set out a plan to integrate the armed opposition into the army. Negotiations had been halted for several days during this round of talks, following the killing of one opposition member and the abduction of five others in the Tajik capital, Dushanbe.

Between 16 and 18 May 1997, the UN and Kyrgyzstan mediated peace talks between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO in Bishkek. The parties signed a draft political agreement encompassing the legalization of the opposition, contingent upon the disarmament of armed Islamic factions of UTO. It also includes provisions for opposition involvement in the Tajik government and participation in the commission for national reconciliation that was tasked with preparing for general elections.

Between 21 and 28 May 1997, the UN and Iran mediated a round of negotiations between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO in Tehran. The aim of the talks was to work out the details of the draft agreement signed in the previous round. The talks led to the signing of the Protocol on the Guarantees of Implementation of the General Agreement on Establishment of Peace and National Accord in Tajikistan. In this agreement, the conflict parties reached agreement on military provisions and a power-sharing arrangement. This concluded the inter-Tajik negotiations and paved the way for the final deal to be signed by Tajik President Imomali Rakhmonov and opposition leader Sayid Abdullo Nuri in the next round of negotiations to be held in Moscow.
agreement_name: Protocol on the Guarantees of Implementation of the General Agreement on Establishment of Peace and National Accord in Tajikistan

description: On 27 June 1997, the UN and Russia mediated the final round of talks between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO in Moscow. The talks led to the signing of the General Agreement on the Establishment of Peace and National Accord in Tajikistan. The Peace Agreement consisted of a primary protocol on military issues and a primary protocol on political issues. The most contentious issues during the peace negotiations revolved around political matters, particularly the distribution of power in a new government. The agreement stipulated that 30% of governmental positions, theoretically across all administrative levels, would be reserved for former UTO members. While thirteen UTO representatives, including the First Deputy Leader Khoji Akbar Turajonzoda, joined the government�some assuming roles such as deputy prime minister�the adherence to this agreement was inconsistent at lower levels of administration. A national reconciliation commission was in charge of monitoring the implementation of the peace agreement. The protocol on military issues aimed to consolidate the various private armies, paramilitaries, and gangs that emerged during the civil war into a unified army. Despite ongoing challenges, including the continued independence of several field commanders, thousands of former United Tajik Opposition (UTO) fighters were incorporated into new military structures, contributing to the formation of a developing national army. The agreement stipulated the return of refugees and support for their resettlement. It also designated the UN and OSCE as international guarantors of the peace agreements.

In January 1998, during peace talks aimed at implementing the peace agreement, UTO leader Said Abdullah Nouri, who also was the Head of the National Reconciliation Commission (NRC), suspended UTO�s participation in the NRC in protest against the government�s failure to implement its side of the accord.

On 23 January 1998, the UTO ended the boycott of the NCR and resumed talks with President Rakhmonov on implementing the agreement. On 12 February 1998, President Rakhmonov issued a number of decrees, appointing members of the UTO to government posts.
Negotiations between the Government of Tajikistan and UTO in March 1998 resulted in the signing of a ceasefire agreement on 30 March 1998.
On 2 May 1998, the Government of Tajikistan and UTO engaged in negotiations and signed a ceasefire agreement.
Negotiations between the Government of Tajikistan and the PFT resulted in agreement on a ceasefire on 14 October 1992.

On 16 November 1992, the PFT, UTO, and the Government of Tajikistan met with the aim of preparing a compromise agreement which could be submitted for parliamentary approval. The parties failed to agree on the agenda.
On 26 November 1992, PFT, UTO, and the Government of Tajikistan declared a ceasefire and issued a pardon for ex-Communist rebels and their pro-Islamic rivals.

From 11 to 12 January 1994, a 27-man national dialogue committee composed of the three ruling parties � the General People�s Congress (GPC), the Yemeni Socialist Party (YSP) representing the south, and the Yemeni Reform Group (al-Islah), as well as members of opposition parties and independents � met in Aden to try to find a peaceful solution to the conflict between the north and the south. Although both President Ali Abdullah Saleh representing the north and Vice-President Ali Salem al-Beidh representing the south were in favour of finding a solution to the crisis, they refused to sign a peace agreement that had been drafted during the talks. The talks subsequently broke down and tensions further increased.

Yemen�s feuding political parties met on 5 February 1994 to find a solution to the impasse that was blocking the signing of the peace accord that had been drafted by the national dialogue committee in the previous month. Disagreements reportedly revolved around the venue of the ceremony, which non-Yemeni groups should be invited to attend, what security measures should be taken to protect their leaders, and what should be done after the agreement was signed. One concrete outcome of the meeting was that the parties decided to form a sub-committee to work out ways of stopping criticizing each other through the media.

Negotiations led to the signing of a national reconciliation accord in Amman, Jordan, by President Ali Abdullah Saleh, Vice-President Ali Salem al-Beidh, and other Yemeni leaders on 20 February 1994. The negotiations were held without the involvement of a mediator, but Arab League Secretary-General Esmat Abdel-Maguid and King of Jordan, Hussein bin Talal, witnessed the signing ceremony. The main points of the agreement included security measures such as removing checkpoints from all cities and halting military mobilization, administrative aspects such as defining the powers of the presidential council, the president and the vice-president, and economic measures such as reforming the monetary system.

On 27 February 1994, peace talks between the conflict parties led to a ceasefire agreement. This agreement, among others, stipulated the integration of army troops. No third-party was involved in mediating these talks.

On 27 April 1994, a commission consisting of Arab � including northern and southern Yemeni officers, as well as defence advisers from Oman and Jordan �, US, and French military attach�s brokered a ceasefire between the conflict parties. The ceasefire collapsed one day later.
third_party: Yemeni military officers, Jordan, Oman, France, USA

description: As the mediation effort by the military commission was not successful, Arab League mediators arrived in Yemen�s capital Sana?a on 13 May 1994 to initiate another round of negotiations. This initiative was not successful as President Saleh rejected the Arab League�s calls for a ceasefire. President Saleh and other northern Leaders also rejected a peace plan proposed by the southern Yemen Socialist Party led by Vice-President Ali Salem al-Beidh. This plan called for the formation of a national salvation government and an immediate ceasefire.

On 20 May 1994, the Government of Yemen (North Yemen) announced a unilateral three-day ceasefire for a Muslim festival. But the ceasefire failed within hours. One day later, on 21 May 1994, Vice-President Ali Salem al-Beidh who led the southern bloc proclaimed the secession of the South and announced the creation of the Democratic Republic of Yemen with Aden as its capital. On 29 May 1994, southern Yemeni proposed a new ceasefire to the north.

On 6 June 1994, the Government of Yemen (North Yemen) declared a unilateral ceasefire following UN Security Council resolution 924 issued on 1 June 1994 calling for an immediate ceasefire. On 9 June 1994, Abdul-Rahman Ali al-Jifri, who had assumed the role of vice-president in breakaway south Yemen, stated at a press conference that the Democratic Republic of Yemen declared a unilateral ceasefire, reiterating its commitment to the UN Security Council resolution.

On his mission to try to implement the UN ceasefire called for by Resolution 924 issued on 1 June 1994, UN Special Envoy Lakhdar Brahimi, appointed on 2 June 1994, met President Ali Abdullah Saleh on 9 June 1994 in Sana?a. The Government of Yemen (North Yemen) reiterated its unilateral ceasefire following the discussion.

On 13 June 1994, the Government of South Yemen reiterated its support to the UN ceasefire call following a meeting between southern leader Ali Salem al-Beidh and UN Special Envoy Lakhdar Brahimi in Mukalla.

UN Envoy Lakhdar Brahimi met again with President Ali Abdullah Saleh in Sana?a on 15 June 1994. According to Brahimi, President Saleh was showing more willingness for the conclusion of a bilateral ceasefire agreement during this meeting. The two reportedly discussed the revival of the military commission tasked to supervise a ceasefire in Yemen. The UN envoy later left to discuss the armed conflict in Yemen with Qatar. The sticking point in the formation of the military commission was the extent to which the North would accept a role for foreign troops. Aden reportedly advocated the formation of a military observer committee consisting of two officers from the Arab League, South Yemen, North Yemen, Jordan, and Oman, as well as military attach�s from China, the US, Russia, Great Britain, and France in Yemen and a UN military representative. The South for its part also wanted the UN and representatives from, among others, Egypt, Syria, India, Indonesia, Nigeria, and Kenya.
On 16 June 1994, �The north�s President Ali Abdullah Saleh told the United Arab Emirates� president [�] he accepted an immediate ceasefire,� the UAE-official news agency said in Abu Dhabi.

On 19 June 1994, UN Special Envoy Lakhdar Brahimi held talks in Cairo, Egypt, with both sides of the conflict. The UN peace envoy met the parties separately and did not manage to bring them together. The United Nations called for another ceasefire in Resolution 931 issued on 29 June 1994.

On 25 June 1994, UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali and UN Peace Envoy Lakhdar Brahimi shuttled between northern and southern leaders in New York. This round of shuttle talks was aimed at encouraging the parties to reach a ceasefire agreement. In response, the Government of Yemen (North Yemen) announced another unilateral ceasefire on 25 June 1994.

On 28 June 1994, northern and southern Yemen representatives met at the United Nations headquarters in New York for another round of peace talks mediated by UN Peace Envoy Lakhdar Brahimi. However, the conflict parties could not agree on a ceasefire. On 29 June 1994, the Security Council adopted yet another Resolution calling for a ceasefire between the two parties.
Russian Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev held talks in Moscow on 29 June 1994 with his counterpart from north Yemen, Muhammad Salem Basendwa, in an attempt to broker a ceasefire.

Russia mediated a round of peace talks between the Democratic Republic of Yemen and the Government of Yemen (North Yemen) in Moscow on 30 June 1994. The talks led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement. Northern foreign minister Mohammed Salem Basendwa and a senior official of the South, Salem Saleh Mohammad, signed the ceasefire agreement.

On 30 June 1994, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) brokered a humanitarian ceasefire between the Democratic Republic of Yemen and the Government of Yemen (North Yemen). The ceasefire was mediated by the ICRC to allow for the reparation of a damaged water supply installation in the South. On 4 July 1994, the Democratic Republic of Yemen declared a unilateral ceasefire. This ceasefire was intended to allow for the resupply of water to the southern capital, Aden.

From early May 1994 onwards, it became increasingly clear that the Democratic Republic of Yemen was losing on the battlefield. On 6 July 1994, the conflict parties were negotiating the status of the forces of southern Yemen. Having obtained military dominance, the northern delegation attending these negotiations demanded that Yemen would be united, and that President Saleh were to continue ruling it. The next day, the southern leaders fled from southern Yemen and so there were nothing left to negotiate over except for the surrender of the southern forces.

On 28 July 1994, government officials of Yemen and leaders of the defeated secessionist faction in the south met with UN mediator Lakhdar Brahimi in Geneva, Switzerland. Planning Minister Abdul Karim al-Iryani and ambassador to the UN in New York Abdallah al-Ashtal represented the Yemeni government side, while the southern secessionists were represented by Haider Abu-Bakr al-Attas and Abdullah al-Asnaj, the Prime Minister and Foreign Minister. The aim of these reconciliation talks was to �explore the possibility of engaging upon a worthy and reasonable political dialogue in a spirit of mutual respect,� according to a UN-statement.

Armed violence erupted again in 2009. The Government of Yemen (North Yemen) subsequently engaged in peace talks with southern leaders, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement on 3 May 2009.

Algeria tried to resume the peace process again. During the last two weeks of November 1997, negotiations between Government of Niger and the FDR, mediated by Algeria, were held in Algiers. The talks led to the signing of a peace accord on 29 November 1997. The Algiers Accord stipulates a ceasefire, political autonomy for the Kawar region, and the release of hostages.

On 22 August 1998, the Chadian government mediated another round of negotiations between the conflict parties in N�djamena. This led to a peace agreement between the FDR and government of Niger. The agreement calls for the incorporation of rebel elements into government security and civilian services.

On 19 September, Yere began his third mission to the islands.
