Following Switzerland�s withdrawal from its mediating role, delegates from the government and different Anglophone separatist groups convened for a round of pre-negotiations in Toronto from 10 to 14 October 2022. This meeting marked the commencement of a new initiative aimed at revitalizing peace negotiations between the involved parties.

In October 2022, the government initiated preliminary discussions with Anglophone leaders residing in the diaspora. This paved the way for government officials in Yaound� to participate at higher levels in pre-negotiation discussions mediated by Canada.

In January 2023, following a round of shuttle talks between the conflict parties, mediated by Canada, the parties agreed to initiate a formal peace process. This involved the forming of technical committees to begin work on confidence-building measures through mediation by Canada. However, no other negotiations mediated by Cananda were held throughout the rest of 2023.

Furthermore, on the side-lines of the 23rd Ordinary Summit of the African Union in Malabo, Equatorial Guinea, in June 2014, the leaders of the Economic Community of Central African States (ECCAS) agreed to organize a ceasefire conference in Brazzaville in July 2014. The leaders also agreed to organizing popular consultations and to implement the idea of the HD workshop to organize a forum, which would later lead to the Bangui National Forum. Congolese President Sassou Nguesso, in his capacity as the ECCAS chief mediator, mediated the ceasefire negotiations between the anti-Balaka and the FPRC in Brazzaville in late July 2014. The Government of the Central African Republic was also involved in the negotiations. These negotiations led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement on 23 July 2014. However, clashes continued between the non-state armed groups.
agreement_name: Accord de cessation des hostilit�s en R�publique Centrafricaine (Brazzaville Agreement on Cessation of Hostilities)

description: Several of the non-state armed groups operating in the Central African Republic participated in a mediation process led by the Kenyan government in Nairobi, with negotiations taking place in early 2015. Building on these ceasefire negotiations, the mediation effort in Nairobi was subsequently replaced by the Bangui Forum in which the government also participated. The United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (MINUSCA) provided political and logistical support to Bangui Forum. Abdoulaye Bathily, the UN Special Representative for Central Africa, chaired the Forum. Special Representatives were also sent by the African Union and the Republic of Congo to support the negotiations. Technical support and expertise were given to the mediations by HD and the EU. Around 600 representatives from the Central African Republic participated. The Bangui Forum was held between 4 and 11 May 2015 and led to the conclusion of two negotiated settlements. First, the parties concluded the Agreement between the Transitional Government and the armed groups on the principles of disarmament, demobilization, reintegration and repatriation and integration into the uniformed State forces of the Central African Republic on 10 May 2015. This agreement included provisions on a ceasefire, as well as on the disarmament, demobilisation, and reintegration for all the armed groups that signed the agreement, including the Front populaire pour la renaissance de la Centrafrique, Rassemblement patriotique pour le renouveau de la Centrafrique, Union des forces r�publicaines fondamentales, Seleka r�nov�e, Mouvement des lib�rateurs centrafricains pour la justice, Front d�mocratique pour le progr�s de la Centrafrique, Coordination des ex-combattants anti-Balaka, Unit� du peuple centrafricain, R�volution et justice, and the Union des forces r�publicaines. Second, the Bangui Forum resulted in the conclusion of the Republican Pact � or in full the Pacte r�publicain pour la paix, la reconciliation, et la reconstruction en R�publique centrafricaine � which, among others, established a local and national mechanism for reconciliation. This agreement was signed by the government and nine out of the ten armed groups operating in CAR. In addition to the ECCAS-led mediation effort and the mediation effort as part of the Bangui Forum, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) mediated a unilateral ceasefire agreement with the FPRC in N�Djamena on 20 December 2015. Cheikh Tidiane Gadio acted as the chief mediator of the OIC. Noureddine Adam promised to refrain from seeking independence from the Central African Republic, issued a unilateral ceasefire, and stated that the ceasefire would make it possible to hold elections. Legislative and presidential elections were held without significant armed fighting in late 2015.
third_party: MINUSCA, Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), EU
agreement_name: Agreement between the Transitional Government and the armed groups on the principles of disarmament, demobilization, reintegration and repatriation and of integration into the uniformed State forces of the Central African Republic, Republican Pact

description: In late 2016, Angola, which had been mandated by the International Conference on the Great Lakes region, mediated between the transitional government and several armed groups � including the anti-Balaka, the FPRC, and the MPC - in Luanda in December 2016. Andr� de Oliveira Jo�o Sango, director general of the secret services, acted as the chief mediator. The Angolan mediators proposed a general amnesty, which was widely condemned in Bangui. The negotiations in Luanda ended without an agreement.
third_party: Angola, International Conference on the Great Lakes Region

description: In March 2017, the Community of Sant�Egidio started a mediation process mainly involving the non-state armed groups operating in the Central African Republic. This led to an agreement, referred to as the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic. The agreement reaffirmed the 2016 elections. In addition, the agreement called for the integration of all �politico-military groups� into the peace process and a restoration of state authority. The agreement also included an immediate countrywide ceasefire. The ceasefire did not hold. Armed clashes between several armed groups already took place in the Bria area already one day after the signing of the ceasefire. The government was not involved in the negotiations in Rome, but the government could nevertheless build on these negotiations. On 28 June 2017, President Faustin Archange Touad�ra held meetings with the representatives of the 14 armed groups that had signed the peace agreement in Rome on 19 June.
agreement_name: Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic

description: On 28 August 2018, Russia � which had begun supplying the Government of the Central African Republic with arms and military instructors in February 2018 � and Sudan mediated negotiations between the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the one side and the anti-Balaka (represented by Maxime Mokom) on the other side. The government was not part of this peace initiative as it expressed its support to the AU-led peace process. The negotiations led to the signing of declaration of understanding and a pledge to support the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation in the Central African Republic led by the AU and regional states with the support of the UN. The UPC and MPC expressed that they were no longer committed to this declaration in October 2018, but they made it clear that they still supported the African Initiative. While the government was not part of the negotiations held in Khartoum in August 2018, these negotiations paved the road for subsequent peace talks in Khartoum in which the government was involved. Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The APPR was signed by 14 non-state armed groups and the Government of the Central African Republic. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements, making the agreement essentially an elite-level pact to buy off armed group leaders.
agreement_name: Accord politique la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: A round of negotiations mediated by representatives of the Islamic Administration and clan elders led to the conclusion of a preliminary peace agreement on 24 February 2009, which among other things stipulated a ceasefire. Islamic Administration forces were subsequently deployed in the area in order to sustain the ceasefire while reconciliation talks continued.

On 26 October 2009, mediation by local leaders and Harakat Al-shabab Mujahideen (also known as Al-Shabaab) led to the conclusion of a final peace agreement. In addition to stipulating a ceasefire, this agreement stipulated that future disputes would be resolved according to Sharia law.

In 2003, the Ghanian government formed the Otumfuo Committee of Eminent Chiefs, tasked with resolving the conflict. This team was headed by Asantehene Otumfuo Osei Tutu II, chief Nayiri-Na Bohugu Shirigu of the Mamprugu, and chief Yagbonwura Bawa Dosie of the Gonja. This mediation team collaborated with the Ministries of Interior and Chieftaincy and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP). Negotiations mediated by these third parties led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in Dagbon on 14 April 2003.

The Otumfuo Committee of Eminent Chiefs continued mediating between the conflict parties throughout 2005. This led to the signing of a roadmap to peace that called to establish an interim regent from the Andani.

The Otumfuo Committee of Eminent Chiefs mediated peace talks between the conflict parties in 2006. Consequnetly, the conflict parties signed the Roadmap to Peace in Dagbon in Kumasi on the 30 March 2006. In early April 2006, the tribes agreed that Kamakuya NaaAbudali Yakubu Andani would be the regent.
A mediation effort by the Otumfuo Committee of Eminent Chiefs from 16 to 18 November 2007 led to the conclusion of a final peace agreement on 18 November 2007.

The leaders of the political parties took part in the inter-party Peace and Security Committee�s meeting held at Transcorp Hilton Hotel on 17 January 2008 in response to this outbreak of violence. Negotiations mediated by the Honourable Ado Moses Okino led to the signing of a ceasefire on behalf of their supporters.

On 11 March 2003, President Obasanjo convened the leaders of the AD and PDP to a peace meeting at Ibadan Airport lounge in view of the April elections. The leaders signed a pact guaranteeing efforts towards peaceful elections.

In response to heavy clashes in May 2000, the Ethiopian government created Integrated Security and Peace Committees that comprised security officials and leaders from both sides. These committees were established at the district, zonal and regional levels. The committees helped to mitigate tensions, among others through overseeing the return of stolen cattle and mediating disputes over use of shared land. Armed violence reignited in March 2002. Minister of Federal Affairs Seyoum Mesfin mediated a reconciliation meeting in Awash and in March 2002.
Mesfin mediated another reconciliation meeting in Dire Dawa in March 2002. This meeting did not lead to the conclusion of an agreement.
A mediation effort by Elders in June 2004 led to the conclusion of an agreement in which both sides promised to avoid civilian causalities. However, both sides violated this agreement.

A peace conference was held in Buqda-Aqable village in January 2005 to reconcile the two subclans, which led to the signing of a peace agreement. This peace conference was mediated by Haji Hussein Ugaases.
Negotiations began at night on 27 October 1999. These talks would end on 28 October with the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement.

Heavy fighting took place between the clans on 3 and 4 September 2002. Negotiations following these clashes mediated by Hussein Haji Bod, an Abgal politician, led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 5 September 2002.

Armed fighting between the Ali-Galif and Mahadade subclans started in August 2002. Clan elders, including Hassan Fidow Asir, mediated between the two subclans of the Hawiye between August and September 2002. This led to the conclusion of a ceasefire by September 2002, which terminated the conflict.

In November 2011, a meeting in Juba was held between a Murle parliament member and a chief to consider conflict resolution methods for the Anuak, Dinka-Bor, Murle and Nuer communities. In late March and April 2012, a disarmament campaign for Jonglei state gathered more than 10,000 arms. Following this effort, on 1 May 2012, a peace conference was held in Bor with the aim to bring peace to the area. Leaders from the Anuak and Nuer participated alongside the Dinka-Bor, Jie, Kachipo, and Murle. Archbishop Daniel Deng acted as the mediator. This peace effort proved successful. On 6 May, with the president of the respective peace committee as witness, the tribal representatives signed a peace agreement. The agreement�s implementation process was moderated by a mixed team of tribal leaders, peace committee members and a civil society group involved in a previous implementation process in Pibor County.

In November 2011, traditional and government delegates convened in Juba in South Sudan to discuss conflict resolution for the Anuak, Dinka-Bor, Murle, and Nuer communities. Beginning in mid-March 2012, a disarmament program was implemented for Jonglei State in South Sudan. With thousands of guns collected, the next step was a peace conference between multiple tribal groups � including the Anuak, Dinka Bor, Jie, Kachipo and Nuer � that was held at South Sudan Hotel in Bor on 1 May 2012. The talks were mediated by Archbishop Daniel Deng along with members of a peace committee and culminated with the signing of a peace agreement by all those present on 6 May 2012. The implementation of the agreement was overseen by tribal leaders, civil society, and the members of the peace committee.

A team of local elders and civil societies immediately intervened to mediate an informal ceasefire on 22 February. On 22 March, fighting resumed following a dispute between two businessmen associated with each side.

On 26 March, another round of negotiations mediated by local clan leaders and religious leaders succeeded in creating a formal ceasefire. This ceasefire was concluded in order to pave the way for negotiations in Mogadishu aimed at concluding a formal peace agreement. However, the ceasefire did not hold, and a third round of fighting took place from 7 to 14 May.

On 13 May, a mediation team made up of the Mudulood clan mediated a temporary ceasefire. This ceasefire collapsed the same month. The ARS/UIC defeated the ARPCT forces in June 2006, which terminated the conflict.

A round of negotiations between community leaders of Bena Nshimba, Bena Kapuya, and Bena Mwembia, mediated by the provincial government, led to the signing of a peace agreement in Katanda territory on 11 September 2020.
The Catholic Diocese mediated a truce between the Bokora Karimojong and Jie in March 2001.

Another round of peace talks between the Bokora Karimojong and Jie was held in Nakithikilet in August 2002. This led to a truce on 20 August 2002, which was adopted through traditional rituals rather than the signing of a document.
Terrence Achia, the chairman of the Local Council responsible for the entire district (LC5) of Moroto, mediated a peace agreement between the Bokora Karimojong and Jie clans on 21 October 2005.
The Bokora Karimojong, Jie, and Matheniko engaged in negotiations that led to the signing of a peace agreement in July 2009.

On 4 December 2016, Jonglei State Peace Advisor Deng Aguer mediated between the Bor Dinka and Murle at a peace conference in Pibor State. The conference was co-organized by the governments of Jonglei and Boma states, with assistance from UNMISS and ZOA International. The mediation effort led to the conclusion of a peace agreement which stipulated a ceasefire, as well as an end to child abductions, cattle raiding, revenge killings, and hate speech. The agreement also called for the promotion of peace and reconciliation between the communities involved, establishing a secure and safe environment to facilitate free movement of people, goods, and services, and respect for rule of law, human rights and traditional cultures. The peace agreement also stipulates the creation of a joint police force consisting of 1,000 officers. The joint force is to patrol the borders, arrest criminals and ensure the safety of movement and trading activities between Boma and Jonglei.

In February 2017, the UN declared famine in Unity State. This famine triggered cattle raids between Dinka groups and Murle and a series of revenge attacks from both sides. On 11 May 2017, the head of UNMISS, David Shearer, expressed concerns over rising tensions in the Bor-Pibor area, especially tensions between youths from the Dinka Bor and Murle communities. He confirmed UNMISS� commitment to providing support to peace efforts on the ground between these communities. On 13 May 2017, Murle tribesmen carried out a major cattle raid in Jonglei state. UNMISS tried to facilitate peace talks in response. At a peace conference in Juba on 23 May, facilitated by UNMISS, Dinka Bor and Murle representatives signed a ceasefire agreement. Chuol Rambang, Chairperson of the South Sudan Peace and Reconciliation Commission, acted as the chief mediator. The stated objective of the agreement concluded was to �commit and obligate the two communities to immediately cease hostilities and create conducive atmosphere to a comprehensive and inclusive dialogue.� This ceasefire succeeded in preventing any further large-scale violence between these communities in the subsequent months.

In September 2020, UNMISS hosted a peace conference to address the prolonged violence in the Jonglei region involving Dinka, Nuer, and Murle groups. The meeting involved political leaders at national and state levels, community elders, civil society representatives, and other stakeholders engaging in peace talks. The conference led to the signing of the Bor Communiqu� on 9 September 2020, which highlighted a commitment to a bottom-up approach for peace involving youth and local leaders in conflict areas.

From 14 to 18 January 2021, Murle and Bor Dinka armed youth leaders from Jonglei State met in Rumbek in Lakes State for a peace meeting. Galweng leaders acted as mediators during this peace meeting. The meeting led to the signing of the Rumbek Commitment to Peace.
A Jonglei-GPAA Inter-Communal Governance Structures meeting was held in December 2021 to follow up on the Pieri Agreement.
A Jonglei-GPAA Inter-Communal Governance Structures meeting was held in Juba in late July 2023 to follow up on the Pieri Agreement.
A Jonglei-GPAA Inter-Communal Governance Structures meeting was held Ayod from 2-6 November 2023 to follow up on the Pieri Agreement.

A peace conference attended by participants Bor Dinka, Murle, and Lou Nuer leaders from Bor County from Jonglei State and Gumuruk County from GPAA took place in Juba from 14 to 15 November 2022. The NGO Peace Canal and UNMISS Civil Affairs supported the conference. The conference led to the signing of the Agreement of Peace Dialogue. However, soon after the signing of this agreement, the Lou Nuer and Bor Dinka mobilized to conduct a large-scale attack on the Murle in the GPAA over the course of December 2022 and January 2023. This attack was allegedly in retaliation for the Murle raids into Lou Nuer and Dinka territory, which the Pieri process had failed to stop.

Fighting in 2006 was sparked over the government�s 2003 land policy, which re-assigned portions of the Borana district to the Guji. A cross-country peace conference was mediated by the Ethiopian government in the Yabello woreda from 11 to 18 July 2006. Government officials from the participating groups, regional NGOs and diplomats from the United States and United Kingdom joined the forum. With over 300 pastoralist groups from 19 different countries in attendance, special attention was given to the conflicts involving the Borana, Gabra, and Guji. The special session was led by the Gada councils of the communities. By the end of the conference, the three groups signed a peace agreement.

On 5 and 6 January 2010, the tribes took part in a cross-border peace meeting. This meeting was organized by the Dire CEWERU LPC with ACCORD. There were 111 attendees from both countries. The conflict parties reached an agreement regarding resource sharing. To implement this, 14 joint committees were established (9 in Ethiopia and 5 in Kenya) for oversight.

In September 2010, the Borana and Gabra communities participated in locally organized peace caravans. The tribal delegates of the Borana and the Gabra � as well as the Meru, Pokot, Rendile, Samburu, Somali and Turkana � engaged in reconciliation talks as part of these peace caravans.

On 27 January 2023, a traditional conflict resolution ceremony was held between the two communities. Traditional leaders agreed to reopen a road connecting the Burji and Guji areas, which had been closed in 2022 to limit interactions between the ethnic groups.

On 25 January 2003, Burundian President Pierre Buyoya held talks with CNDD-FDD leader Jean-Bosco Ndayikengurukiye and the leader of a splinter of the Palipehutu-FNL led by Alain Mugabarabona. At this meeting, the leaders signed a memorandum of understanding with regards to the 7 October 2002 agreement. This memorandum established a joint ceasefire commission comprising six members each from the two rebel groups and the government, under the direction of a UN official. However, fighting continued, which ended more or less with a victory for the CNDD-FDD and its government ally. The Palipehutu-FNL nevertheless survived as a rebel group, although having been severely weakened by the fighting.

A peace conference, facilitated by the UN, was held between 6 and 23 January 2008. During this conference, a meeting was held between the CNDP, PARECO, the Government of the DRC, and the Government of Rwanda at the Ihusi Hotel in Goma on 16 January 2008. Although the UN representatives participated in the conference, the two chief mediators were Abb� Appollinaire Malu Malu and Vital Kamerhe. These two Congolese politicians had been mandated to mediate by the Government. Prior to the actual conference the chief mediators went on an extensive awareness-raising tour through North and South Kivu. On the basis of different consultations and meetings during this tour, they drafted a document specifying 15 objectives of the conference. While the organizers of the conference expected 600 participants, around 1500 people showed up at Goma at the start of the conference on 6 January 2008. The role of the UN representatives was twofold. First, the served as observers in order to ensure the neutrality of the talks. Second, in addition to participating in the plenary meetings, the UN representatives held secret bilateral meetings with Government of the DRC and the CNDP leadership. This led to PARECO ending its conflict with the CNDP on 17 January and the conclusion of a peace agreement between CNDP and the Government of the DRC on 23 January. In addition, the Congolese government and 22 armed groups signed a peace agreement � the Acte d�engagement � in Goma on 23 January 2008, committing all parties to an immediate ceasefire and the disengagement of forces from frontline positions. However, soon after the conclusion of this agreement, the CNDP launched a military offensive to dislodge PARECO and Mayi Mayi Mongol fighters from the Bukombo area. Fighting between these parties continued between February and April 2008.
The two sides reached a temporary ceasefire agreement in late June, but this agreement did not address the underlying conflict issues.

In 2005, leaders from the Dabare and Luway convened at the Togaar Hoos peace conference that was funded by the community. Without any third party involvement, this effort led to the signing of a peace agreement.
On 30 May 2004, local elders mediated negotiations between the Da�ud and Warsangeli, which led to a ceasefire agreement.
The next day, on 12 May 2005, a chief named Muhamoud Ali mediated between the conflict parties. His efforts resulted in a ceasefire between them.
The Didinga and Toposa reached a peace agreement in 2013 in which the leaders of the tribes vowed to end hostility.

In March 2014 a second peace conference, facilitated by the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) and the East Equatorian State Government, led to another agreement. This agreement stipulated a ceasefire, as well as condemned cattle raids and requested the state government to deploy police personnel into the area.

side_b: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: Clan elders arrived from Galkayo and managed to broker a ceasefire between the two clans on 28 January 2002.

side_b: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: The elders negotiated another peace agreement in July 2002. The two ceasefires of January and July 2002 halted the fighting until 2003.

side_b: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: Another round of negotiations began in 2003, and a peace agreement was produced that allowed for the return of those displaced by the clans� violence. This agreement terminated the conflict. However, the conflict would reignite again in 2019.

Another round of negotiations � in which 80 Me�en, 350 Dizi and 20 Suri participated � was held on 11 December 1991. This meeting ended with the conclusion of an agreement that stipulated a ceasefire and a pledge to disarm. The disarmament was scheduled for 15 February 1992. Local elders from the three tribes were selected to oversee implementation.

On 15 February 1992, the EPRDF mediated talks between the Me�en, Dizi, and Suri and oversaw their disarmament. When the Suri did not turn in all their weapons, the EPRDF sought to keep the peace and responded by sending troops to Maji and Turn.
In 1998, Nyangatom elders visited Turkana elders to perform reconciliation rituals.
The two sides performed traditional rituals at a peace meeting in Kibish in 2004, as well as promised to respect a cessation of hostilities.

Later in May 2005, a peace conference, with support from the Kuraz wereda administration, led to the signing of a peace agreement outlining plans for shared grazing resources. However, renewed violence during the second half of May terminated the peace process.

Another peace conference was held with 20 participants in Lokichogio in August 2005. Aimed at reconciling the Dassantech, Nyangatom, and Turkana, this conference was facilitated by the African Union � Interafrican Bureau for Animal Resources (AU-IBAR). This peace conference did not result in a peace agreement.

This meeting was followed up with a peace meeting between Nyangatom and Turkana representatives, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 6 April 2007. Despite this agreement, there were some violent incidences in June 2007.

The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) mediated a four-day peace meeting between the conflict parties and some other tribes in early December 2007, which led to a peace agreement.

On 12 August, the Turkana stole around 13,000 cattle from the Nyangatom. Government delegates from Ethiopia and Kenya mediated between community representatives from the Nyangatom and the Turkana in Nakuru on 10 October 2009.

A joint cross-border peace caravan was organized from 15 to 17 July 2017 to enhance reconciliation, peace-building, and conflict resolution between the Dassanech, the Nyangatom, and the Turkana. At this event at Omorate, 75 people from Turkana County and 75 people from South Omo Zone, as well as local government representatives from Kenya and Ethiopia participated.

In January 2019, the communities met at a peace conference organized by SAPCONE in the Illemi Triangle. Representatives from South Sudan and Uganda also participated. The conflict parties reached a peace agreement. On 6 April 2019, the Ateker Economic Summit convened tribal youth (from the Jie, Karamojong, Nyangatom, Teso, Toposa, and Turkana communities) in Teso North Sub County. Although this summit did not engage in direct negotiations, it was aimed at promoting peaceful relations.
In May 2019, Nyangatom and Turkana governors and tribal leaders met for peace talks to further mitigate cattle raiding and tensions.

side_b: Suleiman subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: When conflict between the clans over land and water rights reignited on 1 December 2012, Al-Shabaab and local clan elders immediately started to mediate between the leaders of the conflict parties. This led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 2 December, which was officially signed on 14 December.
The FAPC and FNI concluded a non-aggression pact in 2003, as well as an agreement to split taxes earned on trade in the region.

In addition, the FNI and the FAPC both signed the Acte d�Engagement de Kinshasa (English: Kinshasa Act of Engagement) on 14 May 2004, along other armed groups such as the Revolutionary Front for Ituri (FPRI), the Popular Front for Democracy in Congo (FPDC), the Party for Unity and Safeguarding the Integrity of Congo (PUSIC), the Union of Congolese Patriots (Thomas Lubanga) (UPC-L), and the Union of Congolese Patriots (Floribert Kisembo) (UPC-K). In September 2004, the Iturian DDR process officially started.

In addition, President Joseph Kabila attempted to reach a ceasefire agreement at Dar es Salaam in June 2004 with all the non-state armed groups operating in the Ituri region, but was unsuccessful. One of the reasons this round of negotiations failed was that the UPC remained deeply suspicious of the government as mediator, since the government had allied with Nyamwisi�s RCD-KML, which, in turn, had sided with Lendu militias. While direct clashes between the different armed groups had significantly decreased by mid-2004, the armed groups nevertheless continued to harass the local population, collect tax revenues, exploit natural resources, and engage in arms trafficking.

When the FAPC signed a mining deal with a Ugandan-based company to mine gold in the Zani river in Djalasiga, the FAPC and the FNI clashed on 15 June 2004, with both parties trying to control the goldmine and the wider region. MONUC mediated between the conflict parties in July 2004, since the fighting was seen as violating the terms of the Acte d�Engagement de Kinshasa (English: Kinshasa Act of Engagement) which had been concluded on 14 May 2004. Both the FAPC and the FNI were signatories of this agreement, which committed seven militias active in Ituri to end hostilities. MONUC�s mediation effort led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 5 July 2004. However, this ceasefire was already violated on 9 July 2004.
Both Abdullahi Yusuf and Jama Ali Jama attended the national reconciliation conference in Eldoret, Kenya, in October and November 2002.

Building on the Eldoret conference, Abdullahi Yusuf and Jama Ali Jama signed a peace agreement, which stipulated a formal power-sharing formula, on 17 May 2003. This peacemaking effort was independent of the national process.

A cross-country peace conference was mediated by the Ethiopian government in the Yabello woreda from 11 to 18 July 2006. Government officials from the participating groups, regional NGOs and diplomats from the United States and United Kingdom joined the forum. With over 300 pastoralist groups from 19 different countries in attendance, special attention was given to the conflicts involving the Borana, Gabra, and Guji. The special session was led by the Gada councils of the communities. By the end of the conference, the three groups signed a peace agreement.

A mediation team consisting of clan elders and local scholars was quickly formed to mediate between the conflict parties. This led to the conclusion of a temporary ceasefire on 7 June 2005, but the conflict reignited the next day.
third_party: traditional leaders, community leaders, local peace committee

description: The Hiran Council of Elders held talks among each other between 10 and 11 June 2005 in order to determine how to best find a solution to the ongoing conflict. It was decided that a set of elders from the Xawaadle clan would mediate between the conflict parties. Following an intervention executed by a disengagement force on 12 June, the fighters on both sides respected a ceasefire. The Xawaalde team mediated negotiations in Beledweyne between 13 and 14 June. The conflict parties signed a peace agreement on 17 June and a standing committee was set to monitor the implementation of this agreement.

Following armed clashes between Gamai and Pan tribes over land ownership in Namu in Plateau State, Governor Joshua Dariye established a committee for inquiry into the conflict as well as implemented a curfew. Governor Joshua Dariye mediated between the conflict parties in the last week of April 2006, which led to a white paper on resolving the conflict.

From 17 to 19 July 2006, Gamai and Pan leaders attended a peace meeting mediated by the International Foundation for Education and Self Help (IFESH) and the Inter-Faith Mediation Center (IMC). This peace meeting culminated in the signing of a peace agreement.
third_party: International Foundation for Education and Self Help (IFESH), local NGO

description: In June 2016, Gamai and Pan representatives began to participate in an inter-community dialogue process mediated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, along with several other community representatives from South Plateau. This led to the signing of the South Plateau Peace Declaration on 22 December 2016.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), community leaders

description: A subsequent mediation effort was led by Shaikh Ali Gure, a Somali-Kenyan religious leader from the Ogaden clan that had participated in a peace process for a Kenyan conflict involving the Garre. Shaikh Ali Gure mediated between the clan elders of both conflict parties between July and August 2005. This mediation effort led to the conclusion of a power-sharing agreement, but the conflict issue of ownership over the town was left for further peace efforts.
In August 2005, several NGOs from Beled Hawa and the Mandera District Peace Committee mediated between the conflict parties in El Wak, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire.
In December 2004, another round of negotiations led to a verbal 15-day ceasefire, but this ceasefire also broke down.
On 17 January 2005, Garre and Murule elders attended a round of peace talks mediated by the provincial government. This meeting led to the signing of a ceasefire.

A round of negotiations mediated by Muslim and Christian religious leaders in April 2005 led to the Umal Accord. The Kenyan government served as a guarantor of this agreement and the District Peace Committee was tasked to oversee its implementation.

The Kenyan government dispatched a 40-elder peace team to the Mandera district to foster continued reconciliation in February 2006. This led to the conclusion of another peace agreement between the Garre and Murule.
Peace talks between the two tribes led to the signing of a peace agreement in Mandera on 14 February 2008.

From 28 to 29 April 2008, 15 leaders from the two tribes met for another round of negotiations in Mandera. The negotiations began with separate meetings with each tribe before the two presented their positions in front of the Mandera Mediation Council led by chief mediator Sheikh Ahmed Sudan. The mediation effort led to a peace agreement that included a provision for a task force to monitor the implementation of the February agreement. The federal and local government jointly established a peace committee in 2015 � which included local tribal, religious and political leadership along with delegates from outside the Mandera district � to mediate between the conflict parties.

From 13 to 15 August 2020, the Garre and Murulle communities engaged in a dialogue process to address the escalating tensions. Facilitated by Interpeace and the NCIC, in collaboration with the Mandera County government, the dialogue brought together a committee of 20 members representing both communities, County government officials, and peace stakeholders. The culmination of this process was the signing of the Granada I peace agreement on 15 August 2020, signaling a commitment to harmony and stability between the Garre and Murulle communities in Mandera County.

On 8 February 2021, a peace agreement, known as Sheikh Umal II, was signed. It involved political leaders, elders, religious leaders, civil society members, and security teams of Murulle and Garre clans. The negotiations leading up to this agreement were mediated by Interpeace, NCIC, and the Mandera County government. The agreement outlined directives for immediate cessation of hostilities, reparations led by local peace infrastructure, and the resolution of the territorial dispute by the government.
In an attempt to end the fighting, a government reconciliation mission met with conflict parties on 13 January 2007.

Following a series of retaliatory attacks throughout the first half of December 2008, both tribes agreed to attend reconciliatory talks in Nyala on 20 December 2008, but this was postponed to 25 December. This peace conference was mediated by the Sudanese government with support from UNAMID. The conference would take until 20 February, but failed because the decision on the boundary demarcation between the tribes was unacceptable to the Fulani. Fighting resumed on 9 March 2009.

Cattle rustling resulted in renewed clashes between the Habaniya and Fulani in early September 2014. In response, UNAMID held meetings with tribal leaders and state authorities to encourage dialogue between the two communities. This resulted in the creation of a mediation committee to further dialogue and peace. UNAMID also met with South Darfur state officials to urge that the underlying and unresolved issue of border demarcation be addressed, which contributed to the defusing of a potentially volatile situation between the two tribes.
In 2006, the local administration organized a reconciliation conference. There, both parties signed a reconciliation document.

In 2000, the violence broke out in the town of Kaduna, leading to more than 200 casualties. Following this violent confrontation, the conflict leaders entered into a round of negotiations mediated by President Olusegun Obasanjo, which led to an informal agreement on 29 February 2000 in Abuja. Hausa leaders agreed to stop pursuing strict Islamic law.

On 17 October 2000, during an emergency meeting mediated by the Governor of Lagos, Bola Tinubu, at the state government secretariat auditorium, the Igbo, Hausa and Yoruba leaders reached a peace agreement. However, new clashes broke out the next day.

On 28 June 2004, representatives of 13 communities of the Jos North Local Government Area of Plateau � Afisare, Anaguta, Berom, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Ebira, Tiv, Sayawa, Southern Kaduna, South-South, and Yoruba � signed a peace agreement in Jos in which they pledged not to mix politics and religion and promised to live in peace.

The Center for Humanitarian Dialogue facilitated another meeting as part of the Jos Forum in December 2014. This led to the signing of the Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation on 11 December 2014. The agreement represents a public commitment to achieve peace among all signatories.
agreement_name: Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation

description: Following armed clashes in Jos in July 2015, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue mediated a round of negotiations between leaders of the Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, and Yoruba communities in Jos. This led to the signing of a joint declaration to end fighting in Jos.

Peace talks initiated in June 2016 and involving community representatives from six Local Government Areas in the Southern Plateau, including representatives of the Hausa and Igbo communities, led to the signing of the South Plateau Peace Declaration on 22 December 2016. The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue mediated the talks leading up this agreement.

On 4 August 2017, a 10-man peace committee equally composed of Hausa and Igbo was set up to find solution to the conflict. A meeting of the committee was held in Kano on 8 August 2017. Isa Tijani acted as the mediator of this meeting, which was aimed at reaching a peace agreement between the two tribes. However, both sides wanted further consultations before committing to an agreement.

In October 2017, the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue brought together several Plateau community leaders in Jos to discuss the recent armed clashes in the state and ways to achieve lasting peace. Among the participants were leaders from the Berom, Hausa, Afisare, Anaguta, Fulani, Igbo, and Yoruba communities. Alhaji Ibrahim Baba Hassan represented the Hausa Community, while Barr. Zacch O. Nwankpa spoke on behalf of the Igbo people. This peace meeting resulted in an appeal to all communities, religious groups, and to the Plateau State government to seek lasting peace in the region, but the talks did not lead to a written agreement.

On 26 March 2020, a joint communique was issued by the chairs of ten communities involved in the mediation process facilitated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) in Benue State. The communities included Agatu, Etulo, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Igede, Jukun, Tiv, and Yoruba ethnic groups. The communique focused on upholding peaceful co-existence during and after the COVID-19 pandemic.

In June 2016, Hausa and Tarok representatives began to participate in an inter-community dialogue process mediated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, along with several other community representatives from South Plateau. This led to the signing of the South Plateau Peace Declaration on 22 December 2016.

The violence erupted again in July 1999 in Shagamu, following the murder of a Hausa woman observing a Yoruba traditional ceremony. Some Hausa subsequently fled to Kano, resulting in the spread of violence in that city, where some Hausas attacked Yorubas in retaliation for the Shagamu events. Following the clashes in Kano, Governor and Police Commissioner Abubakar Mairamri visited the affected areas to try to ease the tension and ensure state support. A curfew was imposed and the Emir of Kano, Alhaji Ado Bayero, the Governors of Kano and Lagos as well as the police commissioner appealed for peace in separated broadcasts. In late July 1999, Bola Tinubu, the Governor of Lagos, held a meeting with Hausa and Yoruba leaders in Lagos to encourage peaceful cooperation. Negotiations between both sides in the palace of the Akarigbo led to the signing of a peace agreement on 24 July 1999. The peace pact led to a few months of peace in the region.

Representatives of the conflict parties met again in Ajegunle in the Ajeromi/Ifelodun council of Lagos State on 3 November 1999 and agreed to an immediate cessation of hostilities in Lagos. The signatories were representatives of the Ijaw, the Ilaje, the Hausa and the Oodua People�s Congress (OPC � a Yoruba militia). Dele Alake, the Information Commissioner, along with other members of the State Executive Council acted as mediators.

On 28 November 1999, in reaction to renewed fighting between Hausa and Yoruba over the control over the Ketu / Mile 12 market in Lagos, the Governor of Lagos, Bola Tinubu, mediated negotiations between the leaders of the Hausa and Yoruba communities. This led to a peace agreement in early December.

However, the armed conflict continued in 2000. In October 2000, the government banned the OPC and imposed a curfew on the city of Lagos. Several members of the OPC went to court. On 17 October 2000, the Governor of Lagos, Bola Tinubu, mediated between Igbo, Hausa, and Yoruba leaders during an emergency meeting at the state government secretariat auditorium. This led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. However, armed fighting resumed the next day.

Violent clashes erupting in Idi-Araba on 2 to 4 February 2002 led to the deployment of the Nigerian army in the area and several meetings between government officials and leaders of the Hausa and Yoruba communities. On 5 February 2002, a meeting between the Governor of Lagos State, Bola Tinubu, and the Hausa and Yoruba leaders took place in Lagos. The Governor encouraged the two ethnic groups to achieve peace and reconciliation.

A peace meeting hosted by the Inter-Ethnic Forum in Lagos in January 2003 gathered ethnic leaders from the Yoruba and Hausa communities from Idi-Araba. The leaders pledged to cease hostilities. The meeting led to the establishment of several committees � for example elders and youth committees composed of both Yoruba and Hausa � that were to ensure a lasting peace.

On 28 June 2004, representatives of 13 communities of the Jos North Local Government Area of Plateau � the Afisare, Anaguta, Berom, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Ebira, Tiv, Sayawa, Southern Kaduna, South-South, and Yoruba � signed a peace agreement in Jos. They pledged not to mix politics and religion and promised to live in peace. The peace meeing was not mediated by an external third party.

On 20 March 2012, following renewed violence in the Mile 12 market in Lagos between youth from the two communities, the local police organized a peace meeting between community leaders at the State Command Headquarters, Ikeja. The Lagos State Police Commissioner, Mr. Umaru Manko, mediated between the conflict parties. The conflict parties agreed to set up a 12-person peace committee. Alhaji Haruna Mohammed represented the Hausa, while Mr. Ashowade Adesina headed the Yoruba delegates. The two groups pledge to stop armed fighting, but did not conclude a written agreement.

The Center for Humanitarian Dialogue facilitated another meeting as part of the Jos Forum in December 2014. This led to the signing of the Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation on 11 December 2014. Umaru Sani and Bankole Falade signed on behalf of the Hausa and Yoruba communities respectively. The agreement represents a public commitment to achieve peace among all signatories.
agreement_name: Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation

description: Following armed clashes in Jos in July 2015, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue mediated a round of negotiations between leaders of the Afisare, Anaguta, Berom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, and Yoruba communities in Jos. This led to the signing of a joint declaration to end fighting in Jos.

On 6 March 2016, following the armed violence in Mile 12, the secretary to the state government representing Governor Akinwunmi Ambode, Mr. Tunji Bello, met with market stakeholders including Yoruba and Hausa traditional leaders at the Alausa Secretariat, Ikeja. This meeting led to a peace agreement signed by the stakeholders and the 12 Mile market reopened. Oba Akiolu of Lagos also held a stakeholders� and residents� meeting in at the Iga-Idugaran, Lagos Island at the beginning of March 2016. He supported the relocation of the market as a path to peace. Finally, on 16 March 2016, community leaders and market traders followed the plan of the state government and accepted the relocation of the market.

In October 2017, the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue brought together several Plateau community leaders in Jos to discuss the recent armed clashes in the state and ways to achieve lasting peace. Among the participants were leaders from the Berom, Hausa, Afisare, Anaguta, Fulani, Igbo, and Yoruba communities. Alhaji Ibrahim Baba Hassan represented the Hausa Community, while Chief Bankole Falade spoke on behalf of the Yoruba people. This peace meeting resulted in an appeal to all communities, religious groups, and to the Plateau State government to seek lasting peace in the region, but the talks did not lead to a written agreement.

Tensions rose again in Akure in May 2018. In response, the state government brought the leaders of the two communities together in the Cocoa Conference Hall for a peace meeting. The meeting resulted in the conclusion of a peace agreement.

On 26 March 2020, a joint communique was issued by the chairs of ten communities involved in the mediation process facilitated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) in Benue State. The communities included Agatu, Etulo, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Igede, Jukun, Tiv, and Yoruba ethnic groups. The communique focused on upholding peaceful co-existence during and after the COVID-19 pandemic.
On 29 July 1999, a reconciliation meeting began in CCI-Nyakasanza and 451 people attended. It continued on 30 July, but did not result in a peace agreement.

Throughout the year, the Ugandan army and rebels aided in mediating the conflict. Wamba dia Wamba who had fled to Bunia in Ituri from Kisangani in August 1999 after the RCD�s split between RCD-Goma and RCD-ML (the latter being thereafter led by Wamba) also tried to mediate between the ethnic groups in 1999 and initially had a pacifying influence as he initiated peace talks and promoted ceremonies of mutual forgiveness. Two initiatives were established by the end of the year to pacify the conflict. The first initiative was the establishment of the Committee of Pacification and Follow-Up in August 1999 by Ad�le Lotsove to investigate the outbreak of violence. The second initiative was the creation of the Commission for Security and Peace in the Djugu Zone by RCD-ML leader Wamba dia Wamba. This commission was led by Jacques Depelchin. Negotiations mediated by Depelchin between November and December 1999 resulted in a brief pause in the fighting, but the conflict reignited in mid-December 1999.

The year 2000 was characterized by leadership struggles in the RCD-ML. Wamba�s power in the RCD-ML was being questioned by RCD-ML�s prime minister and member of an influential Nande family in North Kivu, Mbusa Nyamwisi and RCD-ML�s minister of mining, finance and budget and former head of the Kilo Moto gold mines in Ituri, John Tibasima, himself from Ituri and the Hema ethnic community. Their forces clashed in Ituri and ended with Wamba�s evacuation by the Ugandans in November 2000. This led to a lack of leadership in Ituri and a militarization of the communal conflict. Both Nyamwisi and Tibasima had trained and recruited soldiers for the RCD-ML from both Lendu and Hema communities and provided them with arms and training. With the lack of leadership, these soldiers now dispersed in their communities, which led to an intensification of the conflict between Hema and Lendu towards the end of 2000. A second round of heavy fighting erupted at the beginning of 2001. Lendu militias attacked Bunia for the first time, especially targeting UPDF headquarters and the airport. From 14 to 17 February 2001, the Front de Lib�ration du Congo (FLC) (English: Front for the Liberation of Congo), specifically via Jean-Pierre Bemba, mediated negotiations between the two groups. A peace agreement was signed by more than 150 local chiefs and notables on 17 February 2001. This agreement stipulated an end to hostilities, as well as included a provision for the new governor to be from neither ethnic group and two vice-governors, one from each ethnic group. The agreement also tasked the FLC �with closing ethnic militia training camps, disarming civilians, deploying security forces, setting up peace tribunals throughout the region, rehabilitating prisons, and creating a special provincial follow-up committee.� The eminent persons present thereafter buried their machetes as a sign of reconciliation. Yet, the agreement was not fully implemented as Bemba lost control over Ituri in November 2001 after the disintegration of the FLC in June 2001 and several violent confrontations took place between RCD-ML and MLC. Ituri was subsequently almost fully controlled by RCD-ML.

The RCD-ML appointed a new governor and chief of staff in Ituri in early 2002, Jean-Pierre Mulondo Lonpondo. Many Hema perceived Jean-Pierre Mulondo Lonpondo as biased in favor of the Lendu, although he was from the Nande ethnic group. This further exacerbated local tensions and violence escalated again throughout Ituri, including in Bunia. In August 2002, the Union des Patriotes Congolais (UPC) (English: Union of Congolese Patriotes), a militia predominately made of Hema fighters, formed a government in Bunia and temporarily managed to rule over most of Ituri. In July and August 2002, informal talks were held between Hema and Lendu representatives in Kinshasa. These talks were facilitated by the Congolese Government with human rights minister, Ntumba Luaba, in the lead. The negotiations did not lead to the conclusion of an agreement. Direct negotiations between the Government of the DRC and the Government of Uganda, mediated by Angolan President Jos� Eduardo Dos Santos, led to the conclusion of the Luanda Peace Agreement on 6 September 2002. This agreement not only put forward a timetable of three months for the Uganda forces to leave Ituri, it also established the Ituri Pacification Commission (IPC). The IPC was tasked, with support from MONUC, to bring together the leaders of all armed groups and representatives of civil society in Ituri in an effort to create an administrative authority for the region acceptable to all parties. However, it would not be until April 2003 before the first meeting of the IPC finally took place.

In the final days of December 2002, Ugandan Lt. General Salim Saleh and Ugandan gender, labour and social affairs minister, Zoe Bakoko Bakoru started to mediate a round of negotiations between the ethnic groups in Arua. The negotiations were aimed at concluding a peace agreement that would commit the Hema and the Lendu to halt hostilities.

The representatives of the UPC and the Front des Nationalistes et Int�grationnistes (FNI) (English: Nationalist and Integrationist Front), representing the Hema and Lendu respectively, were supposed to finalize the agreement in Arua on 1 January 2003, but the UPC refused to sign the agreement last minute. However, five days later, Ugandan Lt. General Salim Saleh succeeded in persuading UPC to sign the accord on behalf of the Hema.

The MONUC leadership sent an exploratory committee to Ituri to secure a local ceasefire and start building confidence among the members of the IPC from 22 to 29 January 2003. The MONUC team met all the actors in the Ituri crisis, including the Hema and the Lendu leaders. All agreed in principle to sign a peace agreement in Bunia. However, the UPC remained reluctant to support the IPC, stating that it was dominated by the government that had sided with Lendu ethnic groups through Mbusa Nyamwisi and wanted to pursue its own peace process so it could recuperate Ituri from the Ugandans.

On 11 February 2003, there was a summit in Dar-es-Salaam, Tanzania between Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni, Hema leader Thomas Lubanga, Congolese President Joseph Kabila, and representatives from Rwanda. This meeting served to relaunch the peace process. It was decided that the IPC would meet for the first time on 25 February 2003 and that the Ugandan troop withdrawal from Ituri would start on 20 March 2003. A ceasefire was scheduled to take effect in February 2003, before the first meeting of the IPC, but this ceasefire was postponed because the UPC questioned the good faith of the governments of Uganda and the DRC and MONUC. This stalled the process once again.

On 3 March 2003, the UN Special Representative Namanga Ngongi, with help from P�tronile Vaweka of the Alur tribe and founder and president of the association Fondation pour la Paix Durable, negotiated a ceasefire in Ituri. On 18 March 2003, Ngongi finally succeeded in creating a ceasefire at a round of negotiations in Bunia: the Ituri Cessation of Hostilities Agreement. However, the UPC, claiming to represent the Hema, refused to sign the ceasefire. The ceasefire also included a provision that stipulated the Ugandan troops to leave the DRC by 24 April 2003.

On 26 April 2003 the Ugandan army handed over command of Ituri to MONUC. MONUC deployed 700 peacekeepers, while the DRC government deployed 700 Special Forces. Yet, one week later, violence completely escalated with the government forces overwhelmed and MONUC losing control over Bunia in May 2003. In only two days, 562 civilians were killed by militias. In response, the Government of Tanzania and MONUC facilitated a round of negotiations between the Government of the DRC and leaders of the main Iturian militias on 17 May 2003. This round of negotiations led to the conclusion of the Dar-Es-Salaam Agreement on 17 May 2003, which stipulated a ceasefire and the rights of the militias to be eligible for either integration into the national army or civilian reinsertion. On 30 May 2003, the Security Council adopted Resolution 1484, which authorized an interim emergency multinational force to restore peace and aid in humanitarian relief. This force, called Operation Artemis, consisted of 1,800 French troops and a small 80-man Swedish special forces unit. On 12 June 2003, the EU-led mission was launched in Bunia, the main town of Ituri region. The mission was mandated to last until 1 September 2003. In June 2003, the peacekeepers managed to restore security in the town, although massacres continued in the countryside.

On 1 August 2003, three Ministers of the new transitional government, set up in April and May 2003 and coming into being on 18 July 2003, visited Bunia to support the Ituri Interim Administration. With the exception of UPC, the armed groups expressed their willingness to be incorporated into the new armed forces. The new government mediated a round of negotiations between the Ituri militias in Kinshasa on 22 August 2003, which led to a memorandum of understanding in which the militias agree to work with the government to restore state authority across the region.

On 16 September 2003, an agreement to make Bunia a weapons free zone was reached between the conflict parties. Members of the Interim Administration regularly participated in information-gathering missions outside Bunia, where meetings were held with local authorities and populations to inform them of the existing peace process. The Interim Administration also organized successful peace marches in the town and was solving problems related to illegally occupied houses in Bunia. Yet, between 2003 and 2005, Bunia remained divided into two parts: one controlled by FNI and dominated by Lendu ethnic groups and one controlled by UPC and dominated by Hema ethnic groups. All aspects of public life were separated.

On 14 May 2004, the Dar-Es-Salaam Agreement was reiterated in the Acte d�Engagement de Kinshasa (English: Kinshasa Act of Engagement). This agreement, among others, stipulated a ceasefire. The militias that signed this agreement were the Popular Armed Forces for the Congo (FAPC), the Nationalist and Integrationist Front (FNI), the Revolutionary Front for Ituri (FPRI), the Popular Front for Democracy in Congo (FPDC), the Party for Unity and Safeguarding the Integrity of Congo (PUSIC), the Union of Congolese Patriots (Thomas Lubanga) (UPC-L), and the Union of Congolese Patriots (Floribert Kisembo) (UPC-K).

In September 2004, the Iturian DDR process officially started. In addition, President Joseph Kabila attempted to reach another ceasefire agreement at Dar es Salaam in June 2004 with all the non-state armed groups operating in the Ituri region, but was unsuccessful. One of the reasons this round of negotiations failed was that the UPC remained deeply suspicious of the government as mediator, since the government had allied with Nyamwisi�s RCD-KML, which, in turn, had sided with Lendu militias. While direct clashes between the different armed groups had significantly decreased by mid-2004, the armed groups nevertheless continued to harass the local population, collect tax revenues, exploit natural resources, and engage in arms trafficking. The International Committee in Support of the Transition in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (CIAT) gave an ultimatum to all militia groups in Ituri to voluntarily disarm by the end of March 2005 or face major consequences. In early April 2005, CIAT requested that the Government of the DRC launch both national and international arrest orders against leaders of militia groups in Ituri accused of crimes against humanity. Most militia chiefs subsequently stepped down from power or were arrested between March and April 2005.

Fighting resumed in 2016. In March 2016, MONUSCO and provincial authorities helped to facilitate negotiations between the Hema and Lendu in the Irumu territory. This led to a pledge to cease hostilities and a subsequent reduction in violence. However, violence increased not long after.

Following a series of armed clashes between the Hema and Lendu communities in Djugu territory, MONUSCO staff from Bunia co-mediated a round of peace talks on 29 December 2017, along with the Territorial Administrator of Djugu territory and the president of Committee of Customary Chiefs of Ituri (COCCI). The traditional chiefs from both communities concluded a local agreement. It was also decided to set up local peace committees between neighbouring Hema and Lendu communities in order to enhance mutual trust.

On 30 March 2008, during its summit in Damascus, the Arab League formulated an Arab Initiative for the Resolution of the Lebanese crisis. This initiative called for the election of the Commander in Chief of the Army, Michel Sleiman, as the consensus candidate for President, the establishment of a unity government, and the normalization of Syrian-Lebanese relations. From 1 to 3 May 2008, the League�s Secretary General Amr Moussa held talks with Parliament Speaker Nabih Berri, Prime Minister Fouad Siniora, Michel Suleiman, Saad Hariri, Michel Aoun, Hezbollah member of parliament Haj Hassan Khalil, member of parliament Michel al-Murr, and Defense Minister Elias al-Murr to discuss the implementation of the Arab initiative. Since the PSP is a party on the side of the government, these shuttle talks are considered mediated negotiations.

On 11 May 2008, Talal Arslan, a Druze leader and ally of Hezbollah, brokered a ceasefire between the two sides following a request by PSP leader Walid Jumblatt. The two parties were heavily fighting in the mountainous area of Aley, when Jumblatt urged Arslan to secure the redeployment of the Lebanese Army there. However, the ceasefire did not hold.

On 11 May 2008, the Arab League held an emergency meeting and established a Ministerial Committee, led by Qatari Prime Minister Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani and Secretary General Amr Moussa, to intervene in the Lebanese crisis. On 14 May 2008, the government announced the repeal of some of the contentious decisions it had previously made concerning the airport security department and Hezbollah�s communication network. On the same day, the Arab League mediation team led by Qatari Prime Minister Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani visited Beirut to present a six-point agreement aimed at resolving the political crisis in the country. This visit preceded the national dialogue scheduled to take place two days later in Doha. The Lebanese parties agreed on the proposed deal and to engage in new talks.

To resolve the 18-month political crisis in Lebanon, the Arab league committee, headed by Emir Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani of Qatar, organized the Lebanese National Dialogue Conference in Doha from 16 to 21 May 2008. Parties present included Hezbollah, the Amal Movement, the Syrian Social Nationalist Party, the Lebanese Democrat Party, the Progressive Socialist Party, the Future Movement, and the Lebanese Government. Through bilateral and collective meetings, the parties reached the Doha Agreement, which established a power-sharing government and appointed the Commander of the Armed Forces, Michel Suleiman, as president. This agreement also committed the parties to abstain from �resuming the use of weapons and violence in order to record political gains.� Moreover, Hezbollah�s demands were addressed, granting them veto power in the new national unity government and an electoral law was adopted dividing Lebanon into smaller-sized districts.

The trigger for a full-scale armed conflict was the rape of a Newiba girl by a member of the Hotiya in Serif Omra locality. The Hotiya Baggara financially compensated the Newiba during a customary conflict resolution process in October 2005, but this reconciliation process collapsed following an insult by someone from the Newiba delegation. The Hotiya subsequently killed the entire seven-man delegation, which, in turn, prompted a massive counter-attack by the Newiba with support from the Mahariba and Mahamid. The fighting took mainly place in the Nyangadoula area in the Abaata locality.
A reconciliation conference facilitated by the local authorities led to an agreement in March 2006. This agreement successfully terminated the armed conflict.

The Inter-Riverine Development Agency (IRDA) initiated a peace process between the Hubeer and Yantaar communities on 20 January 2005. A Project Community Committee (PCC) was formed with representatives from both sub-clans and Asharaf elders from Dinsoo, along with three IRDA members to facilitate the process. The first phase of the peace conference took place in Hawaala Barbaar from 3-5 March 2005, with 120 attendees from both sides. They agreed to prioritize implementing points in the accord, including the ceasefire, postponing the core issue. The second phase was scheduled for June 2006 but was delayed due to lack of funds. The emergence of the Islamic Courts Union (ICU) further impacted the process, and in November 2006, the peace accord was broken when a Hubeer militia killed a Yantaar member, leading to revenge killings.
third_party: Inter-Riverine Development Agency, local peace committee

description: Local elders mediated between the two subclans at a peace meeting in Idale in February 2006, which led to the confirmation of a peace agreement from 2005.

The Transitional Federal Government (TFG) established the National Reconciliation Commission (NRC) in late 2005 with the task of facilitating reconciliation throughout the country. On 23 November 2006, the NRC arrived in Idale to help find a solution to the conflict between the Huber and Yantar. The NRC brokered a 15-day ceasefire, which was extended for another ten days following another armed clash by the end of the 15-day period.

The ceasefire of November 2006 held, and the NRC facilitated a peace conference in Baidoa on 15 January 2007, which led to the signing of a peace agreement on 15 January 2007. This agreement stipulated that the conflict parties would forgive past actions, that the land, including Idale village, belongs to Allah but that the state would manage it through the municipality, and that the water catchments that triggered the conflict would be managed by the municipality of the village.

The Nigerian government played a central role in mediating between the Ijaw and Isteriki. On 23 April 1997, military authorities announced that they have sent military troop to Warri to restore order. At the beginning of May 1997, youths and leaders from the Ijaw and Itsekiri communities gathered in Effon, near Warri, for a peace meeting chaired by the state administrator, Colonel David Dang, and the General Officer Commanding the 82nd Division of the Nigerian Army, Major General Felix Mojapero. At this occasion, the warring parties agreed to end hostilities. However, there is no public information available on the signing of a written agreement. Furthermore, the Delta State government, under the leadership of the military administrator, Colonel J. Dang, set up a Commission of Inquiry into the violence, chaired by Judge Alhassan Idoko. The commission, composed of Itsekiri, Ijaw, and Urhobo first met in June and July 1997, but the report never went public. As violence erupted again in Warri on 15 June 1997, Itsekiri leaders withdrew from the government commission of inquiry, fearing that the outcome would be unfavorable to them.

As violence between the two communities erupted again in Orgubo on 23 October 1998, the Nigerian government asked the two tribes to meet and negotiate an end to the conflict and instituted a public curfew on 24 October 1998. The leaders of Ijaw and Itsekiri subsequently met at a peace meeting in Asaba, capital of Delta State, on 26 October 1998. This peace meeting was mediated by Commander Walter Feghabor, military administrator, and resulted in a ten-point communiqu� calling for an immediate cessation of the ongoing hostilities. Feghabor, Ijaw, and Isteriki representatives were set to meet with General Abdulsalami Abubaka for follow-up.

The negotiations mediated by Governor James Ibori one week later, in Asaba on 24 June 1999, were successful and led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement. The agreement was signed by Justice Franklin Atake for the Itsekiris, Chief Edwin Clark for the Ijaws, and Chief Benjamin Okumagba for the Urhobos. On 10 October 1999, representatives of young activists from the Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Urhobo communities announced the creation of a new association: the Warri Peace Vanguard. This association had the aim to help the communities to put an end to the conflict that has ravaged Warri for decades. Government, religious groups, traditional leaders, and private agencies were present at the first meeting of the newly founded association. A six-point peace plan was formed that included supporting government peace programs, mobilizing community development, and promoting a peaceful way of life.

Following negotiations, the Ijaw and Itsekiri signed a peace agreement on 1 February 2000. The Delta State Government mediated this round of negotiations. On 17 March, Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Isoko leaders visited President Obasanjo in Abuja to announce the return of peace to Warri.

The Governor of Delta State eventually agreed to renegotiate the electoral boundaries during peace talks in Warri in the end of March 2003. These peace talks between the Ijaw and Itsekiri leaders and the Delta State government led to the signing of a ceasefire between the two communities on 26 March 2003.
Another ceasefire agreement was reached on 26 March 2003 between the Ijaw youth (FNDIC) and the Itsekiri in the presence of state officials.

On 7 April 2003, Obasanjo met with Urhobo, Itsekiri, and Ijaw leaders in Abuja along with the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC), and security chiefs to further talk about peaceful solutions in Warri. At this meeting, the warring tribes reached a ceasefire agreement. Following this meeting, Obasanjo set up a committee headed by General Theophilus Y. Danjuma, the former Minister of defense. This committee was tasked with investigating the Warri Crisis and proposing ways to solve it. The report of this committee has not been made public.
On 15 May 2003, the national leader of Nigeria�s Ijaw ethnic communities reported that the youth of the Ijaw militia agreed to a ceasefire.

In July 2003, Delta State governor, James Ibori, moved the seat of his government to Warri to personally undertake the peace talks. On 20 July 2003, the Delta State Governor announced that leaders of the two tribes declared a ceasefire in Warri.

Concerned about a possible offensive by the Ijaw and Itsekiri youths, the Deputy Inspector General of Police in charge of Zone 5, Mr. Gazali Lawal, and the Delta State Police Commissioner, Mr. Jonathan Akaya, held peace meetings with the leaders of the two communities in the Police Zone Command Office in Warri on the night of 9 to 10 August 2003. The meeting culminated in a communiqu� signed by Mr. Justice Rewane for the Itsekiri, Chief Bare Etobor and Chief Tunde Smooth for the Ijaws, and by Akaya on behalf of the police. He urged the warring youth to support the government�s peace efforts. However, armed violence still erupted in spite of this effort and Nigerian authorities imposed a curfew on the town of Warri on 15 August 2003.

Nigerian troops were deployed in Warri after some 100 people were killed between 15 and 20 August. In addition, the federal government deployed a joint security force in Delta State: �Operation Restore Hope�, which would be maintained in the following years. On 20 August 2003, the leaders of the two ethnic groups met in Warri and signed a ceasefire mediated by Delta State governor, James Ibori. Chief Edwin Clark, the Ijaw leader, and Bob Mene-Afejeiku, the leader of the Itsekiri, announced, in separate interviews on 27 August 2003, that they agreed with Obasanjo�s proposal to end the crisis in Warri. This proposal involved separating political issues from criminal acts in order to facilitate the resolution of the conflict.

On 28 August 2003, James Ibori, Governor of Delta State, addressed the members of the Delta State Assembly in Asaba and proposed a peace plan for the Warri crisis. The plan called for each of the three warring ethnic groups � the Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Urhobo � to have its own local government area. While Ijaw and Urhobo leaders endorsed it, Itsekiri referred to the plan as �illegal� and �unconstitutional� and expressed their dissatisfaction with it.

On 19 September 2003, Nigerian President Obasanjo attended a meeting with Ijaw, Urhobo, and Itsekiri leaders in Warri in order to promote reconciliation. The meeting was chaired by the state administrator, Colonel David Dang, and the General Officer Commanding the 82nd Division of the Nigerian Army, Major General Felix Mojapero. The Ijaws and Urhobos deplored Itsekiri�s unjust domination of political power and supported Obori�s proposal to create local government areas. Itsekiri representatives once again rejected this proposal.

New clashes began in January 2004 between the two rival ethnic groups in the swamps surrounding the port of Warri. A 28-member peace committee, consisting of 14 Itsekiri and 14 Ijaws, met on 18 February 2004 in Warri. James Ibori and the Commissioner for Special Missions, Inter-Ethnic Relations, and Conflict Resolution, Ovuozorie Macaulay, acted as the mediators. The peace committee meeting led to approval of a six-point agreement aimed at peaceful coexistence between the rival groups. Among the main points are the establishment of a joint peace vanguard composed of members of both groups and an agreement that would allow people displaced by the conflict to return to their homes of origin without fear of attack.

On 1 June 2004, leaders of ethnic Ijaw and Itsekiri youth activist groups signed a ceasefire through the platform of the Warri Ijaw/Itsekiri Grassroots Peace Front (WIIGPF) moderated by Pastor Power Ziakede Aginighan.

Three weeks after the ceasefire concluded by the militias and after more than six months of peace negotiations, the Ijaw and the Istekiri leaders signed a peace agreement on 23 June 2004 at the senior officers� mess, NNS Delta Navy base, in Warri. Delta State Commissioner for Inter-Ethnic Relation and Conflict Resolution, Comrade Ovuzuorie Macauley was chief mediator of the negotiations. On 6 July 2004, three Ijaws chiefs � Wellington Okrika, Jonathan Ari, and Clark Gbenewei � from the 14-member delegation to the 28-member peace committee set up in February 2004 withdrew from the agreement, saying they were no longer satisfied with it. Some Ijaws argued that the agreement failed to address some of the contentious issues that had pitted the other two ethnic groups against Itsekiris, in particular the issue of separate local government for each Warri community.

After renewed clashes between the Izzi and Ukele communities, the deputy governors of Ebonyi and Cross Rive States mediated between the conflict parties on 3 July 2018. This led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. The agreement stipulated that both sides would lay down their weapons, as well as establish a peace committee that would investigate the causes of the crisis.

In early December 2019, after repeated attacks between the Izzi and the Ukele, youth from both communities reached a peace agreement after failed efforts from the local state authorities. However, violence resumed in December 2019, which led to the death of a 17-year-old student in the Local Government Area of Izzi.
On 7 July 2008, the Jie and Turkana reached a peace agreement in the Kotido district during a round of peace talks mediated by Kenyan and Ugandan government officials.

The leaders of the Jie and Turkana engaged in peace talks in Turkana West district in December 2013. This led to the signing of a peace agreement in which both sides promised to end cattle raiding. This peace effort took place in Turkana West district.

Conflict over cattle raiding continued in 2016. The two tribes met for peace talks in Kotido. This round of talks was initiated by the Jie peace committee and mediated by KOPEIN. The meeting led to the formation of a taskforce to find the stolen cattle. Several community-level meetings were organized by the taskforce afterward to keep the peace.

The Somali Reconciliation Conference in Eldoret, which was mediated by the Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD), started on 15 October 2002 and led to the conclusion of a temporary ceasefire signed by 22 armed groups on 27 October. The conference was attended by most supporters of the TNG, including the JVA. While General Morgan refused to participate in this peace conference, General Morgan and the JVA signed the Eldoret Agreement in December 2002.

The resumption of armed conflict between the Forces of General Morgan and the JVA in 2004 should be seen in the context of the broader national-level power struggle between the TNG and the opposition. In early 2004, General Morgan resumed attacks against JVA. IGAD condemned this military campaign and called for sanctions on 27 July. Morgan was subsequently also denied entry into IGAD member states. Morgan was defeated, and he fled to Nairobi following heavy fighting in Juba in September 2004. General Morgan subsequently declared a unilateral ceasefire and began to participate in negotiations at the conference on 25 September 2004. In November 2004, the Transnational Federal Government (TFG) was established, with support from JVA. With the TFG in place, IGAD stopped its mediation effort to try and reach a formal ceasefire agreement.
In March 2012, 24 elders from each tribe negotiated a draft agreement mediated by HD.
A round of peace talks mediated by the Upper East Regional Coordinating Council (RCC) led to the signing of a ceasefire on 20 February 2008.

The Ghana Kusasi and Mamprusi engaged in a round of negotiations mediated by World Vision-Ghana, WANEP, and the Northern Development Forum (NDF). This round of talks led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 12 May 2010. Following this agreement, the Mamprusi joined the BIEPC again in June 2010.
third_party: World Vision Ghana, WANEP, Northern Development Forum
