description: President Salva Kiir initiated negotiations with SSDF leader Paulino Matip. This led to the Juba Declaration on Unity and Integration on 8 January 2006. The Declaration primarily laid the basis for unifying rival military forces in South Sudan, but also initiated a disarmament process. In the context of a disarmament process which also targeted the Murle and the Nuer, the SPLM/A mediated between the two tribes in June 2006. This mediation effort reportedly led to a decrease in tensions between the Murle and the Nuer.

The conflict between the Lou Nuer and the Murle escalated in 2009, with violence not only involving cattle raids, but also attacks on civilians and communities as a whole in the Greater Akobo, the greater Pibor, the Greater Bor areas. The Sudanese government, with support from the United Nations Mission in Sudan (UNMIS), facilitated a reconciliation meeting between the Nuer and the Murle in early May 2009, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire. A Joint Lou Nuer/Murle ceasefire committee was subsequently mandated to help implement this ceasefire. This reportedly reduced tensions in Akobo and Pibor counties of Jonglei State. On 13 May, the UN Mission in Sudan (UNMIS) announced it would temporarily deploy around 120 civilian, military and police personnel to Akobo and Pibor to assist local communities to engage in dialogue to prevent further violence. In June 2009, the Southern Sudan Peace Commission worked with state authorities, traditional authorities, UNMIS, UN Development Programme, and PACT to organize a peace conference to resolve the conflict between the Murle and the Nuer, but this conference was postponed several times, until the governor delayed it indefinitely in December 2009.

In February 2011, a Murle milita killed three Nuer chiefs in Thiam Payam. The Southern government authorities and UNMIS mediated a peace agreement between the conflict parties, which was signed on 10 April 2011. However, the Lou Nuer conducted a coordinated, retaliatory attack on Murle cattle camps in the eastern part of Pibor county in late April 2011 and launched a large-scale attack killing hundreds of Murle in June 2011. Armed violence between the Nuer and the Murle continued following South Sudan gaining independence on 9 July 2011. On 18 August 2011, Murle youths conducted a massive attack on Nuer civilians in Pieri in Uror county, which resulted in around 740 people killed and the theft of 38,00 heads of cattle. David Yau Yau and his fighters, who had signed an amnesty agreement with the South Sudanese government in June 2011, allegedly had provided some Murle with weapons prior to this attack.

Jonglei state governor Kuol Manyang Juuk and Jonglei state Minister of Parliamentary Affairs Gabriel Gai Riem repeatedly attempted to organize an all-Jonglei peace conference aimed at resolving the conflict between the Murle and the Nuer, but such a conference failed to materialize in August 2011. However, the Sudan Council of Churches (SCC) managed to initiate peace talks between the Murle and the Lou Nuer at a peace conference on 7 and 8 October 2011. Archbishop of the Episcopal Church of Sudan Daniel Deng Bul acted as the chief mediator. The conference brought together representatives of the Nuer and the Murle, as well as around 100 politicians from both the South Sudan national assembly and Jonglei state legislature. However, the peace conference did not produce a tangible outcome. Instead, the mediation team and the conflict parties agreed upon a four-step process, including (1) the delegations of the conflict parties consulting with their communities how to end the violence and address their grievances, (2) joint delegations with chiefs, women, and youth from both sides visiting communities to show that the peace process is a collective responsibility, (3) consultations with the communities on how to peace process could be taken forward, and (4) a peace conference aimed at an agreement on ending the violence and the return of abducted women and children prior to the start of the dry season in mid-December 2011. UNMISS provided logistical support to the peace process between August and December 2011, supporting key leaders with authority in the communities to advocate for peace.
third_party: religious leaders, local government, government, UNMISS

description: Up until December 2011, the SCC continued consultations with all communities, trying to design a framework for peace. However, the SCC failed to initiate official negotiations because the Lou Nuer and Murle could not agree on where to hold a peace conference. The SCC proposed a neutral area, such as Juba or Rumbek, but the Lou Nuer insisted the conference be held in Waat, which is centrally located in Nuer territory. The Lou Nuer leaders set a deadline of 1 December for action by the Murle community to prevent further cattle raids and for the return of their stolen cattle and women and children. Between October and December 2011, UNMISS representatives, government officials, and church leaders all repeatedly tried to convince the Nuer prophet Dak Kueth Deng to not call for an attack.
third_party: religious leaders, local government, government, UNMISS

description: Nevertheless, following a Murle attack on Bor Dinka in the Jalle area, Dak Kueth Deng decided to a mobilize a large group of Nuer fighters, known as the White Army, to launch a revenge attack on the Murle in Pibor county in December 2011. The SCC called off a peace conference that was set for 12 December when it became apparent that the Lou Nuer would conduct an attack in revenge of the Murle attack in August 2011. In addition to deploying a battalion to the main centers of Pibor county, UNMISS flew Vice-President Riek Machar to Lekwangole town on 28 and 29 December for him to persuade the Nuer militia leaders to withdraw, but with no success. The Nuer militia proceeded towards Pibor county.

When the Lou Nuer attack Pibor town on 2 January 2012, the South Sudanese government forces stationed there opened fire and managed to fend off the attack. This was the first time South Sudanese government forces opened fire to end communal violence. Two armored UN vehicles deterred the Lou Nuer on the eastern side of Pibor town. The Lou Nuer fighters withdrew from Pibor town on 4 January 2011, but moved deeper into Murle territory. The peace conference between Murle and Lou Nuer which had been scheduled for mid-December was held in January 2012, amidst the Nuer attack on the Murle in Pibor. The South Sudanese government deployed more than 12,000 soldiers in Jonglei to stop the fighting between Nuer and Murle in March 2012. Government forces in Jonglei were also tasked with a general disarmament campaign in what was called Operation Restore Peace.
third_party: religious leaders, local government, government, UNMISS

description: Between 1 and 5 May 2012, the leaders of the conflict parties met in Bor for the All Jonglei Peace Conference. While a series of resolutions and recommendations were adopted on strategies for reducing inter-communal tensions, abduction, livestock theft, and disputes over common grazing areas, the resolutions did not detail how these measures might be put into practice and the conflict parties did not agree on a ceasefire.
third_party: local peace committee, religious leaders, government

description: The Lou Nuer leaders and politicians of Greater Akobo held a reconciliation conference from 23 to 25 May 2012, which was supported by UNMISS.

In 2017, UNMISS facilitated several workshops between the Lou Nuer and Murle in Jonglei state in response to tensions between the two communities. These workshops were aimed at preventing a future resumption of previous hostilities.

In September 2020, UNMISS hosted a peace conference to address the prolonged violence in the Jonglei region involving Dinka, Nuer, and Murle groups. The meeting involved political leaders at national and state levels, community elders, civil society representatives, and other stakeholders engaging in peace talks. The conference led to the signing of the Bor Communiqu� on 9 September 2020, which highlighted a commitment to a bottom-up approach for peace involving youth and local leaders in conflict areas.

On 10 December 2020, Lou Nuer and Murle armed youth leaders met in Pieri. They engaged in peace talks and made a resolution for peace, as well as engaged in a spear ceremony guided by Spiritual Leader Gok Deng Dak Kueth.

From 14 to 18 January 2021, Murle and Bor Dinka armed youth leaders from Jonglei State met in Rumbek in Lakes State for a peace meeting. Galweng leaders acted as mediators during this peace meeting. The meeting led to the signing of a mutual commitment to peace witnessed by galweng leaders.
A Jonglei-GPAA Inter-Communal Governance Structures meeting was held in December 2021 to follow up on the Pieri Agreement.
A Jonglei-GPAA Inter-Communal Governance Structures meeting was held in Juba in late July 2023 to follow up on the Pieri Agreement.

A peace conference attended by participants Bor Dinka, Murle, and Lou Nuer leaders from Bor County from Jonglei State and Gumuruk County from GPAA took place in Juba from 14 to 15 November 2022. The NGO Peace Canal and UNMISS Civil Affairs supported the conference. The conference led to the signing of the Agreement of Peace Dialogue. However, soon after the signing of this agreement, the Lou Nuer and Bor Dinka mobilized to conduct a large-scale attack on the Murle in the GPAA over the course of December 2022 and January 2023. This attack was allegedly in retaliation for the Murle raids into Lou Nuer and Dinka territory, which the Pieri process had failed to stop.

On 28 March 2018, the United Nations Peacekeeping Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) organized a two-day pre-migration conference in Duk Padiet in Jonglei. The conference was attended by 30 youth representatives of the Hol Dinka and Lou Nuer. These representatives agreed refrain from using violence during the migration season in the greater Jonglei area.

A Peace Committee organized a reconciliation meeting between the tribal leaders in Nyala in October 2004 in response to the outbreak of armed fighting. The conflict parties agreed to resolve the conflict through the paying of double �dia� blood money for all those killed on both sides, the return of looted money and assets to each other, and the pardoning the perpetrators of violence. In addition, although not part of the official negotiations to end the tribal violence, the Ma�aliyah were granted a separate native administration headed by Nazir A.H. El Basha in 2004.

Renewed fighting broke out in August 2013. The Ma�aliyah accused East Darfur governor Abdel-Hamid Musa Kasha, who is a Rizeigat, of supporting his kin with government-issued vehicles and weapons. A mediation effort by governor of North Darfur Osman Mohamed Youssef Kibir, with support from UNAMID, led to agreement on signing a ceasefire on 14 August 2013. The abduction of 24 Ma�aliyah by Rizeigat led to a delay in signing the ceasefire, but after their release the conflict parties signed a ceasefire in al-Tawisha on 22 August 2013. The ceasefire was supposed to pave the way for a reconciliation conference.

On 22 August 2014, another mediation effort between the Rizeigat and Ma�aliya tribes was held in East Darfur, this time with the support from UNAMID Civil Affairs. This mediation effort led to the signing of a ceasefire by the leaders of the Rizeigat and Ma�aliya tribes on 29 August 2014. Prior to this conference, UNAMID had �engaged leaders of both communities at the state and Khartoum levels, including their respective Shura Councils.�

The theft of 320 sheep belonging to the Southern Rizeigat by the Ma�aliyah in Birghit on 13 January 2015 nearly trigged armed clashes between the tribes, but with support from government officials, leaders from both tribes intervened to stem tensions.

Another peace conference, mediated by Sudan�s first Vice-President Bakri Hassan Salih, was held in the locality of Merowe in March 2015, but the negotiations stalled over the right of land ownership known as Hakura (traditional land grant). Although the conflict parties did not reach an agreement, both sides released one captive on 4 May 2015. The armed fighting continued. Fighting stopped by 13 May, following an intervention by reinforcements from the central government as well as an intervention by the Sudanese Air Force.

On 14 May 2015, a high-ranking government delegation led by the Minister of Interior, Ismat Abdelrahman, arrived to mediate between the conflict parties. After shuttling between the conflict parties, the government decided on a package of measures to be taken by the government to stop the tribal clashes and defuse the tension. Yet, the conflict parties did not sign an agreement.

Fighting between the conflict parties resumed on 20 September, when some Rizeigat stole camels from Ma�aliyah in the Adola Mountain area. The Wali of East Darfur subsequently deployed troops to the area. Following a mediation effort by the Wali, with support from UNAMID, the conflict parties reached a settlement on 27 September.

Clashes between the Ma�aliyah and the Rizeigat as a result of cattle theft erupted again in Yassin locality on 17 April 2016, resulting in at least 20 deaths. In negotiations, facilitated by UNAMID, the conflict parties signed a peace agreement on 6 June 2016, agreeing on financial compensation for the fatalities of the clashes on 17 April 2016. However, fighting continued between the two tribes in West Kordofan on 24 August 2016.

With UNAMID support, government officials mediated another agreement between the conflict parties in Muglad, West Kordofan, on 27 August 2016. However, Ma�aliyah representatives protested against this agreement in Adilla on 3 September 2016, claiming that it was not inclusive of the entire Ma�aliyah community and that it had not been signed by the actual representatives of the Agarba.

Fighting between the Ma�aliyah and the Rizeigat spread to East Darfur on 14 and 15 October 2016. In response to these clashes, UNAMID managed to mediate a peace agreement, stipulating a ceasefire, between the Ma�aliya and Rizeigat tribes in East Darfur on 17 October 2016. The peace agreement also included provisions for the release of two members from the Rizeigat tribe held by the Ma�aliya and the return of 134 cows by the Ma�aliya. The agreement also stipulated that the government of East Darfur had to pay compensation of 650,000 SDG (US$102,000) to the Ma�aliya in order to cover the costs of a local rescue team, over 200 looted cattle, weapons and the blood money for the murder of a member of the Ma�aliyah tribe. The deputy governor of East Darfur subsequently visited Abu Karinka locality to pay representatives of the Ma�aliyah tribe the first half of the compensation.
Another round of negotiations between the Ma�aliyah and the Rizeigat led to the signing of a peace agreement in Khartoum on 27 November 2018.
Reconciliation talks between the two clans were during September and October 1997. This led to a temporary stop in fighting. Armed conflict reignited in May 1998.

No direct negotiations took place between the conflict parties in 1997, but Kenyan and Ethiopian officials signed an agreement in Awassa on 5 July 1997 that emphasized the countries� shared aim for conflict resolution along the shared border, referring namely to the conflict between the Dassanetch and Turkana. On 10 September 2002, the conflict parties engaged in a peace meeting in Lodonyang. The peace talks were mediated by the East Africa Conflict Resolution Component and Intermediate Technology Development Group (ITDG). The meeting led to signing of a peace agreement in the presence of government officials from Kenya and Ethiopia.
third_party: East Africa Conflict Resolution Component, Intermediate Technology Development Group, government, Ethiopia, government officials

description: Another peace meeting between the Dassanetch and Turkana was held in the Turkana District in Kenya in August 2005. This peace meeting led to a peace agreement and a peace committee was established.
In the second half of the year, a Karamoja cross border peace planning meeting was facilitated by CEWARN.

The conflict parties participated in peace talks mediated by Ethiopian and Kenyan government representatives in Hawassa on 2 November 2009. These talks ended with a peace agreement stipulating the set-up of cross-border peace structures and administrations.
In September 2010, a committee comprising Turkana and Dassanesch elders reached a peace agreement designed to end cattle rustling.

Peace talks between the conflict parties were held in Todonyang in Kenya in April 2011. These talks were mediated by a local NGO and security forces. The peace talks led to the conclusion of a peace agreement signed by 17 tribal representatives.

A peace meeting was mediated by government representatives and district leaders from Ethiopia and Kenya in Arba-Minch on 6 October 2016. The participants discussed how to resolve conflict between the Dassanech, Nyangatom, and Turkana and reached the Arba-Minch Resolution at the end of the talk.

A joint cross-border peace caravan was organized from 15 to 17 July 2017 to enhance reconciliation, peacebuilding, and conflict resolution between the Dassanech, the Nyangatom, and the Turkana. At this event at Omorate, 75 people from Turkana County and 75 people from South Omo Zone, as well as local government representatives from Kenya and Ethiopia participated.

A reconciliation conference, which was mediated by the Deputy Nazir of Ed Daein locality, took place in El Obeid from 25 to 28 September 2008. The two tribes reached an agreement on the basis of the border demarcation between Misseriya and the Rizeigat along their tribal border as it existed in 1948.
UNAMID mediated a ceasefire between the Misseriya and the Rizeigat Abbala on 28 March 2010.

However, fighting started again between the two tribes in the Mukjar region on 4 May. To this purpose, UNAMID Civil Affairs helped set up a Reconciliation Committee on 29 April 2010, which comprised 17 members of native administrations and local leaders. Closely working with the committee, UNAMID Civil Affairs conducted another mediation effort in May, which resulted in the conclusion of a ceasefire.
However, fighting resumed in August 2010. A mediation effort by UNAMID led to another peace agreement in November 2010, which did terminate the armed fighting.

A round of peace negotiations was held in Nakuru on 31 March 2015. Communal leaders from Bungoma County participated in this meeting that was mediated by government officials. Religious and civil leaders also attended the talks. The peace meeting ended with the signing of the Abbey Resort Resolutions.

In September 2004, the Rivers governor�s chief of staff organized a behind-the-scenes peace effort between NDPVF and NDV groups with the purpose to reach a peace agreement, but the parties refused to sign an agreement.

President Obasanjo mediated a round of peace talks between Moujahid Asari Dokubo and Ateke Tom, respectively leaders of the NDPVF and NDV, in Abuja on 1 October 2004. This mediation effort resulted in the signing of a peace agreement. Both sides pledged to lay down their arms in exchange for money.

A follow-up meeting was held on 8 October 2004 in Abuja and focused on the rehabilitation of young militiamen in society. After this last meeting, President Obasanjo set up a committee responsible for the reconciliation process between the two groups. This committee, chaired by retired Major General Abdullahi Mohammed, not only mediated between the conflict parties, but also aimed to facilitate the disarming of the NDPVF. Furthermore, the NGO Academic Associates PeaceWorks (AAPW) played a key role in the peace effort by working with the Rivers State government and the federal government to resolve the crisis between militant groups. It helped establish the Disarmament Committee chaired by Governor Odili and the community sub-committee headed by the Deputy governor of Bayelsa State, Goodluck Jonathan. The two subcommittees conducted a series of meetings between October and December 2004. This led to the public destruction of more than 800 weapons of various militias including the NDPVF and NDV at the Nigerian military headquarters in Port Harbour on 15 November 2004. However, armed fighting between the two groups continued.

A peace meeting was mediated by government representatives and district leaders from Ethiopia and Kenya in Arba-Minch on 6 October 2016. The participants discussed how to resolve conflict between the Dassanech, Nyangatom, and Turkana and reached the Arba-Minch Resolution at the end of the talk.

A joint cross-border peace caravan was organized from 15 to 17 July 2017 to enhance reconciliation, peace-building, and conflict resolution between the Dassanech, the Nyangatom, and the Turkana. At this event at Omorate, 75 people from Turkana County and 75 people from South Omo Zone, as well as local government representatives from Kenya and Ethiopia participated.

In 1998, the Sheikhal elders convened a meeting between different clan leaders in Maramaydh locality to discuss a formula to share land, but the meeting did not produce an agreement. The conflict escalated into armed fighting in August 1999. In 2000, Somali National Regional State (SNRS) zonal representatives and Defense Minister Teferra Walwa met in Jijiga and decided that the conflict should be resolved through relocating the Sheikhal clan. An Ogaden subclan (Ugas Nuur) offered the Sheikhal to stay in Janogaban locality, Dinaan Wareda, while the Sheikdal waited for a federal decision on the conflict. In the meantime, local leaders continued to meet to negotiate on a land settlement. Negotiations involving non-Ogaden clans led to an agreement for resettlement. This agreement entailed the Sheikhal moving to Raso.

It took from March 2001 to early 2002 for the clan to completely migrate to their new home. The Ogaden clan opposed this move and clashed resumed in March 2002. In response to the fighting, government officials and clan leaders mediated between the conflict parties, which led to a peace agreement.

Armed fighting again arose in 2004, following referendum that allocated 80 percent of more than 420 kebeles (i.e., the smallest administrative unit in Ethiopia) of land to the Oromo. Although this decision was not implemented, the decision had a major negative impact on the relationship between the groups and led to some clashes. In December 2004, the Oromo and Somali participated in a reconciliation effort organized by local elders. Although no official peace agreement was reached, the talks led to the return of stolen cattle by both groups. In February 2005, a referendum was passed by the two groups in order to establish a local election. The election was to be held in May. Yet, fighting would reignite between the groups in May and August 2005. The violence was quelled after the deployment of government armed forces.

The Ethiopian government set up a committee to monitor the conflict between the groups in 2013. A land dispute between the Oromo and Somali escalated into heavy fighting in 2017, which ultimately led to at least 276 battle-related deaths that year. The Ethiopian government, specifically the Minister for Federal and Pastoral Affairs, mediated negotiations between the conflict parties in April 2017. This led to the signing of a peace agreement on 20 April 2017. The agreement addressed the implementation of a 2004 border and the ethnic affiliation of Moyale. On 16 September 2017, local elders as well as communal and religious leaders from both tribes convened for a round of peace talks mediated by Ethiopian Prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn. The talks did not lead to the conclusion of a peace agreement, but did lead to the deployment of federal security officers and the Ethiopian Human Rights Commission was tasked with investigating the violence between the tribes.
The Pian Karimojong and Pokot attended a peace meeting in May 2005, which led to the conclusion of a peace agreement.

The Pokot and Sabiny engaged in a peace meeting in Trans Nzoia at the Chepchoina Primary School in April 2004. With a thousand people in attendance, Mutea Iringo and Joseph Aruwating, the West Pokot District Commissioner and District Commissioner of Kapchorwa County respectively, acted as the mediators. The Pokot and Sabiny agreed to turn to local authorities to deal with issues of animal theft.

On 10 July 2006, in an attempt to resolve the conflict, the Kenyan government offered over two hundred cattle to the Sabiny after a raid from the Pokot. This offer was rejected by the Sabiny out of fear that this would exacerbate the conflict. Community leaders from Sebei and West Pokot mediated a peace agreement between the Sabiny and Pokot at the Suam border in November 2006. Government officials also participated in this peace meeting. The Kenya Catholic Justice and Peace Commission and the Kapchorwa Civil Society Association funded this peace meeting.
third_party: community leaders, government, religious leaders, local NGO

description: A round of bilateral negotiations between tribal leaders from the Pokot and the Sabiny led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 26 February 2013.

Another round of talks between 130 Pokot elders and 80 Sabiny elders was held in Kanyerus in early March 2013. These negotiations led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. This round of peace talks received support from Oxfam and a local NGO called Saferworld. At this meeting, they reached a peace accord.

Ethiopia mediated between the political heads of Somaliland and Puntland in Addis Ababa in June 2010. This led to the signing of a peace agreement on 9 June 2010. When Puntland officially joined the Federal Republic of Somalia on 1 August 2012, this conflict became a state-based conflict between the Government of Somalia and the Republic of Somaliland.

The round of negotiations of April 2001 paved the way for another round of negotiations, in which the representatives of the government, the rebel groups, and the Mayi Mayi signed the Declaration of Fundamental Principles for the Inter-Congolese dialogue in Lusaka on 4 May 2001.
agreement_name: Declaration of Fundamental Principles for the Inter-Congolese dialogue

description: Following the willingness of both the RCD and the Mayi Mayi to participate in the Inter-Congolese dialogue, a high-level United Nations Development Program (UNDP) mission reported that the time was ripe for direct, local ceasefire negotiations between the Mayi Mayi and the RCD-Goma. Some NGOs subsequently started to mediate, but without support from MONUC.

On 19 April 2002, the government, rebel groups, and the Mayi Mayi signed a partial peace agreement, the Political Agreement on Consensual Management of the Transition in the DRC, also referred to as the Sun City Accord. As part of the wider national-level peace process, the Rwandan army began their withdrawal from the DRC on 17 September 2002, handing over power to the Rwandan-backed RCD-Goma in Kindu. However, Mayi Mayi militias took advantage of the Rwandan withdrawal and attacked RCD forces.

At the national level, however, both parties participated in another round of the Inter-Congolese dialogue, which was mediated by the OAU and the UN. This led to signing of the Global and Inclusive Agreement on Transition in the Democratic Republic of Congo � also known as the Pretoria Agreement � on 16 December 2002.
agreement_name: Global and Inclusive Agreement on Transition in the Democratic Republic of Congo

description: In 2003, South Africa, with support from the UN and the AU, hosted continued talks between the parties. Ketumile Masire acted as the chief mediator, but Thabo Mbeki, acting as the Chairman of the AU, and Moustapha Niasse, acting as the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General of the UN on the Inter-Congolese Dialogue, were also involved in the peace talks. Negotiations in Pretoria that had started in late February resulted in the conclusion of a draft constitution and a memorandum on the military and security arrangements during the transition period on 6 March.
agreement_name: Memorandum on the Military and Security Arrangements During the Transition

description: In late March, talks were held on integrating the rebel groups and the Mayi Mayi into the DRC armed forces and on security measures during the transition period, which led to the conclusion of a preliminary ceasefire. On 2 April 2003, a peace agreement was concluded that confirmed all the previous agreements: the Inter-Congolese Political Negotiations - The Final Act.

In parallel to this national-level peace process which involved both the RCD and the Mayi Mayi, direct talks between the RCD and the Mayi Mayi took place. Two months earlier, in early February 2003, RCD-Goma spokesperson Jean-Pierre Lola Kisanga had announced a general amnesty for Mayi Mayi militias. The offer applied to the members of all the factions of Mayi Mayi militias operating in territory claimed to be under the control of RCD-Goma: �We are asking the Mayi Mayi to leave the forests and disassociate themselves from other armed groups [�.] They will not be charged with any crime whatsoever. Rather, it is out of our hope for reconciliation and an end to hostilities that we are offering this amnesty.� The Mayi Mayi militias and RCD-Goma subsequently began direct negotiations in Burale on 9 September 2003. According to the leader of the Mayi Mayi Marcel Munga, a joint mission of six military officials from the two movements had been sent to the field to begin the negotiations. MONUC�s Radio Okapi reported, �By order of the military leadership, Maj-Gen Sylvain Buki, formerly of RCD-Goma, and his colleague, Padiri Bulenda, formerly of the Mayi-Mayi militia and commander of one of the military regions, the Third Brigade of the Mayi-Mayi and the Tenth Brigade of RCD-Goma, both of whom occupy part of the Walungu territory, came together at the same table on Tuesday in Burale to discuss reconciliation.� The team would be responsible for creating a joint police force with soldiers from the two factions.

Little more than a month after the start of talks on 9 September 2003, negotiations between Mayi Mayi leader General Padiri and the RCD-Goma, mediated by MONUC, led to the conclusion of a peace agreement inn Shabuda, South Kivu Province, on 1 October 2003 in the presence of MONUC�s sector five commander, Col Lawrence Smith. The agreement calls for an immediate ceasefire, the free circulation of people and goods, and the creation of a follow-up commission comprising three members from each of the two sides to monitor implementation of the agreement.

Finally, in cooperation with the newly appointed commander of the military region, another meeting was organized in the Uvira-Baraka area in 2003. This meeting was attended by the entire Mayi Mayi leadership and many national army commanders. This peacemaking effort contributed to a reduction in armed fighting in the province.

In addition, the national-level peace process in which the rebel groups participated continued. In 2003, South Africa was hosting continued talks between the parties. Ketumile Masire acted as the chief mediator, but Thabo Mbeki, acting as the Chairman of the AU, and Moustapha Niasse, acting as the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General of the UN on the Inter-Congolese Dialogue, were also involved in the peace talks. On 6 March 2003, after 11 days of talks in Pretoria, a draft constitution and a memorandum on the military and security arrangements during the transition period was adopted.
agreement_name: Memorandum on the Military and Security Arrangements During the Transition Period

description: On 6 August 2003, the Follow-up Committee of the Inter-Congolese Dialogue held a meeting to come up with a division of military zones of control for signatories to the final peace agreement. The parties concluded an agreement that allocated control of three military regions to the former government, two regions each to RCD-Goma and the MLC, and one region each to RCD-K-ML and the RCD-N.

On 6 January 2002, Brigadier General Mwaniki led a MONUC team to Gbadolite in an effort to persuade MLC leaders to resolve the dispute by peaceful means. Another team went to Isiro to talk to the RCD-K-ML. The MLC leadership promised the MONUC team that they would not take Isiro, would halt their advancement at their traditional area of control, and would stick to a ceasefire unless for reasons of self-defense. However, the MLC took control of Isiro on 7 January 2002. Some of the other areas the MLC took control of seemed to reflect previous agreements about zones of control between the MLC and the RCD-K-ML.

In addition to bilateral negotiations between the rebel groups, the RCD factions and the MLC were engaged in a peace process with the Government of the DRC. Both the RCD factions and the MLC had signed the Lusaka Accord in 1999, which set up the Inter-Congolese Dialogue in which the OAU/AU and the UN would mediate between the conflict parties. The RCD-K-ML on the one side and the MLC and the RCD-N on the other side continued to meet as part of this peace process after they fought each other from June 2001 onwards. The rebel parties and the Government of the DRC were planning to meet as part of the Inter-Congolese Dialogue in Sun City, South Africa, on 25 February 2002, but the MLC boycotted the meeting last minute. The MLC did participate in a round of negotiations which started on 9 April 2002 and led to conclusion of a partial agreement, the Political Agreement on Consensual Management of the Transition in the DRC on 19 April 2002. This agreement specified a political power-sharing formula among the rebel groups and the Government of the DRC. Yet, fighting between the RCD-K-ML on the one side and the MLC and the RCD-N on the other side continued.
agreement_name: Political Agreement on Consensual Management of the Transition in the DRC

description: To move the peace process forward based on political power-sharing agreement the parties had concluded, the UN Secretary-General mandated Moustapha Niasse as his Special Representative to the DRC to mediate a comprehensive peace agreement. Niasse conducted three missions in the region between June and October 2002 during which he consulted with the main rebel leaders and the government officials. Niasse visited the DRC on 16 June 2002. In Pretoria, talks were held in Kinshasa from October 25 to 27 between the rebels and the government.

In November 2002, another round of negotiations as part of the Inter-Congolese Dialogue began, resulting in the conclusion of the Global and Inclusive Agreement on the transition in the Democratic Republic of Congo in Pretoria on 17 December 2002. However, on 20 December 2002, fighting erupted again between the RCD-K-ML on the one side and the MLC and the RCD-N on the other side.
agreement_name: Global and Inclusive Agreement on the transition in the Democratic Republic of Congo

description: On 30 December 2002, the leaders Jean-Pierre Bemba of the MLC, Roger Lumbala of RCD-N, and Mbusa Nyamwisi of the RCD-K-ML met in the northern town of Gbadolite, Equateur Province, in the presence of the ambassadors of the permanent members of the UN Security Council, Belgium, and South Africa, as well as the United Nations� Secretary General�s Deputy Special Representative in the DRC Amos Namanga Ngongi. They reached a ceasefire agreement that same day. The ceasefire agreement stipulated the formation of a ceasefire monitoring body, comprising representatives of the three movements, MONUC, and of South Africa. In addition, MONUC was mandated to supervise buffer zones between the rival forces. The three movements also agreed to demilitarize Mambasa and Komanda. However, the MLC and the RCD-N resumed fighting against the RCD-K-ML already a day after signing of the UN-sponsored ceasefire.

In addition, the national-level peace process in which the rebel groups participated continued. In 2003, South Africa was hosting continued talks between the parties. Ketumile Masire acted as the chief mediator, but Thabo Mbeki, acting as the Chairman of the AU, and Moustapha Niasse, acting as the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General of the UN on the Inter-Congolese Dialogue, were also involved in the peace talks. On 6 March 2003, after 11 days of talks in Pretoria, a draft constitution and a memorandum on the military and security arrangements during the transition period was adopted.
agreement_name: Memorandum on the Military and Security Arrangements During the Transition Period

description: On 6 August 2003, the Follow-up Committee of the Inter-Congolese Dialogue held a meeting to come up with division of military zones of control for signatories to the final peace agreement. The parties concluded an agreement that allocated control of three military regions to the former government, two regions each to RCD-Goma and the MLC, and one region each to RCD-K-ML and the RCD-N.

On 7 January 2007, the Deputy Governor, traveled to the Bulbul area to attempt to mediate between the conflict parties, but his convoy was ambushed, and he was forced to return. The government managed to organize a reconciliation conference in Um Zaifa in late February 2007. The representatives of the Terjam and the Reizegat ambushed, this conference agreed on turning over the perpetrators of theft and murder and pay compensation in the form of blood money for losses. However, on 25 February 2007, before the reconciliation conference concluded, Reizegat fighters attacked Amar Jadeed. This attack undermined the prospects for a successful reconciliation conference.
The Terjam and the Reizegat concluded a ceasefire on 11 August 2007.

The Terjam and the Reizegat Abbala clashed again in Bulbul, 40 kilometers north-west of Nyala, in February 2008. This episode of armed fighting started following the abduction of two Reizegat Abbala boys by Terjam tribesmen on 22 February 2008. The fighting lasted for four days. The Deputy Wali mediated to try to calm the situation down on 25 February 2008.

A 22-person committee, consisting of Clan elders and local businessmen, headed by Sharif Salah mediated between the conflict parties in July 2002. This led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 6 July 2002, which was officially signed on 10 July 2002. The document outlined not only a ceasefire, but also specified fines should the conflict parties violate the ceasefire. However, fighting reignited on 27 July 2002, when Adobe declared himself to be the legitimate chairman of the RRA.

On 2 September 2002, Hasan Shire Muhammad mediated another ceasefire between the conflict parties. This ceasefire also stipulated future talks to the resolve the conflict issues. These reconciliation talks broke down on 30 October 2002.

Mediation efforts by Asharaf clan elders led by Sherrif Ahmed Mohamud Abukar were resumed in November. This mediation effort between the RRA and RRA-MH led to a ceasefire in early November. The conflict parties promised to vacate the conflict zone completely by 14 November, but this ceasefire was broken in December 2002. Both sides joined the Transitional Federal Government (TFG) that was formed in 2004.

side_a: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
side_b: Suleiman subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: Fighting between the Sa�ad and Suleinam communities resumed in 2004. Heavy clashes took place with both sides using technical, rocket launchers, and old Soviet-style tanks. The Transitional National Government (TNG) swiftly tried to initiate a peace process. This peace effort was funded and mediated by the TNG, the Puntland administration, and Norway and Sweden through the NGO Interpeace. In June 2004, clan representatives from both sides attended a peace meeting in Mogadishu at Sahafi Hotel. This effort produced a ceasefire agreement and plans to continue reconciliation between the two communities. Iman Jirow would spread the news of the ceasefire first with a delegation from each side and then with a joint delegation. However, the ceasefire broke down before the planned next round of reconciliation talks could take place, as the Suleiman delegation of the joint committee was ambushed by Sa�ad fighters in November 2004.

side_a: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
side_b: Suleiman subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: Several bloody clashed took place in January 2005. In February 2005, President Abdulahi Yusuf Ahmed mediated a ceasefire, but this ceasefire was violated within a month. In addition, throughout 2005, TNG representatives consulted with the Sa�ad and Suleinam sub-clans in Nairobi and Mogadishu, paving the way for a reconciliation conference.

side_a: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
side_b: Suleiman subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: On 13 February 2006 a six-day meeting started in Galkayo. This conference brought together 60 business and political leaders that represented the conflict parties. The TFG mediated between the conflict parties, with both the President and the Prime Minister of the TFG attending the conference. Representatives of the Center for Research and Dialogue (CRD) and the Puntland Development Research Center (PDRC) were also present. The conference focused on resolving issues concerning access to water points and grazing areas, as well as focused on developing mechanisms to deal with various grievances and avoid revenge killings. The conference ended with the conclusion of an agreement that stipulated a ceasefire and the initiation of follow-up effort to promote reconciliation. The representatives of both conflict parties traveled throughout the region to spread the news of the ceasefire from 7 to 11 April 2006.

side_a: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
side_b: Suleiman subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: From 17 to 22 April 2006, local militia leaders received conflict management training in south Galkayo. Furthermore, smaller meetings were held in Bandiradley and El Hurl by elders from both sides across the region to establish peace agreements on the return of the displaced people and the creation of committees to monitor the ceasefire agreement. From 2 to 6 May, 60 clan representatives from both sides in the conflict and 100 observers attended the meeting in Bandiradley.

side_a: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
side_b: Suleiman subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: From 23 to 26 June, 68 clan members from both sides in the conflict attended the El Hur conference. The smaller peace meetings in Bandiradley and El Hur served to build trust for the main reconciliation conference planned to take place Adado in February 2007.

side_b: Hawarsame Rer Hasan and Habar Ya'qub subclan of Marehan clan (Darod)
description: Around 60 Imams from the conflict parties attended a peace meeting in Berhano in July 2007. This peace meeting was mediated by the Center for Research and Dialogue (CRD). The peace meeting resulted in the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement on the 14 July 2007 and a peace agreement on 23 July 2007.

On 1 December 2015, Turkana and Toposa representatives, including Turkana Governor Josphat Nanok and South Sudan�s Eastern Equatorial region Governor Luis Lobong, held a peace meeting in Lodwar. The main aim of the meeting was to encourage peaceful relations and stop clashes between two communities.

On 28 July 2018, leaders from the Toposa community from South Sudan and Turkana community from neighboring Kenya met in Narus county of Torit state. The leaders discussed the issue of cattle rustling, which they saw as the main source of conflict between the two communities.

Another cattle raid by Turkana took place in Losolia county in South Sudan in early September 2018. In response, Losolia county commissioner Koetein Thomas discussed the armed attack with Turkana leaders in Turkana County.

At a peace meeting in July 2019, Kenya and South Sudan decided to establish a joint border commission to stop conflict and promote peace between the Toposa, the Turkana, and the Nyangatom in the Elemi Triangle. The Commission was mainly focused on resolving border issues between those communities.

In July 2002, the representatives from POKATUSA organized a peace meeting in order to find a solution for cattle raids and to stop the violence at the shared border between Uganda and Kenya. Those meetings were attended by Kenyan central government officials as well as regional government representatives, who mediated between the different communities.

In November 2005, the Tegla Loroupe Foundation organized a peace forum for representatives of the Pokot, Turkana, and Karamonjong at Mtelo Hall, West Pokot District. The main aim was to end violence and stop cattle rustling.

The District Commissioner mediated a peace meeting between the Turkana and Pokot in Chepchoina on 16 April 2007. This meeting led to the creation of a committee of 13 members tasked with finding a solution to the land dispute between the conflict parties.
Following negotiations mediated by Rift Valley Provincial Commissioner Hassan Noor Hassan, the Turkana and Pokot agreed to a truce on 3 July 2009.

On 11 September 2010, the Turkana, Pokot, and Karimojong pastoralists met at a cross-border peace meeting in Moroto to discuss peace at the Uganda and Kenya border. Peace committee members from Amudat, Nakapiripirit, Moroto, and Kaabong districts attended the talks.

Several peace caravans were organized by local leader in September 2010. Representatives of the Samburu, Turkana, Rendile, Borana, Gabra, Pokot, Somali, and Meru communities gathered for reconciliation talks during these peace caravans.

Following negotiations between the Turkana and Pokot in December 2010, the two tribes agreed to the Kainuk-Sarmach-Turkwel-Masol Corridor Peace Agreement. This agreement includes several provisions to prevent cattle rustling and also includes standards for sharing resources.
A reconciliation meeting between the Pokot and Turkana, mediated by local government officials, was held at Sigor in June 2011.
The Pokot and Turkana representatives met in Turkwel in early 2012. This led to the conclusion of an agreement that broke down in March 2012.
On 5 March 2014, Kenyan government officials and the Kenya Red Cross Society facilitated a peace talk in Eldoret between the Pokot and Turkana, which culminated in the signing of a peace agreement.

Following a new bout of fighting in November 2014, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) organized various peace negotiations to resolve the conflict between the Pokot and the Turkana. The mediation efforts by the NCIC resulted in the signing of the Sirikwa Declaration.

On 9 May 2015, Finn Church Aid mediated peace talks in Eldoret between the two sides after another violent clash. Bishop Cornelius Korir of Eldoret Diocese took on the role as lead mediator during these peace talks. The tribal leaders agreed to an immediate cessation of hostilities, as well as to participate in a more comprehensive peace process in the following months.
In May 2015, elders from the Pokot and Turkana tribes reached another ceasefire. This ceasefire was mediated by Finn Church Aid.

On 22 January 2016, the Karamoja Cluster Project held a cross-border peace meeting in Moroto with the Turkana, Pokot, and Karimojong. The Karimojong youth requested from the Kenyan government to disarm the Turkana and Pokot. No peace deal was brokered between the two tribes.

A peace meeting between the the Karimojoing, Turkana and Pokot in Moroto on 12 September 2019, mediated by UN officials, led to the conclusion of the Cross-border Sustainable Peace and Development Agreement. The signing ceremony was witnessed by Ugandan and Kenyan presidents, Yoweri Museveni and Uhuru Kenyatta, and representatives of the United Nations Development Programme.
agreement_name: Cross-border Sustainable Peace and Development Agreement

description: In March 2020 members of the Pokot, Tugen, Ilchamus, Turkana and Samburu communities participated in formation of community-led peace infrastructure in the form of Ceasefire Monitoring Committees (CMCs) that tasked to oversee the implementation of the ceasefire across the North Rift region.
In July 2021, Pokot and Turkana elders signed the Orwa Peace Accord to put an end to decades of cyclical conflict and deadly violence.

The next day, on 27 December 2001, the two sides reached a ceasefire agreement in Mogadishu after a first round of negotiations mediated by local elders led by Hussein Jila'ow. This ceasefire did not last. Both of the conflict parties participated in the Eldoret conference, mediated by Intergovernmental Authority on Development in October and November 2002. No direct negotiations between Musa Sudi and Omar �Finish� took place in Eldoret, but both leaders would sign the Eldoret Agreement, which had been concluded already on 27 October 2002, on 7 December 2002.

Musa Sudi and Omar �Finish� engaged in direct negotiations following another round of fighting near Mogadishu in February 2003. Clan elders mediated between the two leaders, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement on 26 February 2003. The armed conflict between the USC/SSA and the USC/SSA-OMF ended when both groups joined the Transitional Federal Government (TFG) in 2004.

President Dingha Ignatius Bayin of the Cameroon People�s Democratic Movement (CPDM) mediated peace talks between Bafanji and the Blikumbat aimed at resolving their land dispute. On 29 June 2009, the two conflict parties agreed to a ceasefire and the creation of peace committees.

The government deployed troops in the town after two days of fighting. On 19 July 1991, a government mediation effort succeeded in ending the fighting. The tribal leaders shared a symbolic drink of water as a sign of peace.

The Choa Arab and Kotoko clashed on 29 January 1992. On 30 and 31 January, in response to the violence, the Far North governor Benoit Namvou held multiple meetings with local leaders from the government and tribes in order to reach a ceasefire.

President Paul Biya directed the central council of the Cameroon People�s Democratic Movement (CPDM) to mediate between the Choa Arab and Kotoko. Negotiations led to the signing of a comprehensive peace agreement in Kousseri on 18 September 1993. The United Nations collaborated with the government to oversee the ceasefire by launching a peace mission in October 1993.

On 14 January 1994, fighting between the two tribes resumed. On 17 January, the government represented by Gilbert Andre Tsoungui, the local territorial administrator, tried to mediate a ceasefire, but did not succeed.
Negotiations between the MPA/Republic of Anjouan and the MPA-SOC led to the signing of a ceasefire on 5 December 1998, the day that fighting started.
On 13 December 1998, a day after the clash in Mutsamudu, the two parties reached an informal truce.

Members of a French humanitarian mission, Jean-Luc Machuron and Jacques Amblard, with local leaders from Ouani, mediated between Ibrahim and Chamassi. Negotiations between the two sides at the Anjouan airport on 16 December 1998 led to a 48-hour ceasefire. This ceasefire was a formal iteration of the 13 December agreement that had lasted until then.

The key issues of nationality, land distribution, and political representation had not been resolved, and government officials at both the provincial and national levels showed no interest in seeking a lasting solution to the conflict. In early 1994, local peace conferences took place in Mweso town and Masisi town in which members of the different ethnic groups discussed the causes of the violence and sought to make recommendations for preventing its recurrence in the future. The conferences were a joint initiative between a number of local NGOs and OXFAM. The main recommendation of these conferences was that resolution of the nationality question by the Zairean Government was a necessary condition for peace in Masisi. In May and June of 1995, the ethnic militia, known collectively as the �combatants�, launched renewed attacks. The Mayi-Mayi and Bangirima groups of the Hunde, Nande, and Nyanga fought against Hutu Interahamwe militias, which had fled to Zaire from Rwanda, in Masisi and Rutshuru. During the first months of 1996, fighting gradually spread to other parts of Masisi and Rutshuru. On 11 April 1996, following a visit to Goma by a delegation of government ministers, Operation Kimia was launched, in order to restore security in the region. Over the course of several weeks, approximately 800 government troops were deployed in Masisi. However, the operation did not succeed in disarming a sufficient number of militiamen. Furthermore, rather than fight the armed groups, some units in operation Kimia allegedly turned to pillaging livestock and asked for money in exchange for their protection to the Tutsis hoping to be escorted to Goma or Rwanda. Another military operation launched by the government in late May 1996 also failed to disarm the militias.

The key issues of nationality, land distribution, and political representation had not been resolved, and government officials at both the provincial and national levels showed no interest in seeking a lasting solution to the conflict. In early 1994, local peace conferences led by local leaders took place in Mweso town and Masisi town in which members of the different ethnic groups discussed the causes of the violence and sought to make recommendations for preventing its recurrence in the future. The conferences were a joint initiative between a number of local NGOs and OXFAM. The main recommendation of these conferences was that resolution of the nationality question by the Zairean Government was a necessary condition for peace in Masisi. In May and June of 1995, the ethnic militia, known collectively as the �combatants�, launched renewed attacks. The Mayi-Mayi and Bangirima groups of the Hunde, Nande, and Nyanga fought against Hutu Interahamwe militias, which had fled to Zaire from Rwanda, in Masisi and Rutshuru. During the first months of 1996, fighting gradually spread to other parts of Masisi and Rutshuru. On 11 April 1996, following a visit to Goma by a delegation of government ministers, Operation Kimia was launched, in order to restore security in the region. Over the course of several weeks, approximately 800 government troops were deployed in Masisi. However, the operation did not succeed in disarming a sufficient number of militiamen. Furthermore, rather than fight the armed groups, some units in operation Kimia allegedly turned to pillaging livestock and asked for money in exchange for their protection to the Tutsis hoping to be escorted to Goma or Rwanda. Another military operation launched by the government in late May 1996 also failed to disarm the militias.

This paved the way for another round of negotiations, in which the representatives of the government, the rebel groups, and the Mayi Mayi signed the Declaration of Fundamental Principles for the Inter-Congolese dialogue in Lusaka on 4 May 2001.
agreement_name: Declaration of Fundamental Principles for the Inter-Congolese dialogue

description: On 19 April 2002, the government, rebel groups, and the Mayi Mayi signed a partial peace agreement, the Political Agreement on Consensual Management of the Transition in the DRC, also referred to as the Sun City Accord.

In 2003, South Africa, with support from the UN and the AU, hosted continued talks between the parties. Ketumile Masire acted as the chief mediator, but Thabo Mbeki, acting as the Chairman of the AU, and Moustapha Niasse, acting as the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General of the UN on the Inter-Congolese Dialogue, were also involved in the peace talks. Negotiations in Pretoria that had started in late February resulted in the conclusion of a draft constitution and a memorandum on the military and security arrangements during the transition period on 6 March.
agreement_name: Memorandum on the Military and Security Arrangements During the Transition

description: In late March, talks were held on integrating the rebel groups and the Mayi Mayi into the DRC armed forces and on security measures during the transition period. On 2 April 2003, a peace agreement was concluded that confirmed all the previous agreements: the Inter-Congolese Political Negotiations - The Final Act. This agreement requires the parties to adhere to 36 Resolutions from the Inter-Congolese Dialogue, The Global and Inclusive Agreement, and the Constitution of the Transition. The Lusaka Agreement was also affirmed. The agreement specifically mentions the importance of MONUC in safeguarding the transitional institutions established through the Inter-Congolese Dialogue.
A peace meeting between the Amhara and Oromo, without the involvement of a mediator, led to a ceasefire in 2000.

In July 2022, regional leaders together with traditional leaders held discussions with the communities aiming to end violence and restore peace in the North Shewa and Oromo Special zones of the Amhara region.
In January 1993, the Arbore and Borana engaged in bilateral peace talks. This peace meeting focused on reaching an agreement on free grazing access for all livestock.

Elders from both tribes participated in another peace meeting in Turmi from 6 to 9 March 1993. This led to the signing of a peace agreement that addressed the land rights of Borana, as well as access to this land for non-Borana, including the Arbore, Bodi, Dassanetch, Hamar, Konso, Mursi, Nyangatom, and Tsemai.

Another round of peace talks was mediated by government officials from the Oromiyya and Somali Regions. Since this peace effort did not succeed, the federal government sent security forces to stop the fighting.

The Borana, Degodia, Ajuran, Garre, Rendille participated in a peace meeting in Modogashe on 31 August 2001. This meeting was mediated by local communal leaders and provincial commissioners. The meeting led to the signing of a peace agreement that stipulated a ceasefire and included a disarmament provision.

The Borana, Degodia, Ajuran, Garre, Rendille participated in a peace meeting in Modogashe on 31 August 2001. This meeting was mediated by local communal leaders and provincial commissioners. The meeting led to the signing of a peace agreement that stipulated a ceasefire and included a disarmament provision.

Government forces intervened in response to fighting between the Borana and Garre in December 2012. This military intervention was followed by a mediation effort by government officials in December 2012 that led to the conclusion of a ceasefire.
In response to the July 1998 violence, Gedeo and Guji elders and neighboring clan leaders mediated a ceasefire.

The government military intervened and declared a state of emergency in February 1994 in an attempt to quell the fighting. During a round of negotiations on 12 April 1994, the Dagomba, Nanumba, and Gonja agreed to a ceasefire with Konkomba in Accra. The Interior Minister Colonel Emmanuel Osei-Owusu and an 11-person team acted as the mediator during this round of peace talks. It was also decided during the peace talks on 12 April 1994 to set up the Permanent Peace Negotiation Team (PPNT). The PPNT comprised of seven members and was tasked with mediating conflicts in the country�s Northern region.

A round of negotiations mediated by the PPNT, led by Omahene of Efutu Akwa Okumeni Obiri Yeboah, led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in Accra on 9 June 1994. Following this round of negotiations, the PPNT requested each side to submit a position paper to outline its opinion on how create durable peace.
The conflict parties engaged in another round of peace talks in December 1994, which led to the signing of a formal peace agreement.
In June 1995, the Gonja and Konkomba participated in a reconciliation talk in Accra organized by President Rawlings. The Konkomba delegation pledged that Konkomba would no longer attack Gonja farms.
The Kumasi V peace talks held in March 1996 led to the signing of the Kumasi Accord on Peace and Reconciliation Between Ethnic Groups in the Northern Region of Ghana.
third_party: local NGO, Action Aid, Catholic Relief Services, Oxfam, Red Cross, World Vision International, Nairobi Peace Initiative
agreement_name: Kumasi Accord on Peace and Reconciliation Between Ethnic Groups in the Northern Region of Ghana

description: In May 1996, the Gonja and Konkomba participated in a reconciliation ceremony that led to another peace agreement.

Several peace caravans were organized by local leaders in September 2010. Representatives of the Samburu, Turkana, Rendile, Borana, Gabra, Pokot, Somali, and Meru communities gathered for reconciliation talks during these peace caravans.

Another round of negotiations between the conflict parties, between 21 and 22 February, led to the conclusion of the Boma Peace Agreement. This round of negotiations was mediated by government officials and other community leaders. The Boma Peace Agreement included a provision for a team to oversee the implementation of the agreement.
In late September and early October, multiple reconciliation talks were led between tribal elders of the Turkana, Borana, Meru and Samburu tribes in Isiolo County.

The Kalenjin and Kikuyu leaders, along with other community leaders such as those from Luhya, engaged in another peace meeting in Nakuru on 19 August 2012, which led to the signing of the Nakuru County Peace Accord. The signing of the Accord was witnessed by the NCIC, the Truth Justice and Reconciliation Commission, the Provincial Commissioner�s Office, and HD.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), government, local government

description: The Kalenjin and Kikuyu leaders, along with other community leaders such as those from Kisii and the Luo, engaged in another peace meeting in Nakuru on 19 August 2012, which led to the signing of the Nakuru County Peace Accord. The signing of the agreement was witnessed by the NCIC, the Truth Justice and Reconciliation Commission, the Provincial Commissioner�s Office, and HD.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), government, local government

description: In August 2016, another round of negotiations resulted in the Chemelil Declaration in which both communities agreed to end hostilities.
On 6 June 2001, the Kisii and Maasai participated in a reconciliation meeting mediated by district commissioners.

Nakuru district commissioner Aden Noor Aden led a reconciliation meeting between the Maasai and Kikuyu in Longonot on 17 January 1995. The meeting was attended by elders, religious leaders, and local authorities.
third_party: local government, religious leaders, traditional leaders

description: On 2 February 2005, after two-week long clashes over the water of the Ewaso Kedong River, a round of negotiations between the Kikuyu and Maasai was held at the Karima Catholic Church in Mai Mahiu. Internal Security Minister Chris Murungaru mediated these negotiations. Although the conflict parties agreed that a joint solution over the use of water had to be found, no peace agreement was concluded.

A round of negotiations mediated by the NCIC and HD led to conclusion of the Nakuru County Peace Accord on 19 August 2012 in Nakuru, signed by the Kalenjin and the Kikuyu, but also other communities in Kakuru such as the Maasai.
Another round of negotiations mediated by the CJPC led to signing of the Kolowa Declaration at Kolowa in October 2002.

In 2016, large-scale conflict between the tribes reignited. In response, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) organized and supported several peace meetings between representatives of the Marakwet and the Pokot. A round of peace talks led to the conclusion of the Nakuru Declaration in September 2016.
The NCIC mediated another round of peace talks between the Pokot and Marakwet, which led to the conclusion of a peace agreement at the Bontana Hotel on 4 November 2016.

On 31 July 2019, Deputy President William Ruto mediated a round of peace talks in the Kerio Valley. This mediation effort led to the signing of an agreement between communities of the the Baringo, Elgeyo-Marakwet, and West Pokot counties in which these communities committed to disarmament.
In late October 2023, Pokot and Marakwet community members held discussions to bring peace in the Cheptulel, Chesogon, and Tot border areas.

The Orma and Pokomo engaged in peace talks mediated by the Council of Imams and Preachers of Kenya on 21 July 2001. The chief mediator was Sheikh Ali Shee. An Imam, a priest, and tribal representatives from the Ngao, Sailoni, and Simi Karo were also present. This effort resulted in the Orma and Pokomo signing a ceasefire agreement. In October, the Kenyan government led a disarmament operation and suspended the land adjudication program in December 2001.

The NCIC initiated a mediation effort in September 2014. The NCIC worked with religious and community leaders, civil societies, the National Steering Committee on Peacebuilding and Conflict Management (NSC), and the Kenya Red Cross Society (KRCS). The mediation effort focused on mitigating violence in the towns of Amu, Faza, Hindi, and Witu. On 17 September 2014, community leaders signed The Boma Commitment on the Promotion of Peace and Cohesion in Lamu County. President Uhuru Kenyatta attended the signing ceremony. To follow-up with the implementation, peace committees were created in Hindi, Lamu, and Mpeketoni.
third_party: government, religious leaders, community leaders, Red Cross
agreement_name: Boma Commitment on the Promotion of Peace and Cohesion in Lamu County

description: On 2 January 1989, Syria attempted to broker a ceasefire between the feuding Shia Muslim rivals in Beirut�s southern suburbs. However, it only took few hours after this mediation effort for the fighting to flare up again.
On 15 January 1989, the Lebanese Red Cross brokered a temporary humanitarian ceasefire in south Lebanon town of Jubah. This allowed the conflict parties to remove the dead from the battlefield.

From 23 to 25 January 1989, Foreign Ministers Farouk Sharaa of Syria and Ali Akbar Velayati of Iran mediated between Amal and Hezbollah leaders in Damascus. The talks were concluded with a preliminary peace agreement and a ceasefire, which lasted only few hours.

On 30 January 1989, Amal and Hezbollah signed the Damascus Agreement mediated by Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk Sharaa and his Iranian counterpart Ali Akbar Velayati in the Syrian capital. The agreement ensured compliance with the 25 January ceasefire, an end to media hostilities, the withdrawal of all militiamen from Jbaa and Ain Bouswar, the establishment of a common operations room to coordinate the �resistance� against Israel, and the freedom for UNIFIL and other international organizations to operate in Lebanon without harassment. However, the fate of numerous hostages was not addressed in the agreement.
On 8 July 1989, Amal and Hezbollah reportedly pledged to halt clashes at a meeting with foreign ministers Farouq Shaara of Syria and his Iranian counterpart Ali Akbar Velayati in Damascus.
Syrian troops brokered a one-hour ceasefire on 9 July 1989 to allow people to evacuate a beach as Amal and Hezbollah militias fought in southern Beirut.

On 14 July 1989, Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati chaired talks between Amal and Hezbollah to try to resolve their dispute. His goal was to unify Shiite forces in the fight against General Michel Aoun. One day later, on 15 July 1989, the Druze Progressive Socialist Party (PSP) and the leaders of the Palestinian group Fatah Uprising and the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine also joined the discussions with the Iranian Foreign Minister. On 24 July 1989, Amal and Hezbollah issued a statement in Tehran in which they assured cooperation. Yet, in December 1989, clashes erupted again. Despite three calls for a ceasefire from a security committee composed of both Hezbollah and Amal representatives and Syrian officers, the parties continued to fight.
On 25 December 1989, Deputy Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammed Ali Besharati held talks in Beirut with Hezbollah and Amal leaders in an attempt to reach a ceasefire.

On 27 December 1989, Iran successfully mediated a ceasefire between its Shiite Muslim allies Hezbollah and the Syrian-backed Amal militia. This was the result of shuttle mediation aimed to end the violence in the Iqlim al-Tufah area, located 40km south of Beirut. On 3 January 1990, Hezbollah declared a unilateral ceasefire after 12 days of fighting against Amal in south Lebanon.

On 8 January 1990, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) brokered a 7-hour humanitarian ceasefire between the two Shiite rival militias to remove bodies from the battlefield south of Sidon.

From 8 to 9 January 1990, Iranian First Deputy Foreign Minister Besharati held separate talks with Amal and Hezbollah in Beirut. Besharati affirmed that the two Shiite militias had reaffirmed their commitment to abide by the Damascus Agreement signed in January 1989. However, both Amal and Hezbollah denied that a ceasefire had been reached after these meetings.
On 24 January 1990, an Algerian delegation mediated between the two warring militias. Yet, violence continued during the mediation effort.

On 27 January 1990, Amal declared a unilateral ceasefire in response to an ongoing mediation effort by Algerian envoy Mohammed Taher. This declaration followed a meeting with the Algerian peace envoy on the same day. Hezbollah negotiators, who talked to the mediator on the phone, stated that they were observing the ceasefire brokered by Iran.

On 7 June 1990, the two parties met for peace talks mediated by Syria�s chief of military intelligence in Lebanon, Brigadier Ghazi Kenaan, in the Syrian military headquarters in West Beirut. The Iranian Ambassador to Damascus, Mohammed Hassan Akhtari, was also involved as a mediator in these talks. The two sides discussed ways to implement the January 1989 Damascus Agreement. This meeting also had the goal to pave the way for another peace conference in Damascus.

On 30 June 1990, the Amal militia announced a unilateral ceasefire. This ceasefire was related to the holy feast of Eid al-Adha and also proposed to exchange prisoners with Hezbollah. One day later, on 1 July 1990, Hezbollah also declared it would observe the ceasefire called by Amal.
On 19 July 1990, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) brokered a humanitarian ceasefire to evacuate the wounded near Sidon.
On 22 July 1990, Allam Riza Walizadeh, a political officer of the Iranian embassy in Beirut, met with Hezbollah, Amal, and PLO fighters in the city of Sidon to find a way to end hostilities.

On 31 July 1990, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) mediated a ceasefire at a meeting between the two Lebanese Shiite militias and the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) in order to evacuate the dead from Iqlim al Tuffah. The ceasefire eventually took hold on 3 August 1990, allowing the ICRC to remove the bodies.
On 31 August 1990, as fighting continued in and around the ancient town of Baalbek (70km east of Beirut), Syrian officers brokered a ceasefire between Amal and Hezbollah militias.

Between 30 August and 2 September 1990, Hezbollah and Amal representatives held peace talks at the Syrian army headquarters in the eastern village of Anjar. Mediated by Iran�s ambassador to Damascus, Sheikh Mohammed Akhtari, and Brigadier Ghazi Kanaan, the intelligence chief, the talks resulted in a peace agreement between the two rival Shiite parties on 2 September 1990. During the talks, the parties reiterated their will to end their media campaign and work toward a peaceful solution of the conflict.

On 25 October 1990, Amal and Hezbollah representatives met in Anjar, in the Biqa valley, under the auspices of Iran and Syria. The parties discussed the deployment of the Lebanese army in the south and a solution to the situation in Iqlim al-Tuffah.

On 30 October 1990, the two parties reached a ceasefire mediated by Iran and Syria at the Syrian observer forces� headquarters in Beirut. The two sides indicated in a communiqu� that they expected future meetings to discuss possible prisoner exchanges and a comprehensive and final settlement of the conflict.

On 5 November 1990, Amal leader Nabih Berri and Hezbollah Secretary-General Sheik Subhi al-Tufeili signed a reconciliation agreement brokered by Syria and Iran in Damascus. Present for the signing of the agreement were Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa and his Iranian counterpart Ali Akbar Velayati. With this agreement, the two sides agreed to allow the Lebanese army assume order in Shiite Muslim areas of Lebanon. Moreover, the parties agreed that any future disputes would be mediated by Syria and Iran and that the latter would be responsible for overseeing the implementation of the agreement.

On 17 December 1990, Syria and Iran met with Amal and Hezbollah officials with the aim of facilitating the implementation of the peace agreement. Iran�s ambassador to Damascus, Sheikh Mohammed Akhtari, and Brigadier Ghazi Kanaan chaired the discussions. The mediators focused on resolving obstacles that were hindering the deployment of the Lebanese army in the Iqlim al-Toufah area.

Since 1990, Amal and Hezbollah maintained mostly peaceful relations, but violence erupted again in 2000. In an attempt to restore and maintain peace between the two groups, commanders from Hezbollah and Amal in the southern region met at the Syrian intelligence Beirut headquarters on 17 July 2000.

On 15 February 1989, the Forces of Michel Aoun and the Lebanese Forces reached a ceasefire agreement during negotiations that were mediated by Christian cleric Patriarch Nasrallah Boutros Sfeir. The ceasefire stipulated the withdrawal of the Lebanese Forces from the streets. Violence had spread throughout the Christian enclave, extending from East Beirut to the ancient coastal town of Byblos.

On 18 February 1989, Maronite Christian Church officials met with Lebanese Forces chief Samir Geagea to negotiate a solution to the conflict. On the same day, the Maronite Christian Church officials met General Michel Aoun. The talks were aimed at preparing for a more sustained negotiation process, but Michel Aoun rejected church mediation unless it met its demand.

On 20 February 1989, Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea met for the first time directly since the beginning of the armed fighting between their forces. As a gesture of goodwill to end the conflict with the Forces of Aoun, the Lebanese Forces promised to leave the fifth basin at Beirut port. In addition, Samir Geagea promised to put his militia at the disposal of Aoun�s troops in his fight against Syria and its allies.

Tensions rose again when Geagea implicitly recognized � meaning he did not recognize it officially � the National Agreement concluded on 22 October 1989. Another reason why tension rose is that Geagea refrained from condemning the election of President Rene Mouawad and later Hrawi. Aoun, on the other hand, rejected the Arab-sponsored peace agreement under which Hrawi was elected because it failed to ensure the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon. To address these tensions and prevent another violent confrontation, Aoun and Geagea held bilateral talks on 5 November 1989.

On the night of 30-31 January 1990, as conflict flared up in East Beirut, Church mediators held peace talks between Maronite Christian rivals. On 31 January 1990, Aoun and Geagea announced a ceasefire in a joint statement on the radio, but armed fighting continued.

On 1 February 1990, Papal Nuncio Pablo Puente, Vatican peace envoy, brokered a ceasefire between the Forces of Michel Aoun and the Lebanese Forces of Samir Geagea. The ceasefire was reportedly intended to allow both sides to evacuate their casualties and to facilitate the negotiation of a lasting peace by clergymen and politicians, but the ceasefire broke down already after few hours.

On the same day, on 1 February 1990, General Aoun and Samir Geagea agreed on another truce in a bilateral telephone call. This telephone call was the result of efforts made by the Papal Nuncio Pablo Puente. Yet, fighting continued after this phone call.

On 3 February 1990, the Forces of Michel Aoun and the Lebanese Forces announced that they would respect a ceasefire proposed by the Vatican through Papal Nuncio Pablo Puente and the Maronite Catholic Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir.

On 5 February 1990, Christian clerics, supported by the Vatican, mediated another ceasefire between the conflict parties. They also announced the formation of a ceasefire monitoring committee including representatives of the two warring sides.
On 8 February 1990, Christian mediators facilitated negotiations aimed at implementing the latest ceasefire. The conflict parties agreed upon another ceasefire to stabilize the latest ceasefire.
On 10 February 1990, yet another ceasefire was mediated by the Christian committee between the two rival forces.
On 11 February 1990, Christian mediators held hours of separate talks with representatives of the conflict parties, without making any concluding statement.
On 12 February 1990, Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea discussed the modalities of engaging in official peace negotiations during a telephone call.

In response to an appeal by Maronite Patriarch Nasrallah Boutros Sfeir, Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea declared a ceasefire on 17 February 1990. They allegedly accepted the ceasefire to give their forces some rest, strengthen positions, and prepare for new attacks.

On 19 February 1990, Chaker Abu Sleiman, a Maronite community leader part of the Christian committee mediating in the Maronite conflict, mediated a six-point peace agreement between the two Maronite rivals. The pact sought to consolidate a two-day-old ceasefire, provided for a council of Christian leaders to govern the enclave under Aoun�s command, and featured a commitment to avoid force to settle disputes.
In late February 1990, a series of meetings were held aimed at the implementation of the peace agreement concluded on 19 February.

On 2 March 1990, Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea promised to stick to the ceasefire during a telephone conversation with the head of Lebanon�s Maronite Church Nasrallah Boutros Sfeir. Nasrallah Boutros Sfeir put pressure on the conflict parties by threatening them and all those waging the inter-Christian war with excommunication if they were not to lay down their weapons.
On 3 and 4 March 1990, the Christian mediation team continued talks with the conflict parties to bolster the truce.

On 4 March 1990, the Vatican emissary Mgr. Alberto Sozzi shuttled between Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea. He reportedly wanted to avoid a Syrian military intervention in the Christian enclave, encouraging the two Maronite rivals to refrain from violence.

On 1 April 1990, the three-man Christian committee backed by the Vatican mediated a ceasefire between the Forces of Michel Aoun and the Lebanese Forces. On 3 April 1990, Geagea officially recognized President Hrawi on Lebanese radio and accepted the Taif agreement, provoking a vehement response from Michel Aoun.
Following a ceasefire call made by Nasrallah Boutros Sfeir on 4 April 1990, Aoun and Geagea ordered their troops to put down their weapons.
