On 29 April 1990, a Maronite monk, Boulos Naaman, mediated a 36-hour truce in the district of Qlaiaat between the two rival forces, allowing residents to visit their houses and take away their belongings.

On 13 May 1990, Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz shuttled between representatives of the conflict parties in Baghdad. The President of Iraq, Saddam Hussein, allegedly wanted to resolve the inter-Christian conflict before hosting the special Arab League Summit on 28 May 1990 in Baghdad. Iraq was the main arms supplier of the two Christian forces, which should be seen in the context of the tensions between Iraq and Syria. In spite of the close relations with Iraq, the conflict parties refused to sit at the same table during the negotiations.

On 16 May 1990, a Maronite Christian monk, Father Bolous Na�aman, supported by the Vatican, mediated a ceasefire between Aoun and Geagea. The mediator engaged extensively with both sides, but the talks were held separately.
On 26 May 1990, Pablo Puente, the Apostolic Nuncio to Lebanon, mediated a permanent ceasefire between Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea, but their forces continued to fight.

After the ceasefire concluded on 26 May 1990 was announced, Pablo Puente shuttled between the two conflicting parties from 27 May until 6 June 1990. He tried to get both sides to agree on a Vatican peace initiative and stick to the ceasefire. The Vatican peace plan sought to include Aoun and Geagea in Hrawi�s cabinet and proposed revised political reforms. However, Hrawi opposed any amendments to the Taif agreement.
On 19 June 1990, Vatican envoy Pablo Puente held a three-hour discussion with General Michel Aoun to push him towards an end in fighting between his troops and the Lebanese Forces.

On 20 June 1990, director-general of the French foreign ministry Fran�ois Scheer mediated between Aoun and Geagea. Maronite Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir was also involved as a mediator in these talks. The mediators tried to obtain Aoun�s acceptance of the October 1989 Taif Agreement and the presidency of Elias Hrawi.
On 10 July 1990, Maronite Christian rivals agreed to end hostilities after a bilateral meeting.

On 15 July 1990, a mediation attempt was led by Lakhdar Brahimi to implement the Taif Agreement. He first met with President Elias Hrawi, Prime Minister Selim Hoss, and House Speaker Hussein Husseini in west Beirut. Next, he crossed the Green Line to hold discussions with Michel Aoun. The Arab peace envoy sought to persuade Aoun to recognize the Arab-sponsored peace agreement of October 1989 and the Hrawi administration. The next day, on 16 July 1990, Lakhdar Brahimi met with Samir Geagea, who expressed his approval of the Taif agreement, recognized President Hrawi, and indicated that he was willing to start talks with Hrawi�s administration.

On 23 July 1990, Arab peace envoy Lakhdar Brahimi met with General Aoun to propose a new peace plan to end the 15-year civil war. Brahimi sought to convince Aoun to accept the deployment of Hrawi�s army in Christian east Beirut. However, on 25 July 1990, Michel Aoun rejected the new Arab-sponsored peace initiative and refused the deployment of troops loyal to Elias Hrawi in east Beirut. In response, Hrawi�s cabinet imposed sanctions against Aoun on 28 July 1990, including a fuel ban, an embargo on military spare parts and ammunition, and a freeze on the salaries for government employees in Aoun-controlled territory. On 2 August 1990, Iraq invaded Kuwait, reshuffling the cards in the Middle East. As fighting resumed in the Christian enclave of Beirut, Syrian and Lebanese troops loyal to President Hrawi were deployed on 1 September 1990. In September, the constitutional reforms outlined in the Taif agreement were adopted by the Lebanese Parliament and then ratified by President Hrawi. On 13 October 1990, General Michel Aoun eventually surrendered after Syrian planes bombed his presidential palace. Aoun sought refuge in the French embassy and subsequently went into exile in France. Meanwhile, Geagea pledged allegiance to President Hrawi and promised to disband his 6,000-member militia and integrate them into Lahoud�s army.

Negotiations mediated by ECOWAS between the Government of Liberia, the NPFL, and the INPFL led to the signing of the Bamako Ceasefire Agreement on 28 November 1990. The agreement included a ceasefire provision, although the specific details of how it would be implemented were to be determined at a later time. ECOMOG was designated to oversee the monitoring of the ceasefire. Additionally, the parties agreed to address their disagreements concerning an Interim Government for Liberia, as outlined in the ECOWAS Peace Plan. This agreement is commonly interpreted as a sign of the NPFL accepting the ECOWAS Peace Plan.

Another round of talks between these conflict parties, mediated by ECOWAS, led to signing of the Banjul IV agreement on 21 December 1990. The agreement stipulated the extension of the existing ceasefire established in the Bamako agreement and the creation of an Interim government. Additionally, all seaports and airports were designated as military-free zones. Within a timeframe of 60 days, an All-Liberian National Conference was scheduled to convene, focusing on the details of establishing the interim regime. Upon its formation, the Interim government was responsible for disarming the warring factions.

Following two days of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS in the Togolese capital Lome, the INPFL and the NPFL, as well as the government forces, signed a ceasefire on 14 February 1991. The ceasefire was signed by NPFL leader Charles Taylor, INPFL leader Prince Yormie Johnson, and commander of Liberia�s armed forces General Hezekiah.

On 15 March 1991, the All-Liberia National Conference was held to discuss political power-sharing arrangements in Liberia until the upcoming elections. Taylor sent a NPFL delegation, but refused to attend the talks himself. The conference ended on 20 April 1991. The conflict parties agreed to form an Interim Government of National Unity to be led by Amos Sawyer. Elections were stipulated to be held as early as October 1991. Subsequent widespread infighting took place within the INPFL over disagreement about cooperating with the Interim Government. The infighting within the INPFL effectively ended the fighting between the INPFL and the NPFL.The INPFL was excluded from subsequent peace talks in 1991 between the Government of Liberia and the NPFL at Yamossoukro, which were mediated by ECOWAS and the INN.

Prince Johnson and Charles Taylor concluded a modus vivendi in 1992, under which their two militias agreed to cooperate in taking over Monrovia. In what the parties dubbed operation �Octopus�, the NPFL and INPFL were to launch a joint military assault against ECOMOG. However, Prince Johnson reneged on this agreement last minute. Consequently, the NPFL overran the INPFL�s Cadwell Base and killed some of its fighters. Prince Johnson surrendered to ECOMOG and was given sanctuary in Nigeria. The INPFL thus ceased to exist in October 1992.

In April 1994, the transitional government, UNOMIL and ECOMOG undertook efforts to bring about a ceasefire between NPFL and LPC as well as to bring LPC into the disarmament and demobilization process. However, in May 1994, LPC continued to attack NPFL.

In 1994, Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings was appointed ECOWAS chairman. Rawlings mediated negotiations in Akosombo in order to salvage the Cotonou agreement, which led to the conclusion of the Akosombo Peace Agreement in Ghana on 12 September 1994. Yet, the LPC was not included in this peace process either. Hence, the LPC rejected the Akosombo agreement. Consequently, the peace process continued, and another conference started in Accra on 22 November and led to a ceasefire agreement and a reaffirmation of the Akosombo agreement on 22 December 1994. The agreement set up a five-member Council of State. Seats were to be divided between the NPFL, ULIMO, the coalition of anti-NPFL factions which also included the LPC, the Liberian National Conference (LNC) consisting largely of civil society representatives, and a fifth member elected by the electoral college of the Liberian National Transitional Government (LNTG). The Accra Agreement stipulated that a ceasefire would come into effect by midnight on 28 December 1994. The Accra ceasefire lasted little more than a month.

From 15 to 19 August 1995, multiple conflict parties including the LPC and NPFL convened for a round of peace talks in Abuja. This effort was mediated by Ghanian representatives and supported by ECOWAS. A peace agreement was concluded in Abuja on 19 August 1995. The Abuja Accord successfully brought together leaders of all warring factions to form a transitional government in September 1995. This agreement amended and supplemented the Cotonou Accord, the Akosombo Agreement, and the Accra (Clarification) Agreement. Unlike previous agreements, the Abuja Agreement included most non-state armed groups, including the ULIMO, the United Liberation Front of Liberia for Democracy faction led by Roosevelt Johnson (ULIMO-J), LPC, NPFL, AFL, the National Patriotic Front of Liberia - Central Revolutionary Council (NPFL-CRC), and LNC. The Abuja Agreement gave sole authority for military enforcement to ECOMOG and removed the role that the Akosombo Agreement had assigned to the LNTG.

A ceasefire was re-declared, which would take effect on 26 August 1995. The agreement also established a timeframe for the formation of an interim government and the distribution of positions within the interim government. All signatory rebel groups of the Abuja Agreement sent orders to their commanders to cease hostilities. The only exception was LPC, which continued fighting. Fighting continued in the south-east and west.

During a few weeks in the early summer of 1996, fierce battles raged in the Liberian capital Monrovia. These clashes, which are commonly referred to as the third battle for Monrovia, were fought between National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) and the United Liberation Movement of Liberia for Democracy faction led by Alhaji Kromah (ULIMO-K) on the one side and the United Liberation Front of Liberia for Democracy faction led by Roosevelt Johnson (ULIMO-J), the Liberian Peace Council (LPC), and the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) on the other side. The clashes took place in the context of a struggle over political power in the wake of the Abuja Accord concluded in December 1995. ULIMO-J fighters were among the first to violate the terms of this agreement, when they resisted the deployment of ECOMOG troops around the diamond mines near Tubmanburg. The leader of the ULIMO-J, Roosevelt Johnson, was dismissed from leadership in early 1996. Since he represented the ULIMO-J, Roosevelt Johnson was subsequently also removed from the transitional government. On 6 April, Charles Taylor tried to arrest Roosevelt Johnson, which led to heavy fighting between Taylor�s NPFL and ULIMO-J fighters loyal to Roosevelt Johnson. While the ULIMO-K fought alongside the NPFL, the ULIMO-J was supported by the AFL and the LPC. Mediation by ECOWAS � with support from the UN and the OAU � led to the restoration of a ceasefire in Monrovia on 26 May 1996.
Another round of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS, UN and OAU led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement between the factions on 4 July.

Subsequent peace talks, also mediated by ECOWAS, the UN, and the OAU, led to the conclusion of the Supplement to the Abuja Accord on 17 August 1996. The agreement is an amended version of the former Abuja accord with minor amendments to the Transitional Government and an extension of its lifespan. It confirmed the ceasefire and provided for elections to be held in May 1997. The signatories included the NPLF, AFL, LPC, ULIMO-J, and ULIMO-K.

The OAU appointed Reverend Cnaan Banna, the former President of Zimbabwe, as its eminent person to Liberia in January 1993. Together with Gordon-Sommers, Bannana was actively involved in peacemaking activities and discussed the establishment of a ceasefire with Charles Taylor in April 1993.

The early July effort paved the way for another round of negotiations that started on 22 July and led to the signing of a peace agreement between the conflict parties in Cotonou on 25 July 1993. The Cotonou Agreement established a monitored ceasefire and cessation of hostilities by ECOMOG. Troops were required to stay in their locations until encampment and demobilization. A transitional government with full authority over Liberia was agreed upon, including power-sharing arrangements in the executive, legislative, and judicial branches. The executive consisted of a five-member Council of State selected by prominent Liberians. The transitional Assembly comprised delegates from the government, NPFL, and ULIMO. ULIMO was given the right to nominate a delegate to the Supreme Court. Power-sharing extended to the elections commission, amnesty declaration, repatriation program for refugees and displaced persons, and release of prisoners of war. At this peace conference, Somers acted as the UN�s chief mediator, while the OAU�s eminent for Liberia person Canaan Banana acted as the OAU�s chief mediator. In addition, Nic�phore Soglo, President of Benin and chairman of ECOWAS, acted as the chief mediator of ECOWAS. According to the provisions of the agreement, which was signed in Cotonou, Benin, a ceasefire was to take effect on 1 August 1993, after which a provisional government was to be established by the end of September 1993. Elections were scheduled for 1994. In order to ensure compliance with the ceasefire, the agreement also set up a Joint Ceasefire Monitoring Committee, comprising representatives of the Interim Government, the NPFL, and ULIMO, as well as representatives of ECOWAS and the UN. However, the Cotonou ceasefire broke down almost as soon as it was signed. There was renewed fighting between the NPFL and ULIMO, while a new Krahn-dominated militia, the Liberian Peace Council (LPC), emerged in the south-east of the country where it was immediately at odds with the NPFL.
On 9 September, NPFL announced a unilateral ceasefire and the next day ULIMO also announced a ceasefire.

The parties subsequently engaged in another round of negotiations and finalized the Akosombo Agreement in Ghana on 12 September 1994. The agreement was signed by the NPFL, ULIMO, and the Liberian Armed Forces. The Akosombo Peace Agreement served as a complement to the Cotonou agreement and introduced modifications to it. Alongside reaffirming the ceasefire, the agreement included amendments related to the armed forces of Liberia. It outlined the requirements for establishing a new military force. The agreement specified that demobilizing the troops and forming a new national army would fall under the responsibility of the Transitional Government. Furthermore, the agreement stated that the Transitional Government would exist for approximately 16 months, and elections were scheduled to take place on 10 October 1995. However, at the time of the signing of the Akosombo Peace Agreement, the fighting was still raging throughout Liberia. In fact, Charles Taylor and his forces were being expelled from their headquarters in Gbarnga simultaneously to the peace process in Akosombo.

The earlier peace process continued, and another conference started in Accra on 22 November and led to a ceasefire agreement and a reaffirmation of the Akosombo agreement on 22 December 1994. The Accra Agreements, also referred to as the Akosombo Clarification Agreement, reaffirmed and provided additional details to the Akosombo Agreement. Furthermore, the Accra Agreements compelled several non-signatories to adhere to the terms of the Akosombo Agreement. The agreement set up a five-member Council of State. Seats were to be divided between the NPFL, ULIMO, the coalition of anti-NPFL factions, the Liberian National Conference (LNC) consisting largely of civil society representatives, and a fifth member elected by the electoral college of the Liberian National Transitional Government (LNTG). The Accra Agreement stipulated that a ceasefire would come into effect by midnight on 28 December 1994. The Accra Agreement lasted little more than a month.

From 15 to 19 August 1995, multiple conflict parties including the LPC and NPFL convened for a round of peace talks in Abuja. This effort was mediated by Ghanian representatives and supported by ECOWAS. A peace agreement was concluded in Abuja on 19 August 1995. The Abuja Accord established a transitional government in September 1995, incorporating leaders from all warring factions. It amended and supplemented previous agreements including the Cotonou Accord, Akosombo Agreement, and Accra (Clarification) Agreement. A new ceasefire was declared, effective from August 26, 1995. The amendments mainly involved minor adjustments to power-sharing arrangements, such as replacing the five-member Council of State with a six-member council and granting ULIMO-J movement ministerial portfolios. Additionally, there were minor reallocations of other ministerial portfolios.
Mediation by ECOWAS � with support from the UN and the OAU � led to the restoration of a ceasefire in Monrovia on 26 May 1996.
Another round of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS, the UN and OAU led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement between the factions on 4 July 1996.

Subsequent peace talks, also mediated by ECOWAS, the UN, and the OAU, led to the conclusion of the Supplement to the Abuja Accord on 17 August 1996. The agreement is an amended version of the former Abuja accord with minor amendments to the Transitional Government and an extension of its life-span. It confirmed the ceasefire and provided for elections to be held in May 1997. The signatories included the NPLF, AFL, LPC, ULIMO-J, and ULIMO-K.

Mediation efforts conducted by UNOMIL and ECOMOG to resolve the dispute within ULIMO resulted on 6 May 1994 in a ceasefire and an agreement to hold further negotiations. However, the negotiations collapsed, and serious fighting resumed on 26 May 1994. Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings, who acted as the chairman of ECOWAS, mediated negotiations in Akosombo. These negotiations involved the Government of Liberia, the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL), the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), and the of ULIMO-K, but not ULIMO-J.
On 30 November, the ULIMO-J and the ULIMO-K signed a ceasefire agreement during a round of negotiations mediated by UNOMIL and ECOMOG.

In order to bring all major non-state armed groups in Liberia on board of the peace process, another round of negotiations was held in Accra in December 1994. The parties signed the Accra Agreement on 21 December 1994, which enabled the non-signatories to the Akosombo Agreement that had been concluded in September 1994, including ULIMO-J, to accept that agreement. The Accra Agreement stipulated that a ceasefire would come into effect by midnight on 28 December 1994. This ceasefire also entailed an obligation of ULIMO-K and ULIMO-J to stop fighting.

From 15 to 19 August 1995, multiple conflict parties including the LPC and NPFL convened for a round of peace talks in Abuja. This effort was mediated by Ghanian representatives and supported by ECOWAS. A peace agreement was concluded in Abuja on 19 August 1995. The Abuja Accord successfully brought together the leaders of all conflicting factions, establishing a transitional government in September 1995. This agreement served as an amendment and addition to the Cotonou Accord, the Akosombo Agreement, and the Accra (Clarification) Agreement. Both factions of the ULIMO were part of this agreement and both factions committed to a ceasefire that would take effect on 26 August 1995 and several power-sharing provisions included in the agreement. The Council of State, previously composed of five members, was replaced by a six-member council, and the ULIMO-J movement was granted several ministerial positions. Additionally, there were minor reassignments of ministerial portfolios agreed upon.

During a few weeks in the early summer of 1996, fierce battles raged in the Liberian capital Monrovia. These clashes, which are commonly referred to as the third battle for Monrovia, were fought between the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) and the ULIMO-K on the one side and the ULIMO-J, the Liberian Peace Council (LPC), and the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) on the other side. The clashes took place in the context of a struggle over political power in the wake of the Abuja Accord concluded in December 1995. ULIMO-J fighters were among the first to violate the terms of this agreement, when they resisted the deployment of ECOMOG troops around the diamond mines near Tubmanburg. The leader of the ULIMO-J, Roosevelt Johnson, was dismissed from leadership in early 1996. Since he represented the ULIMO-J, Roosevelt Johnson was subsequently also removed from the transitional government. On 6 April, Charles Taylor tried to arrest Roosevelt Johnson, which led to heavy fighting between Taylor�s NPFL and ULIMO-J fighters loyal to Roosevelt Johnson. While the ULIMO-K fought alongside the NPFL, the ULIMO-J was supported by the AFL and the LPC. Mediation by ECOWAS � with support from the UN and the OAU � led to the restoration of a ceasefire in Monrovia on 26 May 1996.
Another round of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS, the UN and OAU led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement between the factions on 4 July 1996.

Subsequent peace talks, also mediated by ECOWAS, the UN, and the OAU, led to the conclusion of the Supplement to the Abuja Accord on 17 August 1996. This agreement is also known as the Abuja II peace agreement. The agreement is an amended version of the former Abuja accord with minor amendments to the Transitional Government and an extension of its life-span. It confirmed the ceasefire and provided for elections to be held in May 1997. The signatories included the NPLF, AFL, LPC, ULIMO-J, and ULIMO-K. Nevertheless, tensions between ULIMO-K and ULIMO-J remained.

On 6 September 1996, the two groups concluded another ceasefire during a round of negotiations mediated by ECOWAS, the OAU, and the UN. Hostilities subsequently ceased in Bomi county and both groups disengaged their forces.
On 24 September 1996, ECOWAS, the OAU, and the UN mediated another ceasefire after some fighting had resumed.

Negotiations between the ARLA and the MPA, without the involvement of a mediator, led to the conclusion of a treaty on 11 April 1994. The treaty was aimed to close the ranks between the two groups in preparation for a meeting in Tamanrasset between MFUA and the Government of Mali.

FPLA leader Zeidane ag Sidi Alamine initiated another round of negotiations between the MPA and ARLA, which led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 15 December 1994. The FPLA also signed the agreement. However, the FIAA was not part of this round of peace talks. On the contrary, the agreement signed by the MPA, ARLA, and FPLA on 15 December 1994 not only stipulated peace between the signatory groups, but also included a provision that the three groups would fight �renegade rebels�, referring to the FIAA. In the weeks prior to this formal treaty, the MPA and FPLA, together with the Mouvement Patriotique Ganda Koi (MPGK), had already reached an informal agreement to fight the FIAA together. As a result of being attacked by several armed groups, Zahaby ould Sidi Mohamed, the leader of the FIAA, finally conceded in June 1995 to adhere to the National Pact. This ended the fighting between the FIAA and the MPA, as well as the former allies of the FIAA: the PLA and ARLA.
Malian and Niger government officials met in Menaka in March 1997 to try and reconcile the two groups.

The government of Mali responded to the violence by inviting the Nigerian government to talks in the city of Menaka in Mali. These talks were held in mid-March 1997 in Menaka after the first outburst of violence. The talks were unsuccessful since violence flared up once again in July 1997. However, armed fighting did not continue after the summer of 1997.

After the start of the civil war in Mali in 2012, the Fulani became fearful that the Tuareg would dominate the inner delta of the Niger river. As a result, tensions between the two tribes increased. In February 2014, tensions between the Fulani and Tuareg escalated into violent clashes, resulting in some 30 Tuaregs killed by armed Fulani around 80 kilometres from Gao, allegedly in revenge for the kidnapping and killing of a member of their community. In March 2014, inter-communal violence between the Tuareg and the Fulani in Gao region further intensified. From 17 to 19 March 2014, the governments of Mali and Niger organized a peace meeting of Fulani and Tuareg community leaders of both countries in an effort to address long-standing intercommunal tensions and foster reconciliation.

Between 14 and 19 April 2015, MINUSMA, in line with its mandate concerning the protection of civilians, which includes the mitigation of intercommunal violence, supported a peace caravan to Goundam Cercle. To restore trust between the communities of Goundam, peaceful messages were disseminated to people in over 20 localities in the Cercle, including members of Arab, Fulani, Songhai and Tuareg communities, as well as representatives of the M�bera refugee camp in Mauritania. Activities included large public meetings in Bintagoungou, Dou�kir�, Goundam, Mbouna and Scale, as well as the facilitation of several focus group sessions aimed at promoting reconciliation. In addition, MINUSMA facilitated a number of intercommunal dialogues between the Tuareg and the Fulani communities in Bamako and the Gao, Kidal and Timbuktu regions between September to December 2015.

In the beginning of September 1993, Mr Saro-Wiwa, the founding member of the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (MOSOP), together with Senator Birabi and representatives of the Rivers State Security Council, went to the destroyed village of Kaa, and Ogoni town, and urged Governor Ada George to take steps to stop the violence between the Adoni and Ogoni. This led to several meetings between Adoni and Ogoni leaders mediated by government officials. In addition, a peace committee was created. This committee was led by headed by Professor Claude Ake. On 25 September 1993, the Nigerian government instructed the military to halt the fighting. Following the creation of the peace committee, Claude Ake went on to organize a peace conference, which was organized by the Rivers State Peace Conference Committee and National Council on Inter-Governmental Relation on 6 October 1993. After the conference, a joint resolution was issued, claiming that all parties accept the immediate resolution of the conflict. Ake dismissed this resolution as he suspected that the government played a role in the conflict. In addition, some of the Ogoni leaders, such as Saro-Wiwa, refused to sign the agreement, arguing that were still too many unanswered questions regarding the role of the government.

Negotiations in February 1995 led to the signing of a peace agreement by three Adoni and three Ogoni representatives in Port Harcourt. The agreement was signed in front of an audience of journalists, government commissioners, and elders from the concerned communities. They agreed to perform traditional rituals to complete the reconciliation and asked the government to devolve more authority, so local leaders could better keep the peace.

In September 2001, clashes erupted in direct response to a dispute over a recent political appointment. Armed fighting led to several thousand deaths. A 10-man commission � referred to as the Niki Tobi Judicial Inquiry Commission � led by Joshua Dariye was set up to investigate the conflict. This commission subsequently mediated between the conflict parties at a peace conference. The Afisare, Anagura, and Birom agreed to the conclusion of a peace agreement, but the Hausa and the Fulani refused to sign it.
The conflict parties attended the Plateau State Peace Summit in early August 2002. Plateau State governor Dariye acted as the mediator at this summit. The negotiations led to an agreement.

On 28 June 2004, representatives of 13 communities of the Jos North Local Government Area of Plateau � Afisare, Anaguta, Berom, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Ebira, Tiv, Sayawa, Southern Kaduna, South-South, and Yoruba � signed a peace agreement in Jos in which they pledged not to mix politics and religion and promised to live in peace.

In addition, local authorities organized a month-long peace conference aimed at bringing peace to Plateau State, which was inaugurated by President Obasanjo on 18 August 2004. This conference was conducted under a twelve-member steering committee and brought together several represenatives of the conflict parties. Government officials and traditional leaders acted as the mediators. All indigenous ethnic groups from Plateau State such as the Afisare, Anaguta, and Birom were allowed to send two representatives each to the conference, while �settlers� such as Fulani and Hausa were allowed only one representative each. The conference culminated in a draft agreement containing a number of resolutions. The draft agreement included a resolution stating that the Berom, Anaguta, and Afisare ethnic nationalities are the owners of Jos. The Hausa, unsatisfied with the conference report, refused to sign it. On 3 March 2010, the Gbong Gwom Jos set up the Stakeholder�s Consultative Committee � a multi-ethnic peace committee � together with ninety community leaders from Plateau State from Igalas, Idomas, Tivs, Afisare, Anaguta, Igbos, Yoruba, Shuwa Arab, Hausa, Fulani, Berom, and South South communities, as well as Youth groups, CAN, and JNI members. This committee had the task to restore peace in the state and met monthly in order to do so. The UN Development Program (UNDP) supported this committee.

The Center for Humanitarian Dialogue facilitated another meeting as part of the Jos Forum in December 2014. This led to the signing of the Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation on 11 December 2014. The agreement represents a public commitment to achieve peace among all signatories.
agreement_name: Joint Statement of Commitment for Peace and Cooperation

description: Following armed clashes in Jos in July 2015, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue mediated a round of negotiations between leaders of the Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, and Yoruba communities in Jos. This led to the signing of a joint declaration to end fighting in Jos.

Following the clashes, on 25 August 1997, the Osun State Council of Obas and chiefs from both communities met in Oshogbo and established a seven-man committee to investigate the events. Directly after renewed violence, on 25 September 1997, the military governor of the state, Lieutenant-Colonel Anthony Obi, invited the leaders of the two communities to an emergency meeting at his headquarters in Oshogbo to end the fighting. However, no written agreement resulted from the meeting.
On 8 December 1997, tribal leaders met with military representatives to discuss how to end the fighting in Ife Town.

Negotiations between the Modakeke and Ife leaders, mediated by the state government (led by the administrator, Lt-Col Assan Ubi), led to the signing of a peace agreement in Oshogbo on 9 December 1997.

Negotiations between the ibale (traditional ruler) of Modakeke Chief Francis Adedoyin and the asiwaju of Ife Chief Orayemi led to the signing of another peace agreement on 15 December 1997. Colonel Ubi, Osun State administrator, mediated this accord.

In response to the resurgence of violence between the two communities in September 1998, the state administrator, Col Theophilus Bamigboye, met separately Modakeke and Ife communities for shuttle negotiations on 7 September 1998. At this occasion, both communities vowed to end hostilities. However, no written agreement was agreed upon.

On 14 September 1998, Oba Okunade Sijuade and Oba Francis Adedoyin, respectively the Ooni of Ife and the Ogunsua of Modakeke met again separately with Col. Theophilus Bamgboye to negotiate an end to the fighting. Both agreed to commit to peace, but no written agreement was signed. On 14 October 1998, the Osun State Council of Obas selected Colonel Theophilus Bamigboye to create a six-person committee called the �reconciliation team� to find a solution to the ongoing ethnic conflict. Simultaneously, a committee was set up by traditional elders to attempt to mediate between the conflict parties.
Negotiations led to the signing of another peace agreement in 1999.

Violence erupted again in the beginning of March 2000. In reaction to this, the Governor of Osun State, Bisi Akande, imposed a curfew on 7 March 2000. On that same day, on 7 March 2000, Frederic Fasheun and Beko Ransome-Kuti � two officials of the Odua People�s Congress (OPC), a pan-Yoruba organization � met with leaders of the conflict parties to negotiate a solution. The following day, the two tribes agreed to a temporary ceasefire that was set to last until 10 March.
On 17 March, the Ife and Modakeke leaders signed a peace agreement, after engaging in indirect negotiations mediated by the Osun Governor Bisi Akande in Oshogbo.

From 23 to 24 March, President Olusegun Obasanjo met with representatives of the Ife and Modakeke, as well as the Governor of Osun State, Bisi Akande and Commodore Olabode George to discuss lasting measures for peace. This led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement. Furthermore, President Olusegun Obasanjo also set up a new peace body with Bishop Gabriel Abegunrin (Osun State�s Catholic Diocese) serving as leader of a 27-person team: the Olabode George committee. The committee was composed of 12 members from Ife, seven from Modakeke, and eight government officials, including former external affairs minister, Professor Bolaji Akinyemi. Among the provisions included is the creation of liaison office, a police-training center and Sijuade�s recognition of Adedoyin�s authority.

Following the recommendation of the Olabode George committee, the Ooni of Ife, Oba Okunade Sijuade and the Ogunsua of Modakeke Chief Francis Orafidiya reached a peace agreement at another round of negotiations mediated by President Olusegun Obasanjo in Abuja on 21 June 2000. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire and a power-sharing mechanism ensuring proportional representation of the two cities on the regional council. The US Agency for Internal Development (USAID) organized workshops and training program to key stakeholders of the Modakeke and Ife towns throughout 2000.

On 15 December 2000, after a two-day meeting with the country�s human rights panel, representatives of the two cities of Ife and Modakeke signed a �Memorandum of Understanding�, reiterating their commitment to peace.

Negotiations between Modakeke Chief Francis Adedoyin and the asiwaju of Ife Chief Orayemi, mediated by Prince Olagunsoye Oyinlola, took place on 6 February 2009. The talks resulted in Adedoyin being recognized as the Oba of Ifeland on 8 February. Furthermore, the agreement provided for the establishment of a unique local council that would be based in Modakeke. The agreement was concluded between the Osun State Government, the Ooni of Ife, the Oba Okunade Sijuwade, the Olubuse II and the Ogunsua of Modakeke, Francis Adedoyin.
The general chief of staff Admiral Akhigbe mediated between the conflict parties in Azure in mid-February 1999. The Ijaws expressed their wish for a local government during these negotiations.

The Ijaw and Ilaje promised to establish a joint peace committee to move the reconciliation process forward during a round of negotiations in Akure on 4 August 1999. The conflict parties also agreed to a truce in the presence of federal security forces and the governor of Ondo State, Adebayo Adefarati.
In mid-August 1999, the two communities met with the Minister of Internal Affairs Chief Afolabi, who tried to negotiate an end to the clashes.

A round of negotiations in Ajegunle in the Ajeromi/Ifelodun council of Lagos State led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 3 November 1999. Governor Bola Ahmed Tinubu mediated these negotiations.
On 16 July 2003, the two conflict parties signed a peace agreement at a round of negotiations mediated by Ondo State governor Olusegun Agagu.

Negotiations between the three communities one week later, mediated by Governor James Ibori of Delta State, led to the signing of a ceasefire on 24 June 1999 in Asaba. The agreement was signed by Justice Franklin Atake for the Itsekiris, Chief Edwin Clark for the Ijaws and Chief Benjamin Okumagba for the Urhobos.

On 7 April 2003, President Obasanjo met with Urhobo, Itsekiri and Ijaw leaders in Abuja, along with the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC), and security chiefs to further talk about peace solutions in Warri. At this meeting, the conflict parties reached a ceasefire agreement. Following this meeting, Obasanjo set up a committee tasked with resolving the Warri Crisis. This committee was headed by General Theophilus Y. Danjuma, who was the former Minister of Defense.

On 28 August 2003, James Ibori, the Governor of Delta State, addressed the members of the Delta State Assembly and proposed a peace plan for the Warri crisis. The plan calls for each of the three warring ethnic groups, Ijaw, Itsekiri and Urhobo, to have its own local government area. While Ijaw and Urhobo leaders endorsed it, Itsekiri claimed the plan to be �illegal� and �unconstitutional� and expressed to not be satisfied with the plan.

On 19 September 2003, Nigerian President Obasanjo attended a meeting with Ijaw, Urhobo, and Itsekiri leaders in Warri in order to promote reconciliation. The meeting was chaired by the state administrator, Colonel David Dungs, and the General Officer Commanding the 82nd Division of the Nigerian Army, Major General Felix Mojapero. The Ijaws and Urhobos deplored Itsekiri�s unjust domination of political power and supported Obori�s proposal to create local government areas. Itsekiri representatives once again rejected this proposal.

The conflict intensified in early 1992. The Nigerian government convened peace meetings between the Jukun and Tiv on two separate occasions during February 1992. On 13 February, the leaders of the conflict parties � H.R.H. Dr. Shekarau Angyu Masa-Ili and H.R.H. Ochivirigh Alfred Akawa Torkula Tor Tiv for the Jukun and the Tiv respectively � signed a 10-point peace agreement in Wukari. Representatives from both Taraba and Benue governments, Reverend Jolly Nyame and Moses Adasu, were in attendance.
Earlier on 13 February 1992, the group had gathered at Aguda House in Abuja with Admiral Augustus Aikhomu in order to discuss the conflict issues and the potential for signing a ceasefire.

The UCDP does not record any armed clashes between the conflict parties between 1995 and 2000, though little progress was made with regard to the implementation of the 1992 agreement. This might explain why shortly after his election in May 1999, Rev. Jolly Nyame set up a peace committee that had the task to mediate between the two communities. Violence intensified again in Taraba in the second half of 2001. On 24 September 2001, Vice-President Atiku Abubakar, following the order of President Olusegun Obasanjo instructed the governments of Benue and Taraba to resolve the continued conflict during a reconciliation meeting in Abuja. Representatives of both warring groups were present. In addition, at the national level, the Federal Government and military authorities asserted that they sent soldiers to Tarabata State and the areas around the Tarabata-Benue border at the beginning of October 2001 in order to restore peace in the region. Meanwhile, on 10 October 2001, a Tiv armed group abducted 19 soldiers. Tiv elements claim that the soldiers were armed Jukuns and did not believe that these soldiers were coming to restore peace. This event triggered the start of a new wave of violence against civilians in the region conducted by the military between 22 and 24 October 2001. The Governors of Benue and Taraba State met several times before the violence erupted, but they failed to prevent the massacre. In response to the outbreak of violence, traditional rulers and opinion leaders from across the confederation went to Warri on 31 October 2001 to discuss the religious clash in Kano and the Tiv/Jukun ethnic conflict in Benue and Taraba States. This discussion was part of a more general meeting on ethno-religious crises within Nigeria. Seen as an �advisory forum�, this general meeting aimed to initiate calm dialogue and find long-term solutions. However, the conflict continued.

The meeting of 11 November with President Obasanjo also paved the way for a meeting involving Jukun and Tiv leaders on 16 November 2001. This meeting was brokered by the Arewa Consultative Forum in Kaduna and led to the signing of a ceasefire. At this meeting, the Nigerian government announced a plan to convene the tribes for another round of peace talks on 19 and 20 December 2001, but no public information exists that suggests that this meeting took place.

On 30 August 2003, a peace conference was held with fifty-one Tiv and Jukun stakeholders from Taraba and Benue State and nine witnesses from state, national and international organizations. This led to the signing of the so called �Jalingo Resolution� in Taraba State, granting indigenous status to the Tiv people in the Taraba State and calling for reconciliation between the Tiv and the Junkun. This agreement was the product of more than two years of consultations and workshops with Jukun and Tiv representatives � between 21 September 2001 and 31 August 2003 � organized in in Mkar, Wukari, Abuja, Gboko, Makurdi, Suntai and Jalingo by the Peace, Justice and Reconciliation Committee of the Reformed Ecumenical Council of Nigeria (RECON) and its implementation committee. The traditional ruler of the Tiv, Dr. Alfred Akawe Torkula, however, contested this resolution, claiming that he never signed it: �he had neither prior knowledge of, nor was briefed before or during the said consultation.�

Another peace effort took place in 2014 and this time not only focused on the Tiv and Jukun, but also included the Fulani and the Hausa communities. On 5 April 2014, Tiv, Fulani, Jukun and Hausa leaders from Wukari, Ibi, Donga and Takum LGA signed a peace agreement in Jalingo (Taraba State) brokered by Michael Zuokumor, Deputy Inspector General of the Police. The secretary General of Tiv Taraba Cultural Social Association, Mr. Julius Butu, the President of Jukun Youth Cultural Development Association, Mr. Zando Hoku, and the State Chairman of Miyetti Allah Cattle Breeders Association, Alhaji Mafindi Danburam signed the resulting communiqu� that appealed for peace between the four communities.

On 29 April 2014, representatives of the Jukun, Tiv and Fulani tribes signed another peace agreement in Bali LGA. No mediator was involved in these negotiations. This agreement failed, as hostilities resumed in the beginning of May 2014.

After the violence of 15 April 2014 in Wukari, the Jukun, Tiv, and Fulani leaders of the Wukari LGA signed yet another peace agreement on 30 April 2014. The peace agreement was mediated by Taraba State Governor Alhaji Garba Umar and Wukari Paramount Chief Shekarau Angyu and signed by Mr. Zando Hoku, President of Jukun State Cultural Association, Mr. James Nungwa, President of Tiv State Cultural and Development Association, and Alhaji Mafindi Danburam, Chairman of Miyetti Allah Cattle Breeders Association. Furthermore, on 16 May 2014, the Governors of Benue (Gabriel Suswam) and Taraba (Garba Umar) States inaugurated a seven-man joint peace committee mandated to ensure the return of peace between the warring ethnic groups, namely the Tiv, Jukun and Fulani living in the border communities of the two states. This took place in Kashimbilla in Takum local government area of Taraba State.

Despite repeated peacebuilding efforts between Jukun and Tiv during an absence of fighting between 2002 and 2015, a new outbreak of fightng occurred on 14 April 2016. A conflict between a small settlement of Jukun and the neighboring community of Angbaye Tiv along the Makurdi-Gboko road in Benue State resulted in between seven and ten deaths. Armed clashes continued during the rest of the year. On 22 December 2016, community representatives from six local areas in the Southern Plateau, including the Tiv and Jukun communities, signed the South Plateau Peace Declaration. This peace agreement was the product of an inter-community dialogue process facilitated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) in the Southern Plateau launched in June 2016.

In the aftermath of clashes in Abinsi town in the Local Government Area of Guma in Benue State, the Tiv, Jukun and Fulani leaders gathered at a peace meeting in Benue in January 2019. The peace meeting was mediated by the army commander of the joint military operation in Benue State, Major General Adeyemi Yekini. The conflict parties agreed on the need to end violence, but no written agreement was concluded at the meeting. On 5 March 2019, a commission of inquiry into the Tiv/Jukun crisis set up by the Benue State Government was inaugurated in Makurdi. The commission, headed by Judge Wilfred Kpochi, was mandated to investigate the causes of the crisis and to restore peace to the affected region.
In early April 2019, the conflict parties engaged in bilateral negotiations in Taraba State. This led to the signing of a peace agreement. However, fighting resumed already one week later.

On 15 April 2019, the deputy governors of Taraba and Benue, Haruna Manu and Benson Abounu respectively, organized a peace meeting between the leaders of the Jukun and the Tiv at the Federal University in Wukari in Taraba State. The meeting resulted in the signing of a communiqu� that called uppon the youth of the two communities to lay down their arms and follow the path of peace. However, the armed violence continued.

A peace meeting between the conflict parties mediated by the army in Kente in Taraba State led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 10 June 2019. In addition to stipulating a ceasefire, the agreement stipulated that the roadblocks that had been erected on the Gbeji-Kente-Wukari axis should be dismantled. However, armed violence continued.

Despite numerous mediation efforts, the conflict parties continued to fight each other. A peace meeting was therefore held at the federal level. Benue and Taraba state representatives, Samuel Ortom and Darius Ishaku, together with traditional Jukun and Tiv leaders, met in Abuja with Federal Government officals on 4 September 2019. This resulted in a communique in which the Federal Government pledged its support for the peace effort between the two communities and in which the Tiv and Jukun leaders called for an immediate cessation of hostilities. However, hostilities resumed in Taraba village already one week later.

On 25 and 26 September 2019, a peace meeting was held at the Government House in Jalingo in Taraba State. The peace meeting was attended representatives of the Tiv, Jukun, and Etulo communities of the Local Government Areas of Wukari, Donga, and Takum. State officials security chiefs acted as the mediators at the peace meeting. The meeting resulted in a ceasefire and the establishment of a 30-member committee composed of representatives of the Tiv and Jukun tribes, which was tasked with ending the conflict through supporting the implementation of the ceasefire. In spite of this agreement, hostilities resumed within a couple of days after it was signed.

From 10 to 11 October 2019, the leaders of the Jukun and Tiv communities met in Jalingo at the initiative of the Coalition of Northern Groups (CNG) to find a lasting solution to the crisis. This meeting, mediated by the CNG, led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement by the President of the Tiv community, Goodman Dahida, and the spokesperson of the Jukun community, Daniel Emmanuel Angyu. The President of the Tiv-Jukun Conflict Reconciliation Committee signed in his capacity as mediator.

A two-day peace meeting, attended by the 30-man committee consisting of representatives of Tiv and Jukun that had been set up by Governor Darius Ishaku, was in Jalingo in late October 2019. Deputy Governor of Taraba State, Haruna Manu, acted as the chief mediator at this meeting. The meeting led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. Danjuma Adamu, Markus Ikitsombika and John Mamman signed the communiqu� on behalf of the Jukun community, while Jime Yongo, Kurason Kura and Isaac Waakaa represented the Tiv community. Armed fighting resumed only few weeks later.

On 14 April 2020, the Deputy Governors of Nasarawa, Benue, and Taraba signed a peace agreement to end the armed violence between the Tiv and Jukun in these states. The formal declaration emerged following a peace meeting held in Lafia.

On 26 March 2020, a joint communique was issued by the chairs of ten communities involved in the mediation process facilitated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) in Benue State. The communities included Agatu, Etulo, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Igede, Jukun, Tiv, and Yoruba ethnic groups. The communique focused on upholding peaceful co-existence during and after the COVID-19 pandemic.

Following an outbreak of armed violence in early September 1995, colonel Mike Attah, the military governor of Anambra State, mediated between the two communities at the Nkisi Palace Hotel in Onitscha. This led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement.

After the 1999 violence, the government of Anambra created a commission of inquiry led by Justice Emmanuel Araka. Participating members were drawn from each of the three feuding communities of Aguleri, Umuleri, and Umuoba Anam. Obaneze Ndi Igbo, an Igbo organization, set up the first civil society initiative to resolve the Aguleri-Umuleri conflict. A first meeting was held in April 1999 to find solutions to the running conflict. The meeting resulted in a communiqu� calling for an immediate end to the violence and increased government action. The Ohanaeze initiative resulted in a temporary cessation of fighting for about two weeks. However, resumed soon after the conclusion of the ceasefire.

Directly after its election in May 1999, President Olusegun Obasanjo visited the communities and invited their leaders to Abuja, where another ceasefire agreement was reached, and a peace committee set up to discuss the issue and pronounce a permanent peace.
Aguleri and Umuleri communities adopted a 6-point plan for peace in late June 1999.

On 14 July 1999, the Aguleri and Umuleri attended a peace meeting. The Anambra state governor Chinwoke Mbadinuju, who mediated between the parties, gave the groups one week to commit to a ceasefire agreement. The conflict parties did, however, not commit to a ceasefire. In mid-July 1999, an alternative track for peace was started by the Anambra East Council of Traditional Rulers and Leaders of Thought at the Onitsha North Local Government. Led by Chief Kelly Nzekwesi, the mediation team involved various tribes, including the leaders of the conflict parties, but also the Nsugbe, Nando, and Umuoba tribes. These groups pledged to cooperate in order to restore peace in the area.

Aguleri and Umuleri participated to a traditional oath-taking ceremony on 25 January 2000, which was facilitated by Igwe N. N. Kelly, leader of Anambra East council. This event, known as the �Declaration no more war� included peace talks that led to an agreement. This agreement committed the conflict parties to the mutual recognition of the communities and their borders and aims to guarantee peace.

In July 2005, Igwe Christopher Idigo, the leader of the Aguleri, informed Senator Joy Emodi that the Aguleri and Umuleri had begun peace meetings to resolve their border disputes. However, no agreement resulted from those meetings.

The Aguleri/Umuleri peace committee that had been set up in 2004 conducted a round of negotiations that led to the conclusion of an agreement in 2006. Chief Pius Okonkwo, the General President of the Union of Umuleri Cities mediated the agreement. The peace agreement concluded in 2006 broke down in 2010, when a group of dissidents from the Umuleri community took up arms again.

The negotiations mediated by Governor James Ibori one week later, in Asaba on 24 June 1999, were successful and led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement. The agreement was signed by Justice Franklin Atake for the Itsekiris, Chief Edwin Clark for the Ijaws, and Chief Benjamin Okumagba for the Urhobos. On 10 October 1999, representatives of young activists from the Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Urhubo communities announced the creation of a new association: the Warri Peace Vanguard. This association had the aim to help the communities to put an end to the conflict that has ravaged Warri for decades. Government, religious groups, traditional leaders and private agencies were present at the first meeting of the newly founded association. A six-point peace plan was formed that included supporting government peace programs, mobilizing community development, and promoting a peaceful way of life.

Following negotiations, the Ijaw and Itsekiri signed a peace agreement on 1 February 2000. The Delta State Government mediated this round of negotiations. On 17 March, Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Isoko leaders visited President Obasanjo in Abuja to announce the return of peace to Warri.

The Governor of Delta State eventually agreed to renegotiate the electoral boundaries during peace talks in Warri in the end of March 2003. These peace talks between the Ijaw and Itsekiri leaders and the Delta State government led to the signing of a ceasefire between the two communities on 26 March 2003.
Another ceasefire agreement was reached on 26 March 2003 between the Ijaw youth (FNDIC) and the Itsekiri in the presence of state officials.

On 7 April 2003, Obasanjo met with Urhobo, Itsekiri, and Ijaw leaders in Abuja along with the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC), and security chiefs to further talk about peaceful solutions in Warri. At this meeting, the warring tribes reached a ceasefire agreement. Following this meeting, Obasanjo set up a committee headed by General Theophilus Y. Danjuma, the former Minister of defense. This committee was tasked with investigating the Warri Crisis and propose ways to solve it. The report of this committee has not been made public.

On 15 May 2003, the national leader of Nigeria�s Ijaw ethnic communities reported that the youth of the Ijaw militia agreed to a ceasefire. In July 2003, Delta State governor, James Ibori, moved the seat of his government to Warri to personally undertake the peace talks.
On 20 July 2003, the Delta State Governor announced that leaders of the two tribes declared a ceasefire in Warri.

Concerned about a possible offensive by the Ijaw and Itsekiri youths, the Deputy Inspector General of Police in charge of Zone 5, Mr. Gazali Lawal, and the Delta State Police Commissioner, Mr. Jonathan Akaya, held peace meetings with the leaders of the two communities in the Police Zone Command Office in Warri on the night of 9 to 10 August 2003. The meeting culminated in a communiqu� signed by Mr. Justice Rewane for the Itsekiri, Chief Bare Etobor and Chief Tunde Smooth for the Ijaws, and by Akaya on behalf of the police. He urged the warring youth to support the government�s peace efforts. However, armed violence still erupted in spite of this effort and Nigerian authorities imposed a curfew on the town of Warri on 15 August 2003. Nigerian troops were deployed in Warri after some 100 people were killed between 15 and 20 August. In addition, the federal government deployed a joint security force in Delta State: �Operation Restore Hope�, which would be maintained in the following years.

On 20 August 2003, the leaders of the two ethnic groups met in Warri and signed a ceasefire mediated by Delta State governor, James Ibori. Chief Edwin Clark, the Ijaw leader, and Bob Mene-Afejeiku, the leader of the Itsekiri, announced, in separate interviews on 27 August 2003, that they agreed with Obasanjo�s proposal to end the crisis in Warri. This proposal involves separating political issues from criminal acts in order to facilitate the resolution of the conflict.

On 28 August 2003, James Ibori, Governor of Delta State, addressed the members of the Delta State Assembly in Asaba and proposed a peace plan for the Warri crisis. The plan calls for each of the three warring ethnic groups � the Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Urhobo � to have its own local government area. While Ijaw and Urhobo leaders endorsed it, Itsekiri referred to the plan of as �illegal� and �unconstitutional� and expressed their dissatisfaction with it.

On 19 September 2003, Nigerian President Obasanjo attended a meeting with Ijaw, Urhobo, and Itsekiri leaders in Warri in order to promote reconciliation. The meeting was chaired by the state administrator, Colonel David Dang, and the General Officer Commanding the 82nd Division of the Nigerian Army, Major General Felix Mojapero. The Ijaws and Urhobos deplored Itsekiri�s unjust domination of political power and supported Obori�s proposal to create local government areas. Itsekiri representatives once again rejected this proposal.

New clashes between conflict parties in the swamps surrounding the port of Warri began in January 2004. A 28-member peace committee, consisting of 14 Itsekiri and 14 Ijaws, met on 18 February 2004 in Warri. James Ibori and the Commissioner for Special Missions, Inter-Ethnic Relations, and Conflict Resolution, Ovuozorie Macaulay, acted as the mediators. The peace committee meeting led to approval of a six-point agreement aimed at peaceful coexistence between the rival groups. Among the main points were the establishment of a joint peace vanguard composed of members of both groups and an agreement that would allow people displaced by the conflict to return to their homes of origin without fear of attack.

On 1 June 2004, leaders of ethnic Ijaw and Itsekiri youth activist groups signed a ceasefire through the platform of the Warri Ijaw/Itsekiri Grassroots Peace Front (WIIGPF) moderated by Pastor Power Ziakede Aginighan.

Three weeks after the ceasefire concluded by the militias and after more than six months of peace negotiations, the Ijaw and the Istekiri leaders signed a peace agreement on 23 June 2004 at the senior officers mess, NNS Delta Navy base, in Warri. Delta State Commissioner for Inter-Ethnic Relation and Conflict Resolution, Comrade Ovuzuorie Macauley was chief mediator of the negotiations. On 6 July 2004, three Ijaws chiefs � Chief Wellington Okrika, Chief Jonathan Ari. and Mr. Clark Gbenewei � from the 14-member delegation to the 28-member peace committee set up in February 2004 withdrew from the agreement, saying they were no longer satisfied with it. Some Ijaws argued that the agreement failed to address some of the contentious issues that had pitted the other two ethnic groups against Itsekiris, in particular the issue of separate local government for each Warri community.

The ceasefires concluded in June 2004 led to a fragile peace. However, tensions in the Delta North remained. Between 18 and 19 June 2005, Ijaw, Itsekiri, and Urhobo traditional rulers launched a traditional leaders� forum in Ozoro. This forum was initially headed by Ijaw retired Brigadier General Cletus Emein, retired Senator Francis Okpozo, and Itsekiri Chief Isaac Jemide and had the goal to minimize the tensions between the ethnic groups. The meeting resulted in a covenant that recognizes the need to build the capacities of different communities. After renewed violence in the Delta region, President Obasanjo convened a stakeholders� meeting on 6 April 2006. The participants included Senator Fred Brume, Itsekiri leader Chief Isaac Jemide, gubernatorial aspirant Chief Kenneth Gbagi, national president of the Federated Niger Delta Ijaw Communities (FNDIC) Chief Bello Oboko, and leader of the Warri National Congress Mr. Collins Eselomo. The Stakeholders adopted a vote of confidence in the Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC) and called for an increase in its funding.

side_a: Abdalle subclan of Habar Awal clan (Isaaq)
side_b: Aidagalla subclan of Habar Garhadjis clan (Isaaq)
description: In October 1996, a broader peace conference took place in Hargeisa, aimed at bringing peace to Somaliland. This conference was mediated by the Peace Committee for Somaliland, which was a unified collection of Somaliland expatriates representing a broad constituency of clans and civil society. Both Aidagalla and Abdalle representatives attended the conference. This conference lasted until February 1997, bringing this fight to an end. The conference extended the Somaliland administration�s tenure for a further four years, as well as ratified a transitionary constitution and notably increased non-Issaq representation. The conference resulted in peace in Somaliland.
In spite of an absence of large-scale fighting between 2002 and 2004, the Runnirgod peace meeting attended by both conflict parties led to a peace agreement.

side_a: Ayr subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
side_b: Sa'ad subclan of Habar Gidir clan (Hawiye)
description: Peace talks at Hotel Shafi in South Mogadishu led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement on 19 July 2001, as well as a formal promise to collaborate over the use of the strategic junction of KM-7, which links the capital to the southern regions of Somalia. In practice, this meant that Ayr businessmen traveling through the zone would not be harmed. This peace agreement contributed to a reduction of violence in Mogadishu.

Negotiations at a bilateral peace meeting led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 1 February 1999. This peace meeting involved 10 delegates from each side. Beyond ending violence, the agreement stressed the importance of future dispute settlement via peaceful means, an exchange of prisoners, and ensuring free access to roads.

This paved the way for the start of a peace conference in Hargeisa in October 1996. This conference was mediated by the Peace Committee for Somaliland, which was a unified collection of Somaliland expatriates representing a broad constituency of clans and civil society. The peace conference in Hargeisa would last until February 1997. Locally executed, the conference agreed to a cessation of violence, as well as to Somalialand�s second interim constitution, broadening the political system from a clan based electoral representation to a multi-party democracy. Following these peace conferences, Somaliland has largely been conflict-free.
Another round of negotiations mediated by the ICU on 25 June 2000 led to the conclusion of a ceasefire, but this ceasefire broke down the next day.

In yet another mediation effort by the ICU on 29 June 2000, the two clans signed a peace agreement in Afgoi. The agreement stipulated that a monitoring committee with aid from an Italian NGO Coordinamento delle Organizzazioni per il Servizio (COSV) would oversee the implementation of the agreement. However, the agreement had already fallen apart by 5 July 2000. This committee was set up on 13 July 2000. ICU fighters subsequently intervened in the conflict to impose the ceasefire.

In mid-April 1994, the conflict between the Habar Gadir and Xawaalde was mediated by the United Nations Operation in Somalia (UNOSOM). This led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement that would take effect on 22 April 1994. On 3 May 1995, the Habar Gedir expressed interest in ending their conflict with the Xawaadle, but this did not lead to negotiations.
In April 1996, the clan leaders of the Habar Gidir and Xawaadle met in Beled Weyn and concluded an agreement to resolve the conflict between the Habar Gidir and Xawaadle.

On 10 September 2000, elders from both sides met for a peace meeting in the village Qurac Ceel Been. This conference lasted ten days and culminated in the two sides signing a peace agreement on 20 September. This comprehensive peace agreement included a clear separation of clan land, security of shared public routes, return of property, and a commitment to the death penalty for murderers.
On 8 November 2000, the two conflict parties agreed to a ceasefire in Jowhar.

The first effort to pacify the conflict in the Republic of Somaliland took place at a peace conference in Sheekh on 23 October 1992. Women and guurti had initiated this conference, with the latter serving as mediators. The conference resulted in an agreement on clan representation, increased government control over particular assets. On 25 November 1992, 150 elders and 30 militia leaders arrived in Sheekh to declare their commitment to peace in Somaliland.

In March 1992, Mohamed Sahnoun was appointed as the Special Representative on Somalia for the UN Secretary-General. Sahoun was mandated to work out a �plan whereby the United Nations could facilitate the cessation of hostilities between the Somali factions, promote reconciliation, and provide urgently needed humanitarian assistance.� By mid-October 1992, all major conflict parties agreed to a reconciliation conference. The Ethiopian President Meles Zinawi would act as the chief mediator of this conference that was scheduled to take place in Addis Ababa in January 1993. The UN Secretary-General would attend the conference as well. On 5 December 1992, the American-led Unified Task Force (UNITAF) was deployed in Mogadishu to create a secure environment for conducting humanitarian operations. However, the force was also used to move the conflict parties to the negotiation table. For instance, as soon as USC/SNA leader General Mohammed Farah Aideed made it clear that he would not participate in the Addis Ababa conference, the US attacked one of his camps in Mogadishu with 400 marines. Aideed subsequently agreed to come to Addis Ababa. From 4 to 15 January 1993, the UN � in collaboration with Ethiopia, the OAU, the Arab League, the OIC, and the US � convened a preparatory meeting for a conference of national reconciliation and unity in Addis Ababa between several Somali political movements. Both the SNF and the USC/SNA attended these negotiations. In addition to hosting the talks, Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi mediated the negotiations. In his opening speech, Boutros-Ghali emphasized that the UN peace enforcement mission deployed in December 1992 created a window of opportunity that would not remain open for long, stating that, �The world could forget about Somalia in a few minutes.� On 8 January 1993, the conflict parties declared a ceasefire that would take effect on 15 January 1993. The signatories also promised to end all hostile propaganda against each other. In the following days, the adversaries reached consensus on issues regarding the disarmament and monitoring of the ceasefire. Moreover, an ad hoc committee was created. It was agreed at the first meeting of this ad-hoc committee on 22 January that another reconciliation conference would be held in Addis Ababa in March 1993.
third_party: UNOSOM, Ethiopia, OAU, Arab League, OIC, US

description: A donor conference organized by the UN was held prior to the second conference in Addis Ababa, with the goal to collect funds for humanitarian assistance. In addition, the American-led UNITAF was conducting attacks on some of the conflict parties to enforce the ceasefire agreement. The second Addis Ababa conference led to the conclusion of the Addis Ababa Agreement, which was signed on 27 March 1993. The agreement stipulates a ceasefire. It also includes a provision which states that Somalia insurgent groups disarm through handing over their weapons to UNITAF/UNOSOM. The parties agreed to set up a Transitional National Council (TNC) for a period of two years, after which a political system was to emerge based on democratic governance, rule of law, decentralization of power, and the protection of human rights and individual liberties. The TNC would have legislative functions during the transition period and it would further establish an independent judiciary. It would be composed of representatives from all regions in Somalia, as well as the political factions that participated in the peace conference in Addis Ababa. Moreover, Central Administrative Departments, Regional Councils, and District Councils would be established. However, fighting between the conflict parties continued. In a mission to capture two of Mohammed Farah Aideed�s high-echelon lieutenants on 3 October, a battle ensued between forces of the United States and Somali militia fighters. This resulted in the death of 19 US soldiers and around 100 militia fighters. The US subsequently decided to withdraw its forces. In order to create sufficient order for the US to withdraw and limit political damage, US President Bill Clinton sent Ambassador Oakley back to Somalia.
third_party: UNOSOM, Ethiopia, OAU, Arab League, OIC, US

description: No armed clashes have taken place between the SNF and the USC/SNA from 1994 onwards. However, both parties participated in negotiations in 2002. A national reconciliation program in Eldoret on 27 October 2002 led to the signing of the Eldoret Declaration. The SNF and USC/SNA signed this declaration along with twenty other groups.
Following heavy clashes in Garbaharrey in 1999, the conflict was inactive in 2000. On 4 June 2001, the two sides signed a peace agreement following negotiations mediated by Kenya and Ethiopia.

In March 1992, Mohamed Sahnoun had been appointed as the Special Representative on Somalia for the UN Secretary-General. Sahoun was mandated to work out a �plan whereby the United Nations could facilitate the cessation of hostilities between the Somali factions, promote reconciliation, and provide urgently needed humanitarian assistance.� By mid-October 1992, all major conflict parties agreed to a reconciliation conference. The Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi would act as the chief mediator of this conference that was scheduled to take place in Addis Ababa in January 1993. The UN Secretary-General would attend the conference as well. On 5 December 1992, the American-led Unified Task Force (UNITAF) was deployed in Mogadishu to create a secure environment for conducting humanitarian operations. From 4 to 15 January 1993, the UN � in collaboration with Ethiopia, the OAU, the Arab League, the OIC, and the US � convened a preparatory meeting for a conference of national reconciliation and unity in Addis Ababa between several Somali political movements. Both the SPM and the SPM/SNA attended these negotiations. In addition to hosting the talks, Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi mediated the negotiations. In his opening speech, Boutros-Ghali emphasized that the UN peace enforcement mission deployed in December 1992 created a window of opportunity that would not remain open for long, stating that, �The world could forget about Somalia in a few minutes.� On 8 January 1993, the conflict parties declared a ceasefire that would take effect on 15 January 1993. The signatories also promised to end all hostile propaganda against each other. In the following days, the adversaries reached consensus on issues regarding the disarmament and monitoring of the ceasefire. Moreover, an ad hoc committee was created. It was agreed at the first meeting of this ad-hoc committee on 22 January that another reconciliation conference would be held in Addis Ababa in March.
third_party: UNOSOM, Ethiopia, OAU, Arab League, OIC, US

description: A donor conference organized by the UN was held prior to the second conference in Addis Ababa, with the goal to collect funds for humanitarian assistance. In addition, the American-led UNITAF was conducting attacks on some of the conflict parties to enforce the ceasefire agreement. On 22 February, two weeks before the second Addis Ababa Conference, the SPM led by Morgan was able to chase out the SPM/SNA led by Omar Jess from Kismayo. The second Addis Ababa conference led to the conclusion of the Addis Ababa Agreement, which was signed on 27 March 1993. The agreement stipulates a ceasefire. It also includes a provision which states that Somalia insurgent groups disarm through handing over their weapons to UNITAF/UNOSOM. The parties agreed to set up a Transitional National Council (TNC) for a period of two years, after which a political system was to emerge based on democratic governance, rule of law, decentralization of power, and the protection of human rights and individual liberties. The TNC would have legislative functions during the transition period and it would further establish an independent judiciary. It would be composed of representatives from all regions in Somalia, as well as the political factions that participated in the peace conference in Addis Ababa. Moreover, Central Administrative Departments, Regional Councils, and District Councils would be established. However, fighting between the conflict parties continued.
third_party: UNOSOM, Ethiopia, OAU, Arab League, OIC, US

description: On 30 May 1993, another round of negotiations between the SPM and the SPM/SNA began in Mogadishu. General Mohamed Abshir, the leader of the Somali Salvation Democratic Front (SSDF) leader, acted as the mediator at this second round of negotiations in Mogadishu, with support from UNOSOM. The negotiations led to a preliminary ceasefire 30 May led to the conclusion of the Declaration of Peace and Reconciliation on 3 June 1993. This agreement stipulated the complete cessation of hostilities in the Lower Juba Region, the reunification of the population of Jubaland in seven days, the reopening of the Juba region, the establishment of a working committee on the peace process, and the creation of an interim standing committee of elders to judicially resolve differences arising among parties in the region.

On 23 June, 152 representatives and 50 observers concluded a preliminary ceasefire and then began negotiations via four committees at Kismayo airport. The four committees focused on the conclusion of a ceasefire and disarmament, reopening of roads, the reunification of the people and communities, and the return of property. UNOSOM helped to facilitate these negotiations. These negotiations ended on 6 August with the signing of the Jubbaland Peace Agreement. This agreement stipulates a ceasefire, as well as stipulates the reactivation of trade, restoration of essential services, reestablishment of police and the judiciary, and deployment of UNOSOM forces in each of the 14 districts mentioned in the agreement.

Peace efforts to end fighting between the SPM and the SPM/SNA, facilitated by UNOSOM, in Kismayo took place in March 1994, resulting in the conclusion of a ceasefire on 27 March 1994. The conflict parties also agreed to organize a peace conference on 8 April 1994, but this conference was postponed to May.

The conference, referred to as the Lower Juba Reconciliation Conference, was held in Kismayo between 24 May and 19 June 1994, with support from UNOSOM. It resulted in the signing of a nine-point agreement, including a ceasefire to take effect in the region on 24 June 1994.

It was not until June 1999, with support from Ethiopian forces that RRA was able to take back the city. Rather than seek to punish those siding with SNA, the Rahanweyn community focused on reconciliation. As a product of the Somalia National Reconciliation Conference (SNRC) led by Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD), the USC/SNA and the RRA signed the Eldoret Agreement in December 2002.

Prior to these clashes, Mohamed Sahnoun had been appointed as the Special Representative on Somalia for the UN Secretary-General in March 1992. Sahoun was mandated to work out a �plan whereby the United Nations could facilitate the cessation of hostilities between the Somali factions, promote reconciliation, and provide urgently needed humanitarian assistance.� By mid-October 1992, all major conflict parties agreed to a reconciliation conference. The Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi would act as the chief mediator of this conference that was scheduled to take place in Addis Ababa in January 1993. The UN Secretary-General would attend the conference as well. On 5 December 1992, the American-led Unified Task Force (UNITAF) was deployed in Mogadishu to create a secure environment for conducting humanitarian operations. However, the force was also used to move the conflict parties to the negotiation table. For instance, as soon as USC/SNA leader General Mohammed Farah Aideed made it clear that he would not participate in the Addis Ababa conference, the US attacked one of his camps in Mogadishu with 400 marines. Aideed subsequently agreed to come to Addis Ababa. From 4 to 15 January 1993, the UN � in collaboration with Ethiopia, the OAU, the Arab League, the OIC, and the US � convened a preparatory meeting for a conference of national reconciliation and unity in Addis Ababa between several Somali political movements. Both the SSDF and the USC/SNA attended these negotiations. In addition to hosting the talks, Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi mediated the negotiations. In his opening speech, Boutros-Ghali emphasized that the UN peace enforcement mission deployed in December 1992 created a window of opportunity that would not remain open for long, stating that, �The world could forget about Somalia in a few minutes.� On 8 January 1993, the conflict parties declared a ceasefire that would take effect on 15 January 1993. The signatories also promised to end all hostile propaganda against each other. In the following days, the adversaries reached consensus on issues regarding the disarmament and monitoring of the ceasefire. Moreover, an ad hoc committee was created. It was agreed at the first meeting of this ad-hoc committee on 22 January that another reconciliation conference would be held in Addis Ababa in March.
third_party: UNOSOM, Ethiopia, OAU, Arab League, OIC, US

description: A donor conference organized by the UN was held prior to the second conference in Addis Ababa, with the goal to collect funds for humanitarian assistance. In addition, the American-led UNITAF was conducting attacks on some of the conflict parties to enforce the ceasefire agreement. The second Addis Ababa conference led to the conclusion of the Addis Ababa Agreement, which was signed on 27 March 1993. The agreement stipulates a ceasefire. It also includes a provision which states that Somalia insurgent groups disarm through handing over their weapons to UNITAF/UNOSOM. The parties agreed to set up a Transitional National Council (TNC) for a period of two years, after which a political system was to emerge based on democratic governance, rule of law, decentralization of power, and the protection of human rights and individual liberties. The TNC would have legislative functions during the transition period and it would further establish an independent judiciary. It would be composed of representatives from all regions in Somalia, as well as the political factions that participated in the peace conference in Addis Ababa. Moreover, Central Administrative Departments, Regional Councils, and District Councils would be established.
third_party: UNOSOM, Ethiopia, OAU, Arab League, OIC, US

description: Negotiations solely involving the SSDF and the USC/SNA, mediated by the UN, led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 16 April. In addition, the SSDF and the USC/SNA were involved in local peacemaking efforts without the presence of a third party.
