The International Committee in Support of the Transition in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (CIAT) gave an ultimatum to all militia groups in Ituri to voluntarily disarm by the end of March 2005 or face major consequences. In early April 2005, CIAT requested that the Government of the DRC launch both national and international arrest orders against leaders of militia groups in Ituri accused of crimes against humanity. Most militia chiefs subsequently stepped down from power or were arrested between March and April 2005.

Uganda tried to mediate, inviting the UPC to Kampala and offer them to put them in touch with RCD-K-ML leader Mbusa Nyamwisi. The Ugandans subsequently brought the UPC delegation to Kasese in early August 2008 to negotiate with an RCD-K-ML delegation, though Nyamwisi was not present at these negotiations. The talks end without resolution. When arriving for supposedly another round of negotiations in Uganda mediated by Museveni, the UPC delegation was deported to a prison in Kinshasa. Yet, on 22 August 2002, the UPC � now led by General Floribert Kisembo (who would later lead the Parti pour l�unit� et la sauvegarde de l�int�grit� du Congo (PUSIC) (English: Party for Unity and Safeguarding of the Integrity of Congo) together with Yves Khawa Panga Mandro) � took control over Bunia from RCD-K-ML, chasing Jean-Pierre Mulondo Lonpondo and his forces to Beni. The UPC subsequently formed a government in Bunia and temporarily managed to rule over most of Ituri. When the Human Rights Minister, Ntumba Luaba, visited Bunia in August, the UPC took him as a hostage and demanded the release of the prisoners that had been deported from Uganda to Kinsaha. These prisoners were subsequently brought to Bunia in September 2002.
The conflict parties engaged in bilateral negotiations in June 2001 that led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement.

In July 2005, the Turbi massacre took place and led to bloody fighting between the Borana and the Gabra in Moyale Sub-County. In response, the Arid Lands Resources Management Project in Moyale, ActionAid, Codep, and Oxfam collaborated in an effort to reconcile the communities. A first round of peace talks mediated by these third parties took place in Yabello in Ethiopia in December 2005.
third_party: World Bank, Action Aid, Codep, Oxfam

description: A second round of peace talks facilitated by the Arid Lands Resources Management Project in Moyale, ActionAid, Codep, and Oxfam took place in Moyale in Kenya from 15 to 18 January 2006. Around 150 leaders from the Borana, Gabra, and Rendille clans in the Marsabit and Moyale Districts attended the talks. A final round of peace talks aimed at signing a peace agreement was scheduled to be held in April 2006. This round of peace talks would be witnessed by Kenyan and Ethiopian members of parliament. However, the peace talks were cancelled because the plane carrying the members of parliament crashed.
third_party: World Bank, Action Aid, Codep, Oxfam

description: A cross-country peace conference was mediated by the Ethiopian government in the Yabello woreda from 11 to 18 July 2006. Government officials from the participating groups, regional NGOs, and diplomats from the United States and United Kingdom joined the forum. With over 300 pastoralist groups from 19 different countries in attendance, special attention was given to the conflicts involving the Borana, Gabra, and Guji. The special session was led by the Gada councils of the communities. By the end of the conference, the three groups signed a peace agreement.
On 4 December 2008, the groups clashed once again. The violence took one life and led to hundreds of cattle being stolen. In response, a cross-border dialogue was led by Ethiopian local authorities.

USAID mediated between community members of the Borana, Gari, Guji and Gabra people, residing in the bordering areas of Somali and Oromia regional states, in the context of the Negelle Peace Process that started in February 2009.

On 19 July 2009, leaders from the Borana and the Gabra convened in Maikona for a peace meeting. At this meeting, the two groups signed Maikona Declaration. The Kenya National Steering Committee (NSC) supported this peace effort.
Top clan leaders, regional government officials, and a peace committee signed a peace agreement in Yabello in December 2009.
In June 2011, the leaders of the conflict parties ratified the Negelle Peace Accords.
Another round of peace talk was held in Nairobi on 18 October. This round of talks was mediated by the Marsabit Interfaith Council and led to the conclusion of a peace agreement.

Leaders from the Borana and Gabra tribes took part in a peace conference in Eldoret on 15 July 2019. The peace talks were mediated by local authorities from Marsabit. The peace conference led to the signing of a peace agreement.

The Pokot and Samburu engaged in peace talks at Lake Naivasha Tourist Resort in October 2006, which resulted in the conclusion of a 26-point peace agreement. Dekha Ibrahim Abdi and Francis Mutuku Nguli, who were both mandated by the Kenyan government, acted as the mediators at these talks.

In addition, several peace caravans were organized by local leader in September 2010. Representatives of the Samburu, Turkana, Rendile, Borana, Gabra, Pokot, Somali, and Meru communities gathered for reconciliation talks during these peace caravans.

On 29 August 2006, 50 participants (religious, political as well as Pokot, Samburu and Turkana) convened for an ecumenical prayer meeting. The meeting was held in Samburu District and proved to be productive for peace talks. At the end, the attendees reached an 8-point peace plan that included provisions for future talks.

In addition, several peace caravans were organized by local leader in September 2010. Representatives of the Samburu, Turkana, Rendile, Borana, Gabra, Pokot, Somali, and Meru communities gathered for reconciliation talks during these peace caravans.

On 6 June 2015, fighters from the Turkana and the Samburu engaged in a gun battle in Attan in Isiolo County, which lasted for six hours despite intervention by police. To curb the violence, the government launched a disarmament campaign in cooperation with county leaders. From 19 to 21 June 2015, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) mediated peace talks between the Samburu and Turkana in Nanyuki at the Sportsman's Arms Hotel. The lead mediator of these peace talks was Francis Ole Kapar from the NCIC. The talks led to the signing of the Sportsman�s Arms Ceasefire and Peace Agreement on 21 June 2015 in Nanyuki.
agreement_name: Sportsman's Arms Ceasefire and Peace Agreement

description: The NCIC, together with Northern Rangeland Trust (NRT) and Finn Church Aid, mediated a two-day peace forum with government and community leaders at Lewa Downs in November 2015. This mediation effort led to the conclusion of the Lewa Down Peace Agreement. Both the Samburu and the Turkana signed the agreement.
third_party: government, local NGO, Finn Church Aid

description: During another round of negotiations in Loruko in December 2015, the Samburu and Turkana signed the Morans Peace Accord.

In November 2019, a 5-day peace caravan consisting of religious and traditional leaders, as well as local authorities, visited locations of violence between the Samburu and Turkana to promote reconciliation between the two groups.
third_party: religious leaders, traditional leaders, local government

description: In 1991, negotiations between the Ari and Mursi mediated by the Ethiopian government led to the conclusion of an agreement. The agreement stipulated that compensation had to be paid by the Mursi and stolen property had to be compensated or returned. In 1999, the killing of a Mursi again triggered retaliatory attacks by the Mursi on Ari settlements. The local authorities demanded that the Mursi responsible for the killing of between 30 and 30 Ari hand themselves over to the police. Until the Mursi that had participated in the fighting handed themselves over, the Mursi were not allowed to trade at the markets in Berka and Balamer. This led to protracted negotiations throughout the year.
In July 2011, a round of negotiations between district officials from the Dassanech and the Nyangatom, aimed at the return of stolen cattle, took place.

A round of peace talks was held between the Dassanech, Nyangatom, and Turkana in Arba-Minch on 6 October 2016. Government representatives and district leaders from Ethiopia and Kenya acted as mediators during the talks. The conflict parties reached the Arba-Minch Resolution at the end of the talks.

The Peace and Development Center (PCD) and Saint Peter�s Community Network (SAPCONE) started the East Karamoja Cross-border Conflict Mitigation project in March 2017 to promote peaceful coexistence between the Nyangatom, the Dassanech, and the Turkana tribes. The Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD)�s CEWARN supported this project financially. The implementation period started at the beginning of March 2017 and ended by the end of September 2017. The project was focused on the South-Omo-Turkana corridor of the Karamoja cluster. During the implementation period, several peace meetings, forums, and cross-border committees were organized. On 12 and 13 May 2017, PDC and SAPCONE organized an event to form and train Joint Cross-border Peace Committees at Todonyang police station in Kenya. This event gathered local peace committee representatives, influential leaders and community members, women, youth, and local government representatives of Kenya and Ethiopia. The aim was to train participants on how to mitigate conflict and to improve peacebuilding efforts to achieve peaceful co-existence between the Dassanetch, the Nyangatom, and the Turkana communities.

A joint cross-border peace caravan was organized from 15 to 17 July 2017 to enhance reconciliation, peace-building, and conflict resolution between the Dassanetch, the Nyangatom, and the Turkana. At this event at Omorate, 75 people from Turkana County and 75 people from South Omo Zone, as well as local government representatives from Kenya and Ethiopia participated.

On 22 February 2010, state authorities visited the conflict areas to mediate between the conflict parties. Armed clashes between the Gok Dinka and the Rek Dink continued after South Sudan gained independence in July 2011, with another outbreak of violence in November 2012. All armed violence between the Gok Dinka and the Rek Dink in South Sudan from July 2011 is listed under South Sudan. The Gok and Rek clans of the Dinka used to only engage in low-intensity clashes as a result of cattle raiding, but armed fighting between the groups escalated in February 2010 in the area around Bahr Gel village. Armed clashes between the Gok Dinka and the Rek Dink continued after South Sudan gained independence in July 2011, with another outbreak of violence in November 2012.
The conflict parties attended the Plateau State Peace Summit in early August 2002. Former Plateau State governor Dariye acted as the mediator at this summit. The negotiations led to an agreement.

Part of Alli�s Program was also a month-long peace conference that was inaugurated by President Obasanjo on 18 August 2004. This conference was mediated by a twelve-member steering committee and brought together government officials and traditional leaders to find compromises to bring peace to Plateau State. All indigenous ethnic groups from Plateau State (e.g., Afisare, Anaguta and Birom) were allowed to send two representatives each while �settlers� (i.e., Fulani and Hausa) were allowed only one representative each. It culminated in a report containing a number of resolutions. These included the resolution stating that �the Birom, Anaguta and Afisare ethnic nationalities are the owners of Jos.� However, the Hausa, unsatisfied with the conference report, refused to sign it.

On 23 June 2010, the Local Government Council brought together Birom and Fulani leaders for a peace meeting. This led to the signing of a peace agreement guaranteeing that both tribes forgive each other and take the path of peace. The Fulani group was represented by Alhaji Hashim Giroma, president of the Miyetti Allah Livestock Breeders Association and the secretary, Alhaji Yusuf Aliyu, while Da Gyang Mali, the chief of Gyel district, and his counterpart from Du district, Sir Augustine Pwakim, represented the Birom community.

On 24 September 2012, the Plateau State government and the Special Task Force (STF) mediated a peace conference between the Birom and Fulani at the conference hall of Gwol Motel in Barkin Ladi. Other communities � including the Barkin Ladi, Bogoro, Mangu, Kanke, Pankshin, Riyom, and Tafawa Balewa also participated in this peace conference. The conference was mediated by Governor Jonah Jang. The conference led to the conclusion of a peace agreement to end cattle rustling.
Bilateral negotiations between Birom and Fulani leaders led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in Jos on 5 May 2013.

After meeting separately with HD, each community drafted a road map for peace and established a steering community to represent its tribe at the Inter-Communal Dialogue meetings. The representatives signed a peace plan in Jos on 10 July 2013.

In February 2015, Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South South, and Yoruba representatives attended peace talks mediated by the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), local government authorities, and government forces. The talks led to the conclusion of an agreement on violence-free elections. The talks took place within the framework of the HD Jos Dialogue Forum.

HD mediated another round of talks between representatives of the Afisare, Anaguta, Birom, Fulani, Hausa, Igbo, South-South, and Yoruba communities in Jos on 13 July 2015. The talks led to a declaration of commitment to achieve peace.

On 27 April 2019, representatives of the Birom and Fulani of Jol and Mahanga from the Local Government Area of Riyom in Plateau State engaged in negotiations mediated by the Search for Common Ground. The conflict parties committed themselves to a ceasefire in a communique.

The two communities clashed for the first time in May 2001, but it was not until February 2005 that a peacemaking effort was conducted for the first time, when the United Nations Operation in C�te d�Ivoire (UNOCI) organized reconciliation meetings between the two groups. The French operation Licorne collaborated with UNOCI to establish security for a peace process. This effort failed to resolve the conflict.

Local administrators mediated a round of peace talks between the Garre and Degodia in Banisa on 23 June 2013. This round of talks led to the signing of a peace agreement to stop fighting and prevent future violence.

On 4 July 2013, a three-day peace conference was held in Mandera County. This conference was mediated by leaders from Northeastern Province communities and was attended by leaders of the Garre and Degodia. Kenyan president Uhuru Kenyatta was also involved in this peace conference. Kenyatta called for illegal arms to be collected in Mandera and Wajir counties. The conflict parties signed a peace agreement at the end of the conference.

On 16 and 17 February 2016, the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) facilitated the Mandera Peace Mediation Initiatives. This effort took place in Nairobi with local authorities and community representatives from Mandera and Wajir Counties in attendance. The Degodia and Garre agreed to a ceasefire, as well as committed to the Mandera Peacebuilding Programme that was designed to facilitate peace within the district, with special attention to the conflicts between the Degodia and Garre.

In 2020, the leaders of the Garre and Degodia clans pledged to end hostilities during peace talks, resulting in the signing of the Banissa Peace Declaration. The agreement led to an immediate cessation of hostilities and a reduction in criminal activities such as raids and property damage, resulting in much lower levels of internal displacement. The dialogue was facilitated by Interpeace and the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC). A Ceasefire Monitoring Committees (CMC) was created to support the implementation of the agreement.

In March 2020, a peace effort led to the signing of five intervillage pacts by members of the Garre and Degodia clans. The pacts focused on the sharing of water and grazing land. The process was facilitated by Interpeace and NCIC.

On 12 September 2022, elders from the Garre and Degodia communities revisited a two-year-old peace deal, after a three-day meeting under the leadership of Osman Raqiso. The agreement was aimed at resolve differences, foster a peaceful coexistence, and regulate financial compensation for past wrongs.

On 21 December 2022, ceasefire talks between the Garre and Degodia were held. Members of the Garre community gathered with the county governor, Mohamed Adan Khalif, Banisa MP, Kulow Maalim Hassan, and other Garre political leaders to discuss the recent clashes. The peace dialogue was facilitated by Interpeace, in coordination with officials from the Mandera county government, and with the support of the Federal Foreign Office of Germany.
In 2013, the Dodoth and Matheniko Karimojong, along with the Bokora, Jie, Pian and Pokot, signed the Nabilatuk Declaration following mediation by Ugandan government officials.

Negotiations in 2013 between the Dodoth, Matheniko Karimojong, Bokora, Jie, Pian, and Pokot led to the conclusion of the Mourititi Declaration. This agreement, among others, stipulated a set of provisions aimed at deterring cattle rustling.

Forces loyal to Abdullahi Yusuf clashed with forces loyal to Yussuf Hajji Nur on 6 August 2001. Fighting continued despite combined peace efforts by local business and clan leaders throughout August 2001. The Supreme Court organized a conference between 26 August and 14 November to select a successor to Abdullahi Yusuf. At this conference, clan elders selected Jama Ali Jama as President of Puntland. However, Abdullahi Yusuf managed to defeat the forces of Jama Ali Jama. As such, Abdullahi Yusuf remained in power throughout his second term as president of Puntland until October 2004. He subsequently became the became President of the Transitional Federal Government (TFG).

From 30 September to 1 October 2016, a round of peace talks was held in Geneva between the Muslim Council of Elders and the World Council of Churches (WCC). In a communique, the two parties affirmed their commitment to pursuing a peaceful relationship.
On 27 October 2017, the Coptic Christians and Muslims took part in a Bedouin Peace Reconciliation meeting in Al Kashery. However, the latter threatened the former into participation.

The Government of the CAR mediated negotiations between the conflict parties in October 2011, which led to the signing of a ceasefire on 8 October 2011.This ceasefire is referred to as the �Accord de Cessez-le-Feu Entre d�une part L�Union des Forces Democratiques pour le Rassemblement (UFDR) et d�autre part la Convention des Patriotes pour la Justice et la Paix (CPJP).� The ceasefire was signed by Zakaria Damane for the UFDR and Hissene Abdoulaye Ramadan for the UFDR. This ceasefire terminated the fighting.
The religious Hausa and Sayawa leaders in the region entered into peace talks, mediated by Bauchi State Governor Isa Yuguda in January 2011. These talks led to the conclusion of a peace agreement.

In addition, Senator Julius Ucha mediated between the conflict parties at his home on 12 May 2008. The fourteen Ezilo and Ezza leaders who participated in this peace meeting signed a peace agreement stipulating an immediate cessation of hostilities.

Another meeting between the tribe leaders, mediated by Senator Ucha and other state officials, took place at the council headquarters on 16 May 2008. This meeting led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. A traditional ceremony held at the local government headquarters in Ezillo in late 2008 was supposed to mark the end of the conflict. However, retaliatory attacks quickly resumed. The Governor of Ebonyi State, Martin Elechi, announced his strategy for ending the violence in the region on 2 October 2008, which, among others, entailed a plan to relocate the Ezza people to the lands of Egu Echara.

Governor Martin Elechi and the Police Commissioner Ammanual Dipo Yeni visited the conflict area in February 2010 to mediate between the conflict parties. This led to a ceasefire in late February 2010, after which the tribes began to surrender their arms to the local authorities. However, the ceasefire did not hold.

In April 2015, the Deputy Governor of Ebonyi shuttled between the conflict parties before bringing them together for peace talks. The peace meeting resulted in the issuing of a communiqu� guaranteeing that neither party would re-enter the buffer zone that had been set up in between the two communities.

Following a round of negotiations mediated by Ebonyi State governor David Umahi, Ezilo and Ezza leaders signed a peace agreement at the Abakaliki Township Statium on 5 September 2016 in the presence of the minister of Agriculture and Rural Development, Chief Audu Ogbeh, the Minister of health Prof. Issac Adewole, and the Deputy Governor Kelechi Igwe.

Following armed clashes between Tiv and Fulani in the Gwer West Local Government Area in Benue State, special adviser to the governor Titus Madugu mediated between the representatives of the Tiv and Fulani tribes on 16 February 2011. The two groups accepted to lay down their arms and find a way out of the crisis, but did not conclude a written agreement. The Benue State Government also established a peace committee in February 2011 tasked with examining the causes of the clash between the Fulani and Tiv and outlining a way out of the crisis. On 1 July 2011, the Benue and Nasarawa State governments set up together a further peace committee that had the task to find the cause of the conflict that happened at the border between the two states and achieve peace between the two groups.

On 18 March 2012, the Madakin Lafia, under the orders of the Emir of Lafia Alhaji Mustapha Agwai I summoned the leaders of Tiv and the Fulani � Barrister Gabriel Akaaka and Senator Jibrin respectively � to a peace meeting in Lafia. This meeting resulted in the signing of a peace agreement.

On 31 March 2014, Tiv and Agatu leaders signed a peace treaty with the leadership of the Miyetti Allah Cattle Breeders Association, representing Fulani herdsmen, promising to end the violence in the region. This agreement was mediated by the Deputy Inspector General of Police, Mr. Michael Zoukomo.

Tiv, Fulani, Jukun and Hausa leaders from Wukari, Ibi, Donga, and Takum enagaged in peace talks, mediated by Deputy Inspector General of Police Michael Zuokumor, in Jalingo in Taraba State on 5 April 2014. These peace talks led to the conclusion of a ceasefire agreement that appealed for peace between the four communities.

Representatives of the Jukun, Tiv and Fulani tribes of Bali Local Government Area signed another peace agreement during a peace meeting on 29 April 2014. However, the hostilities resumed in the beginning of May 2014 in that area.

On 30 April 2014, Jukun, Tiv, and Fulani leaders in Wukari Local Government Area held a peace meeting in response to armed clashes in Wukari on 15 April 2014. Taraba State Governor Alhaji Garba Umar and Wukari Paramount Chief Shekarau Angyu acted as mediators during this peace meeting. The meeting led to the signing of a peace agreement.

In June 2015, following recurrent clashes in the Logo Local Government Area, Chief Terkura Suswam, under the auspices of the state government, mediated between Tiv and Fulani leaders, which resulted in the signing of a peace agreement. Violence nevertheless continued in the region.

The Turan community in the Kwande Local Government Area in Benue State, which was mainly composed of Tiv people, engaged in peace talks with Fulani herders in March 2016. The talks were mediated by an ex-member of House of Representatives, retired Colonel Benjamin Aboho. The peace talks led to the signing of a peace agreement on 13 March 2016 in which both sides committed to a ceasefire and pledged to bring back peace in the area. The Tiv traditional ruler Zaki YAlu Agbo and the representative of the Fulani for the area, Yakubu Abubakar, signed the agreement. Furthermore, a 20-person committee was set up at the end of the meeting to monitor the peace process.

In June 2016, Fulani and Tiv representatives began to participate in an inter-community dialogue process mediated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue, along with several other community representatives from South Plateau. This led to the signing of the South Plateau Peace Declaration on 22 December 2016.

On 23 September 2017, the Nasarawa State governor Umaru Tanko Al-Makura represented by his Adviser retired Brigadier-General Muhammed Adeka mediated peace talks between Fulani and Tiv representatives in Lafia in Nasarawa State. Alhaji Haruna Usman, representing the Fulani community, and Peter Ahemba, president of the Tiv Development Association, agreed to a ceasefire on behalf of their respective communities during this peace meeting.

On 16 January 2018, Governor of Ekiti State Ayodele Fayose summoned the Fulani and Tiv leaders to a peace meeting to avoid a spiral of reprisal killings following the murder of a Fulani herder. The Fulani and Tiv leaders agreed to a communiqu� in which they called for peace between the two communities in the region.

Tiv and Fulani representatives held another peace meeting in Lafia on 25 April 2018, which led to the signing of a peace agreement between the two tribes. Nevertheless, violence resumed a few days later.

On 26 March 2020, a joint communique was issued by the chairs of ten communities involved in the mediation process facilitated by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) in Benue State. The communities included Agatu, Etulo, Fulani, Hausa, Idoma, Igbo, Igede, Jukun, Tiv, and Yoruba ethnic groups. The communique focused on upholding peaceful co-existence during and after the COVID-19 pandemic.

On 22 May 2022, the leaders of the Tiv and Fulani communities reached an agreement in Jalingo. The agreement aimed to halt the killings and create conditions for the displaced individuals to safely return to their homes.

The SPLM/A facilitated a peace meeting between the Misseriya and the Ngok Dinka in Malwal Agak on 12 April 2000, which led to the conclusion of an agreement that stipulates the right of carrying weapons, access to pasture, commerce, payment of tax, protection of citizens and property, and the establishment of a committee to resolve violations of the agreement peacefully.

A Dutch government delegation and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) organized a nine-day conference in Abu Nafisa in April 2001. This resulted in the conclusion of an agreement stipulating access to pasture, commerce, ending of rape, an end to the burning of villages by Misseriya, a committee to monitor peace, and an agreement on IDP resettlement.

A follow-up meeting was organized by the Dutch government and the UNDP, this time with the involvement of the Sudanese government, in Muglad in October 2001. This meeting led to the conclusion of the Abyei Peace Agreement, which condemned the conflict between the tribes, affirmed the co-existence of Dinka and Misseriya and the rights of each over water and pasture, supported the return and resettlement of the Dinka communities in Abyei Province. A joint committee was established to review the achievements of the peace process, and to deal with violations of the agreement.

The UNDP and the Sudanese government convened a peace meeting between the Misseriya and the Ngok Dinka, as well as the Twic Dinka, in Abyei in January 2002. This led to the signing of a peace agreement by 11 tribal leaders, who agreed to live together in peace, restore good relations that they inherited from their ancestors, cooperate in the rehabilitation and development of the region, stop hostilities, and reinstate justice.
The Dinka and Misseriya also signed a peace agreement in Aweil in 2008.

Finally, a resolution was adopted at the Bentiu Peace Conference Resolutions on 2 November 2010, referred to as the Decision and Recommendation of Peaceful Co-existence in Unity State. The resolution addresses issues between Misseriya and Dinka Ngok in Unity State, including the opening of roads, police escorts of tribes, restrictions on firearms of the cattle herder, and co-operation between tribes in regards to crime.
agreement_name: Decision and Recommendation of Peaceful Co-existence in Unity State

description: The UCDP reports that fighting broke out between the Misseriya and Ngok Dinka in January 2011. The violence between the conflict parties around this time was triggered by a referendum on whether Abyei would join the north or south and that was supposed to be held on 9 January 2011, but which was postponed due to a dispute over whether the Misseriya � who enter Abyei for a few months each year to graze cattle � should be given the right to vote. This also gave the conflict an international dimension, as Sudan�s ruling National Congress Party (NCP) demanded the Misseriya to be allowed to vote, while the Sudan People�s Liberation Movement which governs the south says that only the Dinka Ngok have the right to participate in the referendum. In response to the outbreak of violence, a reconciliation conference was held in Kadugli on 13 January 2011. The Deputy Governor of Southern Kordofan mediated between the leaders of the Misseriya and Ngok Dinka, with support from the Governor�s Adviser for the Western Sector and the Deputy Governor of Abyei Administration, the State Security Committee, and the United Nations Mission in Sudan (UNMIS). The conflict parties signed the Kadugli Conference Agreement at the end of the conference. This agreement calls for an end to the violence, but also calls for the establishment of security and awareness along the migration paths used by Misseriya herdsmen. The agreement also stresses the importance of the payment of blood money according to local custom.

The Federal Minister of Interior and the Minister of Interior of the Republic of Southern Sudan discussed the armed conflict between the Misseriya and Dinka Ngok in Abyei. UNMIS was also involved in these talks. The talks ended with the signing of the Agreement of the Minister of Interior on Security Arrangements in Abyei on 17 January 2011. This agreement stipulates the facilitation of the voluntary return of displaced people through protection by Joint Integrated Units of the north-south Sudan law enforcement and UNMIS. The agreement also stipulates the opening of corridors for cattle and includes provisions on the regulation of arms carried by Misseriya herdsmen. Heavy fighting resumed in March 2011. Haile Menkerios, the special representative for the UN secretary-general condemned the fighting, stating it was a clear violation of the letter and spirit of the peace agreement signed between the two sides in January.
agreement_name: Agreement of the Minister of Interior on Security Arrangements in Abyei

description: A round of negotiations mediated by the Abyei Joint Oversight Committee (AJOC), with support from the United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (UNISFA), led to the conclusion of a preliminary agreement between the Ngok Dinka and the Misseriya on 10 August 2012: the Abyei Joint Oversight Committee (AJOC) Pact on Core Principles for Peaceful Coexistence. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire, as well as stressed the importance of implementing �norms and practices of tolerance� agreed upon. A referendum proposed by the in the African Union in 2012 to decide the fate of Abyei stipulated that only those residing permanently in the area would be allowed to vote in the plebiscite, but the Sudanese government rejected the proposal. However, the Ngok Dinka went ahead with a unilateral referendum in October 2013. Unsurprisingly, an overwhelming majority voted in favor of joining South Sudan. Sudan rejected the results.
agreement_name: Abyei Joint Oversight Committee (AJOC) Pact on Core Principles for Peaceful Coexistence

description: UNISFA also facilitated an intercommunity traditional leaders� meeting at Todach on 4 August 2016, which resulted in an agreement that stipulated a ceasefire and peaceful coexistence, payment of compensation for past cases of criminality, and measures to end the insecurity surrounding the common market at Amiet by establishing a joint traditional court.

With intercommunal tensions running high and an armed clash on 22 July 2017, UNISFA convened separate meetings with Misseriya community leaders in Diffra and with Ngok Dinka community leaders in Dokura on 26 July 2017. Through those meetings, UNISFA was able to broker an agreement between leaders from the two communities when they met in Dokura on 27 July 2017. This agreement stipulates a cessation of hostilities and commits the parties to resolve existing problems by using traditional mechanisms.

However, on the day of this agreement, on 27 July 2017, some Ngok Dinka people stole 141 cows of the Misseriya and killed three herders. UNISFA subsequently mediated negotiations between the Ngok Dinka and the Misseriya representatives of the joint peace committee on 30 July, which led to an agreement that stipulated that the Ngok Dinka return the cows and paid blood money for the three casualties.

On 14 November 2017, the traditional chiefs of the Misseriya and Ngok Dinka communities met in Addis Ababa. The meeting had been called for during an Abyei Joint Oversight Committee meeting held in March 2015. UNISFA facilitated the travel of the Ngok Dinka traditional chiefs from Abyei to Juba to attend the meeting. The traditional leaders signed an agreement on the establishment of a fund to compensate victims of attacks and cattle rustling. They further underscored the need for joint access to the revenues of oil revenues from Abyei Area, in line with the Abyei Protocol to the Comprehensive Peace Agreement of 2005. The leaders also expressed their full support for maintaining the common market in Amiet.

UNISFA supported a pre-migration conference in Abyei in early March 2018. The conference was attended by more than 150 people from both the Ngok Dinka and Misseriya communities. The meeting led to the signing of a peace agreement on 5 March 2018, stipulating a ceasefire and peaceful coexistence of both groups. This agreement reportedly resulted in a decrease in violence and the annual migration of the nomadic Misseriya through Abyei proceeded mostly peacefully.

On 9 April 2020, the UN Interim Security Force for Abyei (UNISFA) facilitated another peace meeting between the Ngok Dinka and Misseriya traditional leaders at Diffra. While no written agreement was reached, both sides reiterated their commitment to peace.

On 11 February 2021, UNMISS in collaboration with the government hosted a peace and pre-migration conference between the nomadic people of Misseriya and Dinka community in Malual. The representatives who met in Aweil agreed on a series of resolutions and recommendations to promote peace and freedom of movement.

From 17 to 19 May 2022, the Joint Traditional Leaders� Peace Conference, organized by UNISFA, commenced with the participation of thirty leaders representing the Misseriya and Ngok Dinka communities from Abyei. This three-day conference in Entebbe, Uganda, aimed to foster dialogue between these communities, providing a platform to seek sustainable solutions for peaceful coexistence in the region.

The Dinka and Misseriya held a peace conference in Aweil in Northern Bahr el Ghazal state between 26 and 30 March 2023. The state�s Acting Peacebuilding Minister, William Anyuon Kuol, opened the conference. The peace conference was funded by UNMISS and UNDP. The participants discussed cross-border issues, including shared cross-border water and grazing access of Misseryia pastoralists from Sudan�s West Kordofan State and coordinating a response to inter-tribal crime. The conference made several decisions, including raising the compensation for blood-related issues from 31 to 41 cows, along with imposing a fine of SSP 200,000 or its equivalent in Sudanese Pounds. Additionally, if an individual is injured and suffers the loss of a body part, they will receive compensation of 15 cows, and the person responsible for the injury will be fined SSP 200,000 or the equivalent in Sudanese Pounds. The conference also decided to prohibit civilians from possessing firearms and military-related items such as uniforms, belts, boots, and caps.
The conflict parties held a peace meeting on 15 May 2001, which led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement. UN Special Representative Oluyemi Adeniji acted as a mediator during this peace meeting.

side_a: Black Axe, Bush Boys, Deebam, KK, NDV
description: The leaders of the NDV, the Greenlanders, Bush Boys, the Niger Delta Solidarity Front, the Outlaws, the KK, and the Black Axe � subsequently participated in peace talks mediated by the Kirike Bese Peace and Development Project and the Wakirike United Peace Guide in July 2007. Clara Ngelemabiri led the mediation team. The peace talks led to the signing of a peace agreement in Okrika aimed at restoring calm in the Niger Delta on 14 July 2007. All groups pledged to end the hostilities. The full name of this agreement is the Wakirike Peace Declaration 2007 between all the warring factions involved in Okrika crisis and mediated by the Kirikie-Be-Se Peace Development Project and the Wakirike United Peace Guide.

In June 2012, in an attempt to calm the violence, Governor Tanko Almakura mediated between the conflict parties in order to encourage them to stop the killings and resolve their differences peacefully. However, the conflict resumed in November 2012.

Negotiations involving the Eggon and Alago, but also some other tribe representatives of Nasarawa State as for example the Tiv, led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in Tudun Ababu in the Obi Local Government Area on 2 May 2014.

The leaders of the Greenlanders and the NDV � along with the leaders five other cult groups in Okrika, including the Bush Boys, the Niger Delta Solidarity Front, the Outlaws, the Klansmen, and the Black Axe � participated in peace talks mediated by the Kirike Bese Peace and Development Project and the Wakirike United Peace Guide in July 2007. Clara Ngelemabiri led the mediation team. The peace talks led to the signing of a peace agreement in Okrika aimed at restoring calm in the Niger Delta on 14 July 2007. All groups pledged to end the hostilities. The full name of this agreement is the Wakirike Peace Declaration 2007 between all the warring factions involved in Okrika crisis and mediated by the Kirikie-Be-Se Peace Development Project and the Wakirike United Peace Guide.

In July 2016, the conflict parties, along several other cult groups, participated in negotiations mediated by the Special Adviser to the Governor on Amnesty Programme Ken Chinda, the Special Adviser on Revenue Matters Harvey Ideozu, and members of the peace security and reconciliation committee in Ahoada. This led to a peace agreement aimed at ending violence in the Ahoada East Local Government Area in Rivers State on 25 July 2016. On 16 September 2016, as part of the ongoing efforts to restore peace in Port Harcourt and Rivers State, Governor Nyesom Wike established the seven-member Rivers State Amnesty Programme Committee. He promised that anyone who surrendered their weapons would not be prosecuted and would be rehabilitated in society. More than 20,000 sectarians and activists, including many Greenlanders and NDV members, subsequently accepted the amnesty and surrendered their weapons.

On 16 November 1992, the PFT, UTO, and the Government of Tajikistan met with the aim of preparing a compromise agreement which could be submitted for parliamentary approval. The parties failed to agree on the agenda.
On 26 November 1992, PFT, UTO, and the Government of Tajikistan declared a ceasefire and issued a pardon for ex-Communist rebels and their pro-Islamic rivals.

In response to the fighting, the National Transitional Council (NTC) formed a committee to resolve the fighting. Progress was made towards conflict resolution on 19 June 2012 when the �Committee of Libya Wisemen� met with leaders from the Zintan and Mashashia tribes, who subsequently signed a three-day ceasefire agreement.

On 18 May 2017, the Zintan and the Mashashia participated in a peace meeting that led to the signing of a reconciliation agreement regarding skirmishes in al-�Awiniyya, Zawiyya al-Baqul, and �Umur. A reconciliation council of various local tribes such as the Warfallah Tribe and al-Zuwayyah acted as the mediators during this peace meeting.

In January 2001, Governor of Bayelsa State Chief D.S.P. Alamieyeseigha and the Deputy-governor Lionel Jonathan set up the Nembe Peace and Reconciliation Committee. The committee consisted of twelve members, including representatives from the Nembe community, security agencies, the local government council, the Ijaw National Congress, and the Ijaw Youth Council. This committee aimed to promote reconciliation among the youth groups in the area and implement a new community constitution in Nembe State. Peace talks during a first meeting of the Nembe Peace and Reconciliation Committee resulted in the lifting of the ban on the Isongo-furo people returning to Ogbolomabiri.

Direct negotiations between the conflict parties (in January 2001) resulted in a three-point agreement, stipulating among others the establishment of a joint commission and mutual respect. Finally, the two leaders delivered a speech to the Nembe people at the town hall and ensured that they were committed to reconciliation and peace. Violence flared up again when the Isongo-furo that had fled returned in 2002 during local elections.
The faith-based NGO Hope for the Hopeless Global Initiatives mediated between the feuding youth groups and convinced them to lay down their arms and sign a peace agreement in late June 2005.

In response to an attempt by Saad Hariri�s government to challenge several of the Hezbollah�s privileges in May 2008, Hezbollah undertook an armed incursion into West Beirut. This, in turn, was followed almost immediately by armed violence in Tripoli. The Sunnis in Tripoli responded to the events in Beirut by taking revenge on Hezbollah�s Alawite ally in Jabal Mohsen. In a bid to calm the fighting, the Lebanese army deployed in Tripoli�s neighbourhoods on 11 May 2008. On 12 May 2008, representatives of the Future Movement (a Sunni party) and the Arab Democratic Party (an Alawite party) held talks mediated by Lebanese army officials. This led to the signing of a ceasefire and a lull in the battles.

On 22 June 2008, the grand mufti of North Lebanon mediated between the representatives of the feuding districts of Bab al-Tabbaneh and Jabal Mohsen. The negotiators agreed that their gunmen would stay off the streets and that the army could enforce security. Yet, clashes continued. Lebanese army and police troops entered Tripoli and patrolled the Alawite and Sunni districts to enforce the ceasefire on 23 June 2008.

On 9 July 2008, the mufti of Tripoli and northern Lebanon, Sheikh Malek al-Shaar, brokered a ceasefire between Tripolitan Alawite and Sunni representatives, allowing the deployment of the army in the two neighbourhoods.

On 25 July 2008, the mufti of Tripoli and northern Lebanon, Sheikh Malek al-Shaar, mediated a ceasefire between the two sides. It was made clear to the parties during the peace talks that the army would take action against anyone violating the truce. The Lebanese army subsequently deployed reinforcements in Bab al-Tabbaneh and Jabal Mohsen districts, but fighting erupted again only few hours later.
third_party: Mufti of Tripoli and Northern Lebanon

description: On 6 September 2008, Lebanese Sunni Muslim leader Saad Hariri met with Ali Eid, an Alawite leader and leader of the Arab Democratic Party (ADP). The mufti of Tripoli and northern Lebanon, Sheikh Malek al-Shaar, mediated the talks at his private house. The talks were aimed at paving the way for a reconciliation meeting between Sunni and Alawite fighters in Tripoli. At the end of the meeting, Hariri and Eid agreed to end all visible armed presence in Tripoli and to entrust security to the Lebanese army.
third_party: Mufti of Tripoli and Northern Lebanon

description: On 8 September 2008, the �Tripoli Document� was signed between the political representatives of the two communities. The meeting was held at the house of the mufti of Tripoli and northern Lebanon, Sheikh Malek al-Shaar, under the auspices of Prime Minister Fouad Siniora. Saad Hariri, the leader of the Future Movement, and Omar Karameh, the former Prime Minister, represented the Sunnis. ADP leader Ali Eid and his son Refaat represented the Alawite community. While the agreement provided for the withdrawal of armed men from the street, the deployment of Lebanese security forces, the return of displaced persons, compensation for material damage, and an economic development plan for the city, no implementation mechanism was put in place. Furthermore, militia fighters were not included in the negotiations and expressed resentment over the lack of consultation. As a result, the belligerents did not surrender their weapons following the agreement. The agreement however allowed the deployment of the army in the two adjacent neighbourhoods and the return of displaced persons. Although sporadic attacks between the two groups and against the army continued, the situation remained relatively calm in the following months.
third_party: Mufti of Tripoli and Northern Lebanon

description: The arrest of Sunni cleric Shadi al-Mawlawi reignited clashes between Alawites and Sunnis in Tripoli on 12 May 2012. The Lebanese army deployed in the Syria street demarcating the neighbourhoods of Bab al-Tabbaneh and Jabal Mohsen on 14 and 15 May 2012. On 15 May 2012, the two sides agreed on a ceasefire imposed by the Lebanese army.

Heavy fighting continued in the beginning of June 2012. On 3 June 2012, the Lebanese army intervened to stop the fighting and sent more troops to the area. On 20 August 2012, the Lebanese army enforced an end to fighting between Bab al-Tabbaneh Sunnis and Jabal Mohsen Alawites. Yet, clashes continued. Peace talks held on 22 August 2022 led to the signing of an agreement at the house of Deputy Mohammad Kabbara from the Future Movement. This agreement called for the army to redeploy units in the Syria street in Tripoli. The meeting also ended with the declaration of a unilateral ceasefire on the part of Bab al-Tabbaneh representatives. Despite the deal, casualties continued to be reported during the deployment of Lebanese government troops. Jabal Mohsen Alawite representatives reportedly also committed to the ceasefire agreement. However, clashes continued in the Tripolitan neighbourhoods.

On 23 October 2012, following two nights of fighting, the Lebanese army brokered a ceasefire between Tripoli Alawite and Sunni gunmen after talking to both parties. However, fighting already resumed the same evening. In December 2012, the Lebanese army sought to impose a security plan in Tripoli. It installed checkpoints in Jabal Mohsen and Bab al-Tabbaneh and expanded its deployment in the city. However, lacking a political mandate, the army neither seized weapons nor arrested fighters.

A new round of violence erupted on 19 May 2013. In response to calls for a ceasefire, peace talks were held in the Harba Mosque in Bab al-Tabbaneh on 22 May 2013. Members of parliament, religious leaders, and other community leaders were among the negotiators present at this meeting. No ceasefire was reached.

On 26 May 2013, two meetings were held in different mosques in Tripoli between leaders of armed groups in the neighbourhoods of Qibbeh, Al-Shaarani, and Mankoubin. Sunni leaders insisted on the departure of head of the Arab Democratic Party, Refaat Eid, from Jabal Mohsen as a precondition for a ceasefire. One of the meetings was headed by Sheikh Khalid Sayyid, who managed to broker a truce between the Alawites and the Sunnis. This truce was reportedly aimed at facilitating the deployment of the army in Bab al-Tabbaneh. A new Tripoli security plan was set up in early October 2013, following a meeting of top security officials chaired by interim Interior Minister Marwan Charbel. On 2 December 2013, the government authorized the army to take charge of security in Tripoli for six months, even though the army had so far been unable to quell the violence.

On 22 January 2014, a ceasefire was agreed during an emergency meeting at the Tripoli residence of interim Prime Minister Najib Mikati, gathering members of parliament, religious leaders, other community leaders, and army representatives. The meeting was also attended by the head of the Army Intelligence in the north. On 1 April 2014, the Lebanese government launched a new security plan for Tripoli. The army deployed in the city, dismantling militia barrages, replacing them with army checkpoints. This ended armed fighting.

On 23 April 1999, the three tribes reached a peace agreement in Bukavu that outlined new access to markets and herding land. Armed clashes between the Bafulero and the Banyamulenge erupted again in 2014, this time with the involvement of the Barundi. On 6 June 2014, the Bafulero on the one side and the Banyamulenge and the Barundi on the other side clashed around Mutarule. The Banyamulenge claimed that a Bafulero militia had attacked Banyamulenge herders � and in revenge Banyamulenge and Barundi youths attacked and killed over 33 Bafulero that had gathered to attend an outdoor church service.

After another bout of violence in September 2012, the Kenyan government sent 1,000 soldiers to stabilize the Tana River District and tried to organize another round of peace talks. However, neither community wished to participate in this mediation effort, preferring instead to engage in bilateral negotiations. In mid-September 2012, tribal elders from the Mijikenda signaled their intention to mediate between the Orma and Pokomo, but this did not lead to peace talks. On 4 October 2012, 40 elders from the Orma, Pokomo, and Wardei attended a three-day peace conference in Malindi. Several different third parties acted as mediators during the conference, including the Consortium for the Empowerment and Development of Marginalised Communities, the National Commission and Integration Commission (NCIC), National Muslim Leadership Forum, and the Council of Imams and Preachers of Kenya. Although no peace agreement was concluded during this round of talks, the conflict parties agreed that peace was a priority.

The NCIC initiated a mediation effort in September 2014. The NCIC worked with religious and community leaders, civil societies, the National Steering Committee on Peacebuilding and Conflict Management (NSC), and the Kenya Red Cross Society (KRCS). The mediation effort focused on mitigating violence in the towns of Amu, Faza, Hindi, and Witu. On 17 September 2014, community leaders signed The Boma Commitment on the Promotion of Peace and Cohesion in Lamu County. President Uhuru Kenyatta attended the signing ceremony. To follow-up with the implementation, peace committees were created in Hindi, Lamu, and Mpeketoni.
third_party: government, religious leaders, community leaders, Red Cross
agreement_name: Boma Commitment on the Promotion of Peace and Cohesion in Lamu County

description: From 7 to 9 September 2017, 140 community representatives � including village chiefs and religious leaders � from Bambara, Fulani and Dogon communities from the regions of Mopti and S�gou came together in the city of S�gou in order to promote reconciliation between communities in Central Mali. This peace initiative was complemented with several peace meetings between the different tribal communities organized at lower levels in the regions.
On 6 and 7 June 2018, MINUSMA provided logistical support for a mediation effort by a government delegation in Mopti. This led to a local ceasefire.

On 28 August 2018, following a mediation effort conducted by HD involving 34 Dogon and Fulani village chiefs from the Koro district that had begun in early June 2018, the conflict parties signed an intercommunal peace agreement to end violence in the Mopti region. The agreement stipulates a ceasefire, as well as stressed that all communities should have peaceful access to natural resources and calls for the use of traditional mediation mechanisms to prevent and manage disputes over land access. In order to link this agreement to the national-level peace process, HD tried to work together with the monitoring committee set up following the Bamako Agreement concluded in June 2015 � the Comit� de Suivi du present Accord (CSA) � to oversee the implementation of the peace agreement concluded between the Dogon and the Fulani, as well as the Bamako Agreement. However, the Bamako Agreement was rejected by the Dan Nan Ambassagou, which claimed that it had not been involved in the process. On 16 September, the militia group would agree to a unilateral ceasefire referred to as �Commitment to a unilateral ceasefire from Youssouf TOLOBA and his armed group, Dan Nan Ambassagou� in Mopti. The Fulani cultural association Tabital Pulaaku had denounced the Bamako Agreement because its leaders wanted to see Dana Nan Amassagou�s military leader, Youssouf Toloba, tried at the International Criminal Court (ICC). The HD effort to link the peace process between the Dogon and the Fulani to the national-level peace process failed.

In July 2018, MINUSMA started a reconciliation project in three villages in the Koro district of the Mopti region. The project was aimed at preventing further conflicts between the Dogon and Fulani communities.

A peacemaking effort by the Center for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), mandated by the Government of Mali, led to the issuing of a unilateral ceasefire in Mopti on 2 July 2018 by a Dogon militia, called the Dan Nan Ambassagou. As part of this unilateral ceasefire, the Dan Nan Ambassagou armed group also mandated HD to mediate the conflict between them and the Fulani community armed groups actors in the areas of Koro, Bankass, Douentza, and Bandiagara in central Mali.

On 2 October 2018, the Malian Prime Minister chaired inter-community talks between the Dan Nan Ambassagou and Fulani representatives. This led to the conclusion of another ceasefire. However, the Dan Nan Ambassagou leaders denounced this ceasefire in November 2018, arguing that they needed to take up arms again to protect Dogon tribe members after several were Dogon were killed by Malian armed forces.

The Ogossagou massacre of Fulani herders on 23 March 2019 sent shockwaves throughout the region and led to the resignation of the prime minister and his government. In response, the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) began to mediate peace talks between the Bozo, Dafi, Dogon, Fulani and Samoko in June 2019. This led to the signing of a peace agreement in Baye on 25 July 2019. The main commitments of the communities in this peace agreement were to urge their armed groups to cease violence, report any threats or attacks, strongly condemn future violence by their members, and help lift embargoes on villages and markets, facilitating the rapid return of displaced persons.

Local leaders and MINUSMA Civil Affairs mediated between the Fulani and Dogon in the the Bambara community in Macina, San, and Niono cercles in the Segou region and the Djenn� and Tenenkou cercles in the Mopti region. This led to the signing of peace agreement on 3 August 2019.

On 16 August 2019, MINUSMA Civil Affairs, supported by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue and the deputy mayor of Ouenkoro, Housseyni Sankar�, succeeded in mediating a peace agreement between the Dafing, Fulani and Dogon communities. The Agreement committed the parties to cease and prevent violence, aid the rapid return of displaced individuals, respect free movement of people and goods, ensure the return of lost herds to the authorities, help lift embargoes on Ouenkoro's villages and markets, oppose livestock theft irrespective of community ownership, promote peace among community leaders through cohesive messaging, and ensure the agreement's dissemination and ongoing communication regarding its implementation at the community level

Following a visit by the Malian Prime Minister, Dr. Boubou Ciss�, in early July 2019, local authorities initiated a mediation effort between Fulani and Dogon communities living in Sokoura and Tori in the Bankass cercle of the Mopti region. This mediation effort resulted in a round of peace talks in the chef-lieu of Sokoura commune on 18 September 2019. This round of negotiations was mediated by the Prefect of Bankass, with support from MINUSMA Civil Affairs. The peace talks led to the signing of a peace agreement.
MINUSMA and the Mayor of Youdiou mediated between between Dafing, Dogon, Fulani and Mossi communities on 24 November 2019. This led to a local peace agreement.

On 22 January 2021, a peace agreement between the Fulani and Dogon communities of Pel Maoud�, Dougout�n� 1, Dougout�n� 2, Koporo Kendi� Na, Koporo Pen, and Youdiou was signed after four months of mediation by HD.
agreement_name: Peace agreement between the Dogon & Peulh communities of Dougout�n� I, Dougout�n� II, Koporo Kendi� Na, Koporo Pen, Pel Maoud� and Youdiou

description: On 24 January 2021, a peace agreement between the Fulani and Dogon communities from Madougou and Barapir�li was signed after four months of mediation by HD.
agreement_name: Peace Agreement between the Dogon & Peulh communities of Madougou and Barapirely

description: On 7 February 2021, a peace agreement was concluded between the Dogon, Dafing, and Fulani communities in Mali. This accord pledges to uphold the physical safety and freedom of movement for individuals, goods, and livestock, and explicitly denounces the violence in the Bankass circle. The agreement was reached after an eight-month mediation effort conducted by HD.
agreement_name: Peace Agreement between Dogon, Dafing & Fulani communities in Diallassagou, Koulogon Hab�, Lessagou Hab�, S�gue, Soubala, Sokoura and Tori communes

description: In January 2021, HD mediated between the Fulani and Dogon communities in three different locations, each leading to the signing of a peace agreement. On 12 January 2021, the peace agreement between the Fulani and Dogon communities from Dagat�ne, Bondo, Diougani, and Koro was signed after four months of mediation by HD.
agreement_name: Peace Agreement between the Dogon & Peulh communities of Bondo, Dioungani, and Koro

description: On 26 February 2021, a peace agreement was reached between the Fulani and Dogon communities in Koro, Mali. The agreement followed a series of prior peace deals signed on 12, 22 and 24 January 2021, among various Fulani and Dogon communities in specific regions within Koro. The agreement was mediated by HD.

On 26 March 2021, a peace agreement was concluded between the Dogon, Bobo, Mossie, and Fulani communities residing in Timiniri and Bara Sara within Mali's Bandiagara circle, situated in the Bandiagara region. The agreement aimed to address and resolve a community conflict involving armed actors among these groups, fostering peace and reconciliation in the region. The agreement was mediated by HD.

On 10 July 2021, a peace agreement was concluded between the Fulani community from the municipalities of Ouenkoro, Sokoura, and Diallassagou in the Bankass circle, and the Bwa, Dafing, and Dogon communities from the municipalities of Timissa, Lanfiala, Koula, and Benena in the Tominian circle within Mali�s Mopti region. The agreement was facilitated by HD. On 18 September 2021, the municipality of Fangasso acceded to the peace agreement, joining the aforementioned communities in their commitment to peace and reconciliation.

On 30 June 2012, Iyad Ag Ghaly met with some of the CMA leadership, including Colonels Mechkenani, Ntala, and Salat, to discuss the conclusion of a ceasefire between the CMA on the one hand and MUJAO, AQIM, Signed-in-Blood Battalion, and Jama�atu Ahlis Sunna Lidda�awati wal-Jihad on the other hand. The CMA agreed in principle to a ceasefire but the Jihadist groups in the end refrained from delivering a written pledge to formally endorse a ceasefire.
Negotiations between MUJAO and CMA led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 17 November 2012.
Negotiations between the Habaniya and Salamat Baggara led to the conclusion of a peace agreement in 2009.

Large-scale fighting erupted again in April 2017, when tribesmen from the Habaniya and Salamat Baggara clashed over 150 stolen cows in En Nadeef area. The conflict between the two tribes escalated further in Buram locality between 8 and 10 May, resulting in more than 100 people killed or injured. Sudanese government forces separated the two tribes following these clashes. The two communities agreed a ceasefire at a peace meeting on 12 May 2017. A state-level mediation committee, as well as the Governor of South Darfur, community leaders, and UNAMID, mediated this meeting.
third_party: government, local government, community leaders, UNAMID

description: The same third parties (a state-level mediation committee, as well as the Governor of South Darfur, community leaders, and UNAMID) mediated a peace agreement on 29 May 2017.
third_party: government, local government, community leaders, UNAMID

description: In addition, the leaders of both tribes engaged in negotiations, with mediation by the same third parties, on 30 October 2017. This led to the signing of a peaceful coexistence agreement.
third_party: government, local government, community leaders, UNAMID

description: Both groups participated in the Interactive Peace Summit in Benin City on 12 and 13 October 2013, along with several other cult groups including the Green Circuit (Maphites), Norsemen (Vikings), Family Fraternity of Nigeria, and Avarian Organization of Nigeria. The summit focused on ending violence in Edo State. Several state officials were also present such as the Iyase (i.e., the traditional Prime Minister) of the Benin Kingdom, Chief Sam Igbe, and representatives of the Edo State police.

Both the Eiye and the Black Axe took part in the Ikorodu peace initiative in June 2017. Both sides promised to end fighting and stop all forms of criminality. In return, the Governor of Lagos State, Akinwunmi Ambode, granted them amnesty. Abdulazeez Sholebo was there to represent the Eyie brotherhood, while Seyi Ajasa led the Black Axe group.

Both groups participated in the Interactive Peace Summit in Benin City on 12 and 13 October 2013, along with several other cult groups including the Eyie, Norsemen (Vikings), Family Fraternity of Nigeria, and Avarian Organization of Nigeria. The summit focused on ending violence in Edo State. Several state officials were also present such as the Iyase (i.e., the traditional Prime Minister) of the Benin Kingdom, Chief Sam Igbe, and representatives of the Edo State police.

Another round of negotiations started in mid-December 2016, which led to the signing of a peace agreement on 23 December 2016. This agreement stipulated that the contested territory would be governed under shared institutions.

On 17 June 2017, representatives of the Khatumo administration and Somaliland signed a five-clause agreement that stipulated, among others, devolution and a quota system for political representation. However, the traditional leadership in Khatumo vocalized opposition to this agreement.
A follow-up agreement was signed in Hargeisa on 28 August 2017.

A peace conference in Ainaba between 20 and 22 October 2017 led to the signing of the Ainaba Agreement. This agreement stipulated a ceasefire, but also altered Somaliland�s constitution and stipulated the integration of the Khatumo administration�s army into that of Somaliland.

A 10-man commission � referred to as the Niki Tobi Judicial Inquiry Commission � led by Joshua Dariye was set up to investigate armed fighting in Jos in September 2001. This commission subsequently mediated between the Afisare, Anagura, Birom, Hausa, and Fulani at a peace conference in early September 2001. The Afisare, Anagura, and Birom agreed to the conclusion of a peace agreement, but the Hausa and the Fulani refused to sign a peace agreement.
The conflict parties attended the Plateau State Peace Summit in early August 2002. Former Plateau State governor Dariye acted as the mediator at this summit. The negotiations led to an agreement.

Part of Alli�s Program was also a month-long peace conference that was inaugurated by President Obasanjo on 18 August 2004. This conference was mediated by a twelve-member steering committee and brought together government officials and traditional leaders to find compromises to bring peace to Plateau State. All indigenous ethnic groups from Plateau State (e.g., Afisare, Anaguta and Birom) were allowed to send two representatives each while �settlers� (i.e., Fulani and Hausa) were allowed only one representative each. It culminated in a report containing a number of resolutions. These included the resolution stating that �the Birom, Anaguta and Afisare ethnic nationalities are the owners of Jos.� However, the Hausa, unsatisfied with the conference report, refused to sign it. On 7 March 2010, more than 200 Birom civilians were reportedly killed by Hausa and Fulani in Birom villages 10 kilometers south of Jos, in retaliation for previous attacks against Muslims and cattle rustling by Fulani herders. No mediation or negotiation process took place between the three groups after this event.

No longer able to control the Seleka fighters or violence in the Central African Republic in general, Michel Djotodia stepped down on 10 January 2014. This trigged even greater reprisal killings of Muslims conducted by Christians. The French military � which had begun an intervention in the Central African Republic in late 2013, dubbed Operation Sangaris � mediated between the Christian and Muslim communities in the PK5 and Bimbo 3 neighbourhoods in Bangui on 11 and 12 January 2014, which led to the conclusion of a ceasefire.

Intense communal violence between Christians and Muslims also took place in Boda, located 200 kilometer west of Bangui, after the ex-Seleka withdrew from this town when President Michel Djotodia resigned in early January 2014. Bilateral negotiations between Muslim and Christian leaders in Boda led to the conclusion of an agreement to end hostilities on 16 March 2014.

The Government of the Central African Republic facilitated a peace meeting aimed at reconciliation between Muslims and Christians in the PK5 neighbourhood in Bangui in early April 2014, but this did not lead to an agreement. In April 2014, the London-based NGO Conciliation Resources helped to set up the interfaith platform in Bangui, which was a forum where religious leaders in the Central African Republic could engage in dialogue to promote reconciliation between the Muslim and Christian communities. As part of this initiative, several local interfaith �peace committees� were set up. On 10 April 2014, the UN Security Council authorized the United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (MINUSCA).
Another peace meeting mediated by the government, this time with support from the UN, led to the singing of an agreement in PK5 on 17 May 2014.

The government of the Central African Republic, with the support from MINUSCA and various other partners working in the realm of social cohesion and development, mediated between the Muslim community of PK5 and the Christian community in Bimbo 3 between June and September 2015. As part of these negotiations, the UN developed a plan for a labor-intensive project, refereed toi as travail � haute intensit� de main d�oeuvre, in which members from both communities could participate to help reopen the cemetery. In August 2015, 200 youths, 100 from the Christian and 100 from the Muslim community, were mobilized and started working together to weed the grounds of the cemetery. Negotiations culminated into a planned signing ceremony of a non-aggression pact on 17 September 2015, but the conflict parties refused to sign last minute. Violence between the PK5 and Bimbo 3 communities resumed and Muslims were once again prevented from accessing the cemetery.
Negotiations mediated by MINUSCA between representatives of the Christian and Muslim communities in Batangafo led to the signing of the Batangafo Weapon Free Zone agreement on 12 December 2015.

Negotiations between representatives of the Christian and Muslim communities in Batangafo led to the signing of a non-aggression pact on 29 March 2016. These negotiations were mediated by deputy prefect, Ngozila Deo-Bafounga, with support from MINUSCA. The agreement committed both sides to allow for the free movement of people.

The Berberati field office of MINUSCA supported community-led initiatives in Carnot to help displaced Muslims return. On 8 May 2017, MINUSCA organized a workshop to resolve disputes between Christian occupants who resided in the houses of Muslim returnees.

In June 2017, MINUSCA mediated between the internally displaced Muslim community living in Kaga Bandoro and the Christian community of Ndenga. In addition, MINUSCA involved anti-Balaka representatives in the talks. MINUSCA�s mediation effort took place in the context of a high level of tensions between the Muslims and Christian communities in this area in the wake of an ex-Seleka attack on an internally displaced people camp in Kaga Bandoro on 12 October 2016, which resulted in at least 37 deaths. The mediation effort was successful and led to the signing of a non-agression pact on 10 June 2017: the Pacte de non agression et de la libre circulation dans la commune de Ndenga entre les habitats de la commune de Ndenga et les deplaces de Ndenga vivant a Kaga Bandoro.
agreement_name: Pacte de non agression et de la libre circulation dans la commune de Ndenga entre les habitats de la commune de ndenga et les deplaces de ndenga vivant a kaga bandoro

description: Intercommunity dialogue aimed at promoting social cohesion and reconciliation between Christians and Muslims took place in the Haut-Mbomou prefecture in February 2018. This peace effort was led by religious and community leaders and the deputy-mayor of Zemio, but was also supported by the MINUSCA Civil Affairs section in Obo. The peace effort led to the signing of the Pacte de non-agression et de r�conciliation entre les communaut�s in February 2018. This agreement stipulated the non-violent resolution of disputes, freedom of movement, prohibition of carrying weapons, and a commitment to counter false rumours and misinformation. The agreement was successful in mitigating violence between the two communities in spite of clashes between the anti-Balaka and the UPC in the area.
third_party: religious leaders, community leaders, local government, MINUSCA
agreement_name: Pacte de non-agression et de r�conciliation entre les communaut�s

description: A joint mediation of Cardinal Dieudonn� Nzapalainga and Imam Omar Kobine Layam, with support from MINUSCA, led to the signing of the Bangassou Peace Agreement on 9 April 2018. MINUSCA supported the mediation effort. This mediation effort was a response to an escalation of armed violence in the Bangassou area starting in May 2017. As a result of this increase in violence, the whole Muslim community in the area sought shelter at the Bangassou Cathedral. This agreement stipulates an end to violence, the freedom of movement for humanitarians and the general population, opening of the humanitarian corridor, and dismantlement of checkpoints in Bangassou and on the axes. A local peace council subsequently worked to implement the agreement. This local peace council had been set up by the local abbot, Father Alain-Blaise Bissialo, to resolve the numerous conflicts between Christians and Muslims in Bangassou town. The local peace council consisted of both Christian and Muslim notables.

In October 2018, the MINUSCA Civil Affairs section convened a workshop between Christian and Muslim communities in the Haut-Mbomou prefecture to follow up on the Pacte de non-agression et de r�conciliation entre les communaut�s which had been concluded in February 2018. The agreement of February 2018 had held, but tensions between the communities were increasing again as a result of fighting between the anti-Balaka and the UPC in the area. The workshop convened by Civil Affairs led to the signing of another agreement on 27 October 2018. This follow-up agreement confirmed the previous agreement and explicitly stated that the communities are committed to the agreement in spite of armed clashes between the anti-Balaka and the UPC.

Another peace process involving Muslim and Christian communities also started in October 2018. On 18 October 2018, MINUSCA facilitated an exchange of letters between the two Mayors of Pombolo and Gambo. These letters were in response to at least five large-scale clashes between the Muslim inhabitants of Gambo and Christian inhabitants of Pombolo towns since August 2017. These letters requested the start of a reconciliation process and suggested the organization of a round table discussion. Following this initial exchange of letters between the two mayors MINUSCA helped to create a peace committee in Gambo and another one in Pombolo, each consisting of 12 members. On 6 November 2018, MINUSCA and the Prefect of Mbomou facilitated an initial peace meeting between the two mayors in Pombolo. During this meeting the mayors agreed to move forward with the Peace Process and mandated the peace committees to find a solution to the conflict.

Peace talks between the Muslim inhabitants of Gambo and Christian inhabitants of Pombolo mediated by sub-prefect, with support from MINUSCA, continued in 2019. A peace and reconciliation agreement was signed on 20 March 2019.
On 13 June 2019, the agreement was extended to the village of Ngandou, which means the agreement covers the entire sub-prefecture.

On 24 May 2022, MINUSCA, the Local Peace and Reconciliation Committees (LPRC), and local authorities mediated between the Muslim and Christian communities in Obo. This led to the signing of the Agreement for Dialogue and Reconciliation for the Communities of Obo. The latter foresees peaceful coexistence and forgiveness of the violent events taking place in the Obo region in 2020. It encourages free movement and trade in Obo, with a particular note on respecting herders� rights and agricultural land plots. Included in the agreement is the return of displaced persons and the establishment of a follow up committee.
third_party: MIUSCA, Local Peace and Reconciliation Committees, Local Authorities
agreement_name: Agreement for Dialogue and Reconciliation for the Communities of Obo

description: Following armed clashes in a cattle camp 34 kilometers north-east of Rumbek in November 2012, the Minister of Local Government and Law Enforcement visited the area with Rumbek Central Commissioner Abraham Mayen Kuc to gather information and to mediate between the conflict parties near the cattle camp. The government of Lakes State�s also responded through deploying heavily armed police and military patrols to the area in and around the Luak-Makuer Gol cattle camp.
UNAMID, together with Meidob tribal leaders, conducted a mediation effort in Mellit on 21 August 2012. This led to signing of a ceasefire agreement.

Several cattle raids and a conflict over grazing areas triggered renewed conflict in the Mellit area in March 2015. This time, the Berti accused former Janjaweed leader Musa Hilal of supporting the Al-Zayadia and to instigate the armed conflict. Hilal and Osman Mohamed Youssef Kibir were political rivals. The use of heavy weapons in these clashes led to the death of 127 tribe members in 2015. The Zayadia, allegedly associated with paramilitary Border Guards and Central Reserve Police troops, continuously attacked the Berti in Mellit. UNAMID support traditional authorities in their peacemaking efforts. UNAMID was involved in seven meetings in March with key stakeholders both in Northern Darfur and Khartoum as part of efforts to reach a peaceful resolution of the conflict. The conflict parties subsequently signed a ceasefire on 24 March 2015, as well as agreed on forming a commission to investigate the recent clashes.

However, fighting resumed again already the next day. UNAMID was heavily involved in peacemaking throughout July 2015, engaging with community leaders, local authorities, influential tribal figures in Khartoum, the native administrations in Khartoum, and the Darfur Regional Authority. UNAMID also supported the Sudanese government�s mediation effort, which led to the conclusion of another ceasefire agreement on 13 July 2015, but fighting continued.

The Mayi Mayi consisted of many local armed group and several Mayi Mayi groups in North Kivu signed an agreement with the FLC on 21 March 2001. This agreement was endorsed by the Brigade Raisonneur Lafontaine of the Mayi Mayi, while the agreement also had the buy-in of Brigade Karisimbi represented by Kambale Maghulu, Brigade Rwenzori by Kiyungu, Brigade Vurondo by Kambale Tsongo, Brigade Rwenzori/Lubwe by Lakule Vulendi, and Brigade Mabanga by Sadamu Mindul. The Ugandan army, religious leaders, traditional chiefs, and civil society representatives witnessed the signing of the agreement. The agreement provided for an extension of the FLC�s area of control to cover North Kivu areas occupied by the Mayi-Mayi, where some Mayi Mayi groups had been fighting against the presence of the Ugandan army. In a letter dated on 23 March 2001 addressed to the UN Special Representative, Bemba spoke of an agreement that Mayi Mayi groups in North Kivu had allied themselves to FLC and would be forming a �Division speciale Mayi-Mayi� within the military forces of FLC. The March agreement also pointed out that, since it was difficult to know who was genuinely Mayi Mayi because the militia has a loose structure, it was a collective responsibility of all signatories to help make clear who committed to the newly concluded agreement. However, the agreement did not hold. However, on 25 April 2001, FLC clashed with Mayi Mayi warriors in Butembo. In June 2001, the FLC alliance broke down.

On 27 May 2012, the leaders of both sides tried to reconcile their differences through bilateral negotiations. This led to the conclusion of an agreement in late May 2012. Both groups agreed to merge and create the independent Islamic state of Azawad. CMA spokesman Moussa ag Assarid said the alliance marked a compromise. The conflict parties agreed to an Islamic state but one developed by their own imams and suited to local religious practices. However, the agreement broke down almost immediately and Ansar Dine turned again to their Islamist allies. In the summer of 2012, Ansar Dine allied with al-Qaida al-Jihad fi Bilad al-Maghrib al-Islami (AQIM) (English: al-Qaida Organisation in the Islamic Maghreb) against the CMA and captured the regional capitals of Kidal, Timbuktu, and Gao, destroying many Sufi shrines and enforcing sharia law.
