The conflict parties initiated negotiations in late August, which led to the signing of a peace agreement on 7 September 2015.

On 3 March 2016. Sudanese government soldiers and police forcefully disarmed members of the Salamat and Fulani in Tullus and Buram localities. This led to the detaining of 84 members of both tribes. On 16 May 2016, the conflict parties held a reconciliation conference supported by UNAMID. The violations of the September 2015 peace agreement were discussed, and the parties signed a new reconciliation agreement committed to disarmament and financial compensation for those killed.

Following clashes between Rezeigat and Massalit over access to land in the Graida area on 20 and 27 November, local authorities deployed security personnel and started to mediate between the conflcit parties. This mediation effort led a peace agreement on 11 December 2015.

The conflict parties held a reconciliation conference in Bielel on 10 December 2016, where they did not sign an agreement, but agreed that all Rizeigat herders would leave the locality until the end of the farming season in mid-January 2017.

District and tribal officials from the Nyangatom and the Hamar held a week-long peace conference Kangaten in July 2007. The conflict parties reached an agreement to cease hostilities over grazing land and water.

In April 2015, a mediation effort was initiated by local chiefs, a county commissioner, and the governor�s peace adviser. UNMISS Civil Affairs provided logistical support by shuttling community leaders from both sides to meetings for discussing their issues. The two communities then appointed representatives who met at a roundtable organized by the NGO ACTED and UNMISS Civil Affairs to find solutions to the underlying problems of resource sharing and road access. The negotiations resulted in the conclusion of a ceasefire, which was celebrated through a series of ceremonial intermarriages between the two clans.
A reconciliation committee with representatives from both communities was set up in January 2018 in response to heavy clashes in December 2017, but this mediation effort did not lead to an agreement.

UNMISS and Oxfam facilitated a peace meeting in Malek County, near Rumbek, on 31 December 2018. This meeting led to conclusion of a peace agreement, which stipulated a ceasefire to end the intercommunal violence, cattle raids, and deadly revenge attacks. It was also agreed that both sides would return stolen cows and promote intercommunal interaction.

While the CMA and Platform were not engaged in direct negotiations during most of the Algiers process, this changed during the final phase of the process. The Government of Mali, the CMA, and Platform entered negotiations in Algiers on 30 May 2015. They signed the Relev� de Conclusions des Consultations Pr�paratoires � la mise en �uvre de l�Accord pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali Issu du Procesus d�Alger (English: Statement of Conclusions of the Preparatory Consultations for the Implementation of the Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation in Mali Arising from the Algiers Process) on 5 June 2015, which addressed stipulated the creation of two regions in Mali, the integration of rebel fighters into the national army, and several arrangements to promote regional economic development. On the same day, the conflict parties also signed another ceasefire agreement, the Arrangement s�curitaire pour une cessation des hostilit�s (English: Security Arrangements for a Cessation of Hostilities).

description: This paved the way for the Government of Mali, the CMA, and Platform signing a comprehensive peace agreement in Bamako on 20 June 2015: the Accord Pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali - Issu du Processus d�Alger (English: Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation in Mali - Resulting from the Algiers Process), also referred to as the Bamako Agreement.

description: Another round of negotiations between the members of the monitoring committee � the Comit� du Suivi du present Accord (CSA) � was held in late July 2015 to discuss the implementation process, but the members of the committee disagreed on certain stipulations of the implementation process, such as representation and responsibility sharing. The CSA comprises the Government of Mali, the CMA, Platform, as well as the mediation team chaired by Algeria and further including Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the United Nations, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, the African Union, and the European Union.

description: A monitoring committee � the Comit� de Suivi du present Accord (CSA) � to oversee the implementation of the agreement was set up under the terms of the Bamako Agreement. The CSA comprises the Government of Mali, the CMA, Platform, as well as the mediation team chaired by Algeria and further including Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the United Nations, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, the African Union, and the European Union. The CSA met for negotiations on the implementation in Bamako between 3 and 5 July 2015. The UN Secretary General�s Special Representative convened this meeting. Under his auspices, the parties concluded another ceasefire and promised to end all incursions into the areas under the other party�s control. The parties also agreed to initiate dialogue in An�fis, with a goal of solving the long-standing intercommunal and intra-communal tensions at the root of the conflict between them.
third_party: Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU

description: The UN Secretary-General�s Special Representative mediated a round of negotiations that led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 23 September 2015.

On 27 and 28 September 2015, a CMA delegation held meetings with President Ibrahim Boubacar Ke�ta and the leaders of the Platform in Bamako. Following the meetings, CMA announced that it would stick to the ceasefire and order its combatants to refrain from using force against the troops of the Government forces and Platform.

Between 27 September and 14 October 2015, CMA and the Platform engaged in direct talks in An�fis. At the end of the talks, the parties endorsed a road map � the Anefis road map � comprising a series of measures, including the cessation of hostilities, joint initiatives for intercommunal and intra-communal reconciliation, the exchange of prisoners, the establishment of interim local administrations and the free movement of people and goods. During and following the An�fis talks, CMA and the Platform mediated a series of intercommunal and intra-communal reconciliation agreements in Gao, Kidal and Timbuktu regions, including between the Ifoghas and Imghad Tuareg communities affiliated with CMA and the Platform, respectively.

The CSA�s efforts to implement the Bamako Peace Agreement continued in 2016. The CMA and Platform were both unhappy with the slow pace of the implementation of the agreement. Hence, the signatories met in Bamako on 19-26 February 2016, but no progress was made. While the Government of Mali presented the measures that it had taken, including the creation of the M�naka and Taoudenni regions and the review of the Code des collectivit�s territoriales, the signatory armed groups, in a joint letter, deplored the lack of progress on the establishment of the interim administrations, reiterating the need for further efforts on institutional issues before moving forward on security and defense aspects.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Another meeting to discuss the implementation of the Bamako Agreement was held in New York on 23 September 2016, on the margins of the general debate of the seventy-first session of the UN General Assembly. The opening session of the meeting was chaired by the UN Secretary-General together with the President of Mali, Ibrahim Boubacar Keita. The goal of the meeting was to mitigate the tensions that had arisen surrounding the implementation of the Bamako Agreement between July and September 2016. Following the opening session, a meeting was co-chaired by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, International Cooperation and African Integration of Mali, Abdoulaye Diop, and the Minister of State, Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation of Algeria, Ramtane Lamamra, together with the UN Under-Secretary-General for Peacekeeping Operations. In the Co-Chairs� summary of the meeting, the signatories of the Bamako Agreement were urged to fully and sincerely maintain their commitments under the agreement and encouraged to take specific steps to swiftly implement the agreement.

Another meeting on the implementation of the agreement took place on 23 October 2016. During this meeting it was decided to start the implementation of the agreement in November 2016, but this did not happen.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Another CSA meeting on the implementation of the agreement took place on 28 November 2016.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: At another CSA meeting on 20 December 2016, the CMA representatives announced the suspension of its participation in the CSA because of a lack of progress in the implementation of the Bamako Agreement. On 16 January 2017, MINUSMA mediated between government representatives and CMA leaders in Kidal to discuss a return of the CMA to the CSA, but Platform representatives did not participate in this meeting. Following a deadly terrorist attack in Gao on 18 January 2017 � which killed 54 members of a mixed patrol including forces from the government, Platform, and the CMA � the mediators tried to prevent a collapse of the peace process. An international mediation team, including ministers from the Governments of Algeria, Mauritania, and the Niger continued to urge CMA to continue its participation in the CSA. While a CSA meeting was held on 30 January 2017 in Bamako, without the presence of CMA, the CMA remained involved in trying to set up mixed patrols in Gao. On 23 February 2017, the signatory parties launched the first mixed patrols in Gao.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: In the context of the stalling implementation process following the Bamako Agreement concluded in 2015, the violence between the CMA and GATIA intensified in early 2016, with both groups competing for territorial control, particularly in the Kidal area. On 2 February 2016, GATIA and CMA concluded an agreement, without the involvement of any third party. The agreement stipulated that both parties would jointly control the city of Kidal. However, CMA and GATIA continued to clash sporadically after the Kidal power-sharing deal was in place. On 6 June 2016, Platform publicly stated that it considered the February power-sharing agreement on Kidal to have led to an inequitable division of power in Kidal between CMA and the Platform. The CMA reacted by stating that CMA remained in charge of the management of the town.

On 14 July 2016, representatives of the CMA and GATIA held discussions in Niamey, at the invitation of the Government of the Niger, to address outstanding political and security issues between them. On 17 July 2016, an agreement was reached by the two groups on the joint management of Kidal and other measures to reduce tensions. Nevertheless, heavy fighting erupted in Kidal two days later, resulting in GATIA being pushed out of the town.

Heavy fighting continued in August 2016. Talks aimed at cessation of hostilities initiated in mid-August by the Government of Niger ended without reaching agreement and talks broke down in September 2016.
On 23 August 2017, MINUSMA mediated between the CMA and Platform, which led to the conclusion of a 15-day ceasefire in Kidal. The ceasefire was extended on 6 September 2017.

Another round of negotiations mediated by MINUSMA led to the signing of a definitive ceasefire by the conflict parties in Bamako on 21 September 2017. The ceasefire stipulated an immediate halt to hostilities, the release of prisoners, and the return of the CMA-controlled base in Takalot to Platform.

On 10 October 2017, CMA and GATIA signed yet another agreement that was mediated by MINUSMA, referred to as Anefis II. This agreement specified local security arrangements to keep peace in Kidal region.

On 16 January 2018, a CSA meeting, which was also attended by the CMA, led to the endorsement of a timeline to accelerate the implementation of key provisions of the Bamako Agreement. By September 2018, signatory parties made some progress in the implementation of the agreement, including the nomination of interim authorities at the district level, the creation of municipalities for the M�naka and Taoudenni regions, and the adoption of the national security sector reform strategy.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: In June 2018, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 2423, calling for the signing of a �Pact for Peace� by the Malian parties. At a meeting in October 2018, the Malians parties signed this Pact for Peace, emphasizing the urgency of taking steps to �accelerate the full and inclusive implementation� of the agreement.

In June 2018, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 2423, calling for the signing of a �Pact for Peace� by the Malian parties. At a meeting in October 2018, the Malians parties signed this Pact for Peace, emphasizing the urgency of taking steps to �accelerate the full and inclusive implementation� of the agreement.

On 22 August 2019, the signatories to the 2015 peace agreement held a working session in Bamako. This meeting was chaired by the Minister of Social Cohesion, with support from the Carter Center, to examine in detail the progress made with regard to implementing the peace agreement.

On 22 August 2019, the signatories to the 2015 peace agreement held a working session in Bamako. This meeting was chaired by the Minister of Social Cohesion, with support from the Carter Center, to examine in detail the progress made with regard to implementing the peace agreement.

A political crisis and the COVID-19 pandemic brought the implementation of the 2015 peace agreement to a standstill. The CSA held its first-ever meetings outside of Bamako, namely in Kidal, in February 2021.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Another CSA meeting was held in Kayes in March 2021. However, shortly after this meeting, two specific events further stymied the implementation process during the first half of 2021. First, on 13 April 2021, CMA leader Sidi Brahim Ould Sidat was assassinated. Second, a second coup d��tat took place on 24 May 2021.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: At another meeting between the CMA and Platform in Rome on 6 May 2021, the leaders of the two groups signed the Rome Declaration, confirming the creation of the CSP.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, Chad, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: According to the Carter Center, which acted as the official observer of the implementation process of the Agreement on Peace and Reconciliation in Mali concluded in 2015, the implementation had reached a state of unprecedented impasse in its seventh year. The CSA met in October 2021, but this meeting ended when intense disagreements broke out among the signatories. After this meeting, the work of the CSA and its various subgroups was suspended.

description: The signatories to the 2015 peace agreement held a working session in Bamako on 16-17 February 2022. On 16 March 2022, the signatories to the Algiers Accord met in Gao to address their ongoing disagreements, particularly regarding the creation and mission of the Cadre strat�gique permanent (CSP) (English: Permanent strategic coalition), which was formed by the CMA and Platform to strengthen the relations between them, but was also envisioned as a key security provider in the northern regions. The Government of Mali insisted that security matters should remain under the state�s authority and that any concerns raised by the movements should be resolved within the framework of the peace agreement. However, there was no concrete resolution reached.

Although the CSA did no longer meet, the Technical Security Commission (CTS) � tasked with monitoring the ceasefire, investigating potential violations, and monitoring security arrangements � met on 31 March 2022.

The CMA entered into a peace process with the Government of Mali in mid-2014. This peace process, which would become known as the Algiers peace process, was supported by a mediation team led by Algeria, including the UN, ECOWAS, the AU, the OIC, the EU, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Niger, and Chad. The first round of official negotiations in the Algiers peace process took place from 14 to 24 July 2014 in Algiers. The Platform alliance � of which the CM-FPR, GATIA, MAA were members � took also part in the Algiers peace process, but the CMA and Platform refused to sit at the same table of negotiation and talks took place on parallel tracks between the government and the CMA on the one side, and the government and the Platform on the other. The CMA refused to negotiate with the Platform because it saw the alliance as a �government militia,� thereby challenging its legitimacy as a full stakeholder in the process. However, CMA and the Platform alliance met in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, from 25 to 28 August 2014. These talks were mediated by Burkina Faso, whose president was the ECOWAS mediator in the Malian crisis, with support from the UN and the AU. This round of negotiations took place in between the first round of the Algiers process in July 2014 and the second round of negotiations that was planned to be held in Algiers in September 2014. After four days of discussions, the talks in Ouagadougou led to the D�claration finale on 28 August 2014. This peace agreement stipulates a ceasefire, but also describes how the CMA and Platform position themselves in talks with the Government of Mali.

While the CMA and Platform were not engaged in direct negotiations during most of the Algiers process, this changed during the final phase of the process. The Government of Mali, the CMA, and Platform entered negotiations in Algiers on 30 May 2015. They signed the Relev� de Conclusions des Consultations Pr�paratoires � la mise en �uvre de l�Accord pour la Paix et la Reconciliation au Mali Issu du Procesus d�Alger (English: Statement of Conclusions of the Preparatory Consultations for the Implementation of the Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation in Mali Arising from the Algiers Process) on 5 June 2015, which addressed the creation of two regions in Mali, the integration of rebel fighters into the national army, and several arrangements to promote regional economic development. On the same day, the conflict parties also signed another ceasefire agreement, the Arrangement s�curitaire pour une cessation des hostilit�s (English: Security Arrangements for a Cessation of Hostilities).

An international mediation team, including ministers from the Governments of Algeria, Mauritania, and the Niger continued to urge CMA to continue its participation in the CSA. While a CSA meeting was held on 30 January 2017 in Bamako without the presence of CMA, the CMA remained involved in trying to set up mixed patrols in Gao. On 23 February 2017, the signatory parties launched the first mixed patrols in Gao.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: On 23 August 2017, MINUSMA mediated between the CMA and Platform, which led to the conclusion of a 15-day ceasefire in Kidal. The ceasefire was extended on 6 September 2017.

On 16 January 2018, a CSA meeting, which was also attended by the CMA, led to the endorsement of a timeline to accelerate the implementation of key provisions of the Bamako Agreement. By September 2018, signatory parties made some progress in the implementation of the agreement, including the nomination of interim authorities at the district level, the creation of municipalities for the M�naka and Taoudenni regions, and the adoption of the national security sector reform strategy.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: In June 2018, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 2423, calling for the signing of a �Pact for Peace� by the Malian parties. At a meeting in October 2018, the Malians parties signed this Pact for Peace, emphasizing the urgency of taking steps to �accelerate the full and inclusive implementation� of the agreement.

On 22 August 2019, the signatories to the 2015 peace agreement held a working session in Bamako. This meeting was chaired by the Minister of Social Cohesion, with support from the Carter Center, to examine in detail the progress made with regard to implementing the peace agreement.

A political crisis and the COVID-19 pandemic brought the implementation of the 2015 peace agreement to a standstill. The CSA held its first-ever meetings outside of Bamako, namely in Kidal, in February 2021.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Another CSA meeting was held in Kayes in March 2021. However, shortly after this meeting, two specific events further stymied the implementation process during the first half of 2021. First, on 13 April 2021, CMA leader Sidi Brahim Ould Sidat was assassinated. Second, a second coup d��tat took place on 24 May 2021.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: At another meeting between the CMA and Platform in Rome on 6 May 2021, the leaders of the two groups signed the Rome Declaration, confirming the creation of the CSP.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: According to the Carter Center, which acted as the official observer of the implementation process of the Agreement on Peace and Reconciliation in Mali concluded in 2015, the implementation had reached a state of unprecedented impasse in its seventh year. The CSA met in October 2021, but this meeting ended when intense disagreements broke out among the signatories. After this meeting, the work of the CSA and its various subgroups was suspended.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: From 30 January to 3 February 2022, Ara Pacis Initiatives for Peace, an Italian non-profit organization, mediated peace talks between the CMA, Platform, and representatives from the transitional Government, with the Minister for National Reconciliation being part of the government team. The purpose of these talks was to address ongoing tensions between the signatory parties to the Algiers Accord. The talks also focused on disagreement surrounding the Cadre strat�gique permanent (CSP) (English: Permanent strategic coalition).

The signatories to the 2015 peace agreement held a working session in Bamako on 16-17 February 2022. The working session was chaired by the Minister of Social Cohesion, with support from the Carter Center, to examine in detail the progress made with regard to implementing the peace agreement.

On 16 March 2022, the signatories to the Algiers Accord met in Gao to address their ongoing disagreements, particularly regarding the creation and mission of the Cadre strat�gique permanent (CSP) (English: Permanent strategic coalition), which was formed by the CMA and Platform to strengthen the relations between them, but was also envisioned as a key security provider in the northern regions. The Government of Mali insisted that security matters should remain under the state�s authority and that any concerns raised by the movements should be resolved within the framework of the peace agreement. However, there was no concrete resolution reached.

Although the CSA did no longer meet, the Technical Security Commission (CTS) � tasked with monitoring the ceasefire, investigating potential violations, and monitoring security arrangements � met on 31 March 2022.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Although the CSA did no longer meet, the Technical Security Commission (CTS) � tasked with monitoring the ceasefire, investigating potential violations, and monitoring security arrangements � met on 16 June 2022.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: A high-level decision-making meeting was held in Bamako from 1 to 5 August 2022, attended by the Prime Minister, ministers, the High Representative of the transitional President for the implementation of the Agreement, and leaders of the signatory movements. The members of the international mediation team and the Carter Center acting as the Independent Observer were also present at this meeting. During this meeting, the Malian parties reached an agreement on the integration of ex-combatants into the national defense and security forces and the public administration in two phases.
third_party: Carter Center, Algeria, UN, ECOWAS, AU, EU, France, US, MINUSMA

description: The CSA, having been inactive since October 2021, restarted by initiating a ministerial meeting on 2 September 2022.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: Consultations were held among the signatories of the Algiers Accord in Bamako on 9 and 10 January 2023 to discuss the way forward regarding the peace agreement. The former Minister for Foreign Affairs of Algeria, Ramtane Lamamra acted as the mediator.

The international mediation team � including Algeria, the UN, ECOWAS, the AU, the EU, France, and the US � shuttled between the conflict parties in February 2023. On 1 February 2023, the international mediation team met with the CMA leadership in Kidal to discuss the viability of the Algiers Accord concluded in 2015. On 13 February 2023, the international mediation team held discussions with the Platform and the Mouvements de l�inclusivit� in Bamako. The international mediation team conducted a meeting with government officials on 14 February 2023. Following these meetings, the international mediation team called on the parties on 20 February 2023, to demonstrate renewed commitment and to refrain from any statements or actions that could further complicate the situation and efforts for the early holding of a high-level session of the CSA.
third_party: International Mediation Team (Algeria, France, ECOWAS, UN, OIC, AU, EU), MINUSMA

description: On 18 July 2015, tribal leaders participated in a round of negotiations that led to a ceasefire. However, this ceasefire broke down just days later.
Another round of negotiations led to a ceasefire on 25 July 2015.
Qatar began a round of negotiations between the two tribes in Doha on 23 November 2015. The conflict parties signed a ceasefire agreement in Doha on 25 November 2015.
Fighting took place again in January 2016, when tribal leaders met to implement the Doha agreement. Negotiations in February 2016 led to the signing of a comprehensive peace agreement.
The Community of Sant�Egidio mediated a humanitarian accord in Rome on 16 June 2016 between various tribes in the Fezzan region in order to provide aid.

In March 2017, 60 tribal representatives engaged in negotiations in Rome mediated by the Libyan Presidency Council, the Italian Interior Minister Marco Minniti, the Ara Pacis Initiative, and the Community of Sant�Egidio. This led to the signing of the Reconciliation and Peace Agreement on 29 March 2017 and a document regarding methods for implementation on 31 March. A faction of the Toubou tribe rejected this agreement on 6 April and fighting resumed. On 7 April 2018, the Supreme Council of the Tribes and Cities of Fezzan called for a ceasefire for the region. In response, the Toubou announced a unilateral ceasefire on 9 April.
third_party: government, Italy, Ara Pacis Initiative, Community of Sant'Egidio

description: Local leaders mediated a round of negotiations between the two sides, which led to a ceasefire on 19 February 2012. This ceasefire soon broke down.
The government sent an armed force to quell fighting in March and another ceasefire was brokered on 26 March 2012. However, fighting resumed days later.
A round of mediation led by local authorities succeeded in getting the two sides to agree to a ceasefire on 7 July 2012.
The conflict parties reached a truce during a round of bilateral negotiations on 11 May 2013, but this did not prove sustainable.
Negotiations led to the conclusion of a ceasefire on 26 July 2015.

UNSMIL mediated a round of peace talks in Tunis from 19 to 20 February 2018. The two conflict parties agreed to a document outlining mechanisms for reconciliation, which was signed by the conflict parties on 21 February.
In late April 2016, President Yoweri Museveni subsequently mediated another round of peace talks between the leaders of the conflict parties that led to the conclusion of an informal peace agreement.

In March 2017, the Community of Sant�Egidio started a mediation process, with Andrea Riccardi acting as the chief mediator. UN envoy Parfait Onanga-Anyanga, the European Union, and the Italian Government had an observer status during the negotiations. With peace talks ongoing in Rome, FPRC fighters launched an offensive against anti-Balaka elements in Bakouma on 6 June 2017, following an anti-Balaka attack on Nzako. This persuaded the conflict parties at the negotiations to sign a peace agreement on 19 June 2017, stipulating an immediate ceasefire. This agreement, referred to as the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic, was signed by the RPRC, FPRC, FDPC, UPC, RPRC, RJ BELANGA, UFR-F, UPC, RJ SAYO, UFR-F, FPRC, UFR, RJ SAYO, MPC, SELEKA Renovee, Coordination anti-Balaka, anti-Balaka Mokom, MLJC, RJ Belanga, FDPC, MLJC, and the UFR. The agreement reaffirmed the 2016 elections. In addition, the agreement called for the integration of all �politico-military groups� into the peace process and a restoration of state authority. The agreement also included an immediate countrywide ceasefire. The ceasefire did not hold. Armed clashes between several armed groups already took place in the Bria area already one day after the signing of the ceasefire.
third_party: Community of Sant�Egidio, UN, EU, Italy
agreement_name: Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic

description: On 28 June 2017, President Faustin Archange Touad�ra held meetings with the representatives of the 14 armed groups that had signed a peace agreement in Rome on 19 June.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: On 2 October 2017, Abdoulaye Hissene, leader of a faction of the FPRC, arrived in Ippy to conduct negotiations with anti-Balaka-Mokum and the UPC concerning the conclusion of a ceasefire in the region. While the emissaries from Bangui and Birao mediated between the conflict parties, civil society leaders and a community liaison assistant from MINUSCA civil affairs and representatives of the MINSUCA force also participated in the peace meeting in Ippy. On 6 October 2017, the anti-Balaka-Mokom, UPC, and FPRC signed the Ippy Accord. This agreement led to renewed UPC dominance.
third_party: government, local government, community leaders, MINUSCA

description: In mid-April 2018, the FPRC once more organized a conference to unify the ex-Seleka movement, negotiating with the UPC and the MPC in Kaga Bandoro, but the conference did not lead to an agreement. Russia and Sudan started a national-level mediation effort in August 2018, but instead of making peace between the FPRC and the UPC this mediation effort was aimed at negotiations between the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the one side and the anti-Balaka (represented by Maxime Mokom) on the other side. These negotiations led to the signing of declaration of understanding and a pledge to support the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation in CAR led by the AU and regional states with the support of the UN. Furthermore, the AU, with support from MINUSCA, organized a meeting between 14 armed groups in Bouar between 28 and 30 August. The meeting produced a document with demands to the government, signed by all 14 groups that participated in the meeting. The document was handed over to the government following the meeting.

The Civil Affairs section of the MINUSCA Field Office in Zemio, together with community leaders, supported a peace effort between the UPC and the FPRC, which led to a reconciliation agreement signed in October 2018.

Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Nga�ssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, S�l�ka R�nov�e, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: The Civil Affairs section of the MINUSCA Field Office in Zemio, together with community leaders, supported a peace effort between the UPC and the FPRC, which led to a reconciliation agreement signed on 24 November 2019. The document serves to remind the parties to respect the peace agreements previously signed in Zemio in October 2018.

Following another clash in June 2016, government forces were deployed to the area to end the violence. With support from UNAMID, the conflict parties signed a peace agreement on 22 July 2016. Yet, the Mahadi tribal leadership expressed dissatisfaction with this agreement because it did not include any provisions on compensation (diya) and that the Rizeeigat Abbala continued occupy of their land.

Deputy Governor of Cross River State Professor Ivara Esu and Senator Ben Ayade mediated between the members of the two communities in early July 2017. The mediators called on the Wanhihem and Wanikade communities to not return to armed conflict and to agree on clear boundaries between them. The conflict parties did not conclude a peace agreement.

Another peace meeting was held in Mfuma in the Yala Local Government Area on 15 July 2017. Wanhihem and Wanikade leaders, as well representatives of other Ukulle people to which both communities belong, signed a communiqu� at this peace meeting. This communiqu� stipulates a ceasefire between the two communities, as well as calls upon the federal government to assist them in resolving the conflict and to establish a Judicial Commission of Inquiry into the conflict and a Truth and Reconciliation Committee.

A Truth and Reconciliation Committee composed of Fulani and Kadara representatives was set up by the Kajuru government in March 2019. The committee was tasked to find a solution to the ongoing crisis and ensure a ceasefire. This committee was reportedly successful, and fighting ended in the region in August 2019. On the weekend of 19 and 20 October 2019, the Commander of the Nigerian Naval Weapons Technology School in Kachia in Kaduna State), Commodore Tanko Yakubu Pani, mediated between leaders of the Fulani and Kadara communities. The communities, who were given two weeks to surrender their weapons or face sanctions, pledged to contribute to the return of peace in the region. No written agreement was signed on this occasion.

Negotiations between traditional dozo hunters and members of the JNIM in the Niono district in the S�gou region started in October 2020. The negotiations took place in the wake of JNIM militants besieging several villages in the Niono district, accusing the inhabitants of collaborating with the government. Eight emissaries from the High Islamic Council of Mali mediated the talks, which were supported by the junta government in Bamako. After several months of negotiations, the delegates reached an agreement for a ceasefire on 14 March 2021. The meeting took place in the bush near Niono. However, fighting resumed in September 2021, with both sides accusing each other of violating the terms of the agreement.
third_party: High Islamic Council of Mali, Junta Government of Bamako

description: The UCDP records clashes between the MPC and the anti-Balaka for the first time in February 2017, but there were already some mediation efforts between MPC and the anti-Balaka in 2015. A local peace process in Batangafo, with support from the Bossangoa field office of MINUSCA, led to the conclusion of a weapon-free zone agreement in December 2015.

Building on the weapon-free zone agreement that had been concluded in Batangafo in December 2015, MINUSCA mediated a non-aggression pact between the anti-Balaka and the ex-S�l�ka, including the FPRC and MPC, in Batangafo on 29 March 2016.

On 8 March 2016, the MPC and anti-Balaka operating on Kaga Bandoro-Bangui axis signed a Protocole de non agression (English: Non-Aggression Protocol). The agreement was mediated by the MINUSCA field office in Kaga-Bandoro, with involvement from the Local Peace and Reconciliation Committee (CLPR), religious leaders, and local authorities.
third_party: MINUSCA, religious leaders, local government, local peace committee

description: The anti-Balaka on the one hand and the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the other hand signed a non-aggression pact in the sub-prefecture of Mbr�s on 8 June 2016. The agreement was mediated by the MINUSCA field office in Kaga-Bandoro, with involvement from the Local Peace and Reconciliation Committee (CLPR), religious leaders, and local authorities.
third_party: MINUSCA, religious leaders, local government, local peace committee

UN envoy Parfait Onanga-Anyanga, the European Union, and the Italian Government had an observer status during the negotiations. With peace talks ongoing in Rome, FPRC fighters launched an offensive against anti-Balaka elements in Bakouma on 6 June 2017, following an anti-Balaka attack on Nzako. The agreement reaffirmed the 2016 elections. In addition, the agreement called for the integration of all �politico-military groups� into the peace process and a restoration of state authority. The agreement also included an immediate countrywide ceasefire. The ceasefire did not hold. Armed clashes between several armed groups already took place in the Bria area already one day after the signing of the ceasefire.

description: On 28 June 2017, President Faustin Archange Touad�ra held meetings with the representatives of the 14 armed groups that that had signed a peace agreement in Rome on 19 June.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: Another local peace process took place in early 2018. Mediation by local authorities and MINUSCA led to the conclusion of the Accord entre les Groupes Arm�s de Batangafo on 24 February 2018. The signatories were the anti-Balaka and the ex-S�l�ka, including the FPRC and MPC.
agreement_name: Accord entre les Groupes Arm�s de Batangafo

description: On 28 August 2018, Russia � which had begun supplying the CAR government with arms and military instructors in February 2018 � and Sudan mediated negotiations between the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the one side and the anti-Balaka (represented by Maxime Mokom) on the other side. These negotiations led to the signing of declaration of understanding and a pledge to support the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation in CAR led by the AU and regional states with the support of the UN. The UPC and MPC expressed they were no longer committed to this declaration in October 2018, but they made it clear that they still supported the African Initiative. Furthermore, the AU, with support from MINUSCA, organized a meeting between 14 armed groups in Bouar between 28 and 30 August. The meeting produced a document with demands to the government, signed by all 14 groups that participated in the meeting. The document was handed over to the government following the meeting.

Mediation by local authorities and MINUSCA led to the conclusion of the Accord entre les Groupes Arm�s de Batangafo on 12 January 2019. An agreement with exactly the same name had been signed in February 2018. The second agreement, signed in January 2019, was prompted by the failure of the February 2018 accord following violent incidents in late October 2018. The parties involved in the initial accord � the anti-Balaka and the ex-S�l�ka, including the FPRC and MPC � also signed this subsequent agreement, which encompasses the same provisions. However, notable additions were made, as the new agreement received endorsements from local authorities and representatives of civil society.
agreement_name: Accord entre les Groupes Arm�s de Batangafo

description: Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Nga�ssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, S�l�ka R�nov�e, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) and MINUSCA, with support from local officials and traditional and religious leaders, mediated a round of negotiations between the UPC, MPC, RPRC, MLJC, anti-Balaka-Molokom, and FPRC in Bria from 1 to 9 April 2019. This led to the signing of the Bria Accord on 9 April 2019. This local agreement was aimed at reinforcing the implementation of the 6 February 2019 national agreement. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire to end to the violence in Haute-Kotto and Ouaka prefectures, as well as guaranteed the safe and free movement of persons, goods, and humanitarian aid on the main axis.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), MINUSCA, local government, traditional leaders, religious leaders

description: The Somali government immediately ordered an end to the fighting. In order to reconcile the two communities, a government delegation mediated negotiations attended by 20 individuals from both sides.

Negotiations between representatives of Irigwe, Hausa, and Fulani communities led to the signing of a peace agreement in Bassa in Plateau State on 8 February 2011. The president of the Bassa local council, government representatives, soldiers from the Special Task Force, and police officers acted as mediators during the peace talks.
third_party: local government, government, government forces, police

description: The many meetings convened the Special Task Force cumulated in the signing of a ceasefire agreement in early August 2018. Major-General Augustine Chris Agundu, the Commander of the Operation Safe Haven, mediated between the conflict parties at these meetings.

After the alleged attack by an Irigwe man on Fulani people and their livestock in March 2019, the police summoned a peace meeting between the two communities to ensure that such an event would not occur again. However, violence resumed between the two communities in April 2019. On 21 September 2019, on the occasion of the World Peace Day, the Plateau Peace Building Agency (PPBA) facilitated a peace parley between the Irigwe and Fulani leaders in Miango district in the Local Government Area of Bassa in Plateau State. The two leaders of the conflict parties, who had not met in six years, signed a peace agreement and expressed their hope for long-lasting peace in the area. However, attacks resumed only two days later.

In July 2022, a peace accord was signed between the Irigwe and Fulani communities in Plateau State. The agreement was witnessed by various individuals and organizations including the chairman of Bassa local government, Plateau Inter-Religious Council, Kaduna Peace Commission, MACBAN, United States Institute for Peace, among others. The document was produced by a 16-man committee, comprising the two ethnic groups which held a series of consultations, conducted investigations on the causes of the conflicts, and examined modalities for sustainable peace.
third_party: Local government, Plateau Inter-Religious Council, Kaduna Peace Commission, MACBAN, United States Institute for Peace

description: In July 2023, the commander of Plateau State�s Sector 3 Military Command hosted a dialogue to foster peace and unity between the Fulani community in Plateau and leaders of the local Irigwe community. The peace talk was attended by International Christian Concern (ICC), an international NGO, and at least 100 stakeholders from the Fulani and Irigwe communities as well as leaders from other ethnic groups.
third_party: Military Command, International Christian Concern (ICC), local leaders

description: The MINUSCA field office in Bouar town initiated a mediation effort between 3R and anti-Balaka in December 2017. The Prefect of the Nana-Mamb�r� Prefecture and Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) were also involved in this mediation effort. On 15 December 2017, 3R and anti-Balaka signed the Acte d�engagement entre les groupes anti-Balakas de la Nana-Mamb�r� et les 3R. The agreement stipulated a cessation of hostilities, non-use of arms, freedom of movement, and the establishment of information network made up of community leaders, and leaders of the two armed groups. The implementation of the agreement was relatively successful since it contributed to a decrease in violence and direct confrontation between the groups, an improvement in the free movement of people and goods and a considerable decline in livestock theft.
third_party: MINUSCA, local government, Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD)
agreement_name: Acte d�engagement entre les groupes anti-Balakas de la Nana-Mamb�r� et les 3R

description: Another local-level peace procces took place between the anti-Balaka and 3R in Koui-De gaulle between 18 and 20 October 2018. This resulted in the signing of the D�claration de coordination des groupes arm�s � plateforme Rassemblement Centrafricain pour la Paix (English: Declaration of coordination of the armed groups - Central African Rally for Peace Platform). Furthermore, the AU, with support from MINUSCA, organized a meeting between 14 armed groups in Bouar between 28 and 30 August. The meeting produced a document with demands to the government, signed by all 14 groups that participated in the meeting. The document was handed over to the government following the meeting.
agreement_name: D�claration de coordination des groupes arm�s � plateforme Rassemblement Centrafricain pour la Paix

The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Nga�ssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, S�l�ka R�nov�e, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: On 11 November 2017, under an alleged authorization of Abdoulaye Hissene, a local mediation team and a MINUSCA Community Liaison Assistant (CLA) mediated an agreement between the rival wings of the FPRC. The FPRC-AK wing subsequently returned to Bria on 27 November 2017.

Immediately after armed clashes between the Bwatiye and Fulani on 4 December 2017, vice-president Yemi Osinbajo held separate talks with both sides, trying to convince the conflict parties to stop fighting.

In mid-December 2017, the Secretary to the Government of the Federation Boss Mustapha visited the leaders of the Bwatyie and Fulani. He called upon the communities to stop fighting, but no agreement was concluded as a result of these shuttle talks.

On 27 July 2017, Jabhat Fateh al-Sham militants part of the HTS alliance raised the white flag and negotiated a ceasefire agreement in the northern Beqaa Valley of Lebanon with Hezbollah. This ceasefire was mediated by the Lebanese General Security Director, Major-General Abbas Ibrahim. The deal called for a cessation of hostilities and the return of captured Hezbollah fighters in exchange for allowing the militants and their families to leave Lebanon for Idlib in Syria.
third_party: Lebanese General Security Director and Major General Abbas Ibrahim

description: The Pakam Dinka and Rup Dinka attended a two-day peace conference in Greater Lakes on 26 January 2019. This effort was organized by the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS), African Mission Assistance (AMA), and Oxfam. This round of peace talks ended with a peace agreement on 28 January 2019.

The South Sudanese government and the SPLM/A-IO signed a peace agreement in Addis Ababa on 12 September 2018, referred to as the Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan (R-ARCSS). Following the signing of the R-ARCSS, the South Sudanese government and SPLM/A-IO representatives continued engagement to persuade the NAS to sign and implement the agreement. During a meeting in Texas on 23 September 2018, the NAS leader said his group is not committed to the ceasefire in South Sudan even if their group is a signatory to the security arrangements.

side_b: Operations Room Combating Daesh, Shuhada al-Wadi militia
description: Surrounding cities sent peace delegations to mediate an end to the fighting. The United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) urged the parties to cease hostilities in order to allow for citizen to flee the conflict area. Anas al-Dabbashi and Operations Room Combating Daesh subsequently agreed to a three-hour ceasefire on 18 September 2017 to allow residents to leave the conflict area.

side_b: Operations Room Combating Daesh, Shuhada al-Wadi militia
description: Following a diplomatic effort by the Libyan government on 2 October 2017, Anas al-Dabbashi and Operations Room Combating Daesh agreed to another humanitarian ceasefire. The Shuhada al-Wadi militia and Operations Room Combating Daesh managed to defeat Anas al-Dabbashi and Brigade 48 from Sabratha on 6 October 2017.

Negotiations in Miketo, facilitated by MONUSCO, led to the signing of a peace agreement on 20 January. MONUSCO agreed to support the implementation of this agreement. On 22 February 2017, the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of the Interior and Security, Emmanuel Ramazani Shadary, arrived in Kalemie, the capital of Tanganyika, to discuss the recent fighting between the Pygmies and the Bantu. According to a civil society organization which attended the meeting, this meeting did not help to resolve the conflict because no representatives of the conflict parties were invited to participate in the meeting. Fighting continued.

On 24 February, following a mediation effort by the Congolese authorities, the leaders of the communities signed a Peaceful Coexistence pact in Kalemie of the Tanganyika province. The Batabwa on the one side and the Bambuti and the Batwa on the other side did not engage in any armed clashes after the signing of this pact.

In March 2017, the Community of Sant�Egidio started a mediation process, with Andrea Riccardi acting as the chief mediator. UN envoy Parfait Onanga-Anyanga, the European Union, and the Italian Government had an observer status during the negotiations. With peace talks ongoing in Rome, FPRC fighters launched an offensive against anti-Balaka elements in Bakouma on 6 June 2017, following an anti-Balaka attack on Nzako. This persuaded the conflict parties at the negotiations to sign a peace agreement on 19 June 2017, stipulating an immediate ceasefire. This agreement, referred to as the Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic, was signed by the RPRC, FPRC, FDPC, UPC, RPRC, RJ BELANGA, UFR-F, UPC, RJ SAYO, UFR-F, FPRC, UFR, RJ SAYO, MPC, SELEKA Renovee, Coordination anti-Balaka, anti-Balaka Mokom, MLJC, RJ Belanga, FDPC, MLJC, and the UFR. The agreement reaffirmed the 2016 elections. In addition, the agreement called for the integration of all �politico-military groups� into the peace process and a restoration of state authority. The agreement also included an immediate countrywide ceasefire. The ceasefire did not hold. Armed clashes between several armed groups already took place in the Bria area already one day after the signing of the ceasefire.
third_party: Community of Sant'Egidio, UN, EU, Italy
agreement_name: Political Agreement for Peace in the Central African Republic

description: On 28 June, President Faustin Archange Touad�ra held meetings with the representatives of the 14 armed groups that had signed a peace agreement in Rome on 19 June.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: On 2 October 2017, Abdoulaye Hissene, leader of a faction of the FPRC, arrived in Ippy to conduct negotiations with anti-Balaka-Mokum and the UPC concerning the conclusion of a ceasefire in the region. While the emissaries from Bangui and Birao mediated between the conflict parties, civil society leaders and a community liaison assistant from MINUSCA civil affairs and representatives of the MINSUCA force also participated in the peace meeting in Ippy. On 6 October 2017, the anti-Balaka-Mokom, UPC, and FPRC signed the Ippy Accord. This agreement led to renewed UPC dominance. In addition to this local peace process aimed at ending violence between the conflict parties in the Bambari area, the conflict parties were involved in a national-level peace process in 2017.

In mid-April 2018, the FPRC once more organized a conference to unify the ex-Seleka movement, negotiating with the UPC and the MPC in Kaga Bandoro, but the conference did not lead to an agreement. Russia and Sudan started a national-level mediation effort in August 2018, but instead of making peace between the MPC and the UPC, this mediation effort was aimed at negotiations between the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the one side and the anti-Balaka (represented by Maxime Mokom) on the other side. These negotiations led to the signing of declaration of understanding and a pledge to support the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation in CAR led by the AU and regional states with the support of the UN. Furthermore, the AU, with support from MINUSCA, organized a meeting between 14 armed groups in Bouar between 28 and 30 August. The meeting produced a document with demands to the government, signed by all 14 groups that participated in the meeting. The document was handed over to the government following the meeting.

On 28 August 2018, Russia � which had begun supplying the CAR government with arms and military instructors in February 2018 � and Sudan mediated negotiations between the FPRC, UPC, and MPC on the one side and the anti-Balaka (represented by Maxime Mokom) on the other side. These negotiations led to the signing of declaration of understanding and a pledge to support the African Initiative for Peace and Reconciliation in CAR led by the AU and regional states with the support of the UN. The UPC and MPC expressed they were no longer committed to this declaration in October 2018, but they made it clear that they still supported the African Initiative. Furthermore, the AU, with support from MINUSCA, organized a meeting between 14 armed groups in Bouar between 28 and 30 August. The meeting produced a document with demands to the government, signed by all 14 groups that participated in the meeting. The document was handed over to the government following the meeting.

Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Nga�ssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, S�l�ka R�nov�e, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

description: The Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) and MINUSCA, with support from local officials and traditional and religious leaders, mediated a round of negotiations between the UPC, MPC, RPRC, MLJC, anti-Balaka-Molokom, and FPRC in Bria from 1 to 9 April 2019. This led to the signing of the Bria Accord on 9 April 2019. This local agreement was aimed at reinforcing the implementation of the 6 February 2019 national agreement. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire to end to the violence in Haute-Kotto and Ouaka prefectures, as well as guaranteed the safe and free movement of persons, goods, and humanitarian aid on the main axis.
third_party: Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), MINUSCA, local government, traditional leaders, religious leaders

description: Negotiations, mediated by representatives of government forces, led to a reconciliation agreement on 17 August 2013.

On 21 August 2013, a local peace committee with members from both tribes held a meeting with community members, as well as religious, local, and regional authorities in the town. At this meeting, the Arab Brabich and Idnan signed the Document d�initiation au dialogue pour r�habiliter le calme et cesser l�effusion du sang afin d�atteindre la reconciliation.
third_party: local peace committee, religious leaders, traditional leaders, local government
agreement_name: Document d�initiation au dialogue pour r�habiliter le calme et cesser l�effusion du sang afin d�atteindre la reconciliation

description: In January 2019, the CMA represented by Salah Ag Ahmed and Alhousseiny Ag Ahmedou and the MSA represented by Mohamed Ag Kassoum engaged in bilateral negotiations, which led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 20 January 2019. However, fighting resumed the next month.
Another round of bilateral negotiations in Tinfadimata in May 2019 led to the conclusion of a peace agreement on 21 May 2019.
The United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) mediated negotiations between the conflict parties on 19 November 2014, which led to the conclusion of a humanitarian ceasefire for 12 hours.

On 13 March 2020, intercommunity talks were held in Uvira. The talks led to a ceasefire agreement, signed by representatives from various armed groups and local defense forces, such as Biloze Bishambuke, Mai-Mai Mtetezi or FPDC-ML, Twirwaneho, Gumino. Three days after the ceasefire was concluded, violence broke out in Bigaragara.

Building on negotiations mediated by Russia and Sudan in August 2018, a mediation effort led by the AU in Khartoum from 24 January to 5 February 2019 led to the conclusion of the Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR) signed in Bangui on 6 February 2019. The agreement offered far more government posts to representatives of the armed groups than in previous agreements. The agreement was signed by the anti-Balaka-Mokom, anti-Balaka-Nga�ssona, FDPC, FPRC, MPC, MLCJ, RPRC, 3R, RJ-Belanga, RJ-Aile Sayo, S�l�ka R�nov�e, UFR, UFR-F, and the UPC.
agreement_name: Accord politique pour la Paix et la R�conciliation (APPR)

This led to the signing of the Bria Accord on 9 April 2019. This local agreement was aimed at reinforcing the implementation of the 6 February 2019 national agreement. The agreement stipulated a ceasefire to end to the violence in Haute-Kotto and Ouaka prefectures, as well as guaranteed the safe and free movement of persons, goods, and humanitarian aid on the main axis.
